fields.headline: Bent double clinches rout of the Rams
fields.trailText: Derby 2 - 5 Blackburn
fields.body:
Blackburn Rovers have got the expensive players, the plush stands and the moneybags. Now they are setting about dispelling the theory that they lack glitter on the pitch to go with the pots of gold.

The First Division play-off hopefuls are through to the FA Cup fifth round after blitzing Derby with five second-half goals on an extraordinary night here, given the plodding stalemate contested by these sides at Ewood Park 10 days earlier.

Before most of the Blackburn players had even worked up a bead of sweat Derby had manoeuvred an opening goal which stemmed from a dubious foul, awarded for Garry Flitcroft's challenge on Stefano Eranio, and the sense of irritation felt by the visitors seemed to affect their concentration.

As the penalty area filled with bodies the Blackburn defence was guilty of some dreadful dithering and Chris Riggott timed his run exquisitely to head Craig Burley's free-kick beyond Brad Friedel.

Riggott has now scored in all three domestic competitions and his emergence this season as a centre-half of some stature has probably been the most positive aspect of Derby's hitherto turbulent campaign.

Before the midway point of the first half the tie could conceivably have been all but over. Malcolm Christie came a poor second in two one-on-ones with Friedel and before long Graeme Souness was prowling the touchline with increased anxiety as Derby threatened to overwhelm their guests.

As the first half approached its climax, however, there were encouraging signs from the First Division side. Jason McAteer and David Dunn dropped long-range shots on to the roof of the net but their improved possession was undone by a paucity of midfield guile which Eyal Berkovic, ineligible here after signing on loan from Celtic, might have been able to provide.

That Blackburn had lost only one of their previous 17 games suggested they might give a better account of themselves in the second half and Souness's side grasped the initiative only three minutes after the restart.

Just as Blackburn had been guilty of some dreadful ball-watching for the opening goal, Derby's defence dithered in clearing McAteer's corner. Marcus Bent flicked the loose ball into the six-yard area and Flitcroft was unmarked to head the ball inside Andy Oakes's near post.

Suddenly the butterflies that Derby had been displaying at the latter stages of the first half were developing into full-blown jitters.

Eight minutes later Dunn worked the ball superbly to McAteer and Bent emphatically headed his precise centre past Oakes to set up the prospect of an all-Lancashire affair at Bolton on Saturday week.

On 63 minutes that was all but guaranteed. Riggott tripped Alan Mahon on the left side of the area and Dunn sent Oakes the wrong way from the penalty spot.

Eranio converted a cross from the substitute Lee Morris on 70 minutes to give Derby renewed hope but straight from the re-start Damien Duff crossed from the left and Bent knocked in his second of the night.

By the time the substitute Matt Jansen stroked in Blackburn's fifth on 76 minutes most of the Derby fans were heading home.

fields.headline: Sharp Spurs turn the tide for Graham
fields.trailText:
Charlton 2 - 4 Tottenham
Three goals in the space of five minutes ended Spurs' recent barren patch and set up a home tie with Stockport for a place in the sixth round.
fields.body:
Tottenham's beleaguered manager George Graham saw his team's recent barren patch dramatically transformed last night when three goals in the space of five minutes overhauled Charlton and set up a home tie with Stockport for a place in the sixth round.

Given their stuttering league form and early exit from the Worthington Cup at the hands of Birmingham City, Tottenham were well aware that they could afford no slip-up. "This is now our most important game of the season," Steffen Freund had admitted. "We cannot afford to lose it."

Few would have backed them to win after a run of only one victory in 11 games against Premiership opponents, but they must at least have felt confident of avoiding defeat. The two sides had drawn 0-0 in a dire match at White Hart Lane on Saturday and Tottenham arrived on the back of four goalless stalemates.

They finally broke that unhappy sequence last night but even then it took an own goal from Richard Rufus to start the ball rolling before Darren Anderton equalised and Oyvind Leonhardsen snapped up the winner within a minute. Sergei Rebrov then rounded off matters in the 82nd minute.

After only 11 minutes, though, they had found themselves behind. Chris Powell, a lifelong Spurs fan, was the scorer and by ripping off his shirt to celebrate his first goal for Charlton on his 110th start he earned himself a booking.

Sean Bartlett set up the goal when he flicked on a knock-down by Mathias Svensson, and as Neil Sullivan hesitated in coming off his line, Powell nipped between two defenders to head into an empty net.

By then Sergei Rebrov and Leonhardsen had shot wide for Tottenham, who began without a goal in more than six hours and had moved Gary Doherty up from centre-back to partner Rebrov in the absence of the cup-tied Andy Booth. Doherty, of course, had been the last Spurs player to find the net, at Leyton Orient.

Forced forward in search of an equaliser, Spurs proceeded to dominate. When the impres sive Sol Campbell shot powerfully through a ruck of players from outside the area, Sasa Ilic reacted acrobatically to tip over.

Although Tottenham were passing with far greater fluency and looking much livelier than they had at the weekend, they created very little early on. Just past the half-hour, they wasted two good chances as Charlton struggled to make any headway in attack. When a Rebrov shot was deflected into the path of Tim Sherwood, the midfielder might have done better than allow Ilic to make a good save. Rebrov himself was guilty of the next miss, clipping wide from Doherty's pull-back.

Graham must have been cursing his players' lack of conviction and confidence in front of goal when Charlton scored their second three minutes after the restart. Rufus began the move when he picked up a clearance by Campbell, and Graham Stuart's cross was eventually swept past Sullivan by Svensson.

The first chants of "We want Graham out" were soon audible and with Spurs lacking shape , it seemed a third was inevitable. Instead, having failed to score for seven hours, Spurs got three in quick succession.

Rufus got the first with an own goal, diverting the ball past Ilic from Doherty's cross. And no sooner had Anderton squeezed in a low free-kick, which the goalkeeper might have stopped, than Spurs had another almost straight from the kick-off, Leonhardsen bursting clear to shoot across Ilic into the far corner.

webTitle: United's American dream may turn into a nightmare

fields.headline: United's American dream may turn into a nightmare
fields.trailText: The former managing director of merchandising at Tottenham Hotspur and Manchester United gives his verdict on the deal.
fields.body:
Mass hysteria greeted yesterday's news of Manchester United's marketing deal with the New York Yankees, and the reality of the deal has become utterly lost in all the hype that has surrounded this tale of two glamorous brands joining forces.

It is like sport's own royal wedding - and we all know how much nonsense is spoken about such hastily convened relationships, and how they can end in tears.

I have found that on the whole Americans just cannot grasp football. Although the women's game has been extremely successful there, the fact that that success is not mirrored here sums up the cultural differences between us. Americans don't understand what makes the men's game tick as a way of life for people in Europe. They just cannot comprehend the passion and traditions. Do the Americans know more about marketing? Perhaps in general they do but it is certain that they don't know their football marketing better than we do.

This is very dangerous territory. The sports merchandising philosophy in America is totally different to that in England. Theirs is all based on licensing a team's products to many different suppliers. If United plan to head down that road because of this deal, I think they are not only heading for a fall but are also selling out.

United have already sold their merchandising rights to Nike and this is an additional sell-out. If they are not careful they will lose control of their brand, and that would be foolish. Do they really think they are going to sell United products in America? They won't, because 90% of New York Yankees products are licensed out. The licensees would see no benefit to be gained from selling Manchester United products.

I will be fascinated to learn more about how the Yankees fans react to the deal, if they care. My guess is that they will not exactly be welcoming it with open arms. Their club has such a fine tradition and stature that they may not consider that they are embracing equal partners.

There is no doubt that you will see more United fans at Old Trafford wearing New York Yankee baseball caps than Yankees fans wearing United replica shirts to watch their side. Even Roy Keane and David Beckham have, in the past, been photographed wearing Yankee baseball caps. Would you see a Yankee player wearing a United cap? I doubt it.

Over here, will United fans be any happier with the deal? We are a football nation; where does baseball come into it? United are a football institution famed throughout the world; do we really want to adulterate that brand with baseball and Americanise it? I don't think so.

When a Manchester United basketball side was launched a few years ago it was a complete disaster and lost United money because it moved them away from their roots. It all goes over the heads of traditional United fans.

You would not blame the Old Trafford faithful if they felt a little nonplussed and asked: "What has baseball got to do with us?" In all fairness, Manchester United might as well have joined forces with Disney and formed a United Disney theme park. There is more synergy there than in a football and baseball connection.

Although the tabloids are speculating that this deal is worth billions of pounds to United, I would not be losing much sleep if I were working at any of their Premiership rivals. You can almost see a queue of players lining up at Sir Alex Ferguson's door, asking where their share of these billions are. Beckham is no doubt on the phone to his Yankees equivalent Derek Jeter asking how he negotiated a £12m-a-year deal.

More importantly, our other domestic clubs are so far behind United in terms of their merchandising here in England and their profiles in Asia that they should be addressing those areas before worrying about this development.

Everyone is asking what this deal actually means. It raises more questions than it answers. Two years ago United began a marketing and merchandising operation in China and people are now starting to ask what came of that. I would not be at all surprised if in two years' time you ask what this deal means, the answer will be exactly the same: no one knows.

Edward Freedman is a former managing director of merchandising at Tottenham Hotspur and Manchester United, and is now chief operating officer of icons.com

fields.headline: Bargain hunting
fields.standfirst: Knowing where to search for a flight or a holiday can be as problematic as deciding where to go. Imogen Tilden takes a whistlestop tour of a few of the UK's leading online travel shops
fields.trailText: Knowing where to search for a flight or a holiday can be as problematic as deciding where to go. Imogen Tilden takes a whistlestop tour of a few of the UK's leading online travel shops
fields.body:
The joys of the world wide web. No longer do you have to scour the high street or spend hours calling innumerable bucket shops only to be told that the £69 flight to Barcelona you saw advertised is a one-way price and is only for flights leaving on the second Wednesday in months with the letter T in them... On the net, you can do your own searching, comparing and contrasting. The whole world is out there. Or is it?

The reality is that tracking down that bargain flight can be as frustrating an experience as it ever was. Most sites - not unreasonably - constrain your flight search by day and time. The drawback of this is that the £150 fare to New York flagged on the front page may well be a real deal, but you've got no easy way of discovering when this fare is actually available. Last-minute holidays are easier to locate; if you've got the nerve to wait until a matter of days before you want to go, there are always bargains to be had.

Sites and what they have on offer change daily. Many offer online booking, although if your departure date is less than a week away, you'll probably find that you'll have to book over the phone. Whatever you're looking for, try your search on at least three or four sites to get an idea of what's on offer. What follows is a very brief guide to several of the well established sites.

Cheap Flights is a huge search engine that allows you to search alphabetically for your destination and gives you a list of companies who have flights which may meet your requirements. You'll get a phone number and, if available, a URL of the company, whereupon you have to begin your search again. Nonetheless, this is a good starting point.

Air Tickets. Don't be put off by its gaudy design. This is an excellent site that's easy to use, which consistently found the cheapest fares for my search. If your flight leaves in less than 10 days time you have to book by phone, but the phone team is available seven days a week. There is also hotel information and a few holiday offers. Also useful for flights is 1st Net Flights. The Bob Geldof-backed Deckchair.com also deals only with flights. Once you get the hang of the slightly fiddly search function, it's a good site, even if it didn't come up with the cheapest deals. Its failure to mention tax until the final screen is annoying.

Many sites offer both holidays and flights. Teletext's online presence is best for package holidays, but a nice extra is the flight arrivals checker, which gives up-to-the-minute arrival details for all the UK's main airports.

Direct Holidays and The First Resort are also a good source of last-minute bargains for sun seekers. Thomas Cook, the granddaddy of package holidays, has a very impressive online presence, and makes the grand claim of possessing the internet's largest range of package holidays. £1 is donated to UNICEF with every online booking. Bargain Holidays also boasts a huge range of last-minute holidays and flights, combined with a simple layout and friendly tone. You can't book online, but there's a seven-day a week telephone service.

Ebookers has been around since 1996. Sadly, on my visit, the site threw up an error message when I wanted to look at the fare alert, and offered me a blank page instead of the ambitiously named World Guide. Searching for flights for a date a month away offered me tantalising glimpses of cheap fares, only to be told that, alas, that price wasn't available for the day I wanted to travel. Well when IS it for? I cried, but to no avail. The Special offers section has some great last-minute flights and is worth keeping an eye on.

Travelocity is an excellent and straightforward travel portal whose UK arm is run by Emap, the team behind Bargain Holidays. Flights make up most of its business, but you can also hire a car and book a hotel, as long as it's near an airport. Good features include baggage guidelines for each airline, flight tracking, and a seat map so you can select your seat when you book your ticket. The search function is one of the best we came across - a colour-coded calendar allows you select your travel dates and lets you see immediately if the fare you want is available on the day you want. The Fare Watcher on the front page flags up cheap fares (but don't be sucked in by the fact that the quoted price doesn't include tax).

World Travel Direct does most of the things that Expedia and ebookers can do, but in a more user-friendly fashion. All the quoted prices include tax and the cheapest flight options are shown first. But before you can get anywhere, you're required to register. When we looked, one of the four special offers flagged was a flight to New York that had to be booked by the day before yesterday. Sadly, time travel is not one of the options offered.

Expedia, a scion of the Bill Gates empire, is easy to use. Its main strength is flights, but you can also find package holidays, car hire and hotel bookings, as well as many extras including the fare tracker, which identifies the cheapest flights to any destination and will either email them to you each week or store them on the site for future reference. A very few last-minute deals are provided alongside gifts and entertainment ideas from Lastminute.com, a service which does neither site any favours - I didn't want to know about last-minute hand-made chocolates or West End theatre tickets. Talking of which, the infamous Last Minute is worth a look if you are indeed doing something last minute. Or indeed if you're the kind of crazy chick who buys hand-made chocolates at the very last minute. You can search the flights and holidays database for departures up to a month away, but other sites will invariably produce cheaper and better results. Sadly, while I was attempting to investigate what seemed to be a good deal on a flight to the States, my computer froze mid-search, and I had to restart. I didn't dare go back to try again.

If you fancy a weekend break, you might be better off looking at Web Weekends. You can search by location or activity (giving rise to some intriguing possibilities - Scotland plus spiritual and holistic brought no results, similarly Bulgaria and golf failed to match). Frustratingly, you can't search by date, and the listed price is infuriatingly vague. My attempts to book a weekend in the Cotswolds were frustrated because my departure was less than two weeks away; I had to enter my details so someone could phone me to discuss it in working hours. So much for spontaneity.

A very few last-minute deals are provided alongside gifts and entertainment ideas from Lastminute.com, a service which does neither site any favours - I didn't want to know about last-minute hand-made chocolates or West End theatre tickets. Talking of which, the infamous Last Minute is worth a look if you are indeed doing something last minute. Or indeed if you're the kind of crazy chick who buys hand-made chocolates at the very last minute. You can search the flights and holidays database for departures up to a month away, but other sites will invariably produce cheaper and better results. Sadly, while I was attempting to investigate what seemed to be a good deal on a flight to the States, my computer froze mid-search, and I had to restart. I didn't dare go back to try again. If you fancy a weekend break, you might be better off looking at Web Weekends. You can search by location or activity (giving rise to some intriguing possibilities - Scotland plus spiritual and holistic brought no results, similarly Bulgaria and golf failed to match). Frustratingly, you can't search by date, and the listed price is infuriatingly vague. My attempts to book a weekend in the Cotswolds were frustrated because my departure was less than two weeks away; I had to enter my details so someone could phone me to discuss it in working hours. So much for spontaneity.

fields.headline: Morning glory
fields.standfirst: 'We had been told that there were three ways to attract the dolphins: diving down, swimming round in circles, and singing into your snorkel. We must have looked ridiculous, and if I was a dolphin I would have kept well away from this bunch of weird humans, but it worked.'     Sam rises at dawn to swim with dolphins

We must have looked ridiculous, and if I was a dolphin I would have kept well away from this bunch of weird humans, but it worked.' Sam rises at dawn to swim with dolphins
fields.body:
Leaving Queenstown, I travelled down to Dunedin, a small, compact city in the south eastern corner of New Zealand's South Island. It's known as the Edinburgh of the South and there was obvious Scottish influence (even the street names are the same as in Edinburgh).

It was a warm afternoon so I went for a walk in the city botanical gardens and admired the roses. Coming back I wandered through the campus of Otago University - the first such institution to be established in New Zealand.

It was still the summer holidays so the quadrangles were quiet. There were a few students showing their families their new home. The parents looked proud and kept wanting to stop and take photos. The students looked terminally embarrassed and were trying to rush round before any of their friends saw them.

If Dunedin was supposed to be like Edinburgh, then Christchurch, my final stop in New Zealand, was the spitting image of Cambridge. All the street names are English - Oxford Terrace, Victoria Street, Dorset Road. You can even go punting on the river. (Look at Sam's pictures.)

The Arts Centre was my favourite place. It used to be a university, but the gothic buildings are now used as a complex for galleries, craft shops and cafes. I spent a happy time there drinking coffee in the leafy courtyards and watching the world go by.

I was staying in an upmarket hostel called Dorset House 10 minutes from the city centre. I've been getting fed up with sleeping in bunk beds in sterile dormitories, and decided that spending a few dollars extra would be worth it to get a proper bed and a good night's rest.

The hostel itself was very nice with a free pool table and armchairs, even proper duvets on the beds (an unheard of luxury). There were four others in my room (quite a small number) and it all looked very promising.

However, come the early hours I was woken by what I first thought was an earthquake. It was the guy next to me with the loudest snore I have ever heard - even my ear plugs couldn't block him out. After fuming in silence for a while, I thumped his bed and forced him to turn on his front.

All was quiet again.

I was just dropping off when the guy the other side of me started talking in his sleep.

I am beginning to long to have my own space, just for a while.

Some time ago I'd seen Jane's email suggesting I make my way up to Kaikoura to go swimming with wild dusky dolphins off the coast. This seemed a good idea and I booked myself on a trip. Emma had also emailed me to warn me that on the same excursion she had got seasick and almost vomited over one of these magical creatures. Keen to avoid this, I opted for the 6am trip when the sea should be at its calmest.

Waking at 5am in the dark, I began to regret this plan. My hostel was miles from the Dolphin Encounter office, and it took half an hour of stumbling along the beach through the early morning twilight to reach it.

There were about 10 of us in my group including my old Magic Bus friends, Holly and Katy (Katy you'll remember filmed my moment of bungee jump madness). We were kitted out with wetsuit, mask, snorkel and flippers and herded into a motor boat which whisked us out to sea.

Our guide explained that just off Kaikoura there is an unusually deep underwater canyon system. This supports a diverse range of marine life including dolphins and whales which can come very close to the shore.

The sun was slowly rising and it looked like being a beautiful day. The water was calm and clear. As the boat sped along we all looked out, trying to spot the dolphins.

We saw a couple slipping through the water but Steve, our guide, ignored them and headed on. He was looking for a bigger group.

And he found one.

The next time I looked out we were bang in the middle of a sea of dolphins. It was a huge pod - Steve later estimated that there must have been over 200. They were moving along the coast, rising and diving and leaping out of the sea.

There was a mad rush to the back of the boat where we began getting into the water. Out here the sea was over a kilometre deep and I as swam away I did begin to wonder what else might be down there in the dark depths. Putting my head under, the first thing I saw was a jellyfish far below me. This didn't make me feel any better.

We had been told that there were three ways to attract the dolphins: diving down, swimming round in circles, and singing into your snorkel. Frankly we must have looked ridiculous, and if I was a dolphin I would have kept well away from this bunch of weird humans, but it worked.

Two dolphins zoomed under me only a few feet away. Another came up to have a look at me before flicking his tail and vanishing into the distance. Then one swam round me and we circled each other maintaining eye contact the whole time. It was incredible - I could have almost touched him.

Looking up out of the water, I saw Steve waving us back. The pod had moved off and we needed to get back in the boat to catch them up.

For the next hour we chased after the dolphins and got back into the water with them three more times. I saw lots more, but none as close as that first time.

It was a completely different experience from the one I had in Doubtful Sound (see last week's report. That was much more tranquil. This was all a bit of a rush getting on and off the boat, but you got a chance to see these amazing creatures at their best, moving effortlessly underwater.

The final part of the trip was a natural history lesson and a chance to take photos of the dolphins riding the boat's bow wave. (Look at Sam's pictures). We dangled our feet over the bow as they zipped along under us. Then we said goodbye and turned for shore.

I have had an unforgettable time in New Zealand and will definitely be back. The scenery is spectacular, the marine life fascinating and the people a nice combination of enthusiastic and laid back.

But now it's time to move on again. Australia is beckoning and it's all I've been able to think about for the last few days.

Next stop Sydney, where hopefully I'll be meeting up with my fellow Netjetter, Milly.

fields.headline: Baywatch axed after 13 years
fields.trailText: 5.45pm: Baywatch, the smash-hit TV series which turned Pamela Anderson into a tabloid icon, has finally hung up its bikini after a 13-year run, writes Dan Milmo .
fields.body:
Baywatch, the smash-hit TV series which turned Pamela Anderson into a tabloid icon, has finally hung up its bikini after a 13-year run.

Broadcast bosses have left the US lifeguard drama out to dry after a location switch from Los Angeles to Hawaii failed to revive floundering ratings.

Sources told MediaGuardian.co.uk the decision was made yesterday at a meeting of executives.

The show was an instant success when it came to these shores in 1989, reviving the career of Knight Rider star David Hasselhoff and turning cast members into tabloid fixtures.

"Baywatch has been an incredible success story. It is one of the most successful series ever and has been televised in over 100 countries," said Brian Harris, chief executive of programme owner Pearson Television.

At the height of its fame in the mid-90s, the show played to a weekly global audience of over 1bn dedicated fans, who tuned in to follow the melodramatic fortunes of the partially clothed cast.

And it was such a sure-fire winner for early ITV schedules that the network even took the unusual step of investing in Baywatch when it was first threatened with the axe in the early 1990s.

Even the stone-faced rock band New Order admitted to loving the show, and filmed one of their videos with Mr Hasselhoff and the rest of the cast.

The plotlines and acting skills were of secondary importance to the looks of the cast, with the likes of Billy Warlock, Erika Eleniak and Yasmin Bleeth all chosen for their suitability as Athena poster pin-ups rather than as Emmy-winning actors.

But the show fell on hard times following its move to Hawaii after union pay demands forced the series out of its Californian location.

Pearson Television, which bought the show three years ago, today said: "All good things must come to an end.

One Pearson insider said: "It was the law of diminishing returns. It just wasn't get the audiences any more."

There will be one more series of the show.

Was Baywatch sexist? Talk about it here.

webTitle: Retrial for Michael Stone after Russell murder convictions quashed

fields.headline: Retrial for Michael Stone after Russell murder convictions quashed
fields.trailText: Michael Stone is to be tried again for the murder of Lin and Megan Russell after the appeal court this afternoon quashed his conviction for the 1996 killings.
fields.body:
Michael Stone is to be tried again for the murder of Lin and Megan Russell after the appeal court this afternoon quashed his conviction for the 1996 killings.

Mr Stone, 40, won an appeal against his conviction earlier this week and could have been released today if the three judges had not ruled that a retrial was needed. There was no application for bail.

The judges ruled on Tuesday that Mr Stone's appeal "must succeed" on the basis of the unreliability of a key prosecution witness. Barry Thompson gave evidence at Mr Stone's trial at Maidstone crown court in 1998, claiming Mr Stone had confessed the killings to him while they were both in prison.

The judges said they might reveal the reasons for their decision next Wednesday.

The judges rejected an argument by Mr William Clegg QC, counsel for Mr Stone, that his client would never be able to have a fair retrial because of media coverage of the case.

Mr Stone was given three life sentences for the two murders and the attempted murder of Megan's sister, Josie, near their home at Chillenden, Kent.

Josie, then aged nine, survived the hammer attack in which her mother, 45, and six-year-old sister were battered to death. The savage attack was among the most notorious cases in recent British criminal history.

The three were walking along an isolated footpath near Chillenden when they were attacked, tied up and beaten.

The bodies of Lin and Megan were found lying close to each other, covered in blood. Megan's swimming costume was found a few feet away. The family dog had also been killed.

webTitle: Charities must get 'slick' in forging private sector links

fields.headline: Charities must get 'slick' in forging private sector links
fields.trailText: Charities need to become more entrepreneurial when it comes to developing relationships with the private sector, if they are to achieve sustainable long-term funding, a leading social entrepreneur has said.
fields.body:
Charities need to become more entrepreneurial when it comes to developing relationships with the private sector, if they are to achieve sustainable long-term funding.

That was the argument of social entrepreneur Andrew Mawson, speaking at a seminar on sustainable funding organised by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO).

If charities are to move away from dependence on grants, a more diverse funding network is essential, he stressed, and that means building mutually beneficial links with businesses and other organisations.

"We need to become sharper, slicker and faster because the whole climate has changed and become more entrepreneurial," said Mr Mawson, chair of the Bromley by Bow Centre regeneration project in London's East End.

Co-speaker Patrick Law, public affairs director at energy giant Centrica, formerly British Gas, agreed that charities needed to be able to respond quickly: "When we were looking for a voluntary sector partner we asked charities to pitch and just three weeks later we had an agreement with Help the Aged."

Mr Mawson said the traditional bureaucratic processes in many charities had to change: "When there are endless management committee meetings, governance procedures and minute-taking, nothing gets done."

At the Bromley by Bow Centre, for example, an entrepreneurial culture has been fostered by mixing small business enterprises, such as a dance studio and hairdressers, with social schemes such as community care and nurseries.

In the main nursery toddlers come from a variety of family backgrounds: "We charge full rate for those families that can afford it so that we can offer free places to others," says Mr Mawson.

Mr Mawson has also been a key mover behind the Community Action Network (CAN), which aims to create a series of "business-social hubs" throughout the UK. CAN has already brought together a variety of organisations in an office block it refurbished on London's South Bank, including thinktank Demos and volunteering scheme Timebank.

"We all share these open plan offices, and a lot of good ideas emerge from chats over coffee between organisations from different sectors," he said.

As an example of sustainable funding at Bromley by Bow, he points to a health centre built with a £750,000 loan from insurance company Norwich Union.

"We then found a charitable trust to contribute £250,000 and, as we own the building, the rent gives us an income of £20,000 a year, so we're creating assets to further strengthen the local economy," he said.

Mr Law said charities seeking business support needed to carefully study what kind of company they would like to be partners with and to argue the business benefits of such an alliance.

Centrica's community involvement strategy has focused on "fuel poverty" issues, which has made disability and older people's charities natural partners. Its scheme with Help the Aged, one of the largest corporate partnerships in the UK, has raised £500,000 to help vulnerable people.

He advised charities seeking such partnerships to look for companies where there was a synergy. For example, there was a natural shared interest between Centrica and Help the Aged to enable vulnerable older people to have adequate access to gas and electricity.

He added that voluntary organisations could exploit specialist information they may have when dealing with companies, pointing out that Centrica has learned a lot from Help the Aged in areas such as door-to-door visits to older people and in the design of products.

fields.headline: Kitch appeal and cult viewing: Baywatch remembered
fields.trailText: Sun, surf and scantily-clad lovelies and very silly storylines - the world will mourn the death of Baywatch. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Sun, surf and scantily-clad lovelies and very silly storylines - for more than a decade Baywatch was the ultimate trash TV.

The fail-proof combination of semi-naked lifeguards, shapely young women in tight swimsuits and a leading man with the kind of kitsch appeal few could rival turned Baywatch into cult viewing the world over.

David Hasselhof, famed for being cast opposite a talking car in the eighties cop show Knight Rider, has been with the show since the beginning.

The permatanned star and producer got all the best storylines, giving him a chance to show off that famous earnest look.

And who could forget Baywatch's most famous bikini-clad surf queen, Pamela Anderson, who became an international superstar on the back of a few slow-motion jogs along that famous beach.

Even Ruby Wax - who usually reserves her diary space for the likes of Imelda Marcos and Sarah Ferguson - went out to California to interview America's most famous bottle blonde.

Baywatch was the brainchild of Michael Berk and Douglas Schwartz who, when they first floated the idea, were asked "How many times can you do resuscitation?".

Somehow they managed to persuade the Grant Tinker-Gannett company to put up $40,000 for them to shoot a montage as a pitch tool and the first episode of Baywatch was born.

At first the series achieved only modest ratings and it was cancelled after the first season. But a chance meeting between Mr Schwartz and producer Al Burton gave rise to the idea that Baywatch should use the money from advance foreign sales to fund another series.

It wasn't until the third season that ex-Playboy model Pamela Anderson joined the cast as CJ Parker.

Ms Anderson was the longest-serving Baywatch babe, staying on until series eight when she left to focus on her film career.

A role in the blockbuster movie Barb Wire followed but her most famous role by far was in a certain home video that made its way around the world via the internet.

Series eight failed to make it onto ITV, but the show struggled on in the US and all over the world.

But then last year came the blow that was to prove fatal. David Hasselhof left the show to spend more time on his flourishing pop career (well flourishing in Germany anyway). He disappeared last May in an enormous explosion and the show never quite recovered.

RIP Baywatch. The Daily Star will miss you.

He disappeared last May in an enormous explosion and the show never quite recovered. RIP Baywatch. The Daily Star will miss you.

webTitle: Ministers may back down on council secrecy

fields.headline: Ministers may back down on council secrecy
fields.trailText: The government has admitted that it is considering backing down on controversial council secrecy proposals, in the hope of avoiding an embarrassing defeat in the House of Lords tonight.
fields.body:
The government has admitted that it is considering backing down on controversial council secrecy proposals, in the hope of avoiding an embarrassing defeat in the House of Lords tonight.

The Liberal Democrats are continuing negotiations with ministers throughout the day in a bid to reach a compromise ahead of this evening's debate on regulations linked to the Local Government Act 2000. Ministers are keen to head off any attempt by the Tories and Lib Dems to vote down the legislation.

Sources close to the negotiations, however, say the Lib Dems may be prepared to climb down in return for concessions.

Under the government's proposals, mayors and cabinets would be forced to meet in public only when they are taking so-called "key decisions", those which affect more than two wards or incur significant expenditure as defined by individual councils.

The government has confirmed that it is considering putting forward a closer definition of which decisions are "key", and reviewing the regulations after their first year in operation.

A spokesman for local government minister Hilary Armstrong said: "We're open to doing that. We're always open to looking at how we can make these regulations more robust."

These changes would not necessarily mean scrapping the regulations, but could initially be done by amending government openness guidance.

The Tories, however, are determined to wreck the regulations and will tonight attempt to do so. The Tories hope to maintain the status quo in which the vast majority of council meetings are held in public.

If the regulations were scrapped, it could severely delay the introduction of new directly elected city mayors and Westminster-style council cabinets, as civil servants scramble to prepare new proposals.

webTitle: Trafalgar Square pigeons put to flight

fields.headline: Trafalgar Square pigeons put to flight
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: A distant death knell tolled for the pigeons of Trafalgar Square yesterday when Bernard Rayner, whose family has sold bird seed in the square for 50 years, agreed to close his stall in exchange for a substantial pay-off from the London mayor, Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
A distant death knell tolled for the pigeons of Trafalgar Square yesterday when Bernard Rayner, whose family has sold bird seed in the square for 50 years, agreed to close his stall in exchange for a substantial pay-off from the London mayor, Ken Livingstone.

Mr Rayner abandoned an application for a judicial review of the withdrawal of his licence after last-minute negotiations between the two sides.

Mr Rayner has agreed to close down his pitch immediately, leaving Greater London Authority employees to execute a "phased withdrawal" of feeding in the square until April 30.

The GLA hopes the withdrawal of food will cause the 10,000-strong flock to disperse. But animal welfare groups warned that the birds, described as "rats with wings" by Mr Livingstone, face "disaster".

After a brief hearing at the high court, during which Mr Justice Hooper admonished counsel for the mayor for making him "spend an awful lot of time reading about pigeons", Mr Rayner, 47, said he was sad to leave the square.

"I've been concerned with the pigeons all my life, but everything comes to an end," said Mr Rayner, who was accompanied by his wife Paula, 40. Mr Rayner said he would not be contacting his brother David after the pay-out, as the two had fallen out over the inheritance of the family stall. Mr Rayner won the licence by competing against his late father in 1995.

Mr Livingstone said in a statement later: "I am delighted we have managed to reach agreement so quickly."

A Greater London authority statement added that it would now organise a three-month programme for the phased withdrawal of feeding the birds in Trafalgar Square until April 30 so as to "disperse the pigeons without cruelty".

The GLA said biodiversity experts would monitor the flock and both Mr Rayner and the mayor hoped there would be "no outside interference" involving animal lovers bulk-feeding the birds and disrupting the dispersal programme.

An agreed sum would be paid to Mr Rayner "to recognise the fact that he will be unable to trade in the square in the future".

The statement added: "At the request of his solicitors, part of the sum representing Mr Rayner's costs will be donated to an animal welfare organisation."

webTitle: Comment: Dissent is in the air: take to the streets

fields.headline: Dissent is in the air: take to the streets
fields.standfirst: Public meetings are the new rock'n'roll as unlikely groups unite
fields.trailText: Public meetings are the new rock'n'roll as unlikely groups unite.
fields.body:
At last it's happening. Just as the neo-liberals on both sides of the Atlantic proclaim universal victory, a composite radical opposition movement is beginning to emerge. It's confused, it's contradictory and it looks like nothing we've ever seen before. But for the first time in 14 years of campaigning, I feel that I've witnessed something unstoppable.

I've spent this week touring the country with a ragged coalition of greens, anarchists and socialists. Everywhere we've been so far, I've picked up a sense of excitement I've never felt in Britain before. In Glasgow we drew 500 people: according to the locals I met it was the biggest political meeting in the city for 15 years. In London, 1,300 turned up.

But the numbers, unprecedented though they may be, are less impressive than the unity of purpose. In London, green activists stood and cheered an RMT official as he left the stage to join the Tube strike. In Coventry, car workers demanded an end to global warming. No one denies that there are issues which divide us, but in contesting the neoliberalism to which almost every major political party on earth has now subscribed, we have discovered an oppositional accord which overrides our differences.

Neoliberalism demands the privatisation of everything. While the general agreement on trade in services, due to be negotiated next month, would force governments gradually to transfer their mandate to the corporations, Britain has anticipated it with the universal application of the private finance initiative.

PFI serves companies better than overt privatisation, as the government guarantees their income stream. For the same reason it serves us worse: we lose both public control and public funds.

Neoliberalism also insists that companies be permitted to dump their costs on to people and the environment. As deregulation allows firms both to pollute the planet and to sack their staff without consultation, steelworkers and global warming campaigners have discovered, to their surprise, that they're on the same side.

New corporate freedoms, moreover, can be sustained only by denying freedom to everyone else. While the companies seizing our public services are permitted to use "commercial confidentiality" to disguise their intentions, our emails, even our computers can now be monitored and raided by the security services without a warrant.

While corporations have acquired the legal status of human beings, but without most of the accompanying criminal liability, jury trials are being denied to those who protest against them. The government, which granted passports to the billionaire businessmen accused of involvement in the biggest arms corruption scandal in modern times, has just announced new restrictions on asylum seekers. The world has been wrested from our hands.

In seeking to wrest it back, we have yet to develop a coherent political programme to which all of us can subscribe. While the greens support small business, trades unionists find workers within big corporations easier to mobilise. The anarchists want to smash the state, while the socialists want to rebuild it.

But the unprecedented solidarity between these disparate groups is beginning, I feel, to develop into a programme in its own right: a grassroots reorganisation of the political process, propelling democratic renewal from below.

We must, of course, be careful not to mistake the affirmation expressed at these meetings for wider public consent. But the public support for the strikers contesting the privatisation of the London Underground and the West Midlands hospitals suggests that some, at least, of our demands are beginning to resonate with Britain's biggest political movement: the disillusionment party. The extraordinary numbers promising to attend the protests at Faslane, the Scottish nuclear base, on Monday and the G8 summit in Genoa in July, suggest that this is the beginning of something big.

The new political movements have rediscovered in the public meeting an effective forum for dissent. We were promised that television and the internet would promote participation; instead they have provided our representatives with new screens to hide behind. As radical movements struggle to escape from an enclosed and virtual politics, public speaking has become the new rock and roll.

The enclosure of power will not be easily reversed. But had any New Labour ministers attended the meetings we have held so far, they would have scurried back to Westminster very worried indeed.

This is not the end of neoliberalism. But it is the beginning of the end.

webTitle: Meritocracy at heart of Blair's new 'big ideas'

fields.headline: Meritocracy at heart of Blair's new 'big ideas'
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today start unveiling the new ideas that will form the centrepiece of his bid for a second term with the key themes likely to be meritocracy, choice and extension of opportunity.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today start unveiling the new ideas that will form the centrepiece of his bid for a second term with the key themes likely to be meritocracy, choice and extension of opportunity.

Two new 10-year plans on education and crime, parallelling the existing 10-year plans for health and transport, will be set out over the next month, starting with new ideas on teacher recruitment and retention this weekend leading to the publication of the education plan next week.

The prime minister is also promising a further white paper on the knowledge based economy, greater resources for regional development agencies and new incentives for universities to become incubators for change.

Meritocracy and choice, backed by yet more challenging targets for the public services, will be the key themes. The crime plan will centre on four major themes - mod ernising the courts, sentencing, police reform, and tackling the 100,000 hard core criminals.

The courts reform will be based on the Auld inquiry into the courts. Thousands of cases which now qualify for jury trial are likely to be reserved for a new hybrid court consisting of a professional judge, or stipendiary, sitting with two lay magistrates.

Juries would be reserved only for the most serious cases, under the proposals, which are contained in a report by Sir Robin Auld, the appeal judge.

The police reform package may centre on four themes - use of new technolgy by the police including DNA, the likely shape of future crime, especially organised crime, the future structure of the police, including possibly regionalisation, and ensuring a greater police visibility in the streets, the single biggest complaint against the police.

Ministers are keen on having police in supermarkets, post offices and community centres, an idea pillaged from New York.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, has already set out plans to target 100,000 persistent offenders.

A sentencing review already under way in the lord chancellor's department could end with a major change in the law. Mr Straw wants to accept the demand from the Association of Chief Police Officers to be allowed to disclose in court past criminal records of defendants.

In the field of education, the focus in the 10-year plan will shift from reform of primary school reform to secondary schools, adult literacy and equal access to higher education.

Fourteen-year-olds are to be given the option of a vocational path and the aim will be to "customise" qualifications to meet the needs of each pupil.

Ministers will promise a big expansion of vocational GCSEs, which are being introduced in 2002.

State schools, likely to be broken up into more specialist schools, will be urged to let their brightest students take GCSEs at 15, giving them time to take more A levels, AS levels, and the new "world class" advanced extension awards.

Ministers are also to announce plans to make sure expansion of higher education does not exclude bright children from deprived areas.

Twenty-seven universities are being targeted for extra money to recruit from more diverse areas.

fields.headline: New Labour's 30-second doorstep challenge
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Not seen your MP in four years? Get ready for a politics-free 30-second doorstep chat before he or she gallops off to buttonhole a neighbour.
fields.body:
Not seen your MP in four years? Get ready for a politics-free 30-second doorstep chat before he or she gallops off to buttonhole a neighbour.

Labour's general election candidates have been told to watch the clock and avoid difficult discussions about government policies in Operation Turnout which is to use "blitzing" - canvassing on the run - to win support.

A Millbank guide sent to thousands of activists this month drills New Labour's crack troops on how to appear concerned while trawling for as many votes as possible in as little time as possible.

Parliamentary hopefuls are instructed to spend no more than half a minute per doorstep after an advance guard of volunteers has knocked on doors so electors are ready and waiting for the visit chat.

Labour supporters will enjoy a full half-minute of the candidate's precious time, which is half a minute longer than Liberal Democrat, Tory, nationalist or other voters will get - they are to be avoided altogether.

Tricky subjects, such as why is the NHS in such poor shape or secondary class sizes are so big, are to be sidestepped in favour of a smile, handshake and plea for support.

And after the 30 seconds is up, candidates must not dawdle to the next address.

"The MP or parliamentary spokesperson will (often literally) run from house to house as he or she is called over by one of the helpers," says the February issue of Countdown, a monthly Labour newsletter.

"The MP or parliamentary spokesperson should spend just 30 seconds or so with sympathetic voters (opposition voters having been screened out by the helpers), without getting waylaid in any heavy discussions."

Any information gleaned from brief encounters, says the guide, should be used to add a "simple handwritten PS" to standard letters sent out later.

Tories and Liberal Democrats use similar tactics and stalwarts of all parties attempt to keep opponents on the doorstep to waste their time.

But given that the BBC calculates people speak about 180 words a minute, no more than 90 words will be spoken in a typical visit - or 45 words each if there is a conversation.

That should be just long enough for a Labour candidate, perhaps, to say: "Hello, lovely to see you again. I trust I can count on you to vote Labour so I can be an MP, concerned about your issues. Vote for me and I promise not to waste another 30 seconds of your time for four years. Goodbye."

webTitle: Comment: Millionaires' handouts will not sustain a democracy

fields.headline: Millionaires' handouts will not sustain a democracy
fields.standfirst: The state should take over the funding of political parties
fields.trailText: Vernon Bogdanor: The state should take over the funding of political parties
fields.body:
Should our political parties be compelled to rely on millionaires for their money and their policies? Last month, a wealthy businessman, Stuart Wheeler, gave £5m to the Conservatives, a sum amounting to over one-third of their central income, declaring his support to be contingent upon the party remaining Eurosceptic and keeping Kenneth Clarke out of the leadership. Three other businessmen, two of whom are peers, recently admitted giving £2m to the Labour party.

This dependence is something new in modern British politics. Traditionally, the funding of the two major parties derived largely from institutional sources, companies and trade unions. In the early 80s, the trade unions provided no less than 75% of Labour's central income and companies just over 50% of the Tories' central income. In recent years, however, both parties have sought, with considerable success, to reduce their reliance upon institutions. This is particularly important for Labour since, as Tony Blair declared in September 1995: "Nobody believes in this day and age that the business of the Labour party is to be the political arm of the trade union movement." Today, the bulk of party finance comes not from institutions but from individual donors.

In an ideal world, political parties would be financed wholly through individual membership subscriptions. In no democracy, however, are parties able to support themselves entirely from their members. In Britain, with just 750,000 people belonging to the three main parties, it would hardly be possible for them to finance their activities by subscriptions alone.

In the past, the gap was filled by institutional finance. But, with that source in decline, the major parties have fallen back on rich donors. Yet that source too may be under threat, since, under the provisions of the Political Parties, Referendums and Elections Act, the parties will now have to disclose both the names of donors and the size of their donations. This will no doubt embarrass many donors and may have the effect of curtailing their contributions. It has been alleged that, in the past, large donations to a political party increase one's chances of a knighthood or peerage. A large donation was a rich man's political levy enabling him to enter, if not the kingdom of heaven, then at least the house of lords. But sunlight, as Mr Justice Brandeis once said, is the best disinfectant. Perhaps, in future, a large gift to a party will be seen as a good reason not to give someone an honour rather than grounds to reward them with a peerage or knighthood.

If the parties are to raise sufficient funds to carry out their democratic functions, therefore, they will need state aid. In Britain, the fundamental argument against it has always been that parties are voluntary organisations. Yet the principle of public funding is already accepted as part of our national life. Since 1937, the leader of the opposition has been paid a salary, while since 1975, the opposition parties in parliament have been in receipt of public funds - the so-called "short money" - to aid their parliamentary activities.

Admittedly, aid to political parties for their activities outside parliament would be a new departure. Yet, money paid to the parties for their parliamentary activities inevitably increases the sum available for party work outside parliament.

A prime reason why in Britain the state aids political parties is that the existence of a healthy party system is in the interests of democracy. Thus the opposition parties play as vital a role in preserving democracy as the government. The issue, therefore, is not whether a new principle ought to be introduced into our political life, but whether an already accepted principle should be extended.

State aid to parties can take different forms. On the continent, the state generally funds parties in proportion to votes won or seats gained in general elections. This is said to devitalise democracy by making parties over-reliant on public funds and remote from their members and supporters. But the continental method is not the only way in which aid can be provided.

In the US and Canada, aid is triggered in a different way, with individual contributions to candidates and parties qualifying for tax relief or tax credits. This is accepted as perfectly natural both on the left and on the right. Indeed, Ronald Reagan's libertarian principles did not prevent him from accepting public funds for his presidential campaigns in 1980 and 1984.

In 1998, the Neill committee on standards in public life recommended aid in the form of tax relief on donations. But that would be inequitable since it would not benefit non-taxpayers - pensioners and students, for example - who might wish to give money to political parties.

The thought behind the Neill proposal, however, was that the parties ought to broaden their basis of support and rely less on large donations. That could be achieved were aid to be made conditional upon some visible index of public support, such as party membership. As long ago as 1981, the Hansard Society's commission on the funding of political parties, chaired by the late Edmund Dell, to which I acted as secretary, proposed a system by which party membership subscriptions could trigger state aid. For each £10 raised, for example, the state would make a matching payment of £10 to the party.

If a ceiling of aid were calculated such that, to achieve its maximum, each party would have to secure membership subscriptions from one in 12 of those who had voted for it in the previous general election, the total cost to the exchequer would be around £30m a year, less than one-fifth of the annual cost of the driver and vehicle licensing agency. A system of this kind would encourage parties to seek new members and stimulate fundraising; and constituency organisations would probably become more lively and more representative organisations than they are today. Moreover, a legal limit could then be placed on the size of individual donations, thus further limiting the power of big money.

The issue of how parties should be funded is not, then, one of freedom versus the state. Instead, with the decline of institutional funding, it has become one of whether the parties should rely on large donors, or on their members. With public funding, the special interests of the wealthy would be weakened while the general interest would be strengthened. Political parties would be compelled to rely upon a large number of small contributors rather than the tainted generosity of a few large contributors. The cost would be a small price to pay for improving the health of our democratic system.

Vernon Bogdanor is professor of government at Oxford University

fields.headline: Green-fingered King reveals Plant's profits
fields.trailText: Stephen King's ebook experiment, The Plant, appears to have paid-off, according to a simple profit and loss chart posted on his website yesterday
fields.body:
Stephen King's ebook experiment, The Plant, appears to have paid-off, according to a simple profit and loss chart posted on his website yesterday.

The figures show that the total money received from downloading of the six-part book was $721,448.61 and after expenses, which included $140,766.75 for advertising, $14,000 for 'compositing and design services' and $102,849.59 for 'web hosting and maintenance', the net profit was $463,832.27.

King, who has suspended the project for six months in order to work on his next book, allowed readers to pay by an 'honour system', trusting them to pay after the story was downloaded. King charged $1 for the first three instalments and $2 for the following three. Following accusations of naivety from the media, King last month defended this payment method in an article in Time Magazine claiming: "I felt that I had armed myself with a stick to protect my carrot", referring to his threats to halt the project if people did not pay up. Although the figures show a profit, it is not clear how many downloads were actually paid for.

Despite King's decision to return to print publishing for his next two books, he doesn't consider The Plant - the tale of a supernatural vine which grows wild in a publishing house - dead and buried, "just lying dormant for half a year."

For those who missed any of the instalments, King's publishing company, Philtrum Press, will soon be publishing the first six parts in ebook format for $7 each. This time, however, he wants the payment up front.

webTitle: Blair shows his hand on the euro

fields.headline: Blair shows his hand on the euro
fields.trailText:
Tony Blair dramatically clarified his plans to take Britain into the single currency yesterday when he
           promised that a re-elected Labour government would decide within two years whether to hold a
           referendum .
fields.body:
Tony Blair dramatically clarified his plans to take Britain into the single currency yesterday when he promised that a re-elected Labour government would decide within two years whether to hold a referendum .

He promised the Treasury's assessment of the five economic tests for entry would be held within two years but vowed he would not bounce the British electorate by making the assessment within months of the election.

It is the first time Mr Blair has defined the government's previously vague timescale to make the assessment "early" in the next parliament.

He made the commitment in answer to a question from William Hague during prime minister's questions in the Commons.

Mr Blair told a startled Mr Hague: "Early in the next parliament means exactly what it says. Early in the next parliament would, of course, be within two years."

If the prime minister had said the economic assessment might be held later than two years after the election, it would have opened the serious possibility of Britain not entering the euro within the next parliament.

On the assumption that the Treasury concluded the British economy had met the five tests - especially that the British and European economies had converged - a Labour government would still have to hold a referendum , prepare notes and coins as well as negotiate with the EU on the entry rate for sterling against the euro .

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press spokesman, said the referendum could be held within two years, but did not commit the government to this timetable.

Mr Blair's remarks reflect a new confidence about the euro within government after its rise on the markets. Pro- euro cabinet ministers, including Stephen Byers and Robin Cook, have also noted the clear statements from car chiefs that they will disinvest unless there is a real prospect of sterling joining the euro . They were eager not to allow any backsliding from the policy after the resignation of the pro-European Peter Mandelson.

Mr Hague later claimed that Mr Blair had "just blown his policy on the single currency out of the water" and "given the pound two years to live". He added: "There can be no doubt that the fate of the pound will be a huge issue at the election."

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy led pro-Europeans in welcoming the move, but claimed it was too late. Even a pro- euro cabinet decision in 2002 would leave little time to complete the nuts-and-bolts moves to join the euro before the 2005-6 election, some experts warned.

Eurosceptic claims that Mr Blair had effectively slapped down his chancellor, Gordon Brown, were dismissed by both Downing Street and the Treasury.

Mr Blair will today put the creation of a meritocratic Britain at the top of Labour's priorities - and identify university elitism as a crucial barrier to be demolished.

Following Mr Brown's attack last year on Oxbridge elitism, ministers have negotiated a package with 27 universities which currently recruit less than 80% of their students from state schools.

All 27 will be monitored for year-on-year improvement as targeted schools also get extra help to raise their pupils' expectations, part of a drastic makeover for the comprehensive system to extol choice and diversity over regimentation.

With Labour headquarters at Millbank gearing up for the expected May 3 election, the prime minister will use a speech at a north London school today to make a determined effort to persuade voters that, if re-elected, Labour will use its growing self-confidence and national affluence to be more radical than it has been since 1997.

The cabinet remains committed to reform of the public services as the centrepiece of its campaign. To ram home his message Mr Blair will today promise to match his ambitious plans for transport and the NHS with sweeping 10-year plans to revitalise both education and the criminal justice system.

The education plan will be unveiled next week, the crime plan later in the month as part of a flurry of announcements which precede Mr Brown's cautiously generous budget, probably on March 6 or 13.

Today the prime minister will argue that better public service - above all, education - provides the best means to break down the barriers to what he will call "a true meritocracy where people can rise according to their own ability".

Mr Blair will argue that Labour's task is to open up opportunity to all - not least by removing barriers of poverty, poor education, adult illiteracy and failing public services.

fields.headline: Bob buys Barney
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: Bob the Builder creator HIT Entertainment has been given the go-ahead to buy the US firm behind Barney the Dinosaur, writes Dan MilmoFeb 1: HIT suspends shares
fields.body:
HIT Entertainment, creator of kids' favourite Bob the Builder, has been given clearance to buy the US company behind Barney the Dinosaur.

The Federal Trade Commission's website revealed that the UK company has been "granted early termination" to buy Lyrick Studios and its subsidiaries Big Feats and Lyons Partnership in an all-share deal.

The announcement ends a week of speculation about HIT's mystery takeover target, after its shares were suspended at the beginning of the month pending an acquisition.

A successful deal would bring together two of the most popular children's characters of recent times, with Barney selling over 130m videos and books worldwide.

Lyrick is a much larger company than HIT, which is currently valued at £400m, but HIT has timed its move perfectly.

Bob the Builder is one of the biggest children's TV hits on the BBC and a spin-off single went to number one at Christmas.

It accounts for 60% of HIT's revenues, which hit £20.3m last year but some analysts doubt if the character's success can last forever.

"HIT knows the success of Bob the Builder will not go on forever, so it is using its current strong share price to make an acquisition," said one analyst.

A breakthrough in the US market would give Bob an extended lifespan, and is a key reason behind the move for Lyrick.

Other mooted targets included EM.TV's Jim Henson Company, which makes the Muppets show.

Lyrick's other characters include Wishbone the Jack Russell terrier, Joe Scruggs and Australian music group the Wiggles.

HIT's shares were trading at 440p before their suspension.

Relevant story Feb 1: HIT suspends shares

fields.headline: Obituary: Sir Richard Southern
fields.standfirst: Historian whose biographies of a medieval monk and bishop mirrored his own search for practical answers to the questions posed by faith
fields.trailText: Richard Southern, who has died aged 88, became a great medieval historian. But, as a schoolboy at Newcastle Royal Grammar School, he was unenthusiastic about history, seeing it to be a matter of dates and names.
fields.body:
Richard Southern, who has died aged 88, became a great medieval historian. But, as a schoolboy at Newcastle Royal Grammar School, he was unenthusiastic about history, seeing it to be a matter of dates and names.

That changed when he was reading a book on the Tudors and his eye fell on the sentence, "Henry VII was the first businessman to sit upon the English throne."

In an instant the schoolboy understood. His father was a businessman, importing timber (the sign "MH Southern and Brothers" is still visible over the timber yard next to Bede's monastery in Jarrow). Young Southern had often seen his father and uncles stay up late with their account books, and now he knew how Henry VII had tackled government. He had moved from outside to inside history.

The sentence about Henry VII was not, as it happens, historically correct. Southern recognised that later, but the damage had been done: he won the Domus exhibition to Balliol College, Oxford. There, he was attacked by a new kind of doubt, this time about the history course.

The Oxford modern history school had been designed in the late 19th century by William Stubbs, as a documentary study of British constitutional development. That ideal began to look inadequate in 1929, with the Wall Street crash triggering the first mass unemployment and the League of Nations starting to look precarious. English constitutional development was not enough for Southern, and he thought he had picked the wrong course.

Much later still, when Southern was appointed Oxford's Chichele professor in 1961, his earlier undergraduate doubts would bear rich fruit in his pellucid inaugural lecture, The Shape and Substance of Academic History, on the role of history in universities, and then as president of the Royal Historical Society from 1968-72, in four presidential lectures in which he explained how Europe came to interest itself in history at all. (The series is called Aspects of the European Tradition of Historical Writing, and is in the Transactions of the society for 1970-73.)

The doubting undergraduate had been rescued by two Balliol tutors, who pulled him out from slightly different angles, but both in the right direction. One was Vivian Galbraith, ex-Public Record Office, who saw the historian's job as the interpretation of particular documents and who remained in Southern's memory as "the most energising historian I have ever met".

The other was Maurice Powicke. Like Stubbs, Powicke saw history as past politics, but, unlike Stubbs, Powicke included in "politics" questions of family background, education, friendships, religion.

An undergraduate essay Southern wrote won the Royal Historical Society's Alexander prize. It was on Ranulf Flambard, a careerist Anglo-Norman cleric. Galbraith had shown Southern some newly published charters of Flambard, and in the winter of 1930-31 Southern had studied them and worked them into the essay. He went on to win a first, and was taken up by Exeter College with a five-year junior research fellowship.

Southern's undergraduate doubts had also led to a decision to take seriously his membership of the Church of England, into which he had been baptised. He remained a regular communicant, supporting - and occasionally preaching at - the chapels of his successive colleges, and latterly at St Giles' parish church.

Southern was a fides quarens intellectum (a faith seeking understanding), with all the active and intellectual obligations the two parts of that formula respectively involve. He felt a natural attraction towards great figures in European history of whom the same was true, and brought to his own time an exceptional sympathy and perception as to their interpretation.

St Anselm was the first. A monk, philosopher and second archbishop of Canterbury after the Norman Conquest, he had been a man of international stature and influence. Southern himself became a wandering scholar, to Paris, in 1933-34, to study under Ferdinand Lot, and also more briefly, in 1935, to Munich.

In 1937, Galbraith left Oxford, and Balliol elected Southern to replace him as tutor. When the second world war broke out, Southern joined the Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry, moving in 1941 to the Durham Light Infantry as second lieutenant, and from there, in 1942, to the 155th regiment of the Royal Armoured Corps, where he became a tank commander.

In 1943, he was promoted to captain and transferred again, to the political intelligence department of the Foreign Office. There, in 1944, he became a major, which entitled him to a secretary. The woman who took the job, Sheila Crichton-Miller, was the widow of an RAF hero recently killed in action, and her first act on arriving in the major's office was to cause ink to spill over his papers. They were married later that year.

In 1945, Southern returned to Balliol to begin a 15-year period as tutor and university lecturer. In his first lecture he was embarrassed to find he had run short of material 15 minutes before the hour; so he simply said "good morning" and left. That never happened again. His lectures became proverbial for their well-ordered clarity and a quietly sparkling erudition.

He had an unfailing gentleness of manner, but when there was disciplinary dirty work to be done at Balliol, the other dons, who included Christopher Hill and Michael Wallace-Hadrill, would pick on Southern to do it. The university took the same view, and made him a proctor for 1948-49.

In l952 he was diagnosed with tuberculosis, and during a slow convalescence wrote The Making of the Middle Ages (1953), his first book. It has been translated into 27 languages.

Southern would himself later voice the view that scholars should not write books until they have finished as full-time university teachers. His own career at least partially fits that principle. In 1961, he moved from Balliol to All Souls, with his appointment as Chichele professor, a post which entails much lecturing, in and out of Oxford, and graduate supervision, but no undergraduate tutoring.

And his next two books were occasioned by invitations to lecture, outside Oxford: one from Harvard, which led in 1962 to the publication of his Western Views of Islam in the Middle Ages; another from Cambridge (to give the Birkbeck Lectures for 1959), which led to St Anselm and his Biographer (1963). It appeared almost simultaneously with his critical edition of the Life of St Anselm by Anselm's contemporary Eadmer, in the Oxford Medieval Texts series.

In 1969, Southern resigned his chair to become president of St John's College, where he stayed until 1981. As president he remained a source of tireless encouragement to younger medievalists, especially graduate students. A visitor once expressed admiring astonishment, after a graduate seminar at which Southern had presided, that young speakers had joined in without giving any impression of being cowed by the great man's participation.

On leaving the seminar, Southern confided his secret: "You've got to let them crawl all over you." Any who came back to study in the unique Bodleian collections, and who lacked an Oxford toehold, would regularly be made welcome in the former servants' quarters of the President's Lodgings.

In 1970, a year after his arrival at St John's, Western Society and the Church in the Middle Ages, Volume 2 in the Penguin History of the Church, appeared (Southern had at first been asked to write Volume 3 but had asked for and obtained a double chronological ration); and (in the same year) a collection of several of his earlier articles as Medieval Humanism and Other Studies.

Meanwhile, Southern had turned increasingly to another model of fides quarens intellectum , Robert Grosseteste, the polymathic Oxford philosopher who became bishop of Lincoln, and died in 1254.

Although Grosseteste was undoubtedly one of England's great men, his historiography had always bristled with problems, not least in that more than 2,500 manuscripts survive of his writings.

Like Grosseteste at Lincoln, Richard Southern combined effective administration with exemplary scholarship, and his highly readable Robert Grosseteste: the Growth of an English Mind in Medieval Europe would permanently change scholarship on the subject.

The book did not finally appear until 1987, when Southern and his wife had moved from the college to St John's Street - a world away, they sensed, from the university current, and the occasion of Southern's greatest literary productivity.

His lifelong interest in St Anselm had led him to seek ever more exactitude in portraiture, and in 1990 a wholly recast version of his earlier book appeared as Saint Anselm: a Portrait in a Landscape.

And at last, in 1995, there began to appear his most ambitious project.
