But, as a schoolboy at Newcastle Royal Grammar School, he was unenthusiastic about history, seeing it to be a matter of dates and names. That changed when he was reading a book on the Tudors and his eye fell on the sentence, "Henry VII was the first businessman to sit upon the English throne." In an instant the schoolboy understood. His father was a businessman, importing timber (the sign "MH Southern and Brothers" is still visible over the timber yard next to Bede's monastery in Jarrow). Young Southern had often seen his father and uncles stay up late with their account books, and now he knew how Henry VII had tackled government. He had moved from outside to inside history. The sentence about Henry VII was not, as it happens, historically correct. Southern recognised that later, but the damage had been done: he won the Domus exhibition to Balliol College, Oxford. There, he was attacked by a new kind of doubt, this time about the history course. The Oxford modern history school had been designed in the late 19th century by William Stubbs, as a documentary study of British constitutional development. That ideal began to look inadequate in 1929, with the Wall Street crash triggering the first mass unemployment and the League of Nations starting to look precarious. English constitutional development was not enough for Southern, and he thought he had picked the wrong course. Much later still, when Southern was appointed Oxford's Chichele professor in 1961, his earlier undergraduate doubts would bear rich fruit in his pellucid inaugural lecture, The Shape and Substance of Academic History, on the role of history in universities, and then as president of the Royal Historical Society from 1968-72, in four presidential lectures in which he explained how Europe came to interest itself in history at all. (The series is called Aspects of the European Tradition of Historical Writing, and is in the Transactions of the society for 1970-73.) The doubting undergraduate had been rescued by two Balliol tutors, who pulled him out from slightly different angles, but both in the right direction. One was Vivian Galbraith, ex-Public Record Office, who saw the historian's job as the interpretation of particular documents and who remained in Southern's memory as "the most energising historian I have ever met". The other was Maurice Powicke. Like Stubbs, Powicke saw history as past politics, but, unlike Stubbs, Powicke included in "politics" questions of family background, education, friendships, religion. An undergraduate essay Southern wrote won the Royal Historical Society's Alexander prize. It was on Ranulf Flambard, a careerist Anglo-Norman cleric. Galbraith had shown Southern some newly published charters of Flambard, and in the winter of 1930-31 Southern had studied them and worked them into the essay. He went on to win a first, and was taken up by Exeter College with a five-year junior research fellowship. Southern's undergraduate doubts had also led to a decision to take seriously his membership of the Church of England, into which he had been baptised. He remained a regular communicant, supporting - and occasionally preaching at - the chapels of his successive colleges, and latterly at St Giles' parish church. Southern was a fides quarens intellectum (a faith seeking understanding), with all the active and intellectual obligations the two parts of that formula respectively involve. He felt a natural attraction towards great figures in European history of whom the same was true, and brought to his own time an exceptional sympathy and perception as to their interpretation. St Anselm was the first. A monk, philosopher and second archbishop of Canterbury after the Norman Conquest, he had been a man of international stature and influence. Southern himself became a wandering scholar, to Paris, in 1933-34, to study under Ferdinand Lot, and also more briefly, in 1935, to Munich. In 1937, Galbraith left Oxford, and Balliol elected Southern to replace him as tutor. When the second world war broke out, Southern joined the Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry, moving in 1941 to the Durham Light Infantry as second lieutenant, and from there, in 1942, to the 155th regiment of the Royal Armoured Corps, where he became a tank commander. In 1943, he was promoted to captain and transferred again, to the political intelligence department of the Foreign Office. There, in 1944, he became a major, which entitled him to a secretary. The woman who took the job, Sheila Crichton-Miller, was the widow of an RAF hero recently killed in action, and her first act on arriving in the major's office was to cause ink to spill over his papers. They were married later that year. In 1945, Southern returned to Balliol to begin a 15-year period as tutor and university lecturer. In his first lecture he was embarrassed to find he had run short of material 15 minutes before the hour; so he simply said "good morning" and left. That never happened again. His lectures became proverbial for their well-ordered clarity and a quietly sparkling erudition. He had an unfailing gentleness of manner, but when there was disciplinary dirty work to be done at Balliol, the other dons, who included Christopher Hill and Michael Wallace-Hadrill, would pick on Southern to do it. The university took the same view, and made him a proctor for 1948-49. In l952 he was diagnosed with tuberculosis, and during a slow convalescence wrote The Making of the Middle Ages (1953), his first book. It has been translated into 27 languages. Southern would himself later voice the view that scholars should not write books until they have finished as full-time university teachers. His own career at least partially fits that principle. In 1961, he moved from Balliol to All Souls, with his appointment as Chichele professor, a post which entails much lecturing, in and out of Oxford, and graduate supervision, but no undergraduate tutoring. And his next two books were occasioned by invitations to lecture, outside Oxford: one from Harvard, which led in 1962 to the publication of his Western Views of Islam in the Middle Ages; another from Cambridge (to give the Birkbeck Lectures for 1959), which led to St Anselm and his Biographer (1963). It appeared almost simultaneously with his critical edition of the Life of St Anselm by Anselm's contemporary Eadmer, in the Oxford Medieval Texts series. In 1969, Southern resigned his chair to become president of St John's College, where he stayed until 1981. As president he remained a source of tireless encouragement to younger medievalists, especially graduate students. A visitor once expressed admiring astonishment, after a graduate seminar at which Southern had presided, that young speakers had joined in without giving any impression of being cowed by the great man's participation. On leaving the seminar, Southern confided his secret: "You've got to let them crawl all over you." webTitle: No university top-up fees, promises Blunkett

fields.headline: No university top-up fees, promises Blunkett
fields.standfirst:
The 1998 Act
University review of funding options
Special report: tuition fees
fields.trailText: Education secretary David Blunkett today ruled out university top-up fees in the next Parliament if a Labour government is re-elected.
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett today ruled out university top-up fees in the next Parliament if a Labour government is re-elected.

Prime minister Tony Blair meanwhile confirmed the governmentÍs drive to recruit 50% of people under 30 into higher education by 2010, and told MPs that by the end of the next academic year only half of students' parents will pay current tuition fees.

Mr Blunkett said: "I have made my position clear for the last two years. I am opposed to top-up fees. For the next Parliament - there will be no levying of top-up fees if we win the next election."

The education secretaryÍs statement, in response to a question in the House of Commons, came as a complete surprise to universities, who are currently reviewing the future funding options for the higher education sector. The government wants academic institutions to take on more students, but is unwilling to commit more public money to the sector.

"More money has been directed towards higher education recently but it's clear the sector needs much more support to be able to bring in the extra students the government wants to see in our universities," said Diana Warwick, chief executive of Universities UK. "If higher contributions from students or graduates are ruled out, more public funding will be necessary in the future."

The refusal to even consider allowing universities to charge extra fees on top of current tuition fees Ü a maximum of £1050 a year for students Ü will put the Labour government on a collision course with some university heads, who believe that fees are inevitable. Last week the University of Nottingham vice-chancellor, Sir Colin Campbell, said that academic institutions will face financial ruin if they were not allowed to charge richer students extra fees.

Under the governmentÍs Teaching and Higher Education Act 1998, any institution which charges top-up fees could incur financial penalties.

Also speaking in the House of Commons, Mr Blair said that by 2010 he wanted to achieve a university participation rate of more than 50% among under-30-year-olds. The prime minister said that by the next academic year, 50% of students' parents will not pay tuition fees.

He noted that at present, nearly three-quarters of the children of professional parents go to university, but barely one in six children of parents of manual occupations do so.

But he said that the government will be introducing bursaries of £2,000 offered to 25,000 students from poorer backgrounds, and an extra 5% funding for students from less privileged neighbourhoods.

University summer programmes for sixth-formers from state schools, designed to encourage them to apply for university, were also being expanded.

From April 2001, ïleadingÍ universities will receive £6m a year in ring-fenced government funding for three years to improve access for "able young people from low participation backgrounds".

webTitle: University access committee accused of partisanship

fields.headline: University access committee accused of partisanship
fields.trailText: A cross-party House of Commons investigation into widening access to university has ended in a furious political row, with opposition MPs accusing Labour colleagues of kowtowing to ministers and failing in their parliamentary duty properly to scrutinise the government.
fields.byline: Rebecca Smithers and Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
A cross-party House of Commons investigation into widening access to university has ended in a furious political row, with opposition MPs accusing Labour colleagues of kowtowing to ministers and failing in their parliamentary duty properly to scrutinise the government.

The long-awaited report into higher education by MPs on the all-party education select committee is published today. Its 37 recommendations include radical measures such as shaking up the school year to allow universities to select pupils when they already know their A-level grades.

But in farcical scenes yesterday in the Commons, opposition MPs distanced themselves from the main report agreed by the Labour MPs, instead giving briefings on their own 'minority' reports. The two Conservative MPs and one Liberal Democrat MP were particularly upset that a critical reference to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, was deleted shortly before publication. Mr Brown last year stoked a major debate about access to university after Oxford University rejected the application of comprehensive schoolgirl Laura Spence. There is no reference anywhere in the report to Mr Brown, or, indeed, to Miss Spence, who has since taken up a place at a US university after getting five straight As in her A-levels.

Committee member Dr Evan Harris, who is Liberal Democrat MP for Oxford West and Abingdon, and the party's higher education spokesman, attacked what he described as the "most craven and most fawning performance of the majority ever witnessed in a select committee report". He said that the MPs' failure to act on evidence criticising Gordon Brown's "misdirected outburst" was "a castrated testimony to the worship of cabinet by backbench MPs, whose job should be to scrutinise".

Fellow committee member Nick St Aubyn, Conservative MP for Guildford, claimed that "the committee has failed in its duty to parliament, its duty to higher education and its duty to students". Mr St Aubyn claimed that MPs removed mentions of Mr Brown after the Labour party intervened. The official record shows that the committee initially agreed that the chancellor's remarks were "not the most apposite example which he could have chosen". This statement was later withdrawn.

"There was no new evidence produced to explain this change of mind," said St Aubyn. "The only logical explanation is that the Labour Party brought undue influence to bear on its committee members."

The committee's chair, Barry Sheerman, MP for Huddersfield, said he had worked "very hard" to make all the MPs agree on the report, and regretted the Liberal Democrat and Tory attempts to hijack the report for "party political purposes".

"This is about so much more than Gordon Brown and two elite universities; there are more than 100 excellent universities in the country", he added. "This is the first major inquiry into higher education in 25 years". He urged government ministers to take seriously the recommendations, which include extra financial incentives for universities which accept students from poor areas and 'first generation' entrants. "If the Government doesn't accept this then I'll kick the hell out of them", he said. "and I'll be kicking down the chancellor's door because we need more money".

A related report on student retention, or drop-out rates, will be published separately next month.

webTitle: Tourism is bad for our health

fields.headline: Tourism is bad for our health
fields.standfirst: Travellers looking for guilt-free trips should be aware that there's no easy solution, argues Guardian Unlimited's Environment Editor, Joanna Griffiths
fields.trailText: Travellers looking for guilt-free trips should be aware that there's no easy solution, argues Guardian Unlimited's Environment Editor, Joanna Griffiths
fields.body:
More than 500m people travel for leisure each year. Our mass migrations wreak havoc on the environment. Among the most severe environmental effects of international travel are the carbon emissions belched from aeroplanes at high altitudes, which contribute directly to global warming. At ground level, logging of forests and mining of coral reefs for materials to build resorts have devastated wildlife; the development of beach fronts has led to the disappearance of wetlands; safari trails have interfered with hunting habits and the availability of quarry; and the boom development of popular tourist cities has increased urban pollution. From the Polar regions to Yellowstone National Park to the Lake District, tourism has supplied vast quantities of litter and debris, adversely affecting wildlife and polluting landscapes.

Is there an alternative? Eco-tourism's commercial practitioners claim that is what they offer. They work with local people to conserve fragile ecosystems, support endangered species and habitats, preserve indigenous cultures and develop sustainable local economies.

But the basic notion behind eco-tourism is a pragmatic one - where there's a public will, there's a market. Many travellers would rather their trip abroad had a minimal effect on the environment and culture of the country they're visiting, and the past two decades have seen a substantial expansion in eco-tourism.

Next year is to be the International Year of Eco-tourism, and in May 2002 Quebec will host an international Summit meeting, convened by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and the World Tourism Organisation (WTO). David de Villiers, Deputy Secretary General of the WTO, believes that, "sustainable development is the only way forward to guarantee the long-term viability of tourism businesses."

Travel operators offering eco-friendly holidays aim not only to reduce the ill effects of tourism (eg by booking with hotels that recycle waste and use environmentally-friendly utility systems, and minimising use of damaging forms of transport), but also they aim to "respect the indigenous" - accept the locals' right to privacy and respect their local customs and their very difference.

These are all commendable aims. The trouble starts when eco-tour operators - profit-making companies as they are - suggest that their particular brand of 'cleaned up and enlightened' tourism can positively enhance the regions it alights upon. This leads to a high moral tone, an implied suggestion that by wandering around the Galapagos Islands on an eco-tour the tourist is performing an equal good to a summer's worth of sweaty conservation work. Organisations such as the National Audubon Society, a US eco-tourism group, argue that tourism can be a "powerful tool favoring environmental conservation," by "enhancing public awareness of environmentally sensitive areas." Conservation International, a "private, non-profit organisation" suggests that eco-tourism can be "both an effective conservation tool and a successful community development model."

But tourism is, essentially and inescapably, environmentally destructive. An Oxford-based ecological 'footprinting' company, Best Foot Forward, points out that a return flight from London to Brazil uses 2,391kg of carbon. This means in this one trip a traveller uses twice the average annual carbon emissions of an average African (1,200kg), and half the average annual carbon emissions per person globally (4,000kg). An average Briton, who takes one or two trips abroad, emits 9,000kgs of carbon a year. If everyone in the world emitted this much carbon, we would need two and a half planets to support us all.

The impacts of global warming have been and will continue to be worst felt in poor, developing regions, through increased incidents of drought, flooding and freak weather. Any short-term 'development' of these countries through tourism must be set against the catastrophic effects already seen and still anticipated from global warming.

There is no such thing, in real terms, as eco-tourism. If we travel, we should do so in the knowledge that our tourism brings with it environmental damage. We travel for our enjoyment, because we can, because it is increasingly cheap to do so. We should not delude ourselves that are performing an altruistic social service.

webTitle: Nearly half of all secondaries to specialise

fields.headline: Nearly half of all secondaries to specialise
fields.standfirst: Specialist schools
fields.trailText: The number of specialist secondary schools will double in the next five years, Tony Blair promised today, in a speech setting out a radical reworking of comprehensive education.
fields.body:
The number of specialist secondary schools will double in the next five years, Tony Blair promised today, in a speech setting out a radical reworking of comprehensive education.

The Prime Minister revealed that by 2006 about 46% of schools would have specialist status, with a new emphasis on science, engineering, and business and enterprise. Like the existing technology, languages, sports and arts colleges, they will receive extra funding and will be able to select 10% of their pupils by aptitude.

"We are going, within five years, to more than double the number of specialist schools to 1,500," Mr Blair announced. "The business and enterprise schools will develop strong business and entrepreneurial links and encourage many more pupils into business and industry."

Meanwhile, the National Curriculum for 14-15 year olds will be "freed up" to enable schools to devote more time to their specialisms.

The general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, Doug McAvoy, said the plan "could not be achieved under current circumstances." He added that all comprehensive schools needed "proper funding".

Education secretary David Blunkett praised the record of existing specialist schools. "GCSE results show pupils at specialist schools excelling in their academic work." he said. "Three out of the top five in the list of one hundred most improved schools are specialist schools."

The government hopes to open the first wave of engineering, science and business schools in September 2002. Any school wishing to apply must raise £50,000 in sponsorship prepare four-year development plans with measurable targets in teaching and learning in the specialist subject area, and make provision to involve other schools and the wider community. Successful applicants receive a grant of £100,000 and £123 per pupil per year (for the first 1000 pupils), initially for four years.

Mr Blunkett said that the engineering colleges were likely to prove popular in areas where where engineering is a major employer. The business colleges, he claimed, would encourage local businesses to "help pupils to learn about the world of work, offer enhanced work experience opportunities and help bring business acumen to school management. "

John Dunford of the Secondary Heads' Association described the announcement as "welcome", but said he regretted the government had not included humanities and the community as two of the new categories.

fields.bodyText: The number of specialist secondary schools will double in the next five years, Tony Blair promised today, in a speech setting out a radical reworking of comprehensive education. The Prime Minister revealed that by 2006 about 46% of schools would have specialist status, with a new emphasis on science, engineering, and business and enterprise. Like the existing technology, languages, sports and arts colleges, they will receive extra funding and will be able to select 10% of their pupils by aptitude. "We are going, within five years, to more than double the number of specialist schools to 1,500," Mr Blair announced. "The business and enterprise schools will develop strong business and entrepreneurial links and encourage many more pupils into business and industry." Meanwhile, the National Curriculum for 14-15 year olds will be "freed up" to enable schools to devote more time to their specialisms. webTitle: In brief: Hannibal too violent for Australian critic

fields.headline: Hannibal too violent for Australian critic
fields.standfirst: Plus: John Cusack to star in film about Hitler's youthful artistic ambitions; Coronation Street star moves to big screen for Ridley Scott military mission
fields.trailText: Plus: John Cusack to star in film about Hitler's youthful artistic ambitions; Coronation Street star moves to big screen for Ridley Scott military mission
fields.body:
 Hannibal is causing a censorship row in Australia before it is even released. The sequel to The Silence of the Lambs starring Anthony Hopkins and Julianne Moore was awarded an MA (Mature Accompanied) rating by the Australian Office of Film and Literature Classification which will allow children under 15 to view the film with an adult. However, one of Australia's most prominent film critics, Lynden Barber of the Sydney Morning Herald, has called for the film to be rated R (Restricted to Adults Only) after walking out of a preview screening of the film, unable to take the extreme violence. "I blinked in disbelief before walking out of the cinema," he said. "It's the first time in my career as a film writer that I have been literally unable to stomach a film." The Australian censorship board has defended its rating by saying that the violence in Hannibal was not gratuitous. "There is a theme of violence through the film, but most of that violence is not high impact and most of it is in fact not detailed," said Board director Des Clark. Hannibal is released in the UK on February 16 with an 18 certificate.

 John Cusack has signed up to star in a new film about a young Hitler and his Jewish art teacher. The High Fidelity star told Variety: "It was the best script I've read since Being John Malkovich." The film, called Hoffman, will focus on the art teacher's failure to encourage Hitler's artistic abilities which some people believe is one of the reasons that he turned to politics. The film will mark the directorial debut of Menno Meyjes who also wrote the script.

 Former Coronation Street actor Matthew Marsden has landed a role in Ridley Scott's new film, Black Hawk Down according to ananova. Ewan McGregor and Tom Sizemore have already been cast in the story of 100 elite American soldiers who are dropped into Somalia on a mission to capture two top lieutenants from a renegade warlord. The film is due out next year.

webTitle: Russians left out in the cold

fields.headline: Russians left out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Political opportunism and infrastructural neglect have left Siberians shivering during one of the coldest winters in decades. Ian Traynor reports
fields.trailText: 8 February: Political opportunism and infrastructural neglect have left Siberians shivering during one of the coldest winters in decades. Ian Traynor reports.
fields.body:
A fashionable doomsday scenario has been doing the rounds in Moscow for the past year as Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, struggles to impose an order of sorts on the legacy of chaos he inherited from Boris Yeltsin.

Despite television towers burning, submarines sinking, bombs in Moscow, war in the south, Russians were told they had not seen anything yet. Forget the millennium bug - look forward to the 2003 emergency. The "apocalypse ahead" punditry came from MPs, Kremlin officials, economists and sociologists.

Ordinary Russians could be forgiven for not wanting to get out of bed in the morning. For in 2003, they were told, various factors of economic, demographic and infrastructural decline would combine at critical mass to turn Russia into one big disaster zone.

Thus, exactly a year ago, Mikhail Delyagin, director of Moscow's Institute of Globalisation Problems, waxed profoundly pessimistic: ''Two negative effects will overlap in 2003. The first will be the peak of repayment on debts and the second, the depreciation of fixed assets, will reach a level beyond which lies the mass collapse of all life-support systems.

"The state has not stopped to ponder these problems yet. I don't see any acceptable prospects for Russia. We are heading for a liberal dictatorship, greater degradation of the population, the emigration of the healthy part of society and the inability to handle the 2003 crisis.''

Chilling stuff. But the long-suffering millions of Siberia and Russia's far east, shivering in the most severe winter for decades, could be forgiven for believing that 2003 has dawned two years early.

Temperatures in Siberia and the far east have dropped at times to lower than -60C (-76F) in recent weeks and temperatures of -40C (-40F) or -50C (-58F) have been common. But Russia's ramshackle and heavily corrupt electricity and energy sectors have failed to rise to the challenge, meaning that thousands of homes, factories and schools are going unheated in what is reckoned to be the worst winter since the second world war.

Protesters have been marching, blocking strategic roads around Vladivostok and complaining loudly while the politicians in Moscow and in the regions, and the managers of the electricity industry pass the buck and blame one another.

The world's biggest natural gas producer, its second biggest oil producer, a country that produces more coal than it consumes is this year unable to keep its citizens heated.

The problem is that the impact of years of neglect, corruption and lack of investment in the electricity infrastructure is coming home to roost and the system is breaking down. Anatoly Chubais, the free market zealot who heads the national electricity grid, is using the crisis to push for radical restructuring of the industry. Crooked regional leaders have been failing to lay in fuel supplies for the winter, siphoning off budget funds earmarked for electricity bills, then blaming Moscow for the suffering while diverting the money.

And the Kremlin seems to see the whole affair not so much as an energy crisis as a political opportunity. As a result, the Russian government suffered its first casualty under Mr Putin this week when Alexander Gavrin, the energy minister, was fired. But more significantly, the Kremlin also blackmailed the tyrannical far eastern governor, Yevgeniy Nazdratenko, into resigning.

From the start of the protests a couple of months ago, it was clear that Mr Putin would use the wretched state of affairs to make political capital. His regional envoy, Konstantin Pulikovsky, announced: ''This not an energy crisis, it's a crisis of political legitimacy.''

The Kremlin then started drawing up a dossier on the life and times of Mr Nazdratenko. Selective leaks began appearing in the press. Its full publication would have been unedifying. Then on the day Mr Nazdratenko was scheduled to make the long haul from Vladivostok to Moscow to discuss the crisis, he instead checked into hospital pleading heart trouble.

Mr Nazdratenko is notorious for his iron rule of the past seven years, regularly thumbing his nose at Moscow, snuffing out opposition locally, harassing the press and having his cronies take over local businesses. People opposing him have been bombed. Andrew Fox, a British honorary consul in the far east, fled the region 18 months ago after what he described as threats to his life from Mr Nazdratenko's clique unless he surrendered his stake in a local shipping company.

Now, at least for the time being, Mr Nazdratenko has gone and few will shed any tears for his passing. But he did not jump. He was pushed - by Mr Putin. Armed with its dossier, the Kremlin was threatening to launch a criminal investigation against Mr Nazdratenko unless he went. Conveniently, a new law has just come into force enabling Mr Putin to suspend any elected regional governor who is being investigated for criminal misdeeds.

Mr Chubais could be next in line as Mr Putin signalled when he also blamed the management of the electricity utility for the blackouts, though Moscow commentators expect his deputies rather than Mr Chubais himself to carry the can.

But if Mr Putin is winning his cold war, the people of the far east are still freezing.

webTitle: Administrators called in as Tigers face oblivion

fields.headline: Administrators called in as Tigers face oblivion
fields.standfirst: Investigations continue at club with £2m debt
fields.trailText: The future of league football in Hull, the seventh largest city in England, was thrown into doubt yesterday when the city's financially stricken football club called in the administrators.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso, John Cassy and Andy Wilson
fields.body:
The future of league football in Hull, the seventh largest city in England, was thrown into doubt yesterday when the city's financially stricken football club called in the administrators.

Kroll Buchler Phillips, a leading corporate recovery and financial restructuring group, was appointed administrator after the high court granted a 14-day stay of a winding up order brought by customs and excise and the inland revenue for payment of outstanding taxes of £500,000. The club's total debt is thought to be as much as £2m.

Yesterday's legal moves demonstrate the reality of life for lower league clubs whose hand to mouth existence is a world away from the glamour and wealth of the Premiership. Any white knight attempting to ride to the Tigers' rescue would need between £2m and £3m - less than David Beckham earns in a year - to guarantee the 97-year-old club's financial future.

The moves come a day after David Lloyd, the former chairman and still owner of the club's Boothferry Park ground, ordered bailiffs to lock out Hull's staff and players until he has been paid £45,000 in outstanding rent.

The players have not been paid for five weeks and, should they not receive their wages before the weekend, will be free to leave the club on Saturday. This would be a devastating blow - they are Hull City's only assets.

The club's collapse has been played out against a background of bitterness and recrimination and inquiries into the running of the club by Humberside police fraud squad, the Department of Trade and the Football Association.

In October 1998 Mr Lloyd sold the club, then no more than £100,000 in debt, to Sheffield businessman Nick Buchanan for £80,000, but retained ownership of Boothferry Park. Mr Buchanan resigned yesterday, saying: "I've fought and tried and fought and tried again to turn this club around but decided it's better if someone else has a go."

Today the club's total liability is thought to be almost £2m, run up in a 27-month period during which it has stayed rooted in the third divison and received more than £1m in transfer fees, grants and loans and a share of a TV deal. Mr Buchanan yesterday said the losses were a result of increased investment in players and higher wages.

Humberside police are investigating allegations of financial irregularities follow-ing a 15-month inquiry by the FA, begun after Mr Buchanan took control. Areas the police are looking at are understood to include:

 The purchase of an £80,000 coach shortly after a loan from the players union, the PFA, towards wages was received.

 Accounts purporting to show continuing payments to a former employee who left the club three years ago. He has been interviewed by the police and yesterday said he had not received any money since he left Hull City.

 Allegations of impropriety in the administration of the club's youth development fund which was supported by Sport England and the FA. In 1998 and 1999 the two bodies paid a total of £276,000 into the fund, but withheld a further £138,000 in April last year following the FA investigation.

 A dispute over an unpaid bill of £6,000 at Mr Chu's Chinese restaurant, a favourite of local MP John Prescott.

The club is counter-suing the restaurant alleging non-payment of bills for advertising hoardings.

Mr Buchanan said he was aware of the police inquiry and insisted he was not its focus. "I have absolutely nothing to hide," he said.

He said he was the victim of a "vendetta" by a former director and that an investigation by accountants Deloitte & Touche had found nothing untoward.

Mr Buchanan said the purchase of the coach had been cleared by the board, denied any impropriety with the youth fund and said he was not aware of unusual payments being made.

"I've put an awful lot of money into this club, taken nothing out and received a bucket load of heartache in return," he said.

Hull is the largest city in England never to have boasted a top-flight football team, and uncertainty over the future is holding back ambitious plans by the local authority, among the richest in the country thanks to the multi-million pound windfall from the privatisation of Kingston Communications.

The council wants to build a £343m, 25,000-seater stadium which the Tigers would share with Hull rugby league club which competes in the Super League.

John Topliss, of Kingston-upon-Hull council, said: "What's happening with the football club places it [the stadium] in jeopardy, certainly."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: United feeling the Minchery pinch
fields.standfirst: More than ever, Oxford desperately need to move to their new stadium, argues Rage On
fields.trailText: More than ever, Oxford desperately need to move to their new stadium.
fields.body:
The latest developments at and around the Manor have once more called into question the future of Oxford United, just when the club needs stability more than ever. The successful application by the owner of land adjacent to our half-built new stadium at Minchery Farm to seek a judicial review into the granting of planning permission for the site's multiplex cinema may in itself just be a storm in a teacup. But it is whether or not this leads to any delays in the stadium construction that is the cause for concern. This presumably depends on whether or not chairman Firoz Kassam is advised on how good a case land-owner Les Wells has, and whether or not he is prepared to take a risk.

Throughout Kassam's involvement with the club he has been advised by Oxford City Council officers that Wells was not a serious threat to the stadium and that he had no case. However, Council advice has been shown to be flawed in the past and Kassam must by now be very wary of listening to their promises. Now stadium builders Birse are on a very tight timetable to get the ground ready for next season and any delays could lead to the deadline being missed.

Should Kassam feel that he has no choice but to halt construction until he knows the outcome of a judicial review then United's future is, once again, in jeopardy. With United unlikely to receive another dispensation from the FLA to play at the Manor next season, there don't appear to be any options available for a league-standard venue to play at. Also, given the history of the development, one has to wonder whether or not Birse would consider returning to site once they had left.

As if all this wasn't enough, Kassam had to suffer the added distraction of Joe Kinnear's departure. No-one could blame Kinnear for leaving if, as he claimed, his health and family life were suffering due to his continued involvement with the club. But as he has just become manager of Luton Town, then the man's integrity is blown away. Kinnear may not be football's most pleasant character but he is well respected throughout the game and his presence at the Manor undoubtedly led to the arrivals of Phil Gray, Andy Scott and Robert Quinn as well as the various loan deals that have occurred since he came. It also gave United a higher profile than they would have otherwise have had considering their league position.

If, as has been rumoured, Kinnear were to take David Kemp and Alan McLeary with him to Kenilworth Road, this could prove to be a mixed blessing to United. Kemp has certainly failed to endear himself to United fans, mainly due to his continued omission of Dean Whitehead and his preference for Neil Cutler over Richard Knight, and the continuing run of poor results since he took over hasn't helped. The real concern is who would replace Kemp if he were to jump ship (analogies with rats purely coincidental).

Denis Smith has lost all credibility amongst Oxford supporters (and Firoz Kassam too, allegedly) whilst Mike Ford failed to impress during his brief interim spell in charge (although the players at least showed more motivation). Many fans preferred option, Steve Cotterill, has already turned United down (twice) and, given the U's league position, there can't be many suicidal potential bosses out there ready to chance their arms, and their careers, on what is effectively a lost cause.

Rage Online would like to see a unique socialist experiment and have the team managed by a players collective. That way, when things go inevitably wrong, they could all blame each other equally, they could all share in determining tactics and they could all determine team selection democratically, by drawing names at random from a hat. This could be a wonderful opportunity to change the face of football forever and, if nothing else, it would make it almost impossible for the crowd to chant for the "Manager Out!".

That way, when things go inevitably wrong, they could all blame each other equally, they could all share in determining tactics and they could all determine team selection democratically, by drawing names at random from a hat. This could be a wonderful opportunity to change the face of football forever and, if nothing else, it would make it almost impossible for the crowd to chant for the "Manager Out!".

webTitle: Sharon halts peace process in wake of blast

fields.headline: Sharon halts peace process in wake of blast
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, has responded to a suspected car bomb explosion in west Jerusalem today by pledging that he will not resume peace talks until the violence ends.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, has responded to a suspected car bomb explosion in west Jerusalem today by pledging that he will not resume peace talks until the violence ends.

No one was seriously hurt in the blast which took place at 4:40pm local time (2.40pm GMT) in an ultra-orthodox Jewish neighbourhood.

Only hours before the blast, Mr Sharon angered Palestinians by refusing to resume peace talks where they left off with the outgoing administration of Ehud Barak.

He said: "I will try to advance the peace process, but that depends on an absolute halt to violence. The peace negotiations are important, and the government will do everything to that end, but terrorism and violence must cease."

No one has claimed responsibility for the attack, but police said a motorcycle patrol arrested two men who were fleeing the area on foot. Police added that because the car caught fire before exploding, they could not rule out the possibility that the blast was caused by mechanical problems with the vehicle.

Shimon Hagai, a witness, said parts of the car flew up to the height of about four stories. He said the explosions were 20 seconds apart and clouds of smoke rose high into the air.

The violence follows the election yesterday of veteran rightwinger Mr Sharon, who sparked four months of bloody clashes with the Palestinians when he visited a Muslim holy site in Jerusalem in September.

Mr Barak blamed Palestinians for today's alleged attack, and said the explosion was a strong message to the new government about the future of the peace process.

Mr Sharon further provoked Palestinian anger when he said earlier today that he would not honour agreements reached between Mr Barak's administration and Palestinian negotiators. Mr Barak had drawn near to an agreement with Palestinian representatives although no final accord had been signed when talks broke off just before the election.

Mr Barak had put the partitioning of Jerusalem on the table, an unprecedented step. Mr Sharon has said he will not consider a peace deal that divides Jerusalem.

Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erakat, echoing the views of the Palestinian leadership following a meeting late yesterday, said if Mr Sharon wants to resume the peace process it must be from where it was suspended by Mr Barak.

"There is no turning back, as Sharon would like to," he said.

webTitle: Video panel bans Vieira for one game

fields.headline: Video panel bans Vieira for one game
fields.trailText: Patrick Vieira has been banned for one match and fined £10,000 after an FA video disciplinary panel found him guilty of kicking Leeds midfielder Olivier Dacourt in the face.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira has been banned for one match and fined £10,000 after an FA video disciplinary panel found him guilty of kicking Leeds midfielder Olivier Dacourt in the face.

Vieira had not been booked for the incident during Arsenal's Premiership match at Leeds in November. But TV coverage showing Vieira flicking a leg under Dacourt's chin (as well as going head-to-head with Eirik Bakke) compelled the FA to refer the matter to their video panel.

"The first charge, that he head-butted Eirik Bakke, was dismissed. The panel decided that the second charge, of kicking Olivier Dacourt, was proved," FA head of communications Paul Newman said today.

"The commission ruled that Patrick Vieira should be suspended for one match with immediate effect and be fined £10,000. He will also have to pay the costs of the hearing. In making their finding the panel noted Patrick Vieira's improved disciplinary record."

Vieira will miss Saturday's home game with Ipswich as a result of this afternoon's judgement.

fields.headline: Buy, Bye, and Ban
fields.trailText: HOW TO ARRANGE A TRANSFER, THE JOHN HARTSON WAY (PT IV)
fields.body:
HOW TO ARRANGE A TRANSFER, THE JOHN HARTSON WAY (PT IV)

1. Think about how £5m transfer from Wimbledon to Coventry was called off for good last weekend. Embrace depression as a way of life. Note moisture running down face, as well as black clouds gathering around head.

2. Stop drooling and throw wet blanket over chip pan. Mmm, chips. Decide things aren't that bad and jump joyously in the air.

3. Clamber out of massive new crater in kitchen floor just in time to hear exciting news. "We can confirm that the John Hartson deal has been completed and are delighted that he is finally joining us," says Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson. "We have agreed terms which are private between both parties," he continues, suggesting Wimbledon will be paid on a cash-saving pay-for-play basis.

4. Listen proudly as a happy Richardson waxes lyrical. "We have been creating many chances in recent weeks and not converting them and hopefully John Hartson can rectify that situation," he says. "I also think that Craig Bellamy will benefit from having John Hartson alongside him." This Bellamy looks very small, though, roughly the size of a super-deluxe shish.

5. Meet other new team-mate Cedric Roussel. "I was the one who stopped him coming here because I wanted to remain in the Premiership. The fans have been great to me since but it's good things are sorted out." Roussel Roussel are you hiding a bag of crisps?

6. Wait patiently in foyer for press conference to be called. Mmm, crudités.

7. No time for press conference! Must go straight to training! Wah! What manner of hellhole is this?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HA HA HA, LET'S ALL LAUGH AT KUDDLY

There is something about Kuddly Ken Bates that's really quite laughable. It can't be the beard, nor the huge sunglasses that must have been designed for a woman. It can't be his habit for wearing fur coats, or for tacking on high-quality shopping facilities to anything bigger than a shed (although we'd also like to see his shed). No, it's Kuddly's inability to keep his size-13 gob shut that makes the Fiver giggle. And, after resigning in high dudgeon from the board of Wembley National Stadium Limited today, he's gone and done it again.

"I acquired Wembley for the FA and made a substantial operating profit ... despite having inherited a lacklustre leaderless management," said Kuddly in his resignation letter (which is available to buy in three volumes). "But a sustained press campaign undermined both the project itself and my own credibility." With who exactly? "We [ie: Kuddly and his many friends] know a considerable part of it came from Kate Hoey and her lackeys. But it is also clear that a lot came from within the FA itself. It was quite disgraceful that not one single person on either board stood up to publicly defend the project and my position. Even Jesus Christ suffered only one Pontius Pilate - I had a whole team of them."

Thanks to Ken's latest word-spew, we now know that (a) he's tougher than Jesus, and (b) the Wembley debacle has absolutely nothing to do with the former WNSL chairman. What's more, if it hadn't been for a shadowy conspiracy involving the Labour party, the FA, Chase Manhattan Bank and everybody else in the world, he would still be in charge today, crafting a beautiful structure out of glass and steel (and then tacking some shops on the end). The FA this afternoon released a statement that thanked Ken for his efforts. "While today's letter contains some inaccuracies," the statement said, "they in no way detract from the contribution he has made." Which could be read in a variety of different ways, really.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Nobody knows more than I, Robbie and his agent, how supportive, patient and indulgent I have been with him because I like Robbie as a man. He has had to work to get where he is, and he's an honest guy. If I write a book one day I will stress that" - Who will Gerard Houllier be sending a Valentine's card to next week, do you think?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TOAST-MAN PAT

"Hi, I'm Patrick Vieira. And I'm here to talk to you about anger. For some of you guys out there, you may think that anger is cool, that smashing a glass into your friend's face after 20 bottles of vodka and petrol is in some way trendy. Hey, I know how you feel, I used to think that way on a football field. But I've learned my lesson. I know anger is wrong. And I also know that if Olivier Dacourt doesn't get his big nosey face out of mine, he's going to taste some boot!"

Pat's abortive commercial for the Anger and Rage Sensitivity Exhibition (ARSE) popped into the Fiver's mind this afternoon when the FA gave the Arsenal enforcer another one-match ban to add to his collection. It came courtesy of the video disciplinary committee who, after watching Sky's slo-mo repeats of Pat kicking Olivier Dacourt in the chin during Arsenal's Premiership match with Leeds last November, decided that he had kicked Olivier Dacourt in the chin.

"The commission ruled that Patrick Vieira should be suspended for one match with immediate effect and be fined £10,000. He will also have to pay the costs of the hearing," said the panel of an event that Pat wasn't booked for at the time, and one referee Dermot Gallagher has subsequently said was no worse than most challenges in the Premiership.

But it wasn't all bad news. Pat also got off a charge of headbutting Eirik Bakke, and his recent record of only one yellow card in 25 matches also went down well. "In making their finding the panel noted Patrick Vieira's improved disciplinary record," was the official verdict, which must surely send a message to the kids. Something like: if you're on telly, don't kick people on the chin, in fact.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Brescia defender Daniel Bonera is a target for both Arsenal and Tottenham, according to Planet Football. Juventus, Lazio and Roma are also keeping tabs on the highly rated 19-year-old.

Manchester United are willing to let reserve midfielder Steve Cosgrove join Ipswich for nothing, providing there is a sell-on clause in the 21-year-old Scot's contract.

Colombian international Mario Yepes will join either Aston Villa or West Ham for £9.6m in the near future, according to press speculation in Argentina. But Planet Football reports that River Plate president David Pintado has denied the stories.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Administrators acting for Hull are confident Saturday's league game against Leyton Orient will take place at Boothferry Park. This follows negotiations with stadium owner David Lloyd who, earlier this week, instructed bailiffs to change the locks at the ground until he received around £45,000 in unpaid rent. But today administrators Kroll Buchler Phillips believed a deal had been struck with Lloyd's representatives. "The deal has been agreed in principle and we are expecting to be given the keys to Boothferry Park early this afternoon," a spokesperson said.

Joe Kinnear has confirmed himself as the new manager of Luton Town, replacing Lil Fuccillo. "I'm the manager, full stop," said Kinnear, who was yesterday unveiled as the club's Director of Football. "I'm in charge of anything to do with football." Fuccillo's position is now in doubt, although he will help pick the side for the trip to Northampton on Saturday.

Blackburn today completed the signing of Celtic midfielder Eyal Berkovic on loan until the end of the season. The 28-year-old Israeli international could make his debut at Nottingham Forest.

The SFA today confirmed that Lubo Moravcik of Celtic and Claudio Reyna and Michael Mols of Rangers will all miss Sunday's Old Firm derby after their dismissals during last night's stormy CIS Cup semi-final. They also confirmed that both Jackie McNamara and Alan Thompson - both booked - would now miss Celtic's CIS Insurance Cup final appearance on March 12.

Norwich captain Matt Jackson has handed in a transfer request. Contract negotiations have dragged on for ten months but have now broken down completely. Manager Nigel Worthington said: "We are very disappointed that we couldn't sort out a deal with Matt. He will continue to play for and captain the club until the matter is resolved one way or the other."

England manager Sven-Goran Eriksson will be a guest at the Worthington Cup final between Liverpool and Birmingham at Cardiff's Millennium Stadium on February 25.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.20am) "Hello, you're through to the customer services department of the TV and Radio section. Can I have your customer reference number, please?" Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.30am) "I'm afraid I don't have it to hand. Is it possible to search for my details by name?"

Dutch Football (1am) "No, I'm afraid we cannot search by name."

Argentine Football (2.30am) "You can't search by name?"

Brazilian International Football (4am) "For security reasons we cannot reveal our customers names."

Footy Shorts (5.05am) "But you won't be revealing it. I know my own name."

Sky Sports 1: Non League Football Show (7pm, 12.30am) "For security reasons we cannot reveal our customers names."

Fifa TV (7.30pm, 1am) "Gah! Well, can you search on my address?"

Spanish Football (8pm, 1.30am) "Yes, of course."

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3.30am) "Wonderful. It's 27, The Road, Town."

Australian Soccer League (11pm) "I'm afraid there's no such address in our system, sir."

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 12midnight SS1) "But there must be because you've managed to send me this exorbitant bill! It's the reason I'm phoning up to complain."

Sky Sports 3: Football Gold (10pm) "You couldn't possibly have a bill, sir. I'm afraid you must be mistaken."

British Eurosport: World Cup Football (8pm) "What on earth do you mean? I've got it here in my hand!"

Football (10.15pm) "I can't find you on our system, so it won't be from us."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) "Look, this is ridiculous! I can see it with my own eyes"

Talksport: Football First - Club 1931 with John Kearns (7pm) "I don't have to listen to filthy language like that, sir. I'm afraid I'm going to have to cut you off. You have been charged for this call at our premium rate."

fields.headline: Powell condemns US sanctions
fields.standfirst: The secretary of state, Colin Powell, says foreign sanctions are giving the US a bad name. Is this a new beginning for embargoed nations or is it all about big business? asks Simon Tisdall.
fields.trailText: The secretary of state, Colin Powell, says foreign sanctions are giving the US a bad name. Is this a new beginning for embargoed nations or is it all about big business? asks Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
When the United States disapproves of a foreign government's actions, policies or ideology, it usually pursues one of three options. It bombs, it punishes, or it persuades. Sometimes it does all three together.

Since America's military, economic and diplomatic might is unrivalled, its friends and allies tend, on the whole, to go along with its chosen course of action while America's foes tend to keep out of the way.

Concerted American armed action of the kind seen in Iraq and Serbia is relatively rare and is usually embarked upon as a last resort. If persuasion fails and coercion of a foreign power or dictator is required, the much more usual, preferred tool is punishment by economic and diplomatic means - in other words, sanctions.

Both the US presidency and the US Congress have given themselves sweeping powers to impose sanctions on foreigners who offend America's ideas of what is proper. These measures range from unilateral bans on selected exports or restrictions on entry into the US of "undesirable" individuals to full-scale trade, travel, investment and diplomatic embargoes.

In such latter cases, the US will routinely ask the UN Security Council to endorse its actions, ensuring that other UN members follow its lead. Thanks to its enormous clout and its veto power, it usually gets its way.

Iraq is the most notorious victim of all-out US-led punitive sanctions (even though the measures have been softened in recent years). Although most countries in the UN General Assembly no longer support the sanctions regime as applied to Baghdad, it remains in place regardless.

In other words, in the post-Cold War period when the US finally attained unmatched global superpower status, it did not relax. Far from it. It began to throw its weight around to a greater degree than ever before.

With the Soviet Union vanquished, Europe weak and divided, and China still far from representing a real challenge, the US apparently decided, almost subconsciously, to start running the world its own way - and was quick to use sanctions to punish those who disagreed or upset its plans.

Oddly enough, during this same period there was a rising chorus of complaint within America that it was being expected to do too much. This gave rise to, or was the product of a new unilateralist or neo-isolationist mood. In fact, there is no contradiction. Sanctions were seen as a handy, hands-off way of controlling other people's behaviour without getting directly involved in solving the problem.

The figures on sanctions, provided by US business lobby groups, also form the context for one of the more unexpected initiatives of the new Bush administration. When Colin Powell visited the Senate last month for hearings on his nomination as secretary of state, one of the issues he raised was sanctions.

There were too many of them, he said, they often did not work, and what was more, they gave America a bad name. The repeated use of sanctions as a foreign policy weapon "shows a degree of American hubris and arrogance that may not serve our interests all that well."

Mr Powell, formerly of the Pentagon, is not one to shirk military action if it is deemed unavoidable. Yet he is also known vastly to prefer persuasion and negotiated solutions if at all possible. So what he appears to have been telling Congress is that the middle option for achieving US objectives - punishment and coercion - has been overdone in the past and must be used much more sparingly in future.

Does this presage a new dawn of enlightenment, a new beginning for the embargoed and sanctioned citizenry and governments of Havana, Delhi, Damascus, Tehran, Kabul, Beijing and elsewhere? That is far from clear.

The ending of destructive and outdated US measures targeted at Fidel Castro's Cuba, for example, is long overdue. But that is probably politically impossible for a Republican administration. Moves to end the sanctions imposed on India in 1998 over its nuclear tests, on the other hand, now look quite likely.

Mr Powell has been explicit about two cases: Iraq and Libya. Here the sanctions would remain.

What he has been not quite so forthcoming about is the slightly less noble Republican motivation, fuelled by powerful business interests, to curtail sanctions that hurt US business and trade.

One lobby group estimates that the US may lose up to $19bn a year in exports as a result of its own sanctions. Before he became vice-president, for example, Dick Cheney's Texas oil company lobbied hard for an end to curbs on doing business in Iran. Companies linked to that run by Mr Cheney also did work in Libya and Iraq, despite the sanctions.

It is clear that behind Mr Powell's wish to use sanctions more intelligently and sparingly and his concerns about America's reputation abroad, lie some very hard-headed and pragmatic calculations about money.

And there is another consideration that gives pause. Sanctions are not always bad and they do sometimes work: the example of South Africa during the apartheid era is often given. And it will be remembered that many big businesses, including some British banks, fervently opposed them.

The recently imposed UN curbs on the West African war-stoking trade in "blood diamonds" provide another example of sanctions that are morally desirable and will, hopefully, work. Many feel, on the other hand, that Russian abuses of human rights in Chechnya should be the subject of international sanctions. That they are not is due in part to the US refusal to act.

Having led the way in using sanctions to punish international bad behaviour when it suited its purposes, the US now seems to be in danger of swinging too far in the other direction, again for self-interested reasons.

Who knows? One day they might get it right.

webTitle: Dave Hill on the death of the condom culture

fields.headline: Haven't you forgotten something?
fields.standfirst: A surge in Aids and sexually transmitted infections suggests unprotected sex is back in fashion.  Dave Hill  on the death of condom culture
fields.trailText: A surge in Aids and sexually transmitted infections suggests unprotected sex is back in fashion. Dave Hill on the death of condom culture.
fields.body:
Where have all the rubbers gone? The question, unconnected with the provision of classroom equipment, might seem unnecessary. Long past are the days when purchasing prophylactics involved pharmacists reaching furtively under counters or coded barbershop exchanges about "something for the weekend".

Today, condoms are everywhere. You're waiting for your piles prescription and a rank of gleaming boxes speaks of ribbed shafts, fruit flavours and "Xtra Pleasure for Him and Her". You're in the supermarket perusing frozen peas, knowing that a phalanx of French letters is just an aisle or two away.

But does this brazen visibility, now established so thoroughly, necessarily mean that the condom is doing the good work for which it emerged from the shadows in the first place? The joint may be jumping with johnnies, but what effect has that had on the perils they are designed to prevent? Does the condom culture, so central to the promotion of safe sex, have quite the force it did when it emerged in the early 80s in response to Aids?

The signs are not encouraging. For example, if the new ubiquity of the everyman of contraception has had a limiting effect on rates of teenage pregnancies it hasn't been enough to knock the UK off the top of the European league. Moreover, the latest data on HIV infection and other sexually transmitted infections [STIs] make it tempting to conclude that condom use is going radically out of style. Figures from the public health laboratory service (PHLS) for last year showed 2,868 new HIV diagnoses, with more likely to be added as information continues coming in. This represents a 7% rise on 1999 - which was itself a 10-year high. Other STIs are also being diagnosed in larger numbers. At the end of last year the PHLS also reported big rises since 1995 in diagnoses of genital warts (up 20%), syphilis (up 54%), gonorrhoea (up 55%) and, most spectacularly, genital chlamydia (up 76%).

This data should be handled with appropriate care. Chlamydia was almost unknown to the general public until a few years ago, but has been vigorously targeted by providers of sexual health services and information - hence the huge rise in its diagnosis figure may partly reflect increased amounts of testing.

Similarly, many of the new HIV diagnoses have been of people who were infected some years ago but have only recently come forward for testing, perhaps encouraged in some cases by the emergence of drug treatments which slow the development of the virus. None the less the PHLS view is that "the rises in acute STIs are likely to be associated with increasing unsafe sexual behaviour particularly among young heterosexuals and gay men".

The basic prevention message remains the same: use a condom. So why does rejection of them appear to be strengthening, especially among certain social groups?

Again, there is a need for circumspection. For example, Will Nutland, a health promotion manager at Terrence Higgins Trust Lighthouse, cites research showing that while there is some evidence that gay men are having more unprotected analintercourse, there is also evidence that many of those who do so are aware of their own and their sexual partners' HIV status and proceeding accordingly: if both partners are HIV positive, a condom becomes redundant, as it does if both are free from the virus.

But while this shows that the connection between condom use and the incidence of infection is not straightforward in all respects, no one doubts that the safe sex message in general is at least as important as ever, or that the virtues of the condom must remain integral to it. As Nutland points out, one effect of more successful HIV treatment has been to enlarge the pool of people surviving with the virus and therefore representing a possible source of infection. And Gwenda Hughes, a senior scientist at the communicable disease surveillance centre in Colindale, stresses that the increased diagnoses of syphilis and gonorrhoea seem very directly connected to unsafe sex practices. Hughes also emphasises the invisibility of chlamydia - "70% of cases show no symptoms" - and the very serious consequences it can have for women: infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain.

As ever, it is the young who are at the greatest risk from STIs, especially girls and young women in their late teens, and men in their early to mid-20s. So how can the young be taught to love the condom more? It may not be easy. Nutland is frank in saying that those brave 80s efforts to promote condoms as sexy were doomed to have a limited effect: "In the real world most people just don't think they're sexy at all." From another perspective Greg Falola, a Merseyside youth worker specialising in male sexual health and behaviour, says that a lot of those he works with are put off by the bog-standard models they can get for free, and put off by the price of more exotic varieties: "It means they never get to use a condom that they like."

Behind such practical realities lies a deeper problem too: the connections between certain styles of heterosexual masculinity, social disadvantage and the allure of risk. In one of his projects Falola asked a group of Wirral lads to tell him the things that make a man manly. They listed big money, a big car, and getting lots of notches on their bedposts. Of these, only the last is ever likely to be theirs. As Falola observes: "To them being manly means being big and brave and taking risks. It isn't hard to see how that kind of thinking transfers into their attitudes to condoms and safe sex."

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: David Munk's marathon training
fields.body:
It's called the wall, and is the marathon runner's equivalent of a full stop; a deadening, exhausting, tearful full stop in the middle of a road somewhere between a few yards and 26.2 miles from the finish. Mention it to any long-distance runner and a flicker of fear crosses their face; it's the idea that they can go no further. For the amateur, the occasional jogger, it is mythical; something you are told you are going to hit sometime, someday, but you are never quite sure when.

The wall is when you have run out of steam - when there's nothing left in the tank. People who experience it talk of happily running along with a feeling of energy and ease, maybe mulling over their next visit to a cheese shop, and then the batteries suddenly go flat. The muscles don't have the food to carry on.

My personal training adviser James mentions the wall with some reverence. "You need to respect your body and what its needs are," he says. The best way to avoid that full stop is to ensure your carbohydrate intake is up to scratch. Carbohydrates can come in many forms - potatoes and rice, biscuits and sweet things - and they supply your muscles with glycogen, the fuel they need. But you are unlikely to be pushing a shopping trolley full of nibbles on a marathon, so something else will have to do.

One option is to buy an expensive isotonic drink. You have a sickly sweet orange taste and the knowledge that top athletes across the world swear by it. Alternatively, says James, knock back a shot of olive oil and then swig away on your prepared pack of one-third fruit juice to two-thirds water, seasoned with just a pinch of salt. Like the isotonic drink, the homemade mixture replicates the salt-to-sugar mixture of the blood, enabling the speedy diffusion of those essential energy boosters into the blood stream.

Swigging on one bottle won't do. The trick is to maintain the existing carbohydrate level in the body throughout your run. On a 90-minute one, you should think about taking in around 1.5 litres of fluid. On longer runs you are, naturally, confronted with another problem in the toilet area. More about that later, though.

webTitle: James Meikle on haemophiliacs and infected blood

fields.headline: A safer alternative?
fields.standfirst: Infected blood has ruined the lives of many haemophiliacs. So why are they denied the safe, synthetic alternative?
fields.trailText: Infected blood has ruined the lives of many haemophiliacs. So why are they denied the safe, synthetic alternative?
fields.body:
The NHS has accidentally infected 4,800 British haemophiliacs with the hepatitis C virus. Of these, 1,200 have also been infected with HIV; a third of them remain alive. Now there is a theoretical risk that the NHS has infected some of these people with the human form of BSE, the fatal variant CJD.

No wonder many haemophiliacs are angry. As many as 5,000 people in Britain need a "clotting factor" (made from blood plasma) to treat the painful, excessive bleeding that swells their muscles as a result of haemophilia. Imagine finding out that these products were made from contaminated blood.

And it is no wonder adult haemophiliacs in England are demanding the same "safer" synthetic alternative (known as recombinant) that is on offer to child sufferers throughout Britain, and to older patients in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. You might think any government, having seen the effects of two previous mistakes involving tainted blood supplies, would be keen to cough up the extra cash for such treatment.

But not a bit of it. Ministers, under pressure from the Haemophilia Society's campaign for recombinant and a public inquiry into the overall safety of blood products, appear more worried about the effect "sensationalist" press coverage would have in further distressing patients.

Decisions on providing recombinant should be made on clinical grounds, not on whether a fuss is made. Haemophilia doctors say recombinant should be on offer, although British-sourced products, which might carry vCJD infection from donors, were replaced by US plasma in 1998. Paul Giangrande, at the Churchill centre in Oxford, says this could cost an extra £23m a year.

He, like many other centre directors, is ignoring general NHS guidance not to tell patients they have been treated with products that included material donated by someone who went on to develop vCJD. The third warning of this type, relating to treatments given before the switch to US human product, was sent out by the blood service before Christmas. Dr Giangrande has informed 85 of his patients.

Three years ago, batches involving other vCJD patients had to be recalled. Then, some directors, including Dr Giangrande, told; some did not. Now the NHS is reviewing that don't-tell policy, implemented because vCJD cannot be detected before symptoms are evident. It is also untreatable and incurable. Some haemophiliacs are convinced they have been infected again, and some of the most militant sufferers believe they are acting the canaries in the coal mine in an experiment to see if vCJD can be transmitted through blood.

Reassurances from officials may have little impact. Sufferers know that the NHS, worried enough to have changed the source of most plasma and to have introduced other blood controls at a combined cost of £83m a year in England and North Wales, has been further alarmed by evidence from an experiment with sheep that showed BSE can be transmitted by transfusion. Now officials are considering whether anyone who has received a blood transfusion should be allowed to donate blood themselves.

It could be years before we know if there has been human transmission. The incubation period of vCJD is unknown, and the disease has been identified for less than five years. If most of the current 94 victims were infected by cheap meat products in the mid-80s, how much longer before we know the condition's eventual scale?

Thirteen victims so far have been blood donors, their donations transfused into 23 people, as well as going into blood products used by thousands at home and abroad. The government should be desperately seeking to shore up confidence in blood transfusion, but when it is gearing up to spend £200m on new hospital sterilisation measures, £30m on disposable instruments for tonsillectomies and, if necessary, a great deal more on changing other surgical procedures, can they blame haemophiliacs for thinking another £23m is small change?

 James Meikle is the Guardian's health correspondent. Sarah Boseley is away.
