fields.headline: Robo doc
fields.standfirst: Difficult, dangerous heart ops are now being done by robots.  James Meek  reports from the cutting edge of surgery
fields.trailText: Difficult, dangerous heart ops are now being done by robots. James Meek reports from the cutting edge of surgery.
fields.body:
Last October, David Lee, a retired engineer from Hampshire, went into the Royal Brompton Hospital for a heart bypass operation. It was a striking success. Normally bypass patients take six to eight weeks to recuperate: within a fortnight, the 63-year-old had resumed his regular three-mile morning walk.

It wasn't just Lee's rapid recovery that was exceptional. The surgeon in charge of the operation, Anthony De Souza, sat several feet away from him during the procedure. The arms that delved into the patient's body were not his. Instead, they were made of metal, and bolted to the table.

Lee was one of the first people in Britain to be operated on by a robot that is capable of carrying out the most delicate aspects of the surgeon's art in the confined space of the chest cavity, and with the minimum of damage to the chest itself.

The robots are expensive - around three-quarters of a million pounds each - and rare. There are just two in Britain, and only a few dozen in the whole world. But for heart bypass patients, they offer a huge advantage.

About 30,000 bypass operations take place in Britain each year, a number the government wants doubled. The procedure is actually a series of operations: first, veins or arteries are snipped out from other parts of the patient to replace the failing coronary arteries, blocked by fatty deposits or blood clots.

The surgeon then takes an electric saw, cuts down the middle of the patient's breastbone, and opens up the ribcage like the lid of a box. A cold potassium solution is injected into the heart to stop it, and the business of pumping and oxygenating the patient's blood is taken over by a heart-lung machine while surgeons graft in the good vessels.

When this is finished, the heart is restarted, the inside of the patient cleaned up - anticoagulants administered to keep the blood flowing freely make the inside of the chest a messy place - and the breastbone is wired back together. Given the radical nature of such a procedure, it is extraordinary how routine it has become: it is the most commonly performed heart operation in Britain.

A bypass literally rejuvenates its beneficiaries. But there are drawbacks. The opening and resealing of the chest means a long, often painful recovery period, and in a minority of patients, the use of the heart-lung machine leaves behind tiny bubbles and particles in the bloodstream. These can diminish the person's ability to carry out certain mental tasks, such as maths problems.

So two solutions were needed: a technique to avoid opening up the chest, and a way to avoid using the heart-lung machine. In the 70s, doctors in Latin America solved the second problem. Faced with the impossibly high cost of heart-lung machines, they developed a way of operating on a still beating heart. The device they used, called a stabiliser, immobilised only the small section of the heart being worked on.

And now, with the robot, the first problem has been solved. For a few lucky patients, there is no need to bisect the breastbone. Instead, the two arms of the robot slip in between the ribcage through holes that are smaller than a five-pence piece.

Six holes were made in David Lee - two for the robot arms, one for the camera and light, two for drainage and one for the stabiliser. The word "riddled" comes to mind, but each hole was an easily healed incision.

"I've been left with just small scars," Lee says. "I had very little pain when I woke up, and I'd recommend the operation to anyone. It makes such a difference to your life."

De Souza, who is pioneering the use of surgical robots in Britain with fellow Royal Brompton consultant John Pepper, says: "The fewer holes the better. But they heal so well that you shouldn't think about jeopardising the outcome by using too few of them."

Although the surgeons are as comfortable with the word as the media, "robot" is a misnomer. The machine is really a slave, following the movements made by the surgeon sitting in another part of the operating theatre, and translating movements of centimetres into fractions of millimetres.

Zeus, the make of robot at the Brompton, is an easy workmate. When off-duty, it sits quietly in a small, shabby room. It doesn't draw a salary, never uncorks a bottle of wine, always stays on the hospital premises and, though it has a voice - an American female one - has never been known to criticise a colleague.

The set-up is in three parts: the operating table, with the robot arms and camera attached; the separate computer brain of the system; and the workstation where the surgeon sits. At first the human surgeons watched what they were making the robot do through eyepieces that gave a three-dimensional view, but now they use a conventional flat screen.

Sitting at the workstation, the surgeon holds a control in each hand, tweezer-like instruments that are attached to rods which transmit movement through all axes to the robot.

Staff have set up a practice system for surgeons to hone their robot suturing skills. A cardboard box stands in for the chest cavity; the robot arms and camera plunge inside through holes. For muscle and artery, there is a rubber glove, stretched taut and marked with lines of dots where the stitches are supposed to go.

De Souza pops in a couple of stitches, and invites me to have a go. I sit down and grasp the tweezers. On screen I can see a pair of metal pincers, a needle and thread, and the line of dots. Everything looks huge, but the pincers are only a couple of centimetres long. I engage the system by pushing on a treadle with my foot. Press the tweezers, and the pincers open; move and twist them, and the robot obediently follows. I attempt to stitch. I gouge a hole, then lose the needle. In a real operation, I would be wrestled to the ground and taken into custody, but for a trained surgeon, the system is easy to pick up - as the rows of neat stitching in other practice gloves testify.

The robot surgeon was commissioned by the US department of defence for use in remote field hospitals. However, its use in the US is still restricted by the food and drug administration. Europe has been the test-bed - so far, apparently, with success.

In bypass operations, the robot can only deal with the replacement of a single artery - the critical left anterior descending artery. The average number of arteries replaced is three, and single-artery problems are often dealt with by other, temporary means, such as a balloon inflated at the blockage site - a process known as angioplasty. But De Souza says some surgeons are arguing that single-artery bypasses should be performed more often.

One of the drawbacks of the robot is that the human surgeon cannot feel the yield and texture of the tissues being cut, sewn or probed. The team working with Britain's second surgical robot, at St Mary's hospital and Imperial College in London, are trying to devise just such a feedback mechanism.

St Mary's has been using the robot, known as da Vinci, for bowel operations and plans to carry out its first heart bypass later this year. The lead consultant on the project is Ara Darzi, professor of surgery at Imperial.

"Using the robot is straightforward, natural and intuitive," he says. "It's absolutely wonderful - like doing an open operation but doing it closed. It's probably the most ingenious piece of mechanical engineering I've ever seen."

webTitle: Dear doctor. Dr Ann Robinson answers your health questions.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson on a skier's bruising experience, a very embarrassing problem, and one woman's experience with the 'mask of pregnancy'
fields.trailText: Dr Ann Robinson on a skier's bruising experience, a very embarrassing problem, and one woman's experience with the 'mask of pregnancy'.
fields.body:
Painful pull

Q: I've pulled a muscle in my right thigh (while skiing). It runs from behind my knee to about threequarters the way up the inside of my thigh. A week after pulling it, I have black and yellow bruising all along the line of the muscle and it still hurts, especially when I sit. What's the best thing to do to make it better? And could the bruising mean it's more serious than I think?

A: You can get a tremendous amount of bruising after tearing some fibres of a large muscle like the one that runs up the back of your thigh (which makes up part of your hamstrings). It is highly unlikely to signify any more serious underlying problem. Arnica tablets and cream are great favourites for "bringing out the bruise" but probably make not the slightest difference. When it aches, elevate your leg and put a cold compress (eg a bag of frozen peas wrapped in a pillowcase) under the bruised area.

As the muscle fibres heal, they will shorten so it's all too easy to sustain a similar injury again. The trick is to gradually stretch up the damaged fibres. This means gentle hamstring stretches (ie bending down to touch your toes), starting at a few a day (stop if it hurts) and building up until you have full stretch back. If you belong to a gym, you can use the hamstring- stretching machine with a light weight to further build up the strength.

Troublesome tear

Q: I have an excruciatingly painful and embarrassing problem. A tear in my anus means that passing a motion is almost unbearably painful and that I pass blood with my stool sometimes. I have been told I have an anal fissure and am on a waiting list to have my anus stretched - a prospect that fills me with consternation. Are there any other treatments I could try?

A: Anal fissures are horrible, extremely common and potentially treatable without recourse to surgery. The fissure is a small tear in the lining of the anal canal which sometimes develops after passing particularly hard stools. The sphincter that keeps us faecally continent goes into spasm and this can result in a long-term fissure, a skin tag that hangs down outside your anus and an abnormally tight anal opening. Most fissures heal on their own. It makes sense to avoid constipation by eating a high- fibre diet with plenty of fluids and soften the stool using laxatives or suppositories.

If you are still suffering after six weeks, you may need further treatment. Traditionally, the surgical options have been an anal stretch to loosen the tightened anus, or cutting part of the sphincter for a more long- lasting effect. The problem with the latter is that it can make you faceally incontinent.

Effective treatment is available now in the form of GTN ointment (0.2%) rubbed on to the anus. The active ingredient is the same drug that is used to treat angina. Happily, it relaxes the anal sphincter in the same way as it eases pressure on the heart and allows the fissure to heal. It needs to be specially made up by a pharmacist as it is not yet licenced for use in anal fissures. GTN can give you a whopping headache and you can't take Viagra with it as it is dangerous for the heart. You should see a specialist if bleeding continues to rule out bowel cancer.

Nail nightmare

Q: I've had a recurrent problem with an ingrowing toenail. It flares up occasionally, oozing pus from the corner and becoming very red and painful. I usually get away with an antiseptic cream and cotton wool but attacks are becoming more frequent and lasting longer. Can you help?

A: Ingrown nails may be caused by improper trimming, inherited nail deformities, injuries, fungal infections, or pressure. The big toe is the commonest victim.If the toe is infected, you might see pus or redness.You need to see a podiatrist (previously known as a chiropodist). If the nail is not infected, you may get away with having the corner of the nail trimmed to relieve the pain. For a partially ingrown nail, your podiatrist may need to remove one side of your nail back to the cuticle and treat the base. Severe infections or totally ingrown nails may require antibiotics and temporary or permanent removal of the entire nail. Before you faint at the thought of this medieval-style torture, rest assured that heavy duty volumes of local anaesthetic are used to numb the pain.

Perturbed by a patch

Q: I've a brownish patch that has appeared on my cheek since I've been pregnant. My baby is due in a few weeks time and I am getting a little concerned about the patch though my GP assured me it's not skin cancer. Will it go on its own or do I need to do something?

A: You've probably got chloasma, also known as melasma or "mask of pregnancy". In fact, you don't need to be a pregnant woman to get one, though it helps. It appears on the forehead, cheeks or lips. It is thought to be a reaction to hormones, hence its appearance while pregnant, on the pill or while using depot provera contraceptive injections. The patch of pigment tends to get darker in the sun. It usually fades a few months after delivery but can recur, and be darker, in future pregnancies. Men who use aftershave and then go out in the sun may also develop a similar patch of mottled pigmentation. This is called a phototoxic reaction and is due to ultraviolet radiation being absorbed by the chemical substance (perfume, cologne and other types of fragrance) on the skin.

Best advice for chloasma is to consider coming off the pill, use sunblock, avoid strong soaps, facial cleansers or aftershave and discuss with a dermatologist using bleaching creams that contain hydroquinone or other creams to decrease skin pigmentation. Camouflage creams are also available if you feel very self-conscious.

Cancer choices

Q: I have breast cancer, recently diagnosed. I am trying to find out as much as possible so I can make informed choices about my treatment. I am finding that I am overwhelmed by the information available on the internet and can't see the wood for the trees. Can you recommend any reliable source of information?

A: You are so right to inform yourself as fully as possible. Of all the sites I've checked out, I think the one run by CancerBACUP is the best - www.cancerbacup.org.uk. A full discussion with a member of your breast care team, followed by a second opinion if you feel you need it, should also help to clarify your thoughts. Good luck!

webTitle: Faith, compassion and the Conservative party

fields.headline: Faith, compassion and the Conservative party
fields.standfirst: In his speech to the NCVO annual conference this week, William Hague outlined his vision for the voluntary sector under a Tory government. Margaret Harris, professor of voluntary sector organisation at Aston business school in Birmingham, examines his ideas and their origin
fields.trailText: In his speech to the NCVO annual conference this week, William Hague outlined his vision for the voluntary sector under a Tory government. Margaret Harris, professor of voluntary sector organisation at Aston business school, Birmingham, examines his ideas and their origin.
fields.body:
William Hague and other key members of the Conservative party are actively courting faith groups. It began last year with the launch of the party's new social policy initiative, Renewing One Nation, and has continued through addresses to religious-based charities, letters to the press and, most recently, at a speech at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) annual conference.

The word compassion, which has traditionally been associated with faith-inspired caring and charity, recurs in these public statements: voluntary groups are creators of "compassionate communities"; "compassion means more than a handout"; the party stands for "compassionate Conservatism" and it aims to "denationalise compassion".

How should churches and religious-based welfare organisations respond to such invitations to get more involved in solving social problems? Are they being offered a golden opportunity to renew and develop their traditional role in helping the poor and needy or should they be wary?

Like secular voluntary and charitable organisations, faith-based groups need to be aware that governmental funding invariably comes with strings attached. The strings may be ones that they are prepared to accept (conforming to monitoring systems and best-value regimes, for example, or favouring particular kinds of users).

All the same, the practical implications of accepting governmental funding need to be considered carefully by the leaders and trustees of faith groups, especially as such funding may restrict their ability to favour their own adherents and traditional beneficiaries or to respond to them in informal and unregulated ways.

But beyond this kind of pragmatic consideration, leaders of faith groups may also want to reflect on the transatlantic sources of the ideas being promulgated by the Conservatives in this country.

One such source is the US radical right and its analysis of the causes of social problems. It emphasises personal and individual responsibility for not only the occurrence of social problems such as poverty, homelessness and many forms of ill-health, but also for their solution.

The corollary is an approach to people such as single mothers, drug addicts and those without adequate housing which severely limits the state benefits they can receive during their lifetime. This attitude is aimed at discouraging what is seen as anti-social behaviour and encouraging self help.

A second influential strand of American thinking is related to the first, but is not necessarily identical to it. It is the religious right's viewpoint that was embraced by US president George Bush long before he took office and which is encapsulated in a book entitled Compassionate Conservatism by Marvin Olasky.

In addition to the now standard argument of the political right that big government and state welfare should be severely curtailed, Mr Olasky argues that faith-based organisations are more effective than other kinds of organisations in solving social problems and that they should therefore receive governmental funding, alongside equivalent secular organisations, to carry out their social welfare activities.

In the US, governmental agencies can now legitimately fund faith-based groups and individual congregations even in cases where they discriminate in their employment practices in favour of their own adherents.

This also applies even if the services they provide (for example, prison visiting, daycare or homeless shelters) are overtly linked to beneficiaries attending religious worship, listening to homilies or assenting to particular theological viewpoints on their sinful lifestyles.

Faith groups will no doubt want to consider whether the philosophies underpinning the policies of the US radical right and religious right are commensurate with their own theologies of compassion and caring.

Punitive, stigmatising and selective approaches to those in social distress do not necessarily sit comfortably with more liberal theologies, which tend to be universalistic, accepting and non-judgmental in their approach to social service provision.

Faith groups will no doubt want to consider whether the philosophies underpinning the policies of the US radical right and religious right are commensurate with their own theologies of compassion and caring. Punitive, stigmatising and selective approaches to those in social distress do not necessarily sit comfortably with more liberal theologies, which tend to be universalistic, accepting and non-judgmental in their approach to social service provision.

webTitle: Feature: Kate Hudson, acting's latest It Girl

fields.headline: Golden child
fields.standfirst: Kate Hudson is a Hollywood blue-blood with Goldie Hawn for a mother and Kurt Russell as a stepfather.  Danny Leigh meets acting's latest It Girl
fields.trailText: Kate Hudson is a Hollywood blue-blood with Goldie Hawn for a mother and Kurt Russell as a stepfather. Danny Leigh meets acting's latest It Girl.
fields.body:
The ascendant young actress says she needs a cigarette. I know, she says, it's a terrible thing, and her publicist hands her one. Anything else? Yeah, she says, coffee would be great. So coffee it is. And then come the introductions, and she smiles her sunny smile from across the room, and says hello Dannyfromtheguardian.

The ascendant young actress is called Kate Hudson - her face is all Californian glow and spry insouciance, and staring out from bus shelters across the country, on a movie poster that reads Almost Famous. Almost Famous, the title of the 70s-set rock music fable which, although cast in a supporting role, she effectively walks away with. And Almost Famous, a pithy summation of her current celebrity status. Until you realise that, two months shy of her 22nd birthday, "almost" is redundant. Anointed by the media as this year's It Girl, she's there already.

Which the ascendant young actress isn't quite naive enough not to see through. "Oh, it's obvious," she says when you ask why the world wants a piece of her. She means her family. Specifically, she means her parents; more specifically still, her mother. This, you see, is no mere identikit starlet. Rather, Kate Hudson is Hollywood blue-blood, film business aristocracy, raised by action hero stepfather Kurt Russell and - their resemblance genuinely startling - definitive ditz Goldie Hawn. "The thing with my parents cuts both ways," she says, finally lighting her cigarette. "I mean, if I suck, then maybe I'll never work again because of it. Either way, it brings a certain attention which honestly holds not much importance to me."

But which holds a lot of importance to everyone else. Glance through her ever-thickening press file and, in a single sentence, you'll find reference to the symmetry between her part as a rock star's girlfriend in Almost Famous and real-life role as a rock star's wife (having recently married Chris Robinson, frontman of the Stones-esque Black Crowes), right before the revelation that she still lives with her parents. "And it's like, no, strangely, as a married woman in my 20s, I have actually left home." She tilts her head and squints, as if to say her point's been made: "D'you know what I mean?"

It's the problem with being all things to all people, I say, and she nods. So in one moment she's both this year's hottest blonde and the wide-eyed innocent who did something called "the happy dance" when she landed Almost Famous. "Yeah, I hear that so much. It was one stupid comment. It was like Woo! I did the happy dance! D'you know?" And, in the ardent column inches, you find another mirror to her breakthrough in Almost Famous. There, she's the ideal woman with whom the kid journalist at the film's centre falls hopelessly in love; here, she's the perfect face that journalists - at least male journalists - exhaust their thesauruses drooling over.

Ask her if she knew the part was going to make her, and she drifts into the bromidic language of actors. Oh no, she says, all she cared about was making director Cameron Crowe happy and, anyway, in this business you never know how things will turn out, you just do the best you can. D'you know? She winces. "I guess that sounds really boring."

As if in apology, she talks at length about how she felt playing a groupie in the film's portrait of the baldly sexist 70s music industry. "Um . . . well, a lot of women say it's degrading. But from the people I spoke to, they all knew what they were doing. They made that decision to follow that band, or to be with that man, and not one of them regretted it. And nor should they. Because some of the greatest songs ever written were about these women, right?" She doesn't wait for a reply. "But yes, there's also sadness there. It's like people who are constantly doing drugs. It's not necessarily about the drugs. It's about the problem. The core."

So are drugs something she has experience of? Opinions about? "I do. I have lots of opinions about drugs." And then she says that she's reading Tom Wolfe's Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test, and that drugs should be used "to enhance, not forget", and that hard drugs (mentioned with a grimace) "shouldn't be taken, period. I mean, me personally, I'm scared of drugs. But I believe they can be used in amazing ways. And I have absolutely no problem with marijuana."

Does she smoke it? Is that what she's getting at? "Well . . . I . . . ah . . ." The seconds tick by. "I don't have a problem with people smoking it. If people want to smoke pot, I say go ahead. I do have a problem with kids who think it's cool."

Given her marriage to Robinson, a chalky divorcé with a longstanding yen for legalising cannabis, it's risky ground for a tabloid-friendly figure like herself. Which may be why, with one eye on her publicist, she requests another cigarette and says, somewhat hurriedly: "So that's what I think about pot. D'you know what I mean?"

Although they were only married in the new year, she knows the questions about her 34-year-old "soulmate" Robinson will come soon enough - most hedging, delicately or otherwise, around his role as a surrogate father: "Which, of course, is ridiculous. I have a dad. Kurt's my dad." Yet two and two will surely be put together, particularly with Hudson's biological father Bill walking out on the family when his daughter was barely out of nappies (Russell moved in thereafter). Last autumn, the pair exchanged harsh, public words after Hudson Jr complained that her father "doesn't know me from a hole in the wall". Add in the curiosity surrounding her mother - largely devoted to who's bitterly envious of whom - and you can see why she might be sick of discussing her family.

"It's weird," she says. "I'm not, because I love them, and I miss them, and I like to talk about them. But I don't like the mundane questions. Because it's always, is my mom jealous of me? which is something I get very offended by, or am I jealous of her? And these questions mean nothing. They're just mundane. Because the only answer is no, of course not. Or someone'll say, 'Oh, before you go to awards ceremonies, does your mother give you red carpet tips?' And you go, 'Who do you think we are?' My mother's a Buddhist, for Christ's sake. Who thinks we sit around with her giving me tips on walking down red carpets?"

It's unfortunate, I say, but you've both become symbols of Hollywood's ageing process. One day, for example, you'll no longer be referred to as Goldie Hawn's daughter, and she'll be nothing but Kate Hudson's mother. D'you know what I mean? "Yeah, I see that. I mean, in other people's eyes. But it's so funny, because that's what we are. She's my mom, I'm her daughter, and we're damn proud of each other. We don't look at each other as actresses ."

She peers at her coffee, cold in the cup. "But it's like . . . I've been burned so many times already. Misquoted so many times. But that will never stop me from being honest. That could never break me, because I'm not the one that lives with that karma. D'you know? So I look at it like there's a machine surrounding this business, which I have no control over, and you just have to let the machine do what it does."

And suddenly, with her perfect face and famous parents and great career, you feel oddly, unshakeably sorry for her. Like most of us at two months shy of our 22nd birthdays, her life experience is short, her opinions somewhat woozy, and here she is, a nice, talented, faintly new-agey girl stuck in rooms like this with people like me who - even when they refrain from implying her mother secretly hates her - ask if her husband's a daddy substitute and whether she takes drugs. "You know," she says, "it's like when we were talking about the film making me famous. It is what it is. You do this thing, then the machine takes over. And that's that."

So, through your chippie, British cynicism, you believe her when she says that, while ambitious ("Totally! I'm an Aries!"), she isn't what you'd call competitive. "Only when I'm about to kick someone's ass at Yahtzee. Or soccer." You play football? "Used to." Any good? " Yeah . Oh yeah . . . But I mean, I look at it like there's no reason to ever be competitive about anybody else's life, or career, or opportunities. D'you know? Because everybody's path happens for a reason." And you believe it because she believes it, and then you feel bad the moment you say that, while she may not be competitive, there's probably a lot of actresses failing auditions who look at her glamorous background and glittering future and feel competitive as hell.

The pause that follows is long; longer even than the pause that followed the pot question. "I've never experienced that," she says eventually. "It's not something I've ever . . . I mean, as far as being friendly with other actors and actresses, I've always been friendly with the ones that I've worked with . . ." She trails off, and then you get the smile again.

"See, my thing is I'm not actually fighting with anybody for anything. I'm just having a great time, living my life as if I'm going to die tomorrow. D'you know what I mean? The rest is just the machine."

fields.headline: Dyke considers licence giveaway
fields.trailText: 3.45pm:The BBC could use licence-fee payers' money to fund a giveaway of digital TV equipment, Greg Dyke revealed today, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC could use licence-fee payers' money to fund a giveaway of digital TV equipment, Greg Dyke revealed today.

Speaking at the Commons media select committee, the BBC director general surprised his audience by saying that the corporation had already been in talks about how to achieve universal digital coverage.

His remarks were unexpected - the subject of a possible giveaway of set-top boxes or other technology has always been something of a taboo in the broadcasting industry, who want to encourage as much take-up as possible without having to resort to free equipment.

Responding to questions about how universal take-up of digital television could be achieved, Mr Dyke said he hoped the BBC's new services - the proposed new BBC3, BBC4 and two children's channels - would be a significant driving force.

But he indicated that the BBC could become involved in a future giveaway or subsidy of boxes.

"We have been doing a lot of work on this. Could you give them away, and could the BBC fund them?" he asked.

BBC sources later attempted to play down Mr Dyke's remarks, saying that most people would be attracted to digital television by the prospect of the corporation's new services.

And other broadcasting sources doubted that the BBC would ever use licence-fee payers' money in such a way.

But Mr Dyke's comments have brought into the public arena a debate that has been conducted within the industry about how to convert the final 25-30% of TV viewers who expected to be either unwilling or unable to transfer to digital.

At the moment, take-up rates in Britain are healthy: about 6m homes, around 30%, have digital television.

The government wants to switch off the analogue signal between 2006 and 2010.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has said that 98% of viewers in a transmitter area must have converted to digital before the analogue signal can be switched off.

However, industry estimates suggest that the digital take-up will level off at 75%.

It is likely, at that stage, that the government and the TV industry will consider giving away, or heavily subsidising, boxes or other receiving equipment such as digital televisions.

Some industry figures believe the government has not thought hard enough about the problem: there was little mention of it in the recent communications white paper.

webTitle: Haldane to steer Attic Futura's teen titles

fields.headline: Haldane to steer Attic Futura's teen titles
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Attic Futura has created the role of editorial director for its teenage magazines, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Attic Futura has created an editorial director role for its portfolio of teenage magazines.

The publisher is gearing up to launch CD:UK, the long-awaited magazine based on ITV's successful ITV Saturday morning show.

Pauline Haldane, who was involved in the launch of Ministry magazine, has been put in charge of all Attic's teen titles.

These include TV Hits, Westlife magazine and TV Hits Special.

The appointment follows a management reshuffle late last year.

Vivienne Coterill, former commercial boss of the National Magazine Company's Affluent division, was brought in as managing director.

She joined following a failed management buyout by the then managing director Neil Raaschou.

Meanwhile, Nick Chalmers has been appointed editor of TV Hits.

He replaces Alison Lower, who has left to take a job in music A&R.

fields.headline: A life inside
fields.standfirst: Scars that never heal and men you hope never to meet again
fields.trailText: Scars that never heal and men you hope never to meet again.
fields.body:
"Any movement yet guv?" I was standing in the open doorway of the wing office. Mr Turnlock, our brusque and efficient landing officer was on the phone. Twenty minutes earlier there had been a "general alarm". I thought I knew the reason why. The orderly who delivers the newspapers from the library had told me. Mr Turnlock finished talking and replaced the handset.

"What is it?" he said. "Er, any movement yet?" I repeated, "the stabbing . . ."

"What stabbing?" he said.

"The paper orderly said there had been a stabbing on one of the wings and that was why movement had been stopped."

"Rubbish," said Mr Turnlock. "You see how rumours erupt in these places? Movement was stopped because an old chap collapsed outside the chapel. It started back up again 10 minutes ago."

"Oh," I said, "right."

Feeling foolish, I left the wing and made my way towards the exercise yard. Mr Turnlock was right. After all these years I should have known better than to believe the worst without question. But tensions had been running a little high in the jail. A week earlier a man had been attacked by another wielding a lino cutting blade fixed into a piece of dowling. The home-made weapon had been thrust into the victim's face with such force that the steel edge had ploughed a deep furrow across the bones of his cheek and jaw. The resulting 40 stitches made it look as if he had been flung face first through a car window screen.

I spoke to him briefly in the healthcare centre a few days later when I was up making an appointment to see the dentist. It was the worst chibbing I had ever seen.

I didn't know the scarred man, but coincidentally I had spoken to him once before. It was a couple of days after his arrival last September and we were browsing the same bookshelf in the library. He asked me what the prison was like. "Relatively quiet," I told him. Unimpressed, he began dropping names of reputed tough-guy prisoners he had allegedly already done time with - "faces" in the system.

The conversation was beginning to bore me until I heard him mention the name "Braggs." "Who?" I said, startled, "Donny Braggs?" "No," he said, "his son, Joe. Donny Braggs is dead." "You're kidding," I said. I pressed him for details. It was important to be sure we were talking about the same man. Satisfied we were, I asked him what had happened. "He was stabbed in the leg in a nightclub," he said. "Gangrene set in and it killed him." "Christ," I said, and sighed a deep sigh.

Thirteen years had passed but I had never forgotten my run-in with Donny Braggs. We were on the same wing at the time. Donny was "on the book" (Category A prisoner) and was known for his short temper. One sleepy-eyed Monday morning I bumped into him outside my cell door with my breakfast tray. Immediately he began ranting and hurling abuse. His racket was drawing dozens of pairs of eyes in our direction so I implored him to come into my cell. "The screws will be on us in a minute." I said, "Come on, I'll make us a cup of tea."

He followed me in, but straight away recommenced his tirade. He was becoming hysterical. Realising I had made a mistake I grabbed the front of his shirt, intending to shove him back outside. Instead Donny wrong footed me and swung me around full circle. He reached up behind his head with his right hand and suddenly I felt a stabbing blow in the corner of my left eye. He must have seen my cutlery in a cup on the shelf which was behind me before pulling me around. Luckily the knife he grabbed was only made of plastic.

Other stinging blows to my scalp and face followed before instinct caused me to drop my head and unwittingly crash it against the bridge of his nose. Donny fled, bleeding, from the cell.

We never resolved that conflict. He was shipped out a couple of days later for threatening a prison officer - I explained my swollen eye and the weals on my face by fibbing that I had "collided with someone while jogging".

Over the years I often thought about Donny. The prison system is a small world and I couldn't help wondering if and when there would be another confrontation. God knows if he ever thought about me. Although I'm ashamed to admit it, I felt relieved when I learned of his demise.

On reflection, perhaps it was not so foolish after all to have believed the worst from the library orderly. One thing I'm sure of though - for a long time to come, whenever the young man with the scars hears that "movement has been stopped" he'll be minded to believe the worst without question. And it will be the most natural thing in the world.

 Erwin James is serving a life sentence. He will not be paid for this article.

"He was stabbed in the leg in a nightclub," he said. "Gangrene set in and it killed him." "Christ," I said, and sighed a deep sigh. Thirteen years had passed but I had never forgotten my run-in with Donny Braggs. We were on the same wing at the time. Donny was "on the book" (Category A prisoner) and was known for his short temper. One sleepy-eyed Monday morning I bumped into him outside my cell door with my breakfast tray. Immediately he began ranting and hurling abuse. His racket was drawing dozens of pairs of eyes in our direction so I implored him to come into my cell. "The screws will be on us in a minute." I said, "Come on, I'll make us a cup of tea." He followed me in, but straight away recommenced his tirade. He was becoming hysterical. Realising I had made a mistake I grabbed the front of his shirt, intending to shove him back outside. Instead Donny wrong footed me and swung me around full circle. He reached up behind his head with his right hand and suddenly I felt a stabbing blow in the corner of my left eye. He must have seen my cutlery in a cup on the shelf which was behind me before pulling me around. Luckily the knife he grabbed was only made of plastic. Other stinging blows to my scalp and face followed before instinct caused me to drop my head and unwittingly crash it against the bridge of his nose. Donny fled, bleeding, from the cell. We never resolved that conflict. He was shipped out a couple of days later for threatening a prison officer - I explained my swollen eye and the weals on my face by fibbing that I had "collided with someone while jogging". Over the years I often thought about Donny. The prison system is a small world and I couldn't help wondering if and when there would be another confrontation. God knows if he ever thought about me. Although I'm ashamed to admit it, I felt relieved when I learned of his demise. On reflection, perhaps it was not so foolish after all to have believed the worst from the library orderly. One thing I'm sure of though - for a long time to come, whenever the young man with the scars hears that "movement has been stopped" he'll be minded to believe the worst without question. And it will be the most natural thing in the world.  Erwin James is serving a life sentence. He will not be paid for this article.

fields.headline: Glasgow spurns Cosla
fields.trailText: Scotland's largest council has pulled out of the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities, claiming its membership fee would be better spent elsewhere.
fields.body:
Scotland's largest council has pulled out of the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla), claiming its membership fee would be better spent elsewhere.

Glasgow city council has been unhappy with Cosla since it failed to convince the Scottish executive that a three-year increase in local authority funds should be skewed in favour of those areas with the highest levels of deprivation.

Now Glasgow claims it is not getting best value from Cosla membership and says it will make its own representations directly to the Scottish executive and the parliament.

The decision to withdraw came at a meeting today, when councillors unanimously approved a £2bn budget for next year with a below-inflation council tax increase of 2.4%. The £300,000 cost of Cosla membership will be spent on special needs education for autistic children.

Council leader Charles Gordon said: "Glasgow city council is a large, influential local authority and we feel confident that we will be able to deal directly with the Scottish executive and the Scottish parliament when there are issues on which we want to put a case. Glasgow is not going to be pushed around - it is going to punch its weight."

The council said after that it was in its best interests to deal directly with the Scottish executive. "We don't need any middle-organisation to do it. It may be a matter of convenience for the Scottish executive, but they now have to take into account that Cosla represents 31 councils and Glasgow puts its own case. And it's unlikely the executive will turn its back on Scotland's biggest council," said a spokesman.

Cosla said it was "a matter of great regret" that Glasgow had decided to pull out, but denied its future was under threat. "I am extremely sorry that Glasgow city council has taken this decision. The importance of local government speaking with one voice across the country cannot be over-stated and for more than 25 years Cosla has provided the platform for Scottish councils to do that," said president Norman Murray.

"We are committed to continuing to represent Scottish councils at all levels and we are determined to go on with the excellent work of the organisation with the support of Scotland's 31 other local authorities which are committed to maintaining their membership.

"While the loss of the expertise that Glasgow has brought to Cosla will be missed, there remains a wealth of experience in Scottish local government at both councillor and officer levels that will be brought to bear at all levels of the organisation's operations."

webTitle: Building social partnerships in the workplace

fields.headline: Building social partnerships in the workplace
fields.trailText: "Partnership" has become the new buzz word in industrial relations, with partnership agreements signed in many companies, but what relevance does it have for the voluntary sector?
fields.body:
"Partnership" has become the new buzz word in industrial relations, with partnership agreements signed in many companies, but what relevance does it have for the voluntary sector?

Some would argue that the often shared values between management and staff in charities means that any overt partnership arrangement is unnecessary. But, according to new research, voluntary organisations should not be so complacent.

Partnership deals have become increasingly common in the private sector, as part of a move away from old-style confrontational labour relations. The approach often means management recognises the rights of employees to influence decision making and provides access to information on decisions, while, for their part, staff commit to the success of the organisation and may agree to flexible working conditions.

At a seminar on partnership at work, held during the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) conference, Peter Reilly of the Institute for Employment Studies unveiled a study of partnership working in the sector.

The generally high level of agreement between management and staff over the direction of organisations and shared values meant voluntary organisations were in many ways ideal candidates for partnership, he said.

He studied approaches to management in eight unionised charities and found a high degree of consensus-based decision making and involvement of staff.

But Mr Reilly also found managers could assume that, because staff and managers shared similar basic values, there were never any separate interests to take into account.

"There can be a belief that because everyone works for the same organisation they share the same interests. But that's not always the case, especially in areas like pay," he said.

Alison Lamb, co-ordinator for the NCVO partnership at work project, said there was a particular need to try and reach senior people in charities, who may be reluctant to engage in genuine partnership with staff.

One seminar attendee said: "I'm in favour of partnership but whenever other senior managers in my charity hear the word 'trade union' they run a mile."

Ms Lamb acknowledged this problem: "We need to get senior managers and trustees to sign up to partnership."

Co-speaker Chris Ball, voluntary sector secretary at the MSF union for skilled and professional people, agreed that, in many ways, the voluntary sector had a head start in adopting a partnership approach.

He pointed to examples of partnership working involving the union, such as a scheme with the voluntary sector on Merseyside for training union representatives to become learning representatives.

"There are a lot of obstacles to employees' training, so we're hoping that smaller voluntary organisations will be able to use the union and its distance learning website," he said.

webTitle: Unilever to drop more top brands

fields.headline: Unilever to drop more top brands
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: The consumer goods company is preparing to cut back its product portfolio further, reports Julia Day.
Jan 29: Unilever sells brands to US giant
fields.body:
Unilever is ready to take the axe to more of its brands.

The Anglo-Dutch consumer goods group announced last year it was cutting back the number of its brands from 1,600 to 400.

The move is an attempt to focus on a portfolio of the most profitable core products.

But at a press conference today, Unilever chairman Antony Burgmans said: "Four hundred is not a fixed figure.

"I wouldn't be surprised at a more compact number, such as 375."

Mr Burgmans said the company would announce how many brands it plans to keep when it releases half-year figures in August.

It is taking a long, hard look at the Bestfoods portfolio - which includes the Knorr and Hellman's brands - which it bought for £14.6bn last year.

As part of the company's sweeping restructure, the number of Unilever brands has been slashed to 970.

Of the 570 remaining brands selected for elimination, around 300 are expected to disappear by the end of 2002.

The remaining 270 will be sold or merged into leading brands over the next 24 months, Mr Burgmans said.

Sales of the core portfolio of 400 brands grew 4.9% in the fourth quarter and 3.8% over the past 12 months.

Unilever has already sold brands such as Batchelors and Oxo to the Campbell Soup Company.

But some new products have been added as the result of several big takeovers last year.

These include Slimfast diet products and Ben and Jerry's ice-cream.

webTitle: Calls for a flexible approach to partnerships

fields.headline: Calls for a flexible approach to partnerships
fields.trailText: A more flexible approach to partnership, where government acknowledges a diverse voluntary sector, was a key theme presented to delegates at NCVO's annual conference yesterday.
fields.body:
A more flexible approach to partnership, where government acknowledges a diverse voluntary sector, was a key theme presented to delegates at NCVO's annual conference yesterday.

Speaking to the annual gathering of voluntary, public and private sector professionals, Professor Nicholas Deakin of the Centre for Civil Society at the London School of Economics reviewed the history of voluntary organisations' relationship with government, in order to demonstrate development.

Professor Deakin, who chaired the 1996 commission on the future of the voluntary sector which called for a formal working agreement with government, told delegates that partnership had evolved from the one-way arrangement of the 1980s, when voluntary organisations were expected to help government deliver its priorities but were not invited to contribute at the policy-making stage. The 1998 compact between government and the vountary and community sector in England had contributed to improving this situation, he said, but he warned against imposing rigid partnership arrangements that could stifle potential to succeed.

A diverse sector was one reason for this need for flexibility, Professor Deakin said, adding that the "division of interests" and "multiplicity of partnerships" meant that no one approach fitted all.

"The question is whether the sector is as homegenous in its responses and dealings with government as is expected," said Professor Deakin.

Taking up the current issue of how faith-based organisations can help government to deliver its commitments, as proposed by the Bush administration in the US and currently being promoted by the Conservative party here, Professor Deakin told delegates that this approach did not suit the UK. "We are a multi-faith society but not an observant one, as the US is."

Echoing Professor Deakin's comments on the dangers of treating the sector as a homogenous entity, Professor Jane Lewis of the University of Oxford suggested that the debate should be about how individual organisations, not the generic sector, presented itself to government. She gave the example of Europe and the role of voluntary organisations in creating policy networks to manage social affairs. "It may be that voluntary organisations have to think more flexibly and that there is less room for sector initiatives," she said, adding that the blurring of service provision created new leverage for voluntary organisations and new forms of partnership.

At a time when voluntary organisations are increasingly being called on by government to lead on key issues like volunteering and other involvement in civil society, Professor Lewis highlighted the age-old problem of "instrumentalism".

"He who pays the piper calls the tune," she said, warning that the sector needed to guard its independence. However, she added that the main political parties were "extremely strong on the rhetoric of partnership" at the moment and the present government was keen to reiterate its commitment to the concept.

"Partnership is a buzz word in new Labour's lexicon, along with responsibility and opportunity," she said.

fields.headline: Case study: GUCH Patients Association
fields.trailText: For the thousands of teenagers and adults currently living with congenital heart defects, the Grown-Up Congenital Heart (GUCH) Patients Association is an invaluable source of information and support.
fields.body:
For the thousands of teenagers and adults currently living with congenital heart defects, the Grown-Up Congenital Heart (GUCH) Patients Association is an invaluable source of information and support.

Its national director, Mavis Moore, is certain the organisation has made a difference to the patients' quality of life. What she is less sure of, however, is where the core funding will come from to continue this valuable work in future.

Set up in 1993 with the help of the Royal Brompton hospital in London, the charity exists to help its members to understand their condition, access advice and meet fellow patients.

Its early links with the medical profession helped the association to attract launch funding from another charity, the British Heart Foundation (BHF). An initial grant of £35,000 a year for three years enabled the new charity to cover the core costs of employing Ms Moore as a part-time, national coordinator and the costs of offering printed and telephone advice. The BHF has continued to contribute £5,000 a year to the association, enabling Ms Moore's post to become full time and the charity to expand the services it offers.

But this funding is only guaranteed until August 2002 so Ms Moore is currently having to explore alternative funding opportunities. "We've been very fortunate to have the British Heart Foundation funding us over the years, but our expenditure is increasing, so we have to look at other ways of funding our work," she said.

Last year, the charity spent around £55,000 on providing a telephone advice line, producing information sheets, organising events and representing patients at local, regional and national levels. In the past, it has received grants towards specific projects, such as setting up the advice line and a quarterly newsletter, but these have been time-limited.

Apart from the BHF funding, the charity's only other sources of income are from voluntary joining fees, £10 for employed members and £5 for unemployed members, and from fundraising activities. Association supporters are keen fundraisers, although the death of the charity's patron, Jill Dando, in 1999 has curbed some of this activity. "It was a double blow to lose such a lovely person and one who so actively supported our cause," Ms Moore points out.

While she says this voluntary income generates "a significant amount" for the charity, it is not expected to cover the £85,000 of estimated expenditure over the next financial year. This comprises the additional cost of employing a full-time worker in the north of England, meeting increasing demand for information generated by the helpline and office space (Ms Moore runs the charity from home).

"The whole business of core funding is such a problem for charities, especially small ones like ourselves," she explained. "Our problem is finding the time or the people to concentrate on the specifics of funding."

The association does not have a formal membership scheme and contributions are voluntary, but Ms Moore says this arrangement may have to change in future to help cover the costs of service provision.

She is hoping the charity's application to the Department of Health for section 64 funding will be successful, as this will cover the new post planned. Otherwise, it's back to the task of approaching trusts and foundations. "We have received some one-off grants without strings, but most funders want to see specific projects, not core costs," she said.

Like many small charities, the association lacks adequate resources to tackle fundraising. It uses guides such as the Directory of Social Change's Guide to the Major Trusts, but only relies on hearsay to find out where other organisations are getting their funding from.

"Sometimes you wonder whether you should be working with children or animals because congenital heart disease isn't seen as being sexy," Ms Moore said.

webTitle: Government set to climb down on council secrecy proposals

fields.headline: Government set to climb down on council secrecy proposals
fields.trailText: The government is close to backing down on controversial proposals allowing councils to make decisions in secret, in the hope of avoiding an embarrassing defeat in the House of Lords tonight.
fields.body:
The government is close to backing down on controversial proposals allowing councils to make decisions in secret, in the hope of avoiding an embarrassing defeat in the House of Lords tonight.

The Liberal Democrats are continuing negotiations with ministers throughout the day in a bid to reach a compromise ahead of this evening's debate on regulations linked to the Local Government Act 2000. Sources close to the negotiations say the Lib Dems may be prepared to climb down in return for concessions.

The Lib Dems will tonight move a motion calling on the government to change the openness regime, although it may be dropped if the government meets their demands. They are concerned that the government's proposed regime will give councils too many opportunities to meet in secret.

Among other key concessions, Lib Dems want ministers to define more closely which decisions councillors must take in public. This would not necessarily mean scrapping the regulations, but could be initially done by amending government openness guidance.

If the regulations were scrapped, that could severely delay the introduction of new directly elected city mayors and Westminster-style council cabinets, as civil servants scramble to prepare new proposals.

Under the government's proposals, mayors and cabinets would be forced to meet in public only when they are taking so-called "key decisions", ie those which affect more than two wards or incur significant expenditure.

The Tories, however, are determined to wreck the regulations and will tonight attempt to amend the Lib Dems' motion to do so. The Tories hope to maintain the status quo in which the vast majority of council meetings are held in public.

The Liberal Democrats are continuing negotiations with ministers throughout the day in a bid to reach a compromise ahead of this evening's debate on regulations linked to the Local Government Act 2000. Sources close to the negotiations say the Lib Dems may be prepared to climb down in return for concessions. The Lib Dems will tonight move a motion calling on the government to change the openness regime, although it may be dropped if the government meets their demands. They are concerned that the government's proposed regime will give councils too many opportunities to meet in secret. Among other key concessions, Lib Dems want ministers to define more closely which decisions councillors must take in public. This would not necessarily mean scrapping the regulations, but could be initially done by amending government openness guidance. If the regulations were scrapped, that could severely delay the introduction of new directly elected city mayors and Westminster-style council cabinets, as civil servants scramble to prepare new proposals. Under the government's proposals, mayors and cabinets would be forced to meet in public only when they are taking so-called "key decisions", ie those which affect more than two wards or incur significant expenditure. The Tories, however, are determined to wreck the regulations and will tonight attempt to amend the Lib Dems' motion to do so. The Tories hope to maintain the status quo in which the vast majority of council meetings are held in public.

fields.headline: Crawshaw joins Burson-Marsteller as interactive head
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Burson-Marsteller has poached Miller Shandwick's Tony Crawshaw to run its new media practice, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Burson-Marsteller has poached Miller Shandwick's interactive chief Tony Crawshaw to head its e-commerce and new media practice.

Mr Crawshaw joins as business manager specialising in interactive services.

He will advise clients on how to use interactive platforms in their PR campaigns.

Such a strategy can help companies extend media and stakeholder reach, target online markets, manage issues and streamline internal communications.

At Miller Shandwick, London, Mr Crawshaw's clients included start-ups including Themutual.net and Webmetering.com.

He also helped establish interactive PR campaigns for blue-chip corporations such as Nestle and Microsoft.

"We are working to provide clients with a comprehensive communications strategy to create real business results," said Jonathan Hargreaves, managing director of Burson-Marsteller's e-commerce and new media practice.

"Tony's knowledge and experience will strengthen our European offering."

Mr Crawshaw added: "Burson-Marsteller is serious about building its interactive offering and has the resources to achieve this.

"I'm pleased to be part of such a dedicated team."

The agency's e-commerce and new media practice launched in January 2000.

Clients include travel specialist ebookers.com, internet incubator Xworks and investment research specialist Multex Investor Europe.

fields.headline: Sex and violence pulls in viewers
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: A diet of sex and violence helped C4 and 5 to better-than-usual viewing figures last night. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A diet of sex and violence helped Channel 4 and Channel 5 to achieve better-than-usual viewing figures last night.

A light-hearted look at the Kama Sutra followed by a double bill of raunchy US drama Sex and the City brought well over 2m viewers to Channel 4 after 9pm last night.

But, perhaps unsurprisingly, a documentary about hair loss performed rather less well, lowering the channel's peaktime average.

Just over 2m viewers tuned in to watch Position Impossible: In Search of the Kama Sutra, the first in a three-part series presented by Goodness Gracious Me star Sanjeev Bhaskar, according to unofficial overnight figures.

And the two 40-minute episodes of Sex and the City pulled in 2.3m and 2.6m viewers respectively, giving Channel 4 an average share of around 15%.

Channel 5 continued its Murder Week special with the classic Robert Louis Stevenson film Jekyll and Hyde, pulling in a very respectable 1.4m viewers to give it a 7% share.

This was 100,000 more than tuned into BBC2's acclaimed drama series In a Land of Plenty, also broadcast at 9pm.

On ITV the final episode of police drama series The Vice attracted 7.6m viewers, giving ITV an easy lead over BBC1.

But ITV's 10.30pm news was beaten by BBC1's 10pm broadcast, which pulled in 5.3m viewers to ITV's 4.9m.

webTitle: ITV cries foul over Sky charge

fields.headline: ITV cries foul over Sky carriage charges
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: ITV today claimed BSkyB's charges for carrying its channels would generate 'almost pure profit' for the satellite broadcaster. By Jason Deans and Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
ITV has argued that BSkyB's proposed charges for carrying its channels would generate "almost pure profit" for the satellite broadcaster.

ITV revealed today that BSkyB was asking more than £20m a year for carrying ITV and ITV2 on Sky Digital.

In a submission to the Department of Culture, Media & Sport's select committee on the communications white paper, ITV claimed that the charge - 30p per subscriber per month - was "almost pure profit".

ITV initially refused to put its two channels onto the Sky Digital platform. In the past few months, however, talks between the two sides have taken place.

BSkyB regulatory chief Michael Rhodes, who was being quizzed about the developments by the committee, admitted both broadcasters had held "various meetings over the last six months".

Mr Rhodes said £20m "could be in the top end" of the figure being discussed.

But he dismissed ITV's claim that this annual payment would be pure profit.

"Oftel entitles us to earn a reasonable return on the costs that we have incurred in putting the platform in place. To describe it as pure profit can't be correct," said Mr Rhodes.

Sky is justifying the cost on the grounds that Oftel allows it to generate "a reasonable rate of return" the so-called "automatically entitled" conditional access it needs to make ITV freely available in the UK but not outside.

But ITV's director of finance and development, Kate Stross, argued that Sky was charging far more in real terms than it charged the BBC when it signed carriage deals in 1998.

"We don't know exactly what the BBC's paying. But we do know that they did their deal at a point when the conditional access ratecard was lower," she said.

"We believe it was 10 to 15p per subscriber per month when the BBC did their deal."

Ms Stross added: "Sky's ratecard rose suddenly from 20p to 30p last October. In our view nothing happened for Sky to need to raise the ratecard by that amount."

She also said ITV did not believe Sky's carriage costs had risen enough to justify that size of price rise.

fields.headline: Gunman shot at White House
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: A 47-year-old accountant was shot and wounded by President George Bush's secret service team yesterday after he brandished a gun just outside the White House grounds in the heart of Washington.
fields.body:
A 47-year-old accountant was shot and wounded by President George Bush's secret service team yesterday after he brandished a gun just outside the White House grounds in the heart of Washington.

The man was shot in the leg by a uniformed officer only about a 100 yards from where Mr Bush was taking his regular morning exercise. The president was safe inside his official residence and was never in any danger from the gunman, officials said.

The gunman was named as Robert Pickett of Evansville, Indiana. Mr Pickett was arrested and taken for surgery to nearby George Washington University hospital.

The gunman was seen brandishing a handgun by several tourists near the south-west gate to the White House - which is not a public entrance to the presidential residence - just before 11.30am. From the way he was behaving, Mr Pickett appeared to be planning an imminent suicide attempt.

The shooting followed a ten-minute stand-off with secret service officers. "Put the gun down," they shouted repeatedly, according to witnesses. Mr Pickett refused to obey.

A secret service spokesman said an officer fired a single shot, which struck Mr Pickett in the right knee. No shots were fired by the gunman. Tourists fled in panic as police isolated the area.

"All I heard was one loud bang, then right after the bang everybody started running to where the noise came from," John Piana, a tourist, said.

The incident triggered a huge security alert in Washington, with streets cordoned off as police spread out around the White House.

The incident took place less than half an hour after the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, had left the building after meeting Mr Bush's foreign affairs advisers.

Mr Pickett was not listed in any secret service files as a threat, police sources said.

Neighbours in Evansville described him as an accountant, a friendly man and a frequent jogger. "I was really surprised. As far as I knew he was an outstanding neighbour," said one, Lewis Gates.

Last night, secret service agents searched Mr Pickett's home for firearms, threatening letters and evidence of involvement with militia groups.

Secret Service agent Jim Dennis said in the search warrant that aides to the Indiana congressman John Hostettler indicated that Mr Pickett had sent letters to his offices in the past year about grievances he had with the Internal Revenue Service.

Security at the White House was tightened during the Clinton era but the shooting incident is certain to lead to fresh examination of the terms on which the public has access.

Mr Bush has already been the subject of a variety of threats since he became president last month.

This week, an 18-year-old man in Wisconsin was jailed for threatening to kill him and last week, two boys from Staffordshire were questioned by Special Branch officers after sending a death threat in an email to the White House.

webTitle: Government to work with doctors over patients' information disclosure

fields.headline: Government to work with doctors over patients' information disclosure
fields.trailText: The government says it is prepared to work with doctors and patient groups to ensure that proposed new ministerial powers to disclose patient information without consent - described as "Orwellian" by critics - will not threaten patients' right to privacy.
fields.body:
The government says it is prepared to work with doctors and patient groups to ensure that proposed new ministerial powers to disclose patient information without consent - described as "Orwellian" by critics - will not threaten patients' right to privacy.

Under clause 59 of the health and social care bill, which is being scrutinised by a committee of MPs today, the secretary of state for health will be able to order such disclosure.

The British Medical Association has warned that it is unhappy that the bill gives such "sweeping" new powers to the minister, and has called for restrictions and safeguards to ensure these powers are not abused.

Ministers will not back down over the proposed new powers - they want to ensure that important medical research work, which is carried out in the public interest and which requires the use of confidential patient information, is not compromised.

But they will today attempt to placate critics by pledging to work closely with professional bodies to ensure that adequate safeguards are drawn up and to ensure that applications for use of patient information are rigorously tested, and scrutinised in parliament.

Health minister John Denham said: "While the government believes that informed consent for the use of confidential patient information should be obtained wherever possible, there are some situations where obtaining informed consent proves impractical and cannot be done.

"The bill will ensure that doctors can share patient information in such circumstances, if doing so will benefit patients and the public.

"Our prime objective is to safeguard existing practices, for example, cancer registries, which help to develop more effective treatments for cancer.

"Confidential patient information should only be used where there is a real need and where it is clearly in the interests of patients and the public, and, critically, only when there is no reasonable, practicable alternative."

Mr Denham said the proposed powers had the backing of the data protection commissioner, on the grounds that they would protect the interests of patients.

fields.headline: Channel 5 buys stake in gift website
fields.trailText: 2pm: Channel 5 has signed an airtime-for-equity deal with gift store surpriseyourwoman.com, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has signed an airtime-for-equity deal with online gift store surpriseyourwoman.com.

This is the fifth such deal the broadcaster has struck with a partner.

In return for providing the dot.com with £750,000 of free airtime, Channel 5 has taken an undisclosed minority stake in surpriseyourwoman.com.

The deal kicked off this week with a two-week advertising campaign on the channel.

Further activity is planned over the next five months, with up to two commercials appearing each evening.

Surpriseyourwoman.com launched in December and provides gift ideas for women.

The company is planning to launch surpriseyourman.com

Channel 5 has already signed airtime-for-equity deals with charity shopping site Free2give, competition site Cheekymonkey and travel site TheFirstResort.

Channel 5's first dot.com stake, in Rapidinsure, hit financial difficulties at the end of last year.

It was subsequently offloaded to finance and insurance specialist Berkeley Morgan for an undisclosed sum.

fields.headline: The451.com axes jobs
fields.trailText: 2pm: Technology news service The451.com has slashed 20% of its workforce, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Subscription-based technology news service The451.com has slashed 20% of its workforce amid rumours of the business being up for sale.

The451.com denied it was seeking an all-out sale but confirmed it was in talks with outside investors to raise additional financing.

In all, some 12 staff have been laid off, and 'bureaux' in Germany, Hong Kong and Sydney have been closed down.

Managing director David Massey said the company would now aim to generate sales of the £400-a-year information service in the UK and the US.

"This restructuring of our business combined with the strong sales pipeline will address our core areas more effectively and accelerate our path to profitability," he said.

As part of the realignment, a new sales director has been appointed in San Francisco to drive subscriptions.

Three of the redundancies are in the IT department and "a couple" of less high-profile journalists at the website have lost their jobs.

The451.com was launched last April by a number of national journalists, including Paul Taylor from the Financial Times and Dawn Hayes from Sunday Business.

The job losses and strategy rethink are aimed at reducing The451.com's monthly cash burn, reported to be around £200,000 per month.

The company, which is 62% owned by investment group Durlacher, still refuses to give out subscriber numbers but maintains it is meeting targets.

webTitle: Fugitive takes vacant place in Elf case

fields.headline: Fugitive takes vacant place in Elf case
fields.trailText: The key defendant in France's biggest post-war corruption trial was finally brought before judges in Paris yesterday, after managing to evade the police for four years.
fields.body:
The key defendant in France's biggest post-war corruption trial was finally brought before judges in Paris yesterday, after managing to evade the police for four years.

Alfred Sirven, 74, a one-time executive of previously state-owned oil company Elf Aquitaine, is accused of masterminding a multi-million pound slush fund.

Mr Sirven was arrested in the Philippines last week and made a brief appearance in court yesterday afternoon, when the presiding judge, Sophie Portier, suspended the sleaze trial in which he is a defendant until March 12 to give him more time to prepare his case.

She also ruled that he should remain in Paris's La Santé prison, where he has been held since early yesterday.

Mr Sirven has been on trial in Paris in absentia since January 22, a trial that has gripped France and drawn attention to corruption in the government during the presidency of François Mitterrand. Newspapers branded him " le grand absent " who cast a long shadow over the first two weeks of the Elf trial.

Also on trial are the former foreign minister Roland Dumas, 78, his former lover Christine Deviers-Joncour, 53, and four other former Elf executives. All are accused of siphoning off billions of pounds of public funds from Elf and living luxuriously on the proceeds, and trying to extend the firm's global influence through a network of dubious deals.

Mr Dumas is accused of forcing Elf to hire Ms Deviers-Joncour in a highly paid job with next to no duties.

All six have all claimed that they are happy that Mr Sirven will tell his side of the story in court, but they have spent much of the past fortnight insisting that he was responsible for the dubious dealings embroiling Elf in the late 80s and early 90s.

Mr Sirven may well damage their cases when he gives his explosive evidence next month. None the less, he was greeted warmly by the other defendants when he appeared in court. Ms Deviers-Joncour kissed him on both cheeks, Mr Dumas and the former Elf president Loik Le Floch-Prigent shook his hand.

Last week in court Mr Le Floch-Prigent, who hired Mr Sirven in 1989 and gave him responsibility for "general affairs" at Elf, accused Mr Sirven of having betrayed his confidence.

At his official retirement in 1991, Mr Sirven was put in charge of an Elf subsidiary in Geneva, Elf Aquitaine International. The newspaper Le Monde reported that he allegedly organised fictitious salaries for numerous "counsellors", some close to former political personalities on the left and right.

During the trial Mr Sirven has been accused of hiring Ms Deviers-Joncour, a former model, in order to woo Mr Dumas, President Mitterrand's foreign minister, and lure him into supporting the company's shady dealings. For this Mr Sirven is accused of providing Ms Deviers-Joncour with a £20,000-a-month credit line.

Mr Dumas is also charged with profiting from the money that the company gave his lover to lobby him about the controversial sale of six frigates to Taiwan by another state-controlled firm, Thompson, in 1991.

Mr Sirven was arrested on Friday at his luxury hideaway near Manila, where he had eluded Interpol for nearly four years. He was flown to Frankfurt and held there for four days.

Alfred Sirven, 74, a one-time executive of previously state-owned oil company Elf Aquitaine, is accused of masterminding a multi-million pound slush fund. Mr Sirven was arrested in the Philippines last week and made a brief appearance in court yesterday afternoon, when the presiding judge, Sophie Portier, suspended the sleaze trial in which he is a defendant until March 12 to give him more time to prepare his case. She also ruled that he should remain in Paris's La Santé prison, where he has been held since early yesterday. Mr Sirven has been on trial in Paris in absentia since January 22, a trial that has gripped France and drawn attention to corruption in the government during the presidency of François Mitterrand. Newspapers branded him " le grand absent " who cast a long shadow over the first two weeks of the Elf trial. Also on trial are the former foreign minister Roland Dumas, 78, his former lover Christine Deviers-Joncour, 53, and four other former Elf executives. All are accused of siphoning off billions of pounds of public funds from Elf and living luxuriously on the proceeds, and trying to extend the firm's global influence through a network of dubious deals. Mr Dumas is accused of forcing Elf to hire Ms Deviers-Joncour in a highly paid job with next to no duties.
