webTitle: Sharon rules out resuming peace talks

fields.headline: Sharon rules out resuming peace talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's newly elected prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has rejected Palestinian demands to resume peace talks where they left off with the outgoing administration of Ehud Barak.
fields.body:
Israel's newly elected prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has rejected Palestinian demands to resume peace talks where they left off with the outgoing administration of Ehud Barak.

Mr Sharon's diplomatic adviser, Zalman Shoval, said today that Mr Sharon had ruled out resuming negotiations with the Palestinians after they concluded last month in Taba, Egypt without a final peace deal.

"There was no accord concluded in Taba and what was discussed does not commit the government that Mr Sharon will form, as he said during the election campaign," Mr Shoval said.

The marathon talks in Taba, the most intensive since deadly Israeli-Palestinian violence exploded in September, ended without agreement on any of the key issues still dividing the two sides, although they said they were closer than ever to a deal.

"This government will only be held by signed accords," Mr Shoval said, referring in particular to the 1993 Oslo accords and further interim accords since in Wye River in the US and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

But Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erakat, echoing the views of the Palestinian leadership following a meeting late yesterday, said if Mr Sharon wants to resume the peace process it must be from where it was suspended by Mr Barak.

"There is no turning back, as Sharon would like to," he said.

Mr Erakat warned the new Israeli leader not to implement his political program, saying this would only complicate the situation.

Mr Shoval is due to lead a delegation to Washington next week to outline his peace policies to the new administration of the US president, George Bush.

Mr Sharon's Likud transition team is also due to begin intensive talks today with political allies and foes on the creation of a new government. Likud has only 19 seats in parliament and Mr Sharon is hoping to form a national unity government including members of Mr Barak's Labour party. That would give him enough seats to pass the 2001 budget by the March 31 deadline and stave off early general elections.

With its peace plan in tatters and its leader defeated at the polls, the Israeli Labour party is also trying to find a way forward.

Labour's elder statesmen, Nobel peace prize winner Shimon Peres, confirmed that he will not take over temporary leadership of the party following the resignation of Mr Barak. A bitter war of succession is raging and Mr Peres had been suggested by Labour members as interim leader until party primaries are held.

webTitle: BT boss named 'villain of the year'

fields.headline: BT boss named 'villain of the year'
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: BT boss Sir Peter Bonfield was last night named internet villain of the year, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BT boss Sir Peter Bonfield was named internet villain of the year at last night's Internet Service Providers' Awards.

Unable to collect his award in person, Sir Peter sent a stand-in who said he was delighted to "accept the award on behalf of Peter" and then launched into a sales pitch for BT's unmetered access service.

Ironically, BT had originally been a sponsor of the internet villain award until it saw the shortlist.

Oftel director general David Edmonds must have breathed a sigh of relief on hearing the news, as he had also been a strong contender for the award.

Mr Edmonds has been subject to cricitism by just about everyone last year, including the government, BT, the internet industry and even colleagues within Oftel.

The other new headline-grabbing award - internet hero - was always a foregone conclusion.

It was Tim Berners-Lee, father of the web, of course. Mr Berners-Lee couldn't be there on the night to collect his award so compere Ed Byrne collected it on his behalf.

The government's new e-envoy, the affable Andrew Pinder, made his first public engagement since news leaked of his appointment, and called on the internet industry to help him put together a government technology advisory board.

Confiding in MediaGuardian.co.uk, Mr Pinder said he'd had a busy week and didn't particularly relish the prospect of the busy schedule required of the e-envoy, since he'd already retired and made enough money from previous jobs to be comfortable.

One of his next public meetings will be in Seattle in a few weeks' time when he presses the flesh with Bill Gates.

Other ISPA award winners included the Internet Watch Foundation for the most positive contribution to the UK internet industry; Easynet for best European ISP; iWeb for its iNotes pop-up online advertising model; DooYoo.co.uk for best online consumer product; and Trinity Mirror's ICScotland for best consumer ISP.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Six of the best: Voting sites
fields.body:
Twisted
The 1st international Collection of Tongue Twisters claims to have assembled the world's largest collection at www.uebersetzung.at/twister . It now has 1,846 entries in 77 languages. As they say in Xhosa: Bu bula booshe bubekxa rubexa roola hoodie hoo (Sometimes when I'm lonely I like talking to feet that smell like horse potatoes). Graham Norton would love it.

Snappy stuff
Young photographers have a new showcase online, thanks to BT, which has just added a photography zone to its website at http://getoutthere.bt.com. Visitors will be able to upload pictures and win monthly prizes. The site already has sections for music, film and writing. Creative types will also enjoy the AccessArt site, which has just "gone national". The site is building a series of online workshops for teachers, students, and "life long learners" with the backing of the Department for Education and Employment.

Carnival time
Perhaps you have already planned your visit to the Venice Carnival this month or www.carnivalofvenice.com or www.venicemasquerade.com, or perhaps not. The people at Cityvox seem to have finished their multilingual guide to Venice in time.

The site was launched last April and the target is to cover 40 cities by the end of this month. However, coverage does not stretch to longhaul alternatives such as Trinidad, Rio or New Orleans.

Covered
You now have a month to vote for your favourite new book in the £45,000 WH Smith Book Awards. Well, the most likely winners are the five volumes the judges have shortlisted in eight categories, from fiction to business, but there are blank slots for those with particular passions. The winners will be announced on April 26.

Love match You may not know it but your ideal date is probably a giant anteater, as taking the quiz at www.londonzoo.co.uk may well reveal. Obviously you can't marry a spider, anteater or pygmy hippo (its parents would not approve), but you can at least adopt one. For more traditional Valentine's Day attractions, try http://valentinenet.com.

Gender
Would you prefer a white bedroom, or a blue one? Would you rather fall to your death or drown? Answer enough silly questions and Gender Test can, with a high degree of probability, tell whether you are a man or a woman. And the more people who take the test, the better it gets.

Finished? Go to the Spark home page to find out whether you are a slut, bitch or bastard, or pregnant. It also offers BurnMaker 2, which turns ordinary texts into "flame mail".

Xrefer
If you want to look something up, it is hard to resist Google, but Xrefer is a good place to get quick definitions. The site, launched last summer, includes 50 reference books, including The New Grove Dictionary of Jazz.

Facemail
The idea behind Facemail is that instead of reading letters you get an animated head to read them for you.In future, it should be possible to have the animated head based on your own photograph: a LifeFX Stand-In. At the moment, the choice is limited to five standard stand-ins. See www.lifefx.com/FaceOfTheInternet/pgInit.html/6nations are also covering the event in depth, while Sky is running a fantasy version at www.sky.com/games/6nations .

New & noted
 Amnesty International is campaigning against torture at www.stoptorture.org.
 The Lockerbie verdict can be downloaded from www.scotcourts.gov.uk/html/lockerbie.htm.
 Levi's Vintage Clothing: see the reel thing at www.vintage.levi.com.
 The Doll's House is back with two new dolls, Tara and Rebekah: www.bravo.co.uk/newdolls/.
 Anti-Microsoft joke: www.geocities.com/rcwoolley.

webTitle: A mobile failure waiting to happen

fields.headline: A mobile failure waiting to happen
fields.standfirst: Simon Rockman warns the third generation mobile vision could crash to earth just like the $7bn Iridium satellite project
fields.trailText: Simon Rockman warns the third generation mobile vision could crash to earth just like the $7bn Iridium satellite project
fields.body:
As storm-clouds gather over the telecoms market, the peddlers of "third- generation" futurology should be looking to the example set by the eleventh-hour rescue of the doomed satellite network, Iridium.

With a £22 billion debt owed for third-generation licences in the UK alone, and nothing but a portfolio of concept pictures to substantiate the dream, the hype surrounding the 3G Universal Mobile Telephony System (UMTS) demands considerable suspension of disbelief. The same leap of faith was demanded by Iridium, which cost $7 billion to set up, went belly-up and was "saved" in a deal that valued it at a mere $25 million, sweetened by a $72 million contract from the US government. You could see it as a net value of minus $47 million. The alternative was to burn the satellites by crashing them through the earth's atmosphere. It might have been cheaper in the long run.

It's amazing that anyone could have got their sums so wrong. And what is more amazing is that it is about to happen again. The 3G licence debt is already starting to hurt. The mobile networks are finding it hard to borrow money to build the infrastructure they need.

The mobile phone business is hugely profitable. Ten years ago, the mobile was a joke prop in films about Wall Street wealth. Now, there are 700 million GSM phones in use across the world. Each customer spends about £30 a month. It is not surprising that Iridium thought it could make money: it needed less than 1% of the world market to do well.

Where there is a lot of money there is a lot of competition. The rivalry of mobile telecoms, however, is restricted by physics and legislation. Here we have a lucrative, legislated oligopoly. No wonder so many people want a part of it. That's why the UK 3G licences sold for so much. A second reason was that the incumbent networks could see that if they didn't buy a licence they were going to go out of business. The licences effectively became worth as much as the individual companies so long as the sixth bidder kept playing. It's possible that with only three licences, the prices would have gone even higher.

With each network having spent upwards of £4 billion on a bit of paper - just to gain the right to spend as much again in constructing a new national network - the 3G market is going to have to be worth nearly 10 times the cost of GSM. It is hard to see where the money is going to come from to do this. There won't be 10 times as many users. That would mean five phones per person in the UK, from the babe in the pushchair to the geriatric in a bathchair. It is possible that we'll see more than one GSM connection per person as the real futurology starts and the technology starts to get built into devices like vending machines and cars. But 500% penetration is asking too much.

And frankly, will anyone want to use it at all? That was where Iridium went wrong. While Iridium projected over a million users, it achieved only 100,000. There were a lot of problems: coverage problems, frightening prices, great big ugly handsets. All these problems will be revisited with 3G.

Iridium didn't - sorry, doesn't - work indoors. It was based on dual mode handsets, which could use either the ordinary GSM mobile phone network or, for trips further afield, the Iridium satellite network. You had islands of GSM coverage in a sea of Iridium.

Today third generation coverage is being talked about in terms of islands of UMTS in a sea of GSM. Again, we will have dual mode handsets to use the existing GSM coverage, and only switch into 3G in those areas where it is installed. You'll pay a premium for a phone which won't even deliver 3G benefits for a lot of the time.

Quite how much you will pay is yet to be discovered. It is impossible to guess what a handset will cost, but an existing GSM phone has a bill of materials of around $90. This gives a sensible retail price of £180, less a £150 network subsidy common in the UK market, to sell for £30. The low bill of materials is very much down to the economies of scale.

Mobile phone manufacturers, selling into a world market, expect to sell a million handsets over the life of the phone before they turn on the production line. New entrant Sendo, which prides itself on its efficiency, boasts that it only needs to sell 500,000 handsets over several designs to break even.

Those economies of scale will not exist for third generation. What's more, the components will be much more expensive. It is rash to speculate, but a $900 bill of materials might be conservative. The phones will do a lot more. They will have colour screens and a lot of memory. They will also need to feel like a premium product. Subsidising this down to £30 will not be realistic, so the quantities drop and the price goes up.

Traditionally prices would be recouped through call charges, but in the middle of a long-running tariff war there isn't much scope for a premium rate service. Some early adopters might pay a bit more than the typical 15p a minute peak rate, but the mass market is focused on bundled inclusive airtime, with many peripheral services coming in for free. Orange is currently offering free Wap calls at the weekend, Genie flat rate text messaging and One 2 One free voicemail. Selling premium rate services against this, even if the coverage were not patchy, would be nigh on impossible.

The final blow is the unbridgeable gap between selling the concept and facing up to the reality. Concept photos of proposed 3G phones show slimline, sleek models the size of a powder-compact. The pictures bear little or no relation to the handsets that will really be available to early adopters, which are likely to be clunky and ugly, with a poor battery life, heat problems and unimpressive screens.

The technical require ments for 3G are horribly complicated, which means you need a lot of computing power, which in turn bumps up not only the cost but the size of the battery. We could see the new phones drawing something like 50 times as much power as an existing one.

This means third generation phones are going to need enormous batteries by today's standards. Some manufacturers argue that between now and the launch of the first third generation systems in two years, we'll see the improvements necessary to get handset sizes down to be comparable with today's GSM, that's around 100g. This seems incredibly optimistic, particularly given the probable lack of demand.

So the target customers become people prepared to pay a premium for big clunky handsets that occasionally give better performance than their elegant GSM one. The next stage will be for the networks to argue that typical customers will have two handsets: a GSM one for everyday and a third generation one for when they need it. Again this was an Iridium argument.

There is a further problem which didn't affect Iridium: too many handset manufacturers looking for a piece of the pie. There are around 20 mobile phone manufacturers with even more companies eyeing third generation. They all want to be the next Nokia, so they will fight for market share by selling phones at a loss. For the first time, the Japanese manufacturers become a real threat. Until now, Japan has largely missed out on GSM, because it was never launched in Japan. So Scandinavia got to rule the roost.

Things will be different in the third generation. Japan launches its 3G commercial service well before the rest - 2001, as opposed to 2003 in the UK. And it will be in demand. In Japan, the capacity problems we have seen recently on UK networks are increased many times over, because there is a more limited spectrum allocation on the PHS system used there. This means expansion of the existing networks is not an option. Instead, 3G is the solution. So the Japanese market will have a need for 3G that we don't have here, where networks are expanding their capacity into alternative spectrum.

Visible demand will give the Japanese manufacturers more room to manoeuvre. The established order of Nokia leading, followed by Motorola and Ericsson, is severely under threat. The only Western company to have grasped this is Siemens. Currently dicing with Ericsson for third spot and with an excellent product portfolio, Siemens has looked to the future. An infrastructure deal with NEC and a handset deal with Casio will give Siemens an entry into the Japanese market. The Japanese partners can learn a lot from Siemens today, and in a couple of years Siemens will reap the rewards when it is an experienced manufacturer of third generation handsets. Whether even this is profitable remains to be seen.

It is not surprising that Iridium thought it could make money: it needed less than 1% of the world market to do well. Where there is a lot of money there is a lot of competition. The rivalry of mobile telecoms, however, is restricted by physics and legislation. Here we have a lucrative, legislated oligopoly. No wonder so many people want a part of it. That's why the UK 3G licences sold for so much. A second reason was that the incumbent networks could see that if they didn't buy a licence they were going to go out of business. The licences effectively became worth as much as the individual companies so long as the sixth bidder kept playing. It's possible that with only three licences, the prices would have gone even higher. With each network having spent upwards of £4 billion on a bit of paper - just to gain the right to spend as much again in constructing a new national network - the 3G market is going to have to be worth nearly 10 times the cost of GSM. It is hard to see where the money is going to come from to do this. There won't be 10 times as many users. That would mean five phones per person in the UK, from the babe in the pushchair to the geriatric in a bathchair. It is possible that we'll see more than one GSM connection per person as the real futurology starts and the technology starts to get built into devices like vending machines and cars. But 500% penetration is asking too much. And frankly, will anyone want to use it at all? That was where Iridium went wrong. While Iridium projected over a million users, it achieved only 100,000. There were a lot of problems: coverage problems, frightening prices, great big ugly handsets. All these problems will be revisited with 3G. Iridium didn't - sorry, doesn't - work indoors. It was based on dual mode handsets, which could use either the ordinary GSM mobile phone network or, for trips further afield, the Iridium satellite network. You had islands of GSM coverage in a sea of Iridium. Today third generation coverage is being talked about in terms of islands of UMTS in a sea of GSM. Again, we will have dual mode handsets to use the existing GSM coverage, and only switch into 3G in those areas where it is installed. You'll pay a premium for a phone which won't even deliver 3G benefits for a lot of the time. Quite how much you will pay is yet to be discovered. It is impossible to guess what a handset will cost, but an existing GSM phone has a bill of materials of around $90. This gives a sensible retail price of £180, less a £150 network subsidy common in the UK market, to sell for £30. The low bill of materials is very much down to the economies of scale. Mobile phone manufacturers, selling into a world market, expect to sell a million handsets over the life of the phone before they turn on the production line. New entrant Sendo, which prides itself on its efficiency, boasts that it only needs to sell 500,000 handsets over several designs to break even. Those economies of scale will not exist for third generation. What's more, the components will be much more expensive. It is rash to speculate, but a $900 bill of materials might be conservative. The phones will do a lot more. They will have colour screens and a lot of memory. They will also need to feel like a premium product. Subsidising this down to £30 will not be realistic, so the quantities drop and the price goes up. Traditionally prices would be recouped through call charges, but in the middle of a long-running tariff war there isn't much scope for a premium rate service. Some early adopters might pay a bit more than the typical 15p a minute peak rate, but the mass market is focused on bundled inclusive airtime, with many peripheral services coming in for free. Orange is currently offering free Wap calls at the weekend, Genie flat rate text messaging and One 2 One free voicemail. Selling premium rate services against this, even if the coverage were not patchy, would be nigh on impossible. The final blow is the unbridgeable gap between selling the concept and facing up to the reality. Concept photos of proposed 3G phones show slimline, sleek models the size of a powder-compact. The pictures bear little or no relation to the handsets that will really be available to early adopters, which are likely to be clunky and ugly, with a poor battery life, heat problems and unimpressive screens. The technical require ments for 3G are horribly complicated, which means you need a lot of computing power, which in turn bumps up not only the cost but the size of the battery. We could see the new phones drawing something like 50 times as much power as an existing one. This means third generation phones are going to need enormous batteries by today's standards. Some manufacturers argue that between now and the launch of the first third generation systems in two years, we'll see the improvements necessary to get handset sizes down to be comparable with today's GSM, that's around 100g. This seems incredibly optimistic, particularly given the probable lack of demand. So the target customers become people prepared to pay a premium for big clunky handsets that occasionally give better performance than their elegant GSM one. The next stage will be for the networks to argue that typical customers will have two handsets: a GSM one for everyday and a third generation one for when they need it. Again this was an Iridium argument. There is a further problem which didn't affect Iridium: too many handset manufacturers looking for a piece of the pie. There are around 20 mobile phone manufacturers with even more companies eyeing third generation. They all want to be the next Nokia, so they will fight for market share by selling phones at a loss. For the first time, the Japanese manufacturers become a real threat. Until now, Japan has largely missed out on GSM, because it was never launched in Japan. So Scandinavia got to rule the roost. Things will be different in the third generation. Japan launches its 3G commercial service well before the rest - 2001, as opposed to 2003 in the UK. And it will be in demand. In Japan, the capacity problems we have seen recently on UK networks are increased many times over, because there is a more limited spectrum allocation on the PHS system used there. This means expansion of the existing networks is not an option. Instead, 3G is the solution. So the Japanese market will have a need for 3G that we don't have here, where networks are expanding their capacity into alternative spectrum. Visible demand will give the Japanese manufacturers more room to manoeuvre. The established order of Nokia leading, followed by Motorola and Ericsson, is severely under threat. The only Western company to have grasped this is Siemens. Currently dicing with Ericsson for third spot and with an excellent product portfolio, Siemens has looked to the future. An infrastructure deal with NEC and a handset deal with Casio will give Siemens an entry into the Japanese market. The Japanese partners can learn a lot from Siemens today, and in a couple of years Siemens will reap the rewards when it is an experienced manufacturer of third generation handsets. Whether even this is profitable remains to be seen.

fields.headline: Hunt lobby adverts withdrawn
fields.trailText: Controversial pro-hunting adverts were taken down after sites were vandalised and shopping centres flooded with complaints. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A controversial pro-hunting campaign has had to be withdrawn after advertising sites were vandalised and shopping centres were flooded with complaints.

The Countryside Alliance last month launched the series of adverts to try to drum up support in rural areas ahead of a demonstration next month.

"We are absolutely furious about this," said a spokesman for the alliance.

"They were removed without reference to us after the advertising agency found they had been trashed.

"While we accept that the company acted responsibly, we believe this is a serious infringement of our right to free speech and we will not take it lying down," he added.

One advert showed a picture of an attractive young girl alongside the words, "Hi, my name is scum", in an attempt to show that hunters did not fit the traditional stereotype.

The advertising went up in shopping centres around the country. But Admedia, the company that leases the sites, this week took down the adverts after shopping centre bosses customers complained and many of them were destroyed.

"The trouble with putting up an adverts like that in a shopping centre is that anyone can see it and they might be offended - it's not like putting it in a magazine where you know who the readers are," said a spokesman for Admedia

"The shopping centres received a number of complaints from the public and asked us to take the ads down, which we have now done," he added.

The alliance now plans to run the ads in local papers and is looking at other ways of getting them into the public eye.

"The whole point of this campaign was to fight prejudice and not to incite it," said the spokesman. "We will go on trying to do that."

webTitle: Strong cast, Good Book, big hit

fields.headline: Strong cast, Good Book, big hit
fields.trailText: The plot of a film which opened this week in hundreds of US cinemas, has already set box-office records, and is being heralded as a way for evangelical Christianity to tackle Hollywood on its home ground
fields.body:
The UN general secretary is the anti-christ who comes from Russia and has taken over the world. The true believers in Christ have been gathered up and taken to heaven and non-believers must now suffer for the seven years.

That is the plot of a film which opened this week in hundreds of US cinemas, has already set box-office records, and is being heralded as a way for evangelical Christianity to tackle Hollywood on its home ground.

Left Behind: the Movie was released after a huge campaign by US evangelists to persuade cinema chains to show such films on the big screen.

It coincided with the inauguration of a born-again president who was generously funded by the religious right, which now senses a new cultural mood in the country.

Left Behind was produced by Cloud Ten, a Toronto company owned by Peter and Paul Lalonde, and originally released as a video last year. It sold 2.5m copies, prompting the plan to press cinemas to show it.

A sophisticated email write-in campaign which drew on the estimated 75m evangelical community persuaded distributors that the film was likely to do well.

It is now on show at 900 cinemas, an extraordinary achievement for an independent film by any standards but even more remarkable for one that had sold so well on video.

Churches have also helped by giving away tickets.

Starring Kirk Cameron - best known for his role in the 1980s sitcom Growing Pains - and Chelsea Noble, the film takes its theme from The Revelation of St John, the most popular book the bible for many fundamentalists.

It shows the world taken over by evil forces, embodied in the UN, always a bete noir of the religious right.

While Christians are gathered up to heaven in "the rapture", others must spend a period of penance on Earth suffering under a character called Nicolae Carpathia, whose accent shows that he is Russian.

The new evangelical feature films go well beyond traditional fare with a religious theme, such as The Ten Commandments and Ben Hur.

They are partly based on the success of the series of novels on which Left Behind is based. Such books have become bestsellers with little or no marketing or reviews in the literary pages of newspapers.

Previous successes on the apocalyptic theme include The Omega Code, which came out in 1999 and will be followed soon by a sequel, Megiddo - Omega Code II.

The Omega Code, marketed as "the film that shook up Hollywood", starred Michael York, Casper Van Dien (Starship Troopers), Michael Ironside and Catherine Oxenberg. Time magazine called it "the Blair God Project".

Another Christian film, The Champion, about a boxer, is due out next month.

Distributors hope to exploit what they believe is a vast audience anxious to see such movies on the big screen.

With an actors' and writers' strike in the offing in Hollywood this summer, producers of such films will also be eyeing the possibility of advancing into more cinemas with their product.

"This is a very large niche market I think the studios have missed," Peter Lalonde of Cloud Ten Pictures said.

"We can create a grassroots army on behalf of this film."

His claim is backed up by Christiancinema.com, a website listing 100-plus titles.

Most of these films were made on small budgets, but the new Omega Code and Left Behind both had about £12m, the sort of sum a major independent production enjoys.

Not all of the themes are so doomladen. World Wide Pictures, part of the Billy Graham Evangelistic Association, is releasing a comedy called Road to Redemption.

If films like this continue to succeed, the big Hollywood studios are likely to want to get in on the biblical act, too.

In recent years Hollywood has been attacked for presenting a Godless picture of American life, and both George Bush and Al Gore referred in the election campaigns to a desire to clamp down on un acceptable images of violence.

Senior Hollywood executives were summoned to Washington to give evidence to the Senate commerce committee on the marketing of violent material to under-age children. The industry was effectively warned to clean up its act or face possible legislation.

Religious groups have attacked what they see as blasphemy in mainstream movies, running from Monty Python's The Life of Brian to last year's release Dogma, in which God was portrayed on the screen as a black woman.

webTitle: Man injured in Northern Ireland blast

fields.headline: Man injured in Northern Ireland blast
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText:
A construction worker was injured in an explosion in Northern Ireland today as the RUC investigated renewed bomb attacks by loyalist terrorists.

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.body:
The man was hit by a blast after opening the cab door of a digger at a building site at Moygashel, near Dungannon, Co Tyrone. Police said the victim was treated in Craigavon Area hospital for "superficial injuries".

The cause of the blast has not yet been established, but police said an Army bomb disposal team had been alerted.

The explosion happened just hours after bomb attacks on the houses of Roman Catholic families in Dungannon and at Limavady, Co Londonderry. No one was hurt.

The main Belfast-Dublin rail line was also closed near Newry, Co Down after reports of an explosion close to the Irish border, where dissident republicans opposed to the Good Friday Agreement have been active.

With the number of loyalist attacks now at 44 since the start of the year, Sinn Fein officials met representatives of the Irish government in Dublin today to discuss a sectarian terror campaign which is spreading at a tense and difficult time in the Northern Ireland peace process.

There is also a fear republicans could retaliate. British and Irish officials held more talks today in a bid to end the deadlock on decommissioning, demilitarisation and policing.

But none of the political parties are holding out much hope of a breakthrough in advance of important Ulster Unionist party meetings in Belfast tomorrow and Saturday, when the UUP leader, David Trimble, the first minister at Stormont, could face fresh demands to impose more sanctions on Sinn Fein or even pull out of the power-sharing executive at Stormont.

With the nationalist SDLP calling for some sort of security summit, police chiefs are under increasing pressure to make arrests.

The east Londonderry Ulster Unionist MP, William Ross, said he was confident that those coordinating the attacks would be brought to justice. But he warned: "These are absolutely lethal devices and it is only a matter of time before someone is killed if this goes on."

fields.headline: FT appoints Manning-Cooper to key marketing role
fields.trailText: 12pm: The Financial Times Group has appointed its first ever head of group marketing communications, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Financial Times Group has appointed its first ever head of group marketing communications, Joanna Manning-Cooper, as part of a department restructure.

Ms Manning-Cooper joins from Shandwick International where she was an associate board director.

S"This is the first time the FT Group has engaged a communications head to oversee an integrated strategy across all external and internal communications for the group," said Ms Manning-Cooper.

"The purpose of my role is to integrate a communications and marketing strategy to form a matrix structure across the various departments."

She will report to marketing director Barry Herstein in London on consumer issues and to John Fallon, president of FT Group's parent company, Pearson Inc, on corporate matters.

She previously worked for technology company GTech and as a government press officer.

The restructure of FT Group's communications department sees Anouskha Healy promoted to head of newspaper PR and group PR manager.

Ms Healy has spent five years handling UK PR and international communications at the company. She will report to FT global marketing director Gordon Willoughby.

fields.headline: One2One offers free text messages
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: One2One is launching a mobile phone package boasting free text messages as part of a shake-up of call tariffs, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
One 2 One is launching a mobile phone package boasting free text messages, Text & Talk, as part of a widescale shake-up of its call tariffs.

The mobile network operator is also introducing a range of flat rate monthly mobile packages following the launch of its first all-in product, Precept Max, giving unlimited calls for £75 a month.

One2One is to launch a generic advertising campaign within the next month to promote the new pay monthly call packages.

The move suggests One2One intends to wean customers off pay-as-you-go packages onto "all-in" monthly contracts. The move could be followed by the other three operators - Vodafone, BTCellnet and Orange.

Because the heavily subsidised pre-pay customers buy vouchers to top up their call time, the company has no billing relationship with the user and cannot market other products and services to them.

Monthly contract customers are far more valuable.

The operator wants to shift the emphasis of its business strategy from acquiring customers to building its base of contract customers, says a spokesman, but insists pre-pay will not be phased out.

Pre-pay customers have driven the surge in mobile users over the past two years - representing 77% of One2One's 8.3m customers.

The new Talk & Text plan includes 50 text messages and 500 minutes of off-peak local and national calls a month for £15.

As an incentive to customers to sign up for pay monthly contracts, those who connect to the One2One network until April 30 will also receive 50 free text messages per month for three months, although the free quota can only be sent to other One2One numbers.

fields.headline: Bates resigns from Wembley board
fields.trailText: Chelsea chairman Ken Bates has kept the controvesry surrounding the new Wembley ticking over by resigning from the board of Wembley National Stadium Limited. In a typically forthright resignation letter, he also criticises his fellow board members and the FA.
fields.body:
Chelsea chairman Ken Bates has kept the controvesry surrounding the new Wembley ticking over by resigning from the board of Wembley National Stadium Limited. In a typically forthright resignation letter, he also criticises his fellow board members and the FA.

Bates was replaced as chairman of WNSL by Sir Rodney Walker in December, after FA chief executive Adam Crozier stepped in to assume a more hands-on role in the project amid concerns over costs and delays. Bates became vice-chairman but was then attacked by sports minister Kate Hoey for his role in the saga.

In his letter, Bates outlines his reasons for ending his involvement with the company responsible for the redevelopment of the stadium. He said: "I acquired Wembley for the FA and made a substantial operating profit ... despite having inherited a lacklustre, leaderless management."

But, according to Bates, a "sustained press campaign undermined both the project itself and my own credibility".

He continued: "We know a considerable part of it came from Kate Hoey and her lackeys. But it is also clear that a lot came from within the Football Association itself.

"It was quite disgraceful that not one single person on either board stood up to publicly defend the project and my position. Even Jesus Christ suffered only one Pontius Pilate - I had a whole team of them.

"It would take another four years of my life to complete the project and, after careful consideration, I have decided I do not want to spend it working with people, a number of whom I neither trust nor respect.

"I therefore resign from the board of WNSL with immediate effect."

webTitle: So close to peace, so far away

fields.headline: So close to peace, so far away
fields.trailText: "I hit bottom - but then I heard somebody tapping from underneath." A good many Israeli voters began their lives in Poland. Before this week's prime ministerial election, they may have recalled that Polish one-liner.
fields.body:
"I hit bottom - but then I heard somebody tapping from underneath." A good many Israeli voters began their lives in Poland. Before this week's prime ministerial election, they may have recalled that Polish one-liner.

By the end of December, it seemed that Israel's plight could hardly get worse. The most ambitious of all peace plans, offered by an Israeli leader who had run on a platform of concessions and withdrawals and been elected by a landslide, had failed. This left the Palestinians even less approachable. On top of that, the second intifada had broken out last September.

But, it turns out, Israel has further to fall. Ariel Sharon, barring some miracle, will be elected prime minister this week. How will the world live with Sharon's Israel - including the thousands of Israelis who are appalled at his irresistible rise? To them he is no mellow veteran. He is a killer who led the mass murder of Palestinian civilians at Qibya in 1953, and permitted (if he did not actually order) the massacre of Palestinian refugees in the Sabra and Chatila camps in 1982. They ask why General Ratko Mladic is treated as a war criminal while Sharon is honoured as a statesman.

In less than a year Israel has slithered from the last ridge before peace all the way down to the bunkers. One reason is what Sharon did on a fateful September day, when he strode on to the sacred ground of the Haram al-Sharif in Jerusalem.

He knew that he would provoke Muslim violence. And he did that to look bolder than his rival for the Likud leadership, Binyamin Netanyahu. He probably did not expect that five months later Jews and Arabs would still be shooting each other dead every day. But he did know that Palestinian radicals planned a second intifada, and he touched it off. As a direct consequence, 380 people have been killed, 51 of them Israeli Jews.

The longer explanation for the slither is the weakness of the peace process - and of its players. In 1999 Ehud Barak came to power promising settlements with Lebanon, Syria and the Palestinians within 15 months. South Lebanon was evacuated, but talks with the Palestinians faltered and then seized up. Even though Barak hinted at sharing Jerusalem - something unimaginable even a year before - Yasser Arafat turned him down.

A weak adversary can be more dangerous than a strong one. The fatal flaw in Israel's 1993 Oslo agreement with the Palestinians was that Arafat carried only some Palestinians with him - and that Israelis thought that his loss was their gain. They should have built him up into a Nehru or Mandela, someone who could crush his rivals and make deals that would stick. Instead, they sabotaged all his efforts to win control of his own community. A confident Arafat would have snapped up Barak's bargain. A weak Arafat could only refuse.

Some people expect the apocalypse when Sharon takes power. Others find scraps of hope. One scrap is the saying that it is easier for an extreme rightwinger to make concessions than for a liberal. Ronald Reagan, not Jimmy Carter, agreed to end the cold war.

On the surface there is no sign that Sharon, at 72, will recognise a Palestinian state or dismantle Israeli settlements. His rhetoric is about no surrender, and force as the only language "they" understand. The best hope is that he might save Israel from another Middle Eastern war. And yet all Israeli leaders betray their most devoted followers when new chances appear. Why should Sharon differ?

The chances are there. Sharon hints that he might form a coalition government with Barak and his veteran Labour colleague Shimon Peres, with a cabinet strong enough to perform a u-turn. And the need for the turn is desperate.

Since the end of the cold war there is no Soviet Union to seduce Syria or rape Lebanon. The Americans are not about to drop Israel. But there is now a price for protection that once came free, and that price is an Israeli will to heal the wound.

There is an easy way and a hard way for Israel. But there is no other way. The Observer

fields.headline: A-list stars shun PCC party
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: Royalty mingled with a host of soap and light-entertainment 'celebrities' at last night's celebration, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Feb 8: Securing a prince's privacy
Feb 8: The PCC's greatest hits
fields.body:
There were 400 stars on the guest list but in the end it looked like a joint venture between the Press Complaints Commission's Guy Black and Dame Sallie Ryle from Granada TV.

Not only did she guarantee a coachload of escapees from the Coronation Street set, she was also responsible for the presence of virtually every other "star" at the 10th anniversary party.

These included Richard and Judy from LWT (a Granada company); the delectable Carol Vorderman and Richard Whitely from Yorkshire TV (also a Granada company); Jane Danson, star of A&E (a Granada production) and her boyfriend Robert Beck, star of Emmerdale (a Granada production).

Ms Ryle's pals the Bransons were there too.

But the absence of a pantheon of A-list celebs left the two that did show up - Donatella Versace and her permatan - looking utterly lost.

The Labour party didn't make the effort to turn up either - Tony Blair sent his apologies.

But the government's absence was surely compensated for by the appearance of Tory Peter Bottomley, who arrived clutching a copy of the left-wing Tribune newspaper.

Anna Friel was another absentee.

Her management phoned earlier in the day just to "double check" which celebrities were definitely attending.

Camilla Parker Bowles, who kept at least 10 paces away from Prince Charles, looked relaxed in the company of the press.

However, she did complain the atmposphere was "a bit stuffy".

Selina Scott did make it however - and a minor royal was present in the form of the Duke of York.

The galaxy of TV stars and sycophantic journalists was enough to keep Prince William amused.

However, he didn't recognise Independent on Sunday editor Janet Street Porter.

She thrust her hand forward for a royal handshake, only to withdraw it as the prince turned to speak to someone he did recognise - Joanna Lumley.

The alluring Ms Vorderman was the belle of the ball.

And if Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre hadn't left so early, there may have been something other than her frosted-pink frock to report on.

She was desperate to meet him to give him a piece of her mind, following the paper's reports on her love affair with Mirror sports editor Des Kelly.

Dacre v Vorderman in a celebrity death match would have been a sight to behold.

webTitle: In brief: Tolkien tie-ins to include computer game

fields.headline: Tolkien tie-ins to include computer game
fields.standfirst: Plus: Halle Berry's secret marriage out in the open; A-Team to blast onto big screen; teen movie spoof to be called Teen Movie
fields.trailText: Plus: Halle Berry's secret marriage out in the open; A-Team to blast onto big screen; teen movie spoof to be called Teen Movie
fields.body:
 The nerd contingent of the Lord of the Rings fan club will be cheered to hear that Games Workshop, purveyors of massively successful tabletop role-playing game Warhammer, will be devising similar gaming fun to tie in with the release of the Tolkien trilogy in cinemas. With the film of Dungeon & Dragons hitting the UK this month, it seems that old-school fantasy is back, 12-sided dice and all.

 The hitherto eligible Halle Berry discombobulated guests at the launch of her new website by casually introducing fiancé Eric Benét as her "husband". Mr Showbiz reports that though rumours of the wedding had been circulating all day, Mrs Benét's surprise tactics took the room unawares and that the stealth wedding had taken place two weeks earlier somewhere "exotic". Mr Benét, incidentally, is an acclaimed jazz musician.

 Kevin Brodbin has been hired to write a script for a remake of Saturday afternoon kids' favourite The A-Team, with a brief that requires him "to transform the cult TV series into an action-comedy film with a contemporary feel." As Ananova notes, the writer has stayed true to the A-Team's style in his previous work, most "prominently" as scribe on Steven Seagal's The Glimmer Man. The movie is due out in 2002, so expect entertaining-but-harmless explosions, protestations that "I ain't getting on no plane, sucka!", bad disguises and people building tanks out of old drainpipes around about then.

 Dark Horizons reports that the film formerly known as Ten Things I Hate About Clueless Roadtrips When I Can't Hardly Wait to Be Kissed has undergone a name snip to: Teen Movie. Doubtless, this is following in the vein of Scary Movie, downsized from Scream If You Know What I Did Last Halloween. Movies getting a satirical hose-down in the new film include Cruel Intentions, Bring it On and the forthcoming Save the Last Dance.

fields.headline: A life inside
fields.standfirst: Scars that never heal and men you hope never to meet again
fields.trailText: Scars that never heal and men you hope never to meet again
fields.body:
"Any movement yet guv?" I was standing in the open doorway of the wing office. Mr Turnlock, our brusque and efficient landing officer was on the phone. Twenty minutes earlier there had been a "general alarm". I thought I knew the reason why. The orderly who delivers the newspapers from the library had told me. Mr Turnlock finished talking and replaced the handset.

"What is it?" he said. "Er, any movement yet?" I repeated, "the stabbing . . ."

"What stabbing?" he said.

"The paper orderly said there had been a stabbing on one of the wings and that was why movement had been stopped."

"Rubbish," said Mr Turnlock. "You see how rumours erupt in these places? Movement was stopped because an old chap collapsed outside the chapel. It started back up again 10 minutes ago."

"Oh," I said, "right."

Feeling foolish, I left the wing and made my way towards the exercise yard. Mr Turnlock was right. After all these years I should have known better than to believe the worst without question. But tensions had been running a little high in the jail. A week earlier a man had been attacked by another wielding a lino cutting blade fixed into a piece of dowling. The home-made weapon had been thrust into the victim's face with such force that the steel edge had ploughed a deep furrow across the bones of his cheek and jaw. The resulting 40 stitches made it look as if he had been flung face first through a car window screen.

I spoke to him briefly in the healthcare centre a few days later when I was up making an appointment to see the dentist. It was the worst chibbing I had ever seen.

I didn't know the scarred man, but coincidentally I had spoken to him once before. It was a couple of days after his arrival last September and we were browsing the same bookshelf in the library. He asked me what the prison was like. "Relatively quiet," I told him. Unimpressed, he began dropping names of reputed tough-guy prisoners he had allegedly already done time with - "faces" in the system.

The conversation was beginning to bore me until I heard him mention the name "Braggs." "Who?" I said, startled, "Donny Braggs?" "No," he said, "his son, Joe. Donny Braggs is dead." "You're kidding," I said. I pressed him for details. It was important to be sure we were talking about the same man. Satisfied we were, I asked him what had happened. "He was stabbed in the leg in a nightclub," he said. "Gangrene set in and it killed him." "Christ," I said, and sighed a deep sigh.

Thirteen years had passed but I had never forgotten my run-in with Donny Braggs. We were on the same wing at the time. Donny was "on the book" (Category A prisoner) and was known for his short temper. One sleepy-eyed Monday morning I bumped into him outside my cell door with my breakfast tray. Immediately he began ranting and hurling abuse. His racket was drawing dozens of pairs of eyes in our direction so I implored him to come into my cell. "The screws will be on us in a minute." I said, "Come on, I'll make us a cup of tea."

He followed me in, but straight away recommenced his tirade. He was becoming hysterical. Realising I had made a mistake I grabbed the front of his shirt, intending to shove him back outside. Instead Donny wrong footed me and swung me around full circle. He reached up behind his head with his right hand and suddenly I felt a stabbing blow in the corner of my left eye. He must have seen my cutlery in a cup on the shelf which was behind me before pulling me around. Luckily the knife he grabbed was only made of plastic.

Other stinging blows to my scalp and face followed before instinct caused me to drop my head and unwittingly crash it against the bridge of his nose. Donny fled, bleeding, from the cell.

We never resolved that conflict. He was shipped out a couple of days later for threatening a prison officer - I explained my swollen eye and the weals on my face by fibbing that I had "collided with someone while jogging".

Over the years I often thought about Donny. The prison system is a small world and I couldn't help wondering if and when there would be another confrontation. God knows if he ever thought about me. Although I'm ashamed to admit it, I felt relieved when I learned of his demise.

On reflection, perhaps it was not so foolish after all to have believed the worst from the library orderly. One thing I'm sure of though - for a long time to come, whenever the young man with the scars hears that "movement has been stopped" he'll be minded to believe the worst without question. And it will be the most natural thing in the world.

 Erwin James is serving a life sentence. He will not be paid for this article.

fields.headline: Exorcist prequel greenlighted
fields.trailText: The prequel to one of the most famous horror films of all time will focus on an earlier clash between the priest and the demon who did battle in The Exorcist
fields.body:
Squeezing the final drops of bile out of The Exorcist's commercial potential, a prequel to William Friedkin's seminal 70s horror film has been given the go-ahead. However, the writer of the original novel William Peter Blatty has already slammed the projected prequel.

IMDb.com reports that The Exorcist: Dominion is to enter production from a script by novelist Caleb Carr who is also being slated to direct the project. The story will focus on an earlier battle between the demon Pazuzu and Father Merrin (played by Max von Sydow in the original) while he was working in Africa as a missionary.

It is not yet known who will play the priest, but a casting call has been made for a 10-14-year-old boy, presumably for the role of the demon's unlucky host.

The Exorcist has had two sequels, not to mention blatant cash-ins such as Teenage Exorcist and Kung-Fu Exorcist. If the prequel is to avoid such an ignoble fate, it must capitalise on the increased profile of the original film in recent years after a theatrical re-release in 1998 and a new director's cut last year.

The film market has recently been awash with Exorcist-derived tales of satanic possession, from Arnold Schwarzenegger's End of Days, to Winona Ryder's Lost Souls and Bless the Child, with Kim Basinger.

fields.headline: Students angry at computer 'elitism'
fields.standfirst:
Costs fear over Warwick's compulsory laptops policy

More net news
Education site
fields.trailText: Students yesterday attacked a university for elitism as it revealed plans to make ownership of a laptop computer compulsory for all new undergraduates by 2003.
fields.body:
Students yesterday attacked a university for elitism as it revealed plans to make ownership of a laptop computer compulsory for all new undergraduates by 2003.

The University of Warwick said its "bold" strategy for online learning would improve teaching and "end the digital divide".

But the National Union of Students believes it would set a dangerous precedent and fears reduced access to education and an increase in the graduate debt burden if other institutions follow suit.

The proposals are part of a wider computer strategy for the university, which also includes the provision of unmetered internet access in all student accommodation.

The report, which is undergoing a two-month consultation period, was produced by a working group chaired by the vice-chancellor, Sir Brian Follett.

According to a document issued by the university, 70% of its students already have their own computers. The statement added: "Warwick believes that it could, and should, ensure that 100% of its students should have access to a laptop and there should be no digital divide.

"Those unable to afford the technology by themselves would benefit even more as Warwick will move to eradicate the current digital divide by making provision to ensure those students who cannot afford to spend the sums are given the assistance they need."

A spokesman for Warwick insisted: "The university won't benefit by one extra penny. It is actually going to cost us money, because we will ensure that those students who can not afford laptops will be assisted with leasing a computer. The online teaching will be in addition to what we already do. This is not a cost-saving exercise; we are introducing extra services."

But student leaders said many people would be discouraged from applying to Warwick. "The mandatory requirement to own a compatible computer means students unwilling or unable to purchase will be forced to apply to other universities," said Caitlin McKenzie, the student union president. "Warwick will increasingly become elitist.

"The university is proposing to give laptops to all the staff, but is charging students for them. They are already paying over £1,000 a year for tuition fees."

She was backed by Owain James, president of the NUS, who added: "Not only is the existing system forcing thousands of students into great financial hardship and debt, but it is also deterring many people from entering higher education. If Warwick is allowed to do this, with no doubt other universities following suit, then the crisis in higher education can only intensify."

Government recommendations state that students should not have to pay for computers which are necessary for their studies.

A spokesperson for the Department for Education said: "The guidance explicitly says: 'Increasingly, access to a PC and the institution's own network are becoming a necessary part of many courses. Where this is the case, institutions should ensure that all students have free access to such provision'."

The university has said it will talk to the department about how to implement the scheme if the proposal is approved.

The report, which is undergoing a two-month consultation period, was produced by a working group chaired by the vice-chancellor, Sir Brian Follett. According to a document issued by the university, 70% of its students already have their own computers. The statement added: "Warwick believes that it could, and should, ensure that 100% of its students should have access to a laptop and there should be no digital divide. "Those unable to afford the technology by themselves would benefit even more as Warwick will move to eradicate the current digital divide by making provision to ensure those students who cannot afford to spend the sums are given the assistance they need." A spokesman for Warwick insisted: "The university won't benefit by one extra penny. It is actually going to cost us money, because we will ensure that those students who can not afford laptops will be assisted with leasing a computer. The online teaching will be in addition to what we already do. This is not a cost-saving exercise; we are introducing extra services." But student leaders said many people would be discouraged from applying to Warwick. "The mandatory requirement to own a compatible computer means students unwilling or unable to purchase will be forced to apply to other universities," said Caitlin McKenzie, the student union president. "Warwick will increasingly become elitist. "The university is proposing to give laptops to all the staff, but is charging students for them. They are already paying over £1,000 a year for tuition fees." She was backed by Owain James, president of the NUS, who added: "Not only is the existing system forcing thousands of students into great financial hardship and debt, but it is also deterring many people from entering higher education. If Warwick is allowed to do this, with no doubt other universities following suit, then the crisis in higher education can only intensify." Government recommendations state that students should not have to pay for computers which are necessary for their studies. A spokesperson for the Department for Education said: "The guidance explicitly says: 'Increasingly, access to a PC and the institution's own network are becoming a necessary part of many courses. Where this is the case, institutions should ensure that all students have free access to such provision'." The university has said it will talk to the department about how to implement the scheme if the proposal is approved.

fields.headline: DVD sales quadruple in 2000
fields.trailText: The release of Gladiator on DVD, together with strong pre-Christmas business, helped push sales to four times the amount for 1999
fields.body:
New figures show that sales of DVD discs increased more than fourfold in 2000, reports Screendaily.

British Video Association statistics confirm that 16.6m discs were sold in the UK last year, a huge rise on the 4.05m sold in 1999. The Christmas rush alone beat the 1999 total, with 4.71m DVDs flying off shop shelves in December.

The bestselling disc of 2000 was Ridley Scott's Gladiator (pictured), with 500,000 sales, followed by The Matrix and The Sixth Sense, with more than 300,000 apiece.

However, the increase in the medium's popularity has not adversely affected VHS sales, which saw a 7% rise. But the most popular titles were markedly different on video: Star Wars: Episode I: The Phantom Menace, released on VHS only (2m sales), Toy Story 2 (1.75m) and Gladiator (1.5m).

The DVD UK Committee has concluded that DVD is ten times more popular than CD, because the format has established itself far more rapidly. According to the Committee, 1m players and 21m discs have been sold since the launch of DVD in late 1998. On the hardware count, it took CD five years to achieve such ubiquity.

fields.headline: L Ron's Hubbard's advice to Tom and Nic
fields.standfirst: Plus: Arnie accused of letting his hands do the walking; Mike Figgis shoots another split-screen movie in Venice
fields.trailText: Plus: Arnie accused of letting his hands do the walking; Mike Figgis shoots another split-screen movie in Venice
fields.body:
 As news of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman's divorce rests heavy on the Hollywood community, it emerges that not only have the pair not had time for each other, but they've been neglecting regular Scientology scripture readings too. IMDb.com has unearthed the L Ron Hubbard prescription for failing marriages - invite a Scientology counsellor into your home. The Scientology Handbook suggests that one way: "To restore a high level of communication between marital partners is Scientology Marriage Counselling. This is provided by a Scientology auditor. A husband and wife can utilize good, honest communication between themselves to create and continue a happy, fulfilling marriage." Only $5000 per hour, doubtless.

 Bodybuilder, actor, prospective politician, Arnold Schwarzenegger's CV is in fine shape these days and, if a spate of recent revelations are correct, then he can soon add another string to his bow - pro-league groper. Hot on the heels of the star's lightning raid on London's ladies while promoting The 6th Day comes a new article in US Premiere, "Arnie the Barbarian", alleging a host of sexual dismeanours. The big man's sexual faux pas have apparently included snogging Total Recall co-star Rachel Ticotin, fondling Terminator 2 leading lass Linda Hamilton while then-husband James Cameron wasn't looking and molesting assorted crew members on the set of that film. Well, he said he'd be back

 Moonstone Entertainment are to pick up the tab for Mike Figgis' new digitally filmed feature The Hotel, says Screendaily. The film, which started shooting on Monday in Venice, is another split-screen venture to follow up his acclaimed Time Code, with an equally rich ensemble cast. Figgis has gathered Salma Hayek, David Schwimmer and regular collaborator Julian Sands among others to portray the denizens of a seedy Venetian hotel. The project will again be improvised from a single treatment.

webTitle: Doors must not be shut on asylum seekers

fields.headline: Doors must not be shut on asylum seekers
fields.trailText: The run up to an election is the worst possible time for reforming asylum procedures. Conservative party officials have hailed the way immigration in earlier elections "played well" in the tabloids, and Labour leaks have shown Tony Blair worrying about the government looking soft. Even so, Jack Straw, who visits Stockholm today for talks with EU interior ministers, is right to be pushing two issues: speeding up the UK's current application process; and seeking a common European approach to asylum seekers.
fields.body:
The run up to an election is the worst possible time for reforming asylum procedures. Conservative party officials have hailed the way immigration in earlier elections "played well" in the tabloids, and Labour leaks have shown Tony Blair worrying about the government looking soft. Even so, Jack Straw, who visits Stockholm today for talks with EU interior ministers, is right to be pushing two issues: speeding up the UK's current application process; and seeking a common European approach to asylum seekers.

The need for a common European approach becomes ever more obvious as numbers grow. Equity demands that those arriving should be fairly distributed across the 15 member states. The UK is not taking a disproportionate share: although it accepts the second largest number, once that is related to population, Britain takes seventh place. The issue has been made more acute by a recent high court ruling barring asylum seekers being returned to France or Germany because of their stricter admission criteria. Both countries restrict admission to applicants facing persecution from governments, ignoring the threats which war lords or factions in civil wars can pose. This makes the UK more attractive to the organised gangs running illegal immigration rackets.

A draft EU directive for harmonising approaches is already out for consultation. It will need to ensure a common approach on three crucial fronts - criteria, procedures, and protection. If it does not, "asylum shopping" will continue. The draft already has greater safeguards than the home secretary has proposed, but it will need to incorporate both the 1951 Geneva Convention and the even greater protection extended to asylum seekers by Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights. What must not happen is a levelling down to the lowest common denominator.

Where Mr Straw is wrong is in seeking to rewrite the 1951 convention (with 137 signatories, that has little practical chance); in suggesting that countries from which refugees flee can be divided into three classes of risk: high, intermediate and safe (that is too crude); and in wishing to keep all refugees in camps close to the countries from which they come. All that needs further thought. But what matters most is that the meeting in Stockholm must not result in the withdrawal of the right to make an asylum claim in Europe.

fields.headline: ITV orders comedy sketch show
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: ITV has commissioned its first comedy sketch show for years, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV has commissioned its first comedy sketch show for years, co-produced by Steve Coogan's company and the independent producer behind the Frank Skinner Show.

The as-yet-untitled 30-minute sketch show will feature a five-strong comedy team, including established artists Jim Tavare, Lee Mack and Tim Vine.

The new programme will also showcase the talents of Ronnie Ancona, who plays Posh to Alistair McGowan's Becks in BBC1's Alistair McGowan's Big Impression, and newcomer Karen Taylor, a Daily Telegraph Open Mic Award finalist.

The eight-part series will go out later this year in a post-watershed slot on ITV.

It is being co-produced by Frank Skinner Show producer Avalon Television and Baby Cow Productions, the indie set up by Mr Coogan and Henry Normal.

"The brief was to put together a group who complemented each other and wanted to play to the mainstream," said Avalon founder Jon Thoday.

"We looked for people who could go on the Royal Variety Show and actually be funny."

Mr Thoday said the show would have a traditional sketch show format, with material shot in the studio and on location.

The programme has been commissioned by ITV controller of comedy Sioned Wiliam.

In recent years ITV has struggled to establish any new comedy series of the sketch or sitcom variety.

Gwen Taylor comedy vehicle Barbara has just secured a third series and ITV is about to launch new sitcom High Stakes, starring Richard Wilson as a merchant banker.

But Mr Wilson's last ITV comedy, Duck Patrol, was not recommissioned. The broadcaster also came a cropper with That 70s Show, a local version of the US format that failed to get British viewers rolling in the aisles.

Babes in the Wood, an attempt to transport the success of Friends to St John's Wood with a cast including Denise Van Outen, limped through two series but never won over critics or big audiences.

ITV has enjoyed more critical and ratings success with comedy drama Cold Feet.

fields.headline: Express sales hit all-time low
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The Daily Express's circulation figures have fallen to their lowest the paper's history, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Express loses sports columnist
fields.body:
The Daily Express's circulation figures have fallen to their lowest in the paper's history.

The paper's sales have plummeted to below the 1m mark.

This represents a loss of more than 70,000 copies, a fall of 6.8% year-on-year and a 2.2% decline on last month.

The Express has argued the decline is partly due to a recent decision to drop the paper's bulk circulation strategy.

The circulation figure includes some "optional exclusions" from the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

These allow newspapers to exclude days of the year - such as national holidays - when the circulation is likely to be particularly low.

In figures to be published tomorrow, the Express's losses are expected to contrast with gains made by its arch-rival the Daily Mail.

The Mail has enjoyed an circulation increase of 125,000 as the result of an aggressive marketing campaign.

The Daily Mirror is also expected to post a circulation decline of 120,000.

fields.headline: Seaweed dries up in Japan
fields.standfirst: Coastal land reclamation has decimated this year's nori harvest and alarmed a sushi-loving nation, says Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.trailText: Coastal land reclamation has decimated this year's nori harvest and alarmed a sushi-loving nation, says Jonathan Watts in Tokyo.
fields.body:
Seaweed Day in Japan is usually marked by the satisfied chomping of millions of sushi balls wrapped in crispy sheets of dark-green laver.

This week, however, the festive munching on February 6 was overshadowed by an alarming decline in seaweed harvests that has been blamed on the country's most notorious land-reclamation project.

The existence of an annual Seaweed Day underlines the importance that Japan places on its ocean flora harvest and why its depletion has raised public hackles in a way that other environmental problems have largely failed to do.

Each year, shoppers snap up more than 4bn sheets of nori (laver), which are torn into strips to garnish noodles or wrapped around balls of sushi.

This is nothing new. Seaweed Day marks the anniversary 1,300 years ago of a new legal code that recognized nori as a suitable tribute for the emperor.

The same could certainly not be said of the seaweed at the centre of the current storm of protest.

Until recently, Ariake Sea nori was among the most prized in Japan. Harvested in the waters off Kyushu in southern Japan, it was once prized for its dark colour - a sign of good nutrition - and crispy texture when dried.

Such was the demand and abundance of the crop, that the area supplied 40% of all the nori consumed in Japan.

Last year, however, the harvest hit record low levels and the quality of the crop was shockingly bad.

Instead of a lustrous black-green, the nori was a soggy beige - and nobody wanted it. In the ten months until January, sales of laver dropped by 25%.

Furious fishermen, seaweed harvesters and local politicians have no doubt where the blame lies: the five-mile-long Isahaya Bay sluice gate that was lowered in 1997 to reclaim 3,550 hectares of land.

According to conservationists, the project has devastated the ecosystems both of the dried-up wetlands inside the barrier and the sea outside.

By disrupting the flow of seawater from the East China sea, they say, the sluice gate has allowed plankton to flourish at the expense of the nori.

More than 6,000 fisherman in 1,000 boats have staged an angry protest demanding that the government lift the barrier's 300 shutters.

The government, however, says it lacks evidence to link the reclamation project and the devastation of the seaweed crop.

It is not the first time that the Isahaya Bay project has come under fire.

The project was dreamed up 30 years ago when farmland was scarce, but Japan now has so much more agricultural land than it needs that it pays some farmers to leave their fields fallow.

Although the original logic for the project faded long ago, the powerful construction lobby encouraged bureaucrats and politicians in the ruling Liberal Democratic party to push ahead with the plan on the grounds of flood control.

As with numerous other wasteful public works projects around Japan, critics have focused on the inefficient use of taxpayers' money, but the collapse of the nori harvest has highlighted the growing environmental costs of such ill-conceived plans.

Given the importance and prestige of seaweed in the national diet, it may yet even force the government into a rare change of heart.

The Isahaya Bay project has been blamed for the extinction of local mud skippers and other wetland animals, as well as a decline in fish stocks in surrounding waters, but none of these natural tragedies has made the same impact on the national consciousness as the deterioration of the nori crop.

Questions have been tabled in parliament, newspapers have given the subject intensive coverage and opposition party politicians have braved the elements to show solidarity with the hard-pressed nori harvesters.

So far the impact has been purely psychological, but it could soon start to hit Japanese wallets.

Nori prices around Japan have jumped by between ten and 60% as a result of the poor Ariake sea harvest and analysts warn that it is only a matter of time before the increased costs are passed on to the consumer.

If sushi prices rise, the government will find it difficult to avoid the question of why it puts public works before the environment.

Seaweed could yet force the Isahaya Bay sluice gates open.

webTitle: Text messages to usurp Valentine's cards

fields.headline: Text messages to usurp Valentine's cards
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The traditional way of sending a message of love - a card through the post - is about to be relegated to the scrapheap, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The traditional way of sending a message of love - a card through the post - is about to be relegated to the scrapheap.

More than 30m romantic text messages are expected to be relayed on Valentine's Day.

A "love poll" from Virgin Mobile found one in four of its users plan to send a Valentine's Day text message.

More tellingly, a whopping 75% said they would be happy to receive a text message in place of a card or bunch of flowers.

"Whoever said romance is dead has obviously never used a mobile phone," said a Virgin Mobile spokesman.

"Instead of counting how many Valentines cards we get this year, we'll be keeping our eyes out for the number of messages we receive on our phones."

For those who believe in the sanctity of anonymity, help is at hand.

Various web-based SMS services - offered by Excite.co.uk, Lycos.co.uk and Breathe.com - and network operators plan to offer special anonymous Valentines services.

Vodafone is offering users the choice of 10 anonymous Valentine's messages: from "Hve I told U l8tly that I luv u?" to "Roses r red, violets r blue, did u know that I love u? Guess who?".

Vodafone expects Valentine's Day to break all messaging records.

Its last big day was January 1, when 11m messages were sent over its network.

However, Royal Mail is refusing to be browbeaten.

It expects the number of Valentine's cards sent in the post to be up by between 2m and 12m on last year.

"Our research clearly shows people like receiving and sending written material for special occasions and many treasure their old cards," said a spokesman.

"Someone's handwriting can reval a lot and that makes receiving a Valentine's card from an admirer even more exciting."

The Virgin Mobile "love poll" concluded that text messaging is to become the top aid to romance and dating in the 21st century.

Approximately 50% of "spoken for" and married people plan to send romantic messages this Valentine's Day.

However, these may not necessarily be to their partners: a sneaky 6% plan to send a love text to an ex-partner.

One in every two single people use text messaging to ask someone out on a date, while 43% of people believe text messaging makes people more flirtatious.

One in four single people think they might get lucky this Valentine's Day because texting allows them to be more promiscuous.

Men are bolder when it comes to sending saucy text messages: 34% of men would send a message to someone they fancy, compared with 19% of women.

The downside is that 30% of men send messages when they are drunk - and 15% said they would use text messaging to dump a partner
