More tellingly, a whopping 75% said they would be happy to receive a text message in place of a card or bunch of flowers. "Whoever said romance is dead has obviously never used a mobile phone," said a Virgin Mobile spokesman. "Instead of counting how many Valentines cards we get this year, we'll be keeping our eyes out for the number of messages we receive on our phones." For those who believe in the sanctity of anonymity, help is at hand. Various web-based SMS services - offered by Excite.co.uk, Lycos.co.uk and Breathe.com - and network operators plan to offer special anonymous Valentines services. Vodafone is offering users the choice of 10 anonymous Valentine's messages: from "Hve I told U l8tly that I luv u?" to "Roses r red, violets r blue, did u know that I love u? Guess who?". Vodafone expects Valentine's Day to break all messaging records. Its last big day was January 1, when 11m messages were sent over its network. However, Royal Mail is refusing to be browbeaten. It expects the number of Valentine's cards sent in the post to be up by between 2m and 12m on last year. "Our research clearly shows people like receiving and sending written material for special occasions and many treasure their old cards," said a spokesman. "Someone's handwriting can reval a lot and that makes receiving a Valentine's card from an admirer even more exciting." The Virgin Mobile "love poll" concluded that text messaging is to become the top aid to romance and dating in the 21st century. Approximately 50% of "spoken for" and married people plan to send romantic messages this Valentine's Day. However, these may not necessarily be to their partners: a sneaky 6% plan to send a love text to an ex-partner. One in every two single people use text messaging to ask someone out on a date, while 43% of people believe text messaging makes people more flirtatious. One in four single people think they might get lucky this Valentine's Day because texting allows them to be more promiscuous. Men are bolder when it comes to sending saucy text messages: 34% of men would send a message to someone they fancy, compared with 19% of women. The downside is that 30% of men send messages when they are drunk - and 15% said they would use text messaging to dump a partner

fields.headline: Esquire faces 13% circulation drop
fields.trailText: 9.30am: The men's title faces a shake-up after a predicted 13% fall in circulation, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Esquire will face a shake-up after a double-digit circulation drop, according to media buying agencies.

The men's glossy, published by NatMags, is thought to be the worst-hit magazine in the men's sector, according to Paul Thomas, press director of media agency Mindshare.

Mr Thomas predicted figures out next week would show Esquire's circulation to have fallen by at least 13% this year.

This adds to the 29% decline posted for the same period last year, bringing the magazine's cumulative decline to more than 40%.

Esquire is edited by Peter Howarth.

The magazine, along with other glossy men's titles, have suffered in recent years from an assault by the younger lads' mags.

Its decision to differentiate itself from other men's magazines by banning "totty" covers is thought to have contributed to the decline.

Mr Thomas said the magazine's editorial team would be under pressure to "deliver change".

Among the other predictions was a 9% circulation rise for OK!.

OK! is expected to outstrip rival Hello!, which is thought to have remained static since the previous year.

fields.body:
The hill people and the Mexicans arrived on the same day. It was a Wednesday, early in September 1952. The Cardinals were five games behind the Dodgers with three weeks to go, and the season looked hopeless. The cotton, however, was waist-high to my father, over my head, and he and my grandfather could be heard before supper whispering words that were seldom heard. It could be a "good crop."

They were farmers, hardworking men who embraced pessimism only when discussing the weather and the crops. There was too much sun, or too much rain, or the threat of floods in the lowlands, or the rising prices of seed and fertilizer, or the uncertainties of the markets. On the most perfect of days, my mother would quietly say to me, "Don't worry. The men will find something to worry about."

Pappy, my grandfather, was worried about the price for labor when we went searching for the hill people. They were paid for every hundred pounds of cotton they picked. The previous year, according to him, it was $1.50 per hundred. He'd already heard rumors that a farmer over in Lake City was offering $1.60.

This played heavily on his mind as we rode to town. He never talked when he drove, and this was because, according to my mother, not much of a driver herself, he was afraid of motorized vehicles. His truck was a 1939 Ford, and with the exception of our old John Deere tractor, it was our sole means of transportation. This was no particular problem except when we drove to church and my mother and grandmother were forced to sit snugly together up front in their Sunday best while my father and I rode in the back, engulfed in dust. Modern sedans were scarce in rural Arkansas.

Pappy drove thirty-seven miles per hour. His theory was that every automobile had a speed at which it ran most efficiently, and through some vaguely defined method he had determined that his old truck should go thirty-seven. My mother said (to me) that it was ridiculous. She also said he and my father had once fought over whether the truck should go faster. But my father rarely drove it, and if I happened to be riding with him, he would level off at thirty-seven, out of respect for Pappy. My mother said she suspected he drove much faster when he was alone.

We turned onto Highway 135, and, as always, I watched Pappy carefully shift the gears—pressing slowly on the clutch, delicately prodding the stick shift on the steering column—until the truck reached its perfect speed. Then I leaned over to check the speedometer: thirty-seven. He smiled at me as if we both agreed that the truck belonged at that speed.

Highway 135 ran straight and flat through the farm country of the Arkansas Delta. On both sides as far as I could see, the fields were white with cotton. It was time for the harvest, a wonderful season for me because they turned out school for two months. For my grandfather, though, it was a time of endless worry.

On the right, at the Jordan place, we saw a group of Mexicans working in the field near the road. They were stooped at the waist, their cotton sacks draped behind them, their hands moving deftly through the stalks, tearing off the bolls. Pappy grunted. He didn't like the Jordans because they were Methodists—and Cubs fans. Now that they already had workers in their fields, there was another reason to dislike them.

The distance from our farm to town was fewer than eight miles, but at thirty-seven miles an hour, the trip took twenty minutes. Always twenty minutes, even with little traffic. Pappy didn't believe in passing slower vehicles in front of him. Of course, he was usually the slow one. Near Black Oak, we caught up to a trailer filled to the top with snowy mounds of freshly picked cotton. A tarp covered the front half, and the Montgomery twins, who were my age, playfully bounced around in all that cotton until they saw us on the road below them. Then they stopped and waved. I waved back, but my grandfather did not. When he drove, he never waved or nodded at folks, and this was, my mother said, because he was afraid to take his hands from the wheel. She said people talked about him behind his back, saying he was rude and arrogant. Personally, I don't think he cared how the gossip ran.

We followed the Montgomery trailer until it turned at the cotton gin. It was pulled by their old Massey Harris tractor, and driven by Frank, the eldest Montgomery boy, who had dropped out of school in the fifth grade and was considered by everyone at church to be headed for serious trouble.

Highway 135 became Main Street for the short stretch it took to negotiate Black Oak. We passed the Black Oak Baptist Church, one of the few times we'd pass without stopping for some type of service. Every store, shop, business, church, even the school, faced Main Street, and on Saturdays the traffic inched along, bumper to bumper, as the country folks flocked to town for their weekly shopping. But it was Wednesday, and when we got into town, we parked in front of Pop and Pearl Watson's grocery store on Main.

I waited on the sidewalk until my grandfather nodded in the direction of the store. That was my cue to go inside and purchase a Tootsie Roll, on credit. It only cost a penny, but it was not a foregone conclusion that I would get one every trip to town. Occasionally, he wouldn't nod, but I would enter the store anyway and loiter around the cash register long enough for Pearl to sneak me one, which always came with strict instructions not to tell my grandfather. She was afraid of him. Eli Chandler was a poor man, but he was intensely proud. He would starve to death before he took free food, which, on his list, included Tootsie Rolls. He would've beaten me with a stick if he knew I had accepted a piece of candy, so Pearl Watson had no trouble swearing me to secrecy.

But this time I got the nod. As always, Pearl was dusting the counter when I entered and gave her a stiff hug. Then I grabbed a Tootsie Roll from the jar next to the cash register. I signed the charge slip with great flair, and Pearl inspected my penmanship. "It's getting better, Luke," she said.

"Not bad for a seven-year-old," I said. Because of my mother, I had been practicing my name in cursive writing for two years. "Where's Pop?" I asked. They were the only adults I knew who insisted I call them by their "first" names, but only in the store when no one else was listening. If a customer walked in, then it was suddenly Mr. and Mrs. Watson. I told no one but my mother this, and she told me she was certain no other child held such privilege.

"In the back, putting up stock," Pearl said. "Where's your grandfather?"

It was Pearl's calling in life to monitor the movements of the town's population, so any question was usually answered with another.

"The Tea Shoppe, checking on the Mexicans. Can I go back there?" I was determined to outquestion her.

"Better not. Y'all using hill people, too?"

"If we can find them. Eli says they don't come down like they used to. He also thinks they're all half crazy. Where's Champ?" Champ was the store's ancient beagle, which never left Pop's side.

Pearl grinned whenever I called my grandfather by his first name. She was about to ask me a question when the small bell clanged as the door opened and closed. A genuine Mexican walked in, alone and timid, as they all seemed to be at first. Pearl nodded politely at the new customer.

I shouted, "Buenos días, señor!"

The Mexican grinned and said sheepishly, "Buenos días," before disappearing into the back of the store.

"They're good people," Pearl said under her breath, as if the Mexican spoke English and might be offended by something nice she said. I bit into my Tootsie Roll and chewed it slowly while rewrapping and pocketing the other half.

"Eli's worried about payin' them too much," I said. With a customer in the store, Pearl was suddenly busy again, dusting and straightening around the only cash register.

"Eli worries about everything," she said.

"He's a farmer."

"Are you going to be a farmer?"

"No ma'am. A baseball player."

"For the Cardinals?"

"Of course."

Pearl hummed for a bit while I waited for the Mexican. I had some more Spanish I was anxious to try.

The old wooden shelves were bursting with fresh groceries. I loved the store during picking season because Pop filled it from floor to ceiling. The crops were coming in, and money was changing hands.

Pappy opened the door just wide enough to stick his head in. "Let's go," he said; then, "Howdy, Pearl."

"Howdy, Eli," she said as she patted my head and sent me away.

"Where are the Mexicans?" I asked Pappy when we were outside.

"Should be in later this afternoon."

We got back in the truck and left town in the direction of Jonesboro, where my grandfather always found the hill people.

We parked on the shoulder of the highway, near the intersection of a gravel road. In Pappy's opinion, it was the best spot in the county to catch the hill people. I wasn't so sure. He'd been trying to hire some for a week with no results. We sat on the tailgate in the scorching sun in complete silence for half an hour before the first truck stopped. It was clean and had good tires. If we were lucky enough to find hill people, they would live with us for the next two months. We wanted folks who were neat, and the fact that this truck was much nicer than Pappy's was a good sign.

"Afternoon," Pappy said when the engine was turned off.

"Howdy," said the driver.

"Where y'all from?" asked Pappy.

"Up north of Hardy."

With no traffic around, my grandfather stood on the pavement, a pleasant expression on his face, taking in the truck and its contents. The driver and his wife sat in the cab with a small girl between them. Three large teenaged boys were napping in the back. Everyone appeared to be healthy and well dressed. I could tell Pappy wanted these people.

"Y'all lookin' for work?" he asked.

"Yep. Lookin' for Lloyd Crenshaw, somewhere west of Black Oak." My grandfather pointed this way and that, and they drove off. We watched them until they were out of sight.

He could've offered them more than Mr. Crenshaw was promising. Hill people were notorious for negotiating their labor. Last year, in the middle of the first picking on our place, the Fulbrights from Calico Rock disappeared one Sunday night and went to work for a farmer ten miles away.

But Pappy was not dishonest, nor did he want to start a bidding war.

We tossed a baseball along the edge of a cotton field, stopping whenever a truck approached.

My glove was a Rawlings that Santa had delivered the Christmas before. I slept with it nightly and oiled it weekly, and nothing was as dear to my soul.

My grandfather, who had taught me how to throw and catch and hit, didn't need a glove. His large, callused hands absorbed my throws without the slightest sting.

Though he was a quiet man who never bragged, Eli Chandler had been a legendary baseball player. At the age of seventeen, he had signed a contract with the Cardinals to play professional baseball. But the First War called him, and not long after he came home, his father died. Pappy had no choice but to become a farmer.

Pop Watson loved to tell me stories of how great Eli Chandler had been—how far he could hit a baseball, how hard he could throw one. "Probably the greatest ever from Arkansas," was Pop's assessment.

"Better than Dizzy Dean?" I would ask.

"Not even close," Pop would say, sighing.

When I relayed these stories to my mother, she always smiled and said, "Be careful. Pop tells tales."

Pappy, who was rubbing the baseball in his mammoth hands, cocked his head at the sound of a vehicle. Coming from the west was a truck with a trailer behind it. From a quarter of a mile away we could tell they were hill people. We walked to the shoulder of the road and waited as the driver downshifted, gears crunching and whining as he brought the truck to a stop.

I counted seven heads, five in the truck, two in the trailer.

"Howdy," the driver said slowly, sizing up my grandfather as we in turn quickly scrutinized them.

"Good afternoon," Pappy said, taking a step closer but still keeping his distance.

Tobacco juice lined the lower lip of the driver. This was an ominous sign. My mother thought most hill people were prone to bad hygiene and bad habits. Tobacco and alcohol were forbidden in our home. We were Baptists.

"Name's Spruill," he said.

"Eli Chandler. Nice to meet you. Y'all lookin' for work?"

"Yep."

"Where you from?"

"Eureka Springs."

The truck was almost as old as Pappy's, with slick tires and a cracked windshield and rusted fenders and what looked like faded blue paint under a layer of dust. A tier had been constructed above the bed, and it was crammed with cardboard boxes and burlap bags filled with supplies. Under it, on the floor of the bed, a mattress was wedged next to the cab. Two large boys stood on it, both staring blankly at me. Sitting on the tailgate, barefoot and shirtless, was a heavy young man with massive shoulders and a neck as thick as a stump. He spat tobacco juice between the truck and the trailer and seemed oblivious to Pappy and me. He swung his feet slowly, then spat again, never looking away from the asphalt beneath him.

"I'm lookin' for field hands," Pappy said.

"How much you payin'?" Mr. Spruill asked.

"One-sixty a hundred," Pappy said.

Mr. Spruill frowned and looked at the woman beside him. They mumbled something.

It was at this point in the ritual that quick decisions had to be made. We had to decide whether we wanted these people living with us. And they had to accept or reject our price.

"What kinda cotton?" Mr. Spruill asked.

"Stoneville," my grandfather said. "The bolls are ready. It'll be easy to pick." Mr. Spruill could look around him and see the bolls bursting. The sun and soil and rains had cooperated so far. Pappy, of course, had been fretting over some dire rainfall prediction in the Farmers' Almanac.

"We got one-sixty last year," Mr. Spruill said.

I didn't care for money talk, so I ambled along the center line to inspect the trailer. The tires on the trailer were even balder than those on the truck. One was half flat from the load. It was a good thing that their journey was almost over.

Rising in one corner of the trailer, with her elbows resting on the plank siding, was a very pretty girl. She had dark hair pulled tightly behind her head and big brown eyes. She was younger than my mother, but certainly a lot older than I was, and I couldn't help but stare.

"What's your name?" she said.

"Luke," I said, kicking a rock. My cheeks were immediately warm. "What's yours?"

"Tally. How old are you?"

"Seven. How old are you?"

"Seventeen."

"How long you been ridin' in that trailer?"

"Day and a half."

She was barefoot, and her dress was dirty and very tight—tight all the way to her knees. This was the first time I remember really examining a girl. She watched me with a knowing smile. A kid sat on a crate next to her with his back to me, and he slowly turned around and looked at me as if I weren't there. He had green eyes and a long forehead covered with sticky black hair. His left arm appeared to be useless.

"This is Trot," she said. "He ain't right."

"Nice to meet you, Trot," I said, but his eyes looked away. He acted as if he hadn't heard me.

"How old is he?" I asked her.

"Twelve. He's a cripple."

Trot turned abruptly to face a corner, his bad arm flopping lifelessly. My friend Dewayne said that hill people married their cousins and that's why there were so many defects in their families.

Tally appeared to be perfect, though. She gazed thoughtfully across the cotton fields, and I admired her dirty dress once again.

I knew my grandfather and Mr. Spruill had come to terms because Mr. Spruill started his truck. I walked past the trailer, past the man on the tailgate who was briefly awake but still staring at the pavement, and stood beside Pappy. "Nine miles that way, take a left by a burned-out barn, then six more miles to the St. Francis River. We're the first farm past the river on your left."

"Bottomland?" Mr. Spruill asked, as if he were being sent into a swamp.

"Some of it is, but it's good land."

Mr. Spruill glanced at his wife again, then looked back at us. "Where do we set up?"

"You'll see a shady spot in the back, next to the silo. That's the best place."

We watched them drive away, the gears rattling, the tires wobbling, crates and boxes and pots bouncing along.

"You don't like them, do you?" I asked.

"They're good folks. They're just different."

"I guess we're lucky to have them, aren't we?"

"Yes, we are."

More field hands meant less cotton for me to pick. For the next month I would go to the fields at sunrise, drape a nine-foot cotton sack over my shoulder, and stare for a moment at an endless row of cotton, the stalks taller than I was, then plunge into them, lost as far as anyone could tell. And I would pick cotton, tearing the fluffy bolls from the stalks at a steady pace, stuffing them into the heavy sack, afraid to look down the row and be reminded of how endless it was, afraid to slow down because someone would notice. My fingers would bleed, my neck would burn, my back would hurt.

Yes, I wanted lots of help in the fields. Lots of hill people, lots of Mexicans.

My glove was a Rawlings that Santa had delivered the Christmas before. I slept with it nightly and oiled it weekly, and nothing was as dear to my soul. My grandfather, who had taught me how to throw and catch and hit, didn't need a glove. His large, callused hands absorbed my throws without the slightest sting. Though he was a quiet man who never bragged, Eli Chandler had been a legendary baseball player. At the age of seventeen, he had signed a contract with the Cardinals to play professional baseball. But the First War called him, and not long after he came home, his father died. Pappy had no choice but to become a farmer. Pop Watson loved to tell me stories of how great Eli Chandler had been—how far he could hit a baseball, how hard he could throw one. "Probably the greatest ever from Arkansas," was Pop's assessment. "Better than Dizzy Dean?" I would ask. "Not even close," Pop would say, sighing. When I relayed these stories to my mother, she always smiled and said, "Be careful. Pop tells tales." Pappy, who was rubbing the baseball in his mammoth hands, cocked his head at the sound of a vehicle. Coming from the west was a truck with a trailer behind it. From a quarter of a mile away we could tell they were hill people. We walked to the shoulder of the road and waited as the driver downshifted, gears crunching and whining as he brought the truck to a stop. I counted seven heads, five in the truck, two in the trailer. "Howdy," the driver said slowly, sizing up my grandfather as we in turn quickly scrutinized them. "Good afternoon," Pappy said, taking a step closer but still keeping his distance. Tobacco juice lined the lower lip of the driver. This was an ominous sign. My mother thought most hill people were prone to bad hygiene and bad habits. Tobacco and alcohol were forbidden in our home. We were Baptists. "Name's Spruill," he said. "Eli Chandler. Nice to meet you. Y'all lookin' for work?" "Yep." "Where you from?" "Eureka Springs." The truck was almost as old as Pappy's, with slick tires and a cracked windshield and rusted fenders and what looked like faded blue paint under a layer of dust. A tier had been constructed above the bed, and it was crammed with cardboard boxes and burlap bags filled with supplies. Under it, on the floor of the bed, a mattress was wedged next to the cab. Two large boys stood on it, both staring blankly at me. Sitting on the tailgate, barefoot and shirtless, was a heavy young man with massive shoulders and a neck as thick as a stump. He spat tobacco juice between the truck and the trailer and seemed oblivious to Pappy and me. He swung his feet slowly, then spat again, never looking away from the asphalt beneath him. "I'm lookin' for field hands," Pappy said. "How much you payin'?" Mr. Spruill asked. "One-sixty a hundred," Pappy said. Mr. Spruill frowned and looked at the woman beside him. They mumbled something. It was at this point in the ritual that quick decisions had to be made. We had to decide whether we wanted these people living with us. And they had to accept or reject our price. "What kinda cotton?" Mr. Spruill asked. "Stoneville," my grandfather said. "The bolls are ready. It'll be easy to pick." Mr. Spruill could look around him and see the bolls bursting. The sun and soil and rains had cooperated so far. Pappy, of course, had been fretting over some dire rainfall prediction in the Farmers' Almanac. "We got one-sixty last year," Mr. Spruill said. I didn't care for money talk, so I ambled along the center line to inspect the trailer. The tires on the trailer were even balder than those on the truck. One was half flat from the load. It was a good thing that their journey was almost over. Rising in one corner of the trailer, with her elbows resting on the plank siding, was a very pretty girl. She had dark hair pulled tightly behind her head and big brown eyes. She was younger than my mother, but certainly a lot older than I was, and I couldn't help but stare. "What's your name?" she said. "Luke," I said, kicking a rock. My cheeks were immediately warm. "What's yours?" "Tally. How old are you?" "Seven. How old are you?" "Seventeen." "How long you been ridin' in that trailer?" "Day and a half." She was barefoot, and her dress was dirty and very tight—tight all the way to her knees. This was the first time I remember really examining a girl. She watched me with a knowing smile. A kid sat on a crate next to her with his back to me, and he slowly turned around and looked at me as if I weren't there. He had green eyes and a long forehead covered with sticky black hair. His left arm appeared to be useless. "This is Trot," she said. "He ain't right." "Nice to meet you, Trot," I said, but his eyes looked away. He acted as if he hadn't heard me. "How old is he?" I asked her. "Twelve. He's a cripple." Trot turned abruptly to face a corner, his bad arm flopping lifelessly. My friend Dewayne said that hill people married their cousins and that's why there were so many defects in their families. Tally appeared to be perfect, though. She gazed thoughtfully across the cotton fields, and I admired her dirty dress once again. I knew my grandfather and Mr. Spruill had come to terms because Mr. Spruill started his truck. I walked past the trailer, past the man on the tailgate who was briefly awake but still staring at the pavement, and stood beside Pappy. "Nine miles that way, take a left by a burned-out barn, then six more miles to the St. Francis River. We're the first farm past the river on your left." "Bottomland?" Mr. Spruill asked, as if he were being sent into a swamp. "Some of it is, but it's good land." Mr. Spruill glanced at his wife again, then looked back at us. "Where do we set up?" "You'll see a shady spot in the back, next to the silo. That's the best place." We watched them drive away, the gears rattling, the tires wobbling, crates and boxes and pots bouncing along. "You don't like them, do you?" I asked. "They're good folks. They're just different." "I guess we're lucky to have them, aren't we?" "Yes, we are." More field hands meant less cotton for me to pick. For the next month I would go to the fields at sunrise, drape a nine-foot cotton sack over my shoulder, and stare for a moment at an endless row of cotton, the stalks taller than I was, then plunge into them, lost as far as anyone could tell. And I would pick cotton, tearing the fluffy bolls from the stalks at a steady pace, stuffing them into the heavy sack, afraid to look down the row and be reminded of how endless it was, afraid to slow down because someone would notice. My fingers would bleed, my neck would burn, my back would hurt. Yes, I wanted lots of help in the fields. Lots of hill people, lots of Mexicans.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Singapore has just become the world's first country to announce a move away from boring old paper and metal money. Instead, the country is developing and promoting a range of electronic and card-based instruments that come under the category of digital money.
fields.body:
Singapore has just become the world's first country to announce a move away from boring old paper and metal money. Instead, the country is developing and promoting a range of electronic and card-based instruments that come under the category of digital money.

Singapore is far from the world's most cashless economy: that distinction belongs to Iceland, where cash accounts for less than a fifth of all retail transactions. In Britain, more than four-fifths of transactions are in cash.

What is prompting Singapore's move towards a cashless economy? First, it's more efficient, more convenient, and cheaper. Yes, cheaper. Most people go through their lives buying and selling and never thinking about the cost of money. A lot of people assume it's free. But just consider it - someone, somewhere is paying for the cost of that paper and metal like the printing presses at the Bank of England, the armoured cars transporting sacks of cash from supermarkets to banks, and much more.

So there is pressure for change. Interestingly, it's not the traditional payment system owners - banks - that are in the vanguard. Mostly, the drive is coming from the companies and government.

Look at the US, where McDonalds' customers in the Chicago area are paying for their burgers and fries by waving their Mobil Speedpass cards in the vicinity of the cash register. Exxon Mobil says 4.3 million customers are carrying the Speedpass, which can be used at 3,500 Mobil outlets. Later this year, the program will extend to Exxon stations and stores, and, if the company has its way, to drug, video, and grocery stores.

In Southern California, McDonalds' customers can pay in a similar way with the transponder (fixed to the dashboard) that they use to pay tolls on the motorways, merely by driving through a lane. McDonald's is collaborating with Massachusetts state officials on a similar deal for the state turnpike, which has hired the fast-food chain to run its food concessions.

In Hong Kong, travellers on the mass transit system are using a smart card, called Octopus, to pay for their journeys. Around 7 million cards are in circulation, removing about 25 tonnes of coins per day from the transit system, and making life easier for travellers. Transactions with the smart card take less than a third of a second, and cards can be read from up to 10cm from the reader, so you don't have to take them out of your wallet. The cards work in phone booths, drinks machines, snack bars - even in Starbucks and Maxim's pastry shops. Meanwhile, in London, I'm still fumbling around the bottom of my briefcase for a stray 10p piece when I want to take the tube.

What about shopping over the internet? While most of us are still typing in our credit card number, address, expiry date, and other information on as many as 10 other fields in order to buy a $5 item of shareware, Sony and its Japanese partners have just completed the trial of a new contactless payment card. Called Edy, the electronic "purse" is based on Sony's Felicia system. Consumers will be able to load their purses with electronic money at ATMs or convenience stores and then spend it in various places, including online: Sony says it will launch a PC interface so customers can spend cash over the internet just by sitting next to their computers!

Back in Britain, we are far more conservative about the technology of money. I've never understood why the government considers wasting hundreds of millions printing euro notes and minting euro coins. If the government does decide to join euroland, why doesn't it make the UK home of the e-euro? Let people keep their bank accounts in euros, store their euros on their smart cards, and send them to each other via the web and e-mail using systems like Paypal? The technology exists. It's secure, inexpensive, and easy to use.

Think about it: the Egyptians were using metal coins 2,500 years ago. Paper notes have been around since 1273, when Kubla Khan began issuing money on strips of mulberry bark. Do we have to keep wasting more of our hard-earned taxes on old-fashioned technology?

 Dave Birch is a director of Consult Hyperion, whose fourth annual Digital Money Forum - with speakers from (among others) the European Central Bank, Paypal and Sonera MobilePay -will be held in London on April 25th/26th 2001. For more information, see www.digitalmoneyforum.com

webTitle: Weird, wacky and wonderful? It must be London Fashion Week

fields.headline: Weird, wacky and wonderful? It must be London Fashion Week
fields.standfirst:
With the 2001 edition of London's sartorial fest almost upon us, fashion editor Jess Cartner-Morley runs through this year's highlights, has-beens and rising stars

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: With the 2001 edition of London's sartorial fest almost upon us, fashion editor Jess Cartner-Morley runs through this year's highlights, has-beens and rising stars.
fields.body:
Don't believe everything you read in the newspapers: London Fashion Week isn't all one-legged trousers and men in skirts. London, the second stop on a biannual round trip that also takes in New York, Milan and Paris, has long had a reputation for producing designers with an innovative bent, but it would be unwise to generalise about this most unpredictable of fashion capitals.

The designers who will be showcasing their work on the city's catwalks over the week range in style from understated elegance to glossy glamour, from the conceptual to the downright bizarre.

London Fashion Week expands every season. A few years ago, it was more truthfully a long weekend than a week - now, it lasts six days (from February 18 to 23), and comprises 52 catwalk shows.

The primary venue is the Natural History Museum, where marquees are erected in the forecourt, but locations vary from Claridge's Hotel and the Saatchi gallery to the British Museum. Increasingly, London shows attract international press and buyers crucial for enabling British design to expand.

There will be one glaring omission from this season's schedule. Hussein Chalayan, who until February 20 holds the title of British Designer of the Year, recently liquidated his company due to financial problems, and will not be staging a show during London Fashion Week, although a downscaled collection will be available for press and buyers to view next month in Paris.

With Chalayan out of the picture, the undisputed headline act of the week is Alexander McQueen. In January, his couture collection for Givenchy was closed to the press at the last minute, so the appetite for his design among the fashion industry will be greater than ever. McQueen is the favourite to take the title of British Designer of the Year at the British Fashion Awards, which will be held in Battersea Park on the evening of February 20.

The two other contenders for the title are Clements Ribeiro, a label made up of husband-and-wife team Inacio Ribeiro and Suzanne Clements, and Julien Macdonald, a young designer best known for glitzy, revealing dresses which have won front-page coverage for Kelly Brook and Joely Richardson.

Other awards to be presented on the night include New Generation Designer, a newcomer award for which the contenders are Stella McCartney (who shows not in London, but in Paris, where the Chloe label is based) and the lesser known Anthony Symonds and Roland Mouret. McCartney is also nominated in the Glamour category, alongside Julien Macdonald.

Other rising stars of the catwalk include Matthew Williamson and Sophia Kokosolaki, whose Grecian-inspired collection for last season garnered rave reviews.

There are also five newcomers making their debut the official catwalk schedule: Eley Kishimoto, Blaak, Daniel Herman, Fake London and skin jewellery designer J Maskrey.

An unofficial addition to the schedule is Fashion East, a Brick Lane show that will show the work of new designers Lizzy Disney, Louis de Gama, i.e.uniform and PPQ.

And proving that London fashion isn't all about the young upstarts, there are some long-established names on the schedule, including Nicole Farhi, Jean Muir, Betty Jackson and Burberry - a venerable name that has proved British labels can have staying power.

Email
jess.cartner-morley@theguardian.com

webTitle: Whyte to succeed Brien at Leo Burnett

fields.headline: Whyte to succeed Brien at Leo Burnett
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Stephen Whyte is to succeed Nick Brien as chief executive of Leo Burnett, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Stephen Whyte is to succeed Nick Brien as chief executive of Leo Burnett when he leaves in April.

Mr Whyte, managing director of Leo Burnett, will run the agency with joint executive creative directors, Nick Bell and Mark Tutssel, along with Kate Howe, who is currently deputy managing director, when Mr Brien leaves for a new job in the US.

"Stephen has made a significant contribution towards building our integrated capabilities and recognises more than anyone the need for us to deliver consistently breakthrough creativity across all media channels," said Mr Brien.

"Stephen has the talent, commitment and determination to lead the agency to a higher level of performance."

Mr Whyte joined Leo Burnett three years ago as managing director.

He is credited with helping to drive the agency's new business success with recent account wins including Nintendo, BBC Worldwide and Virgin Energy.

webTitle: David Grossman and Amos Oz on the Israeli election result

fields.headline: What now?
fields.standfirst:
Israel has shocked the world by entrusting its future to the belligerent former general Ariel Sharon. Here the troubled country's two leading writers ask how it came to this - and what happens next. David Grossman says the election result shows that Israelis are not ready for peace, while Amos Oz argues that Yasser Arafat is responsible for Sharon's rise to power

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: David Grossman and Amos Oz on the Israeli election result.
fields.body:
When Ariel Sharon made his victory speech on Tuesday night, his supporters whistled in contempt and loathing each time their leader mentioned Ehud Barak, the left and the Palestinians. That triad has clearly been punished in the most painful possible way by the Israeli public. As one voter said, in perfect sincerity: "I'm not sure that Sharon is the best for Israel, but the Palestinians deserve him!"

May I register my suspicion that Sharon himself does not believe what has happened to him? This man, whom many had already written off as a has-been, this power-obsessed, devious extremist of questionable behaviour who has failed in nearly every public office he has held, who has injured nearly everyone who has been his ally, has now been handed an entire country. He can now try out his views, and his instincts, on it. Unlike in the past, this time there is no one, almost, who can stop him. But perhaps that is precisely the reason that in the final days of his campaign, when his victory was already assured, Sharon's mood suddenly changed.

Sharon, who has a cynical and ven omous sense of humour, and an almost compulsive urge to crack jokes, looked melancholy and lifeless during the days leading up to the election. One of his associates said: "It's as if something in him went out." At moments, perhaps for the first time in his life, he looked almost frightened.

All his life Sharon has operated from the position of the oppositionist, even when he was a cabinet minister. He always, always, challenged the authority of his superiors, both in the army and in the government. A large part of what he did in his military and political careers was done while circumventing authority, disobeying orders, inciting against his leader, and even - as in the case of the Lebanon war - deceiving his superiors.

And now, suddenly, at the age of 73, he is himself the superior. He is the authority. He is the man who is responsible for the country. And there is no one to stop him. Now he is prime minister of one of the most complicated countries in the world, deep in the most extremely delicate situation it has seen for decades. Perhaps Sharon knows, deep down in his heart, that if he does indeed mean to ensure his country's future, he will have to abdicate a large number of the opinions and beliefs and symbols that he has valued for the past generation. If he refuses to do so, there can be no doubt that he will lead Israel into a full-frontal collision, not just with the Palestinians, but with the entire Arab world.

Maybe that is why Sharon is worried. Paradoxically, this anxiety, and this initial awareness of his true political responsibility and of the complexity of the dilemmas that only a leader is forced to face, are encouraging signs that we can be comforted by (given that there is no other hope).

In this context it is interesting to note that, when the right has come to power, there has always been a sense that its leaders do not feel really sure of themselves at the wheel. Something in the rhetoric of Israel's rightwing prime ministers, from Begin to Netanyahu, has continued to be the rhetoric of opposition, of dissent against some lawful regime, even when they themselves were the regime. There were periods during Netanyahu's term, for example, when the government itself behaved as if it were a minority group being persecuted by some wraithlike hostile regime, as if it did not really believe in its own legitimacy.

If that turns out to be the situation this time, we will soon witness a dangerous flare-up of Israeli policy. This is liable to be expressed in more aggressive behaviour on the outside, along with contemptuous arrogance towards our neighbours (remember that Sharon instigated the Lebanon war in order to allow the Palestinians to take over Jordan!). This will also inflame the atmosphere within Israel and make its polarisation more severe. Experience of the years when the right ruled tells us to beware of spectacular, extreme acts that are ostensibly full of "grandeur" - a magic word for the right wing, a one-word slogan coined by Ze'ev Jabotinsky, the revisionist Zionist leader who was Begin's mentor. In reality, they more often than not take place on the boundary between the grotesque and the catastrophic.

The most extreme, fanatical and fundamentalist groups are now returning to the centre of Israel's public stage. The hopes of the moderate, liberal, secular centre to turn Israel into a truly democratic country - less militant in character, more civilian in nature, more egalitarian - have been dealt a resounding blow.

Again there is that old, disheartening sense that because of an unfortunate series of events, and because of a harsh and difficult history, Israelis are doomed to run again and again through a time loop, to once again accelerate settlement in the occupied territories and escalate the conflict between us and the countries around us. The rule that all of us know from our most private lives has come true once more: again and again we trip ourselves up precisely in those places where we are most in need of being saved, most in need of a new beginning.

Immediately after he was elected - as during his entire campaign - Sharon invited the Labour party to join a national unity government. There can be no doubt that in this he expresses the wishes of many Israelis on both the right and the left who yearn to recreate a sense of partnership and brotherhood that is so lacking in Israel today. It is difficult, however, to see what policies the two parties can unite around. Yet if they do succeed in finding a middle ground between them, Israel will find itself the prisoner of that same familiar tragic error that it has been trapped in for years. Once again Israel will present the Arab world with a position that is a respectable compromise between its centre-right and centre-left blocks. But this compromise will have almost no connection with the demands and troubles and hopes of the Palestinians - that is, no connection with reality. Israel will again conduct virtual negotiations between itself and itself, between itself and its fears. Then it will be surprised, and perhaps feel betrayed, when the Palestinians throw its proposals back in its face while setting off a new intifada.

As for the Palestinians, even when they declare that they see no difference between Sharon and Barak, they know very well how big the gap between the two is, and what the consequences will be. For that reason, apparently, they began, in the two weeks leading up to the elections, to gallop towards a compromise with Israel at the Taba talks. Too bad that this zeal was not evident a few weeks, or even months, earlier. It is also unfortunate that Arafat did not succeed in controlling his people and in channelling the authentic energy of the beginning of the intifada into a momentum for reaching an accord while Barak was in power. Dozens of innocent Israeli men, women and children were murdered by Palestinian terrorists during the election campaign. Each funeral, each orphan's tear, "proved" to the Israeli public that Barak had erred in agreeing to compromises. The public was pushed towards the man who promised them that he would not negotiate under fire. The despair and anxiety that possessed the Israeli public - and the total lack of awareness of Palestinian pain and suffering - are what has put Sharon in power. Paradoxically, the anxiety and despair are liable to bring about their own realisation.

The obvious conclusion from these elections is that the Israeli public is not yet ready for peace. Israelis want peace, of course, but they are not yet able to pay the heavy price that such an agreement requires. On the other side are the Palestinians, and they also, apparently, have not yet internalised the need for the painful compromises that peace requires. It is hard to see how we can get out of this dead end without another round of bloodshed.

Fairness requires that we give Sharon a chance to prove that he is right. There is a heavy feeling in my heart. Just writing this pains me - it is one thing to report on a train running off the tracks from a vantage point to the side. It is another thing entirely to report it from inside the train.

David Grossman

 Translated by Haim Watzman.

Arafat's gift to us: Sharon

Ehud Barak was voted down in the winter of 2001 for the very same reason that Yitzhak Rabin was killed in the autumn of 1995 and Shimon Peres was overthrown in the spring of 1996: all three were ahead of their times. Like other great modern leaders, all three had what Anwar Sadat and King Hussein of Jordan possessed, but Yasser Arafat sorely lacks: the courage to compromise and make peace even when many of their own people branded them traitors.

Last August, at Camp David, Barak proposed a peace agreement incorporating a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza Strip with minor border modifications, and with East Jerusalem as its capital. Clenching his teeth, Barak even agreed to place the contentious Temple Mount under Islamic protection.

Had the Palestinians accepted that offer, Barak would have won, albeit by a narrow majority, in the referendum on peace. Arafat's team might have demanded to reduce border amendments still further; negotiations would have continued until an agreement had been reached. But the Palestinians answered neither yes nor no. They answered by opening fire. They responded to Barak's offer by embarking on the Al Aksa intifada, a holy war manifestly intended to cleanse the disputed holy sites of a Jewish presence. They also put forward their sweeping claim to implementation of the "right of return", a code word for eradicating Israel.

Barak's Israel has sought peace, while Arafat's Palestine is demanding justice: full Palestinian justice, a whole and rounded justice that claims Palestine for the Palestinians and claims Israel for the Palestinians too. Justice that allots Islam's holy sites to Islam and denounces Jewish holy sites as fabrications. A tension runs between peace and justice: peace requires compromises; justice detests them.

In retrospect, it seems that at least part of the Palestinian leadership resolved to lash out with a tidal wave of violence immediately after Camp David, in order to topple Barak and drive Israel into the arms of its extremists. Barak's dramatic concessions yielded global support for Israel and put international pressure on the Palestinians to counter-compromise. Violence, so the Palestinian hardliners reckoned, would cajole Barak to use force, and thus lose favour with the international community. Violence would also make the Israelis desperate and push them into electing an extremist government. This, in turn, would ignite an all-Muslim jihad, isolate Israel like Slobodan Milosevic's Serbia, and finally corner it into an internationally enforced retreat from all contended territories, with no matching Palestinian commitment to peace and abandonment of future claims.

Israel, to be sure, is no innocent bystander: both sides abused the Oslo accord. The Palestinians shed blood, set up a shadow army, and abetted hate speech in schools and mosques. The Israelis shed blood, doubled the number of settlements, and inflicted humiliation, oppression and deprivation on the Palestinians.

Barak was voted down because he believed that Palestinian pragmatists would see his courageous concessions at least as a fair platform for final accords. He could only confront Palestinian violence by using force; turning the other cheek was hardly an option. Indeed, in some cases Barak overreacted. He personally, and Israel as a whole, are paying a terrible price for such excessive use of force.

The Israeli voters fell into the Palestinian trap and elected Sharon. They did so out of disappointment with the peace process, out of agony and anger, out of fear of a violent Palestinian blackmail that will not end until Israel falls apart. It is too early to say whether Sharon too will take up the role intended for him in the rejectionist Palestinian script: the role of an Israeli Milosevic, manipulated into brutal retaliation that would tear Israel apart and wreck its international dignity. If he does, Israel will have to surrender to Arab pressures or to break asunder.

But perhaps Arafat may find in Sharon what he did not find in Rabin, Peres or Barak: a twin soul. A fanatic nationalist to face a fanatic nationalist, a blood-shedder confronting a blood-shedder, yesterday's man versus yesterday's man. Sharon and Arafat are now heading two hurt and angry nations. They skilfully represent the self-righteousness, suspiciousness and frustration typical of both nations. Twin souls indeed. And perhaps this anachronistic twosome may find a common idiom. Love at first sight? The beginning of a beautiful friendship? Stranger partnerships have often blossomed in Middle Eastern history.

Israel's peace movement, however, can await no miracles. It will continue to work for the solution that, deep in their hearts, almost everyone - Israelis and Palestinians, moderates and fanatics - acknowledges as inescapable: a fair peace accord. Two states for two nations.

Amos Oz

fields.bodyText: When Ariel Sharon made his victory speech on Tuesday night, his supporters whistled in contempt and loathing each time their leader mentioned Ehud Barak, the left and the Palestinians. That triad has clearly been punished in the most painful possible way by the Israeli public. As one voter said, in perfect sincerity: "I'm not sure that Sharon is the best for Israel, but the Palestinians deserve him!" This man, whom many had already written off as a has-been, this power-obsessed, devious extremist of questionable behaviour who has failed in nearly every public office he has held, who has injured nearly everyone who has been his ally, has now been handed an entire country. He can now try out his views, and his instincts, on it. Unlike in the past, this time there is no one, almost, who can stop him. But perhaps that is precisely the reason that in the final days of his campaign, when his victory was already assured, Sharon's mood suddenly changed. Sharon, who has a cynical and ven omous sense of humour, and an almost compulsive urge to crack jokes, looked melancholy and lifeless during the days leading up to the election. One of his associates said: "It's as if something in him went out." At moments, perhaps for the first time in his life, he looked almost frightened. All his life Sharon has operated from the position of the oppositionist, even when he was a cabinet minister. He always, always, challenged the authority of his superiors, both in the army and in the government. A large part of what he did in his military and political careers was done while circumventing authority, disobeying orders, inciting against his leader, and even - as in the case of the Lebanon war - deceiving his superiors. And now, suddenly, at the age of 73, he is himself the superior. He is the authority. He is the man who is responsible for the country. And there is no one to stop him. Now he is prime minister of one of the most complicated countries in the world, deep in the most extremely delicate situation it has seen for decades. Perhaps Sharon knows, deep down in his heart, that if he does indeed mean to ensure his country's future, he will have to abdicate a large number of the opinions and beliefs and symbols that he has valued for the past generation. If he refuses to do so, there can be no doubt that he will lead Israel into a full-frontal collision, not just with the Palestinians, but with the entire Arab world. Maybe that is why Sharon is worried. Paradoxically, this anxiety, and this initial awareness of his true political responsibility and of the complexity of the dilemmas that only a leader is forced to face, are encouraging signs that we can be comforted by (given that there is no other hope). Something in the rhetoric of Israel's rightwing prime ministers, from Begin to Netanyahu, has continued to be the rhetoric of opposition, of dissent against some lawful regime, even when they themselves were the regime. There were periods during Netanyahu's term, for example, when the government itself behaved as if it were a minority group being persecuted by some wraithlike hostile regime, as if it did not really believe in its own legitimacy. If that turns out to be the situation this time, we will soon witness a dangerous flare-up of Israeli policy. This is liable to be expressed in more aggressive behaviour on the outside, along with contemptuous arrogance towards our neighbours (remember that Sharon instigated the Lebanon war in order to allow the Palestinians to take over Jordan!). This will also inflame the atmosphere within Israel and make its polarisation more severe. Experience of the years when the right ruled tells us to beware of spectacular, extreme acts that are ostensibly full of "grandeur" - a magic word for the right wing, a one-word slogan coined by Ze'ev Jabotinsky, the revisionist Zionist leader who was Begin's mentor. In reality, they more often than not take place on the boundary between the grotesque and the catastrophic. The most extreme, fanatical and fundamentalist groups are now returning to the centre of Israel's public stage. The hopes of the moderate, liberal, secular centre to turn Israel into a truly democratic country - less militant in character, more civilian in nature, more egalitarian - have been dealt a resounding blow. Once again Israel will present the Arab world with a position that is a respectable compromise between its centre-right and centre-left blocks. fields.headline: Coca-Cola updates marketing strategy
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Coca-Cola wants to use quirky promotions to make the brand relevant to people's lives, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is planning to expand on its traditional TV-led approach to marketing.

The company wants to embrace more innovative methods such as viral emails and quirky promotions.

The move will mean an increase in marketing and advertising spend and activity.

The advertiser spends about £25m a year on advertising in the UK.

A "whole step-change in communications" is taking place at Coke, according to a company spokesman.

He said the move to new marketing methods was being driven by a need for the brand to become more relevant to people's lives.

"Innovation is the key, we are always looking for new ways to connect with consumers," he added.

"We have to ensure the best marketeers are coming up with new ways of communicating with consumers."

There will be a repeat of the Coke Auction, which last year encouraged consumers to collect tokens for the chance to bid online for items such as university fees, a lunch with Kevin Keegan and a tour of the Benetton formula one factory.

The Coca-Cola spokesman cited the energy drink Burn, which Coke launched last October, as an example of how the company's marketing is changing.

There is no advertising behind Burn, which is stocked in trendy London bars and clubs, and the only promotion has been a viral email campaign passed around by consumers.

"This is discovery marketing - letting people find out about the brand for themselves. If you had a big advertising campaign, the consumer in this niche would reject it," said the spokesman.

He added the company was to launch five brands in to the UK this year.

These will include Fanta Icy Lemon, a still drink for teenagers called Alive, a relaunched Oasis, and a sports energy drink called Powerade.

The brands will be marketed with a mixture of new and conventional methods.

A wholesale shake-up of Coke's advertising agencies is under way.

Trendy ad agencies such as Soul and Mother have picked up business in the UK.

Last week Coke admitted its marketing efforts in its key markets - the US and Germany - have failed to communicate "brand Coke".

fields.headline: Premier League pay-per-view deal founders
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Premier League football clubs could start next season without a pay-per-view deal, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Premier League football clubs could start next season without a pay-per-view deal as negotiations with broadcasters continue to stall.

The bidders, who include BSkyB, ONdigital, NTL and newcomer u>direct, are having doubts about making money from a PPV package.

"There is a long way to go before anyone gets anything and you have to ask yourself whether anyone can get it organised in time," said one source close to the bidding.

League officials have struggled to secure an arrangement since cable company NTL pulled out of a £326m deal last October.

There are concerns about how much money PPV can generate.

"No one really understands if there is much of a market for it and that is part of the issue," added the source.

Sources at BSkyB and ONdigital - which have previously been tipped as the front-runners for a deal - deny they are anywhere close to serious negotiations.

And u>direct has indicated it cannot afford to get involved in an auction with BSkyB - it too is waiting to make any serious move.

The Premier League's broadcasting committee must decide if it should give the broadcast rights to a single bidder.

Alternatively, it could hive off the cable, internet, digital and satellite franchises to individual companies.

Martin Stewart, chief financial officer at BSkyB, refused to confirm whether the satellite broadcaster was even involved in talks.

He hinted the company would look at PPV after a deal was concluded.

"If there is something we can do with PPV we would be foolish not to look at it. We will be very interested in what people say," he said.

Asked if this meant he was involved in talks, he replied: "I didn't say that."

Even if the Premier League and its 22 club chairmen manage to secure a deal, it will be far below the £328m originally offered by NTL.

The choice of games will also be limited.

The winner of the PPV licence will only be able to select its match after BSkyB, which paid £1.2bn for the broadcasting rights.

A Premier League spokesman could not confirm when a deal would be signed but said negotiations were continuing.

"We are still in detailed negotiations.

"A deal will be concluded as soon as the broadcasting team makes its recommendation to the club chairmen," said the spokesman.

webTitle: Straw tries to soften rejection of drug report

fields.headline: Straw tries to soften rejection of drug report
fields.standfirst: Users given cautions need not tell employers
fields.trailText: The government yesterday tried to take the sting out of its rejection of a report urging reform of drugs laws by announcing that the 50,000 offenders cautioned each year for cannabis possession will not be given criminal records in the future.
fields.body:
The government yesterday tried to take the sting out of its rejection of a report urging reform of drugs laws by announcing that the 50,000 offenders cautioned each year for cannabis possession will not be given criminal records in the future.

Ministers announced that they intend to change the legislation on the rehabilitation of offenders to ensure that the cautions 266,000 people receive each year for all offences, including drugs, will not have to be declared to employers or when travelling abroad.

They also agreed they would review sentencing to ensure that those who are caught selling drugs to a few friends are not treated as harshly as professional dealers.

Home Office ministers have been criticised for their rejection of the 24 main recommendations of the report of the Police Foundation inquiry into the state of Britain's drugs laws.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, finally announced his "considered response" to the landmark report of the inquiry, chaired by Dame Ruth Runciman and which included two serving chief constables.

Mr Straw confirmed yesterday that he had rejected its key recommendations to end the imprisonment of those convicted of cannabis possession and for a less serious classification of drugs such as ecstasy and LSD, which are bracketed with heroin and cocaine. The inquiry argued that the criminal penalties for cannabis possession often did more harm than the drug itself.

The Home Office response yesterday said it was necessary to keep a prison sentence on the statute book for simple possession of cannabis as "an important backstop to ensure that defendants appear in court" and "as an incentive to treatment".

Ministers agreed with the Police Foundation that ecstasy was less toxic than heroin or cocaine but said that when, three years ago, the advisory council on the misuse of drugs discussed its status it concluded that it posed "very real risks of fits, seizures, mental disturbances and death".

It also identified possible longer-term risks to mental health.

Similarly, on LSD the Home Office agreed it was less dangerous than heroin or cocaine but said it should remain a class A drug because "a bad trip is impossible to predict and can be terrifying".

The official Home Office response adds: "Users may be prone to accidents while they are hallucinating and they experience flash backs, often some considerable time after the event."

It also warned that LSD can complicate mental problems such as depression, anxiety and schizophrenia.

One result of the report, however, is that an anti-drug driving publicity campaign - similar to the familiar drink- drive advertisements - is to be launched by the transport authorities.

But the rejection of the landmark report dismayed drugs law reform campaigners.

The head of the inquiry, Lady Runciman, said: "It is disappointing that a real opportunity for constructive dialogue and incremental change has been missed. All our most far-reaching recommendations have been rejected. At no point has the rationale underlying the proposals been addressed. It leaves us with a law that is out of touch with reality. I believe this is good report. Its time will come."

David Winnick, a Labour backbench member of the Commons home affairs committee, agreed with Lady Runciman, adding that he hoped a more sensible debate on drugs would emerge after the pressures of the forthcoming general election campaign had passed.

fields.headline: Viagra rationing 'a risk to health'
fields.standfirst: Doctors say impotence masks serious problems and treatment should be freely available
fields.trailText: NHS rationing of Viagra and other drug treatments for impotence is endangering men's health since the condition is often an early sign of dangerous illness, a coalition of doctors and patients said yesterday.
fields.body:
NHS rationing of Viagra and other drug treatments for impotence is endangering men's health since the condition is often an early sign of dangerous illness, a coalition of doctors and patients said yesterday.

The "unfair and irrational" restrictions put on Viagra's use nearly two years ago meant that only about a fifth of those who would benefit were getting free treatment.

Government fears that wider NHS prescription would help to send its drug bill soaring were ill-founded, said the campaigners, responding to a government review of its rules.

Confusion about such drugs' availability was instead helping to deter men - always reluctant visitors at GPs' surgeries - even to report health problems to doctors.

John Chisholm, chairman of the British Medical Association's GP committee, said: "Erectile dysfunction is a highly distressing condition that has very considerable effects not just on men's lives, but on their relationships, their partners and families.

"It not only causes problems in sexual performance but leads to anxiety, depression, even on occasions suicide. We should not lightly dismiss the significance of the condition by regarding it as trivial, or a bit of a joke."

GPs are allowed to prescribe impotence drugs for a dozen conditions, including diabetes, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, polio and prostate cancer, and to refer patients with all conditions to specialist consultants where they are suffering "severe distress". But campaigners said this was adding to outpatient waiting lists.

The government's recommended treatment for Viagra is one tablet a week, and most GPs start patients on a pack of four 25mg tablets, costing £16.59. Up to 10% of men may suffer impotence problems at some stage in their lives, said campaigners.

There was no evidence that overwhelming demand would "bankrupt" the NHS, and more treatments would save money on treating social consequences of impotence, including alcohol abuse and absenteeism.

Ian Banks, chairman of the Men's Health Forum, said that at present men on average saw GPs only half as often as women. "Men will be even less likely to attend in these conditions. Erectile dysfunction is often one of the first signs of a more serious underlying condition, and I don't think it is up to the government to decide the impact on the man or his partner."

Campaigners also warned that men desperate for treatment might get supplies privately or through the internet.

The "unfair and irrational" restrictions put on Viagra's use nearly two years ago meant that only about a fifth of those who would benefit were getting free treatment. Government fears that wider NHS prescription would help to send its drug bill soaring were ill-founded, said the campaigners, responding to a government review of its rules. Confusion about such drugs' availability was instead helping to deter men - always reluctant visitors at GPs' surgeries - even to report health problems to doctors. John Chisholm, chairman of the British Medical Association's GP committee, said: "Erectile dysfunction is a highly distressing condition that has very considerable effects not just on men's lives, but on their relationships, their partners and families. "It not only causes problems in sexual performance but leads to anxiety, depression, even on occasions suicide. We should not lightly dismiss the significance of the condition by regarding it as trivial, or a bit of a joke." GPs are allowed to prescribe impotence drugs for a dozen conditions, including diabetes, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, polio and prostate cancer, and to refer patients with all conditions to specialist consultants where they are suffering "severe distress". But campaigners said this was adding to outpatient waiting lists. The government's recommended treatment for Viagra is one tablet a week, and most GPs start patients on a pack of four 25mg tablets, costing £16.59. Up to 10% of men may suffer impotence problems at some stage in their lives, said campaigners. There was no evidence that overwhelming demand would "bankrupt" the NHS, and more treatments would save money on treating social consequences of impotence, including alcohol abuse and absenteeism. Ian Banks, chairman of the Men's Health Forum, said that at present men on average saw GPs only half as often as women. "Men will be even less likely to attend in these conditions. Erectile dysfunction is often one of the first signs of a more serious underlying condition, and I don't think it is up to the government to decide the impact on the man or his partner." Campaigners also warned that men desperate for treatment might get supplies privately or through the internet.

fields.headline: BT hit by rising debt
fields.trailText: 11am: BT has reported a sharp drop in underlying profits due to the huge cost of mobile phone licences, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
British Telecom has reported a sharp drop in underlying profits and earnings per share, due to the crippling cost of next generation mobile phone licences.

The £9bn spent on licences in the UK and Germany alone has helped push BT's debt to a staggering £30bn, saddling the company with enormous interest fees.

"The lower earnings in the current period were mainly due to higher interest charges following BT's acquisition of businesses and third generation mobile licences over the year," said BT in a statement.

BT has also spent £4bn on doubling its stake in German mobile phone company Viag Interkom and £3.5bn on Esat Telecom in the Republic of Ireland.

Although BT today reported pre-tax profits of £760m for the three months to December last year, up from £651m for the same period in 1999, the figures were flattered by income from disposals.

The effects of the interest payments become clear as soon as the £500m raised from selling various assets is removed from BT's profit figures.

This is underlined by the slump in earnings per share from 8p to 4.3p.

However, BT executives today insisted that the flotation of its mobile phone division remained the cornerstone of the company's debt reduction strategy.

The stock market launch of BT Wireless, which is expected to raise around £8bn, has been put in doubt because of rival Orange's difficulties in getting its share offer off the ground.

The France Telecom-owned company has been forced to slash its valuation by £6.4bn, as sceptical investors balk at investing in a debt-laden sector.

But BT chief executive Peter Bonfield said he still expected the flotation to go ahead, and that other debt reduction strategies will cut BT's deficit to £20bn by year end.

This means that plans for a flotation or demerger of the Yell listings business and the flotation of its stake in Spanish telecoms operator Airtel will still go ahead.

fields.headline: Interflora ad too racy for Private Eye
fields.standfirst: Click here to see the ad
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Private Eye has finally found something too controversial to print - a Valentine's Day ad for Interflora, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
After decades of searching, the publisher of Private Eye has finally found something too controversial to print - a Valentine's Day ad for Interflora.

The sudden attack of prudishness was prompted by an ad that featured a female torso with roses in place of her breasts.

It had the strapline "Tit elation".

Private Eye rejected the ad, which is under investigation by the Advertising Standards Authority, but agreed to run a toned-down alternative.

The replacement ad, which was created to run in the Financial Times, used the same image with the strapline "Asset management".

The campaign, a radical departure from Interflora's usually safe advertising, also includes an ad aimed at the gay press.

It uses three roses to depict male genitalia and carries the strapline "Floral sex".

"As far as we're concerned this is a very tasteful campaign," said an Interflora spokeswoman.

"Each execution is aimed at a specific target audience whom we have been careful not to offend."

The ASA confirmed it was looking into the campaign after it received one complaint from a member of the public.

fields.headline: Analysts fear cooling US economy
fields.standfirst:
The Bank of England cuts reflect concerns that a US recession could spread to Britain, says economics correspondent Charlotte Denny
More business news
fields.trailText: The Bank of England cuts reflect concerns that a US recession could spreadto Britain, says economics correspondent Charlotte Denny.
fields.body:
After 12 months of sitting on its hands, the Bank of England's monetary policy committee has finally cut interest rates.

The decision to reduce borrowing costs by 0.25% to 5.75% was widely expected by City analysts who are predicting further rate cuts in the months ahead.

Today's move by the Bank was probably a response to worries about the rapid cooling in the American economy - although we will not know for sure until the minutes of the meeting are released in two weeks time.

Growth in the world's largest economy has slowed to zero, according to the chairman of the US federal reserve, Alan Greenspan.

Threadneedle Street fears that a US recession could spread across the Atlantic to Britain because of close investment and trade links between the two economies.

As yet, there are few signs of a slowdown in Britain. Although growth slowed to its slowest pace in two years in the last quarter of 2000, one off factors like the chaos on the railways and a sharp drop in energy consumption and extraction are to blame.

Consumer spending has yet to slow significantly and even the manufacturing sector is still showing signs of life.

So why did the Bank move now, rather than wait until there definite signs that the British economy is catching a chill from America?

According to Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist at Deutsche Bank, the MPC's philosophy today was a stitch in time saves nine.

"By cutting early, and arguably proactively, the MPC may ultimately reduce the amount of cuts needed," he said.

The Bank has plenty of room to manoeuvre - inflation has been under the government 2.5% target for 22 months and some economist predict it could fall as low as 1.5% later this year.

Finally, there is the political dimension. Although the minutes will almost certainly make no mention of it, the MPC's next meeting comes hard on the heels of the likely date of Gordon Brown's budget, while the one after could well be in the middle of the election campaign.

Cutting rates over the next few months therefore risks looking like a political move - either an endorsement of the Budget or a boost to the government ahead of the election - and the Bank cannot afford to have its reputation for independence compromised.

Moving early avoids the problem.

fields.headline: BBC confirms sports channel talks
fields.trailText: 9.30am: The BBC has confirmed NTL as the corporation's 'preferred partner' for a planned sports channel, writes Jessica Hodgson .
fields.byline: By Jessica Hodgson and Lisa O'Carroll
fields.body:
The BBC has confirmed that cable TV company NTL is the corporation's "preferred partner" for a planned sports channel.

A BBC spokesman said that any deal had "a long way to go".

But he added: "We are making progress on discussions."

Director-general Greg Dyke last week admitted he was looking into launching a pay channel as part of his drive to boost its beleaguered sports department.

He has decided to pursue the pay-television strategy because the corporation cannot compete with the chequebooks of Rupert Murdoch's Sky TV and ITV bosses who last year dealt a devastating blow to the corporation by snatching the rights to Premier League football highlights.

The idea was first mooted by Mr Dyke's predecessor Lord Birt two years ago when it seemed that the BBC's sports department - then under the stewardship of the much-criticised Mike Miller - could never recover from the relentless loss of sports events to rivals.

The channel would be used as a "spillover" service, offering viewers a chance to see sports such as minor Wimbledon matches which could not be fitted into BBC1 and BBC2 schedules.

BBC bosses already have an alliance with NTL - they have a £24m four-year deal to show rugby union's European Cup and they have also clinched a deal to screen the BBC's considerable archive.

They also joined forces last year in a £10m deal to produce NTL's pay-per-view football matches although this has collapsed following the cable giant's decision to pull out of the £327m deal with the Premier League.

Rivals, however, today expressed surprise that the BBC could be on the verge of any deal.

"They have been talking to everyone. They are basically trying to find something for their presentation team to do. Once the Premiership goes people like John Motson and Gary Lineker will find themselves under-occupied," said one pay-TV executive.

"I can't see what the BBC will screen on the channel. They simply don't have enough to make a sports channel attractive enough to compete with Sky Sports."

The deal, however, could entail BBC involvement in British Eurosport, which is part-owned by NTL.

And the BBC may yet secure rights to car rallying - it is currently in head-to-head competition for the TV rights with Channel 4, which also plans a sports channel.

The corporation is virtually certain to secure rights to top horse-racing events as part of the Go Racing deal with the Racecourse Association.

An alliance with NTL would set the corporation on a war footing with BSkyB, which will do everything in its power to strangle the competition at birth.

A BBC-backed sports channel would face fierce opposition from commercial broadcasters, who object to the BBC cross-fertilising its commercial activities with licence-fee funded material.

NTL's bid to screen pay-per-view Premier League football collapsed last year amid doubts that the company could make back the £328m it spent on the rights.
