webTitle: Tough action to rescue industrial heart

fields.headline: Tough action to rescue industrial heart
fields.trailText: Manchester city council has backed an ambitious £10m urban regeneration scheme involving one of the largest compulsory purchase orders of its type in a British city.
fields.body:
Manchester city council has backed an ambitious £10m urban regeneration scheme involving one of the largest compulsory purchase orders of its type in a British city.

Tough powers forcing landowners to hand over derelict buildings and sites for redevelopment are to be invoked by the northwest development agency in an attempt to rescue Ancoats, the old manufacturing heart of Manchester and England's first industrial suburb.

With concern growing about the decline of the Ancoats area, which contains seven grade II* listed buildings and a clutch of early 19th century cotton mills, the agency has threatened around 100 owners with compulsory purchase orders. The exercise could cost it £10m.

The agency said it had been forced to act to prevent a crucial 20 acres, barely half a mile from the centre of Manchester, from "sinking into oblivion".

Fears are growing that some owners are holding on to key sites and buildings in the hope of making a killing as land appreciates in value on the back of nearby developments.

Manchester city centre, which housed only a few hundred people 10 years ago, now has a population approaching 10,000, with some penthouses fetching £1m.

But so far the wealth has failed to trickle down to the Ancoats district, which has been earmarked for redevelopment by an urban village company, backed by the development agency and the city council.

It is labelled the world's first industrial suburb, and its oldest cotton mill dates back to 1798, while many of its successors pioneered mass production with steam-driven spinning techniques.

A few buildings have been transformed into workshops and cafes, but the village company says scores of others can be converted to mixed use, embracing flats and offices.

Only 400 people now live in the area, although planners hope it will eventually accommodate 3,000, with new schools and health centres. Lyn Fenton, the chief executive, said the company was determined to ensure new housing went to people on lower incomes to create an inclusive community.

"We would be very disappointed if we ended up with only high-priced apartments, because higher earners are already catered for in the city."

While land in the city centre is going for up to £7m an acre, prices so far are much more depressed in Ancoats. However, the development agency has set aside around £10m to buy land and properties.

fields.headline: Hartson finally joins Coventry
fields.trailText: John Hartson has at last completed his on-off move from Wimbledon to Coventry this morning. The saga finally reached a conclusion late last night and the 25-year-old Welsh international will train today with his new team-mates.
fields.body:
John Hartson has at last completed his on-off move from Wimbledon to Coventry this morning. The saga finally reached a conclusion late last night and the 25-year-old Welsh international will train today with his new team-mates.

The fee is uncertain but it is believed Wimbledon will be paid on a pay-for-play basis.

Coventry chairman Bryan Richardson said: "We are delighted John is joining us. We have agreed terms with Wimbledon, details of which will remain private between the clubs."

The deal for Hartson - who had seen moves to Tottenham and Rangers fail for medical reasons in recent months - has gone through at the third time of asking for Coventry.

The Sky Blues tried but failed to sign the Welsh international striker for £5m last month because Cedric Roussel was unwilling to make the move from the Premiership side to Wimbledon.

A second attempt at landing Hartson foundered last week, with Richardson blaming "a purely technical reason".

But Coventry's determination to get their man bore fruit - and the club are hopeful he will make his debut against former club West Ham on Monday. To that end the club will not be unveiling their new signing at a press conference, preferring instead to send Hartson straight into training.

Sky Blues manager Gordon Strachan is desperate to bring in a new striker to bolster an attack which has managed just 23 goals in 26 Premiership matches.

His signing of Hartson, who has notched 10 goals in 22 appearances this season for Terry Burton's side, gives the Sky Blues an all-Welsh partnership up front, with £6.5m club-record signing Craig Bellamy.

fields.headline: BBC confronts current affairs deficit
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC is to give its current affairs output a confrontational edge with a new four-part series, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC is preparing to liven up its current affairs output with a new four-part series fronted by Paul Kenyon.

Mr Kenyon was pinpointed by head of current affairs Peter Horrocks as an ideal presenter for the show, to be called called Kenyon Confronts.

The BBC has long sought to bring more "personality" to its current affairs coverage.

Mr Kenyon's confrontational style is described as "Roger Cook meets Donal MacIntyre" - a reference to the controversial hit series MacIntyre Undercover.

Kenyon Confronts will launch with an expose of fake marriages in Britain.

Mr Kenyon will pose as a wedding photographer and will snap a variety of sham marriages, including one in which a groom is unable to remember the name of his bride.

This subject was once explored by Mr MacIntyre as an undercover reporter on World in Action.

A spokeswoman said the series would be "almost funny and sometimes cringey".

The programme is to air on Monday nights at 7.30pm.

The ratings for the BBC's flagship current affairs programme Panorama are in decline.

Last year, the programme was moved from its Monday night slot to Sunday evenings, prompting accusations of dumbing down.

Since the move, the show has struggled to attract more than 3m.

fields.headline: Wieden loses £5m Virgin games account
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Wieden & Kennedy is understood to have lost the £5m account for Virgin's games publishing arm, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Wieden & Kennedy is understood to have lost the £5m advertising account for Virgin's games publishing arm, Virgin Interactive Entertainment.

The news comes less than a year after Wieden won the advertising business in a pitch against Court Burkitt & Company.

The agency was hired to launch Virgin's games brands across Europe by making each launch a big event.

Virgin's games include Carmaggedon, Command & Conquer and Street Fighter.

A spokesman for Virgin refused to either confirm or deny reports of a split, describing it as "unofficial".

But sources said the two companies were no longer working together.

No one at Wieden & Kennedy was available for comment.

fields.headline: Express loses sports columnist
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Charles Sale, the widely regarded sports writer, has quit the Express to join arch-rival the Daily Mail, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
Special report: Express Takeover
fields.body:
Charles Sale, the widely regarded sports writer, has quit the Express to join arch-rival the Daily Mail.

And the Mail's new sports editor Colin Gibson is also in talks with Sunday Telegraph golfing guru Derek Lawrenson.

Mr Sale, who has a daily inside-back-page sports column, has been wooed by several papers in the past, including the Times.

"Joining the Mail is like joining Manchester United," said Mr Sale.

The Mail has also offered associate sports editorship to Paul Newman, who has the same role on the Sunday Telegraph.

Mr Gibson, a former sports editor of the Sunday paper, joined the Mail earlier this year.

He described Mr Sale as "the best foot-in-the-door sports journalist" in Fleet Street.

He is the latest of a series of high-profile names - including leader writer Stephen Bollard and editor Rosie Boycott - to quit the Express.

webTitle: MPs back bill on sharing patient information

fields.headline: MPs back bill on sharing patient information
fields.trailText: MPs have backed controversial government proposals to give the health secretary powers to disclose patient information without consent, despite criticisms that it could threaten patient privacy.
fields.body:
MPs have backed controversial government proposals to give the health secretary powers to disclose patient information without consent, despite criticisms that it could threaten patient privacy.

But ministers have moved to address critics' concerns by promising to work with doctors and patient groups to ensure the powers - described as "Orwellian" by critics - are properly regulated to prevent abuses.

Clause 59 of the bill, which was passed by a Labour-dominated scrutiny committee today, will enable the health secretary to approve disclosure of confidential patient information where it is in the public interest.

The British Medical Association had warned that it was unhappy that the bill would give "sweeping" new powers to the minister, and called for restrictions and safeguards to ensure the power is not abused.

Ministers believe the clause will safeguard essential "public interest" medical work in areas such as cancer research which requires the use confidential patient information.

Health minister John Denham said he would work closely with professional bodies to ensure adequate safeguards are drawn up to guarantee applications for use of patient information are rigorously tested, and scrutinised in parliament.

The bill has completed its committee stage. It moves on to report stage and third reading next week before going to the House of Lords.

Mr Denham said: "While the government believes informed consent for the use of confidential patient information should be obtained wherever possible, there are some situations where obtaining informed consent proves impractical and sometimes cannot be done.

"The bill will ensure that doctors can share patient information in such circumstances, if doing so will benefit patients and the public.

"Our prime objective is to safeguard existing practices, for example, cancer registries, which help to develop more effective treatments for cancer."

"Confidential patient information should only be used where there is a real need and where it is clearly in the interests of patients and the public, and critically, only when there is no reasonable, practicable alternative."

Mr Denham said the proposed powers had the backing of the data protection commissioner, on the grounds that it would protect the interests of patients.

He added that the clause was not intended to ban "awkward" reports about the NHS, but to protect patient information from innapropriate use by pharmaceutical companies.

webTitle: How a boy secured a prince's privacy

fields.headline: How a boy secured a prince's privacy
fields.trailText:
Lord Wakeham claimed last night that reporting standards have improved, as Prince William attended the PCC's 10th birthday party, attended by Prince William, writes Matt Wells.
The PCC's greatest hits
fields.body:
Accrington boy met Eton boy last night when press watchdogs threw one of the most unlikely parties of the social calendar to show how an ordinary schoolboy helped secure the privacy of a future King.

As the television B-list rubbed shoulders with the royal A-list, Prince William stepped into the bear-pit called the Press Complaints' Commission 10th anniversary party for his first public engagement.

Entering the ornate Silver Gallery at Somerset House in London, the prince made for Christopher Livesey, the subject of a PCC ruling when he was 15. His local paper in Accrington, Lancashire, had breached the editor's code by interviewing him without the permission of his parents. The PCC chairman, Lord Wakeham, had said in a speech to newspaper editors: "What goes for a child in Accrington goes for a child in Eton."

The prince has moved on from his school days and is preparing for life at St Andrews, while Mr Livesey is a student at Liverpool Metropolitan University. The two chatted for several minutes, and Mr Livesey said: "I'm proud that my case was used to protect the prince while at Eton."

The PCC has been successful at negotiating an understanding between the press and St James's Palace over how Prince William should be treated. Lord Wakeham said he would continue to make media appearances, but expressed a hope that there would be no unauthorised photography of the prince as he pursued his art history course.

The prince was given a taste of his future role when he was guided through a packed crowd of minor soap stars, major actors, and newspaper editors of varying prominence.

But despite the opulence of the setting and the grandeur of the hosts, there was something decidedly low-rent about the affair. From Coronation Street's Liz Dawn to designer Donatella Versace, all had to wait their turn for a few words with the finally-bemused prince.

The diversity of the guest list was a gift to newspaper sketch writers. The strangest sight was Camilla Parker Bowles leading Joanna Lumley through half the cast of Coronation Street to meet William Hague and Sebastian Coe - stopping off via Richard Branson.

Or perhaps it was Mrs Parker Bowles deep in conversation with the Mirror editor Piers Morgan: "We come from the same town," he said excitedly.

Also odd to behold was Andrew Neil accosting Prince William to talk about the delights of St Andrews, where the newspaper publisher is rector.

Prince William seemed to take it all in his stride, despite being forced to make small talk with the unlikeliest of stars - to John Savident, yet another escapee from the Coronation Street, he quipped: "I watch EastEnders." He was clearly more at home discussing the merits of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels with Vinnie Jones; and to a glamorous Radio 1 producer, he declared his enthusiasm for DJs Sara Cox and Chris Moyles.

As for the rest, as the prince's entourage pushed towards the exit, editors made idle chat with some of the people who had complained to the PCC about stories they had sanctioned.

For some, such as Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre, it was a rare outing on the celebrity circuit. For Prince William, Prince Charles and Mrs Parker Bowles, it was their first public engagement together - although all three arrived and left separately.

For the future king, it must have all been rather strange. "It's not an ordeal," he said. "I'm just happy to be here and say thank you to people."

webTitle: Charities say business giving too little

fields.headline: Charities say business giving too little
fields.trailText: Charity leaders called yesterday for the naming and shaming of prominent businesses that give little or nothing to support voluntary organisations working to benefit their local communities.
fields.body:
Charity leaders called yesterday for the naming and shaming of prominent businesses that give little or nothing to support voluntary organisations working to benefit their local communities.

The National Council for Voluntary Organisations produced a manifesto calling on the next government to publish an official league table showing the proportion of profits donated to charity.

It said the business sector provided only 5% of the voluntary sector's donated income. Charities received £315m a year from businesses, but 97% of this came from just 400 companies.

The remaining 3.7m businesses in the UK gave a grand total of £10m - averaging less than £3 a year each.

Stuart Etherington, NCVO's chief executive, said: "The gloves are off in relation to business giving. We have tried to engage with companies and I would be the first to praise those that do well. But it is time the government got tougher by taking a more active stance in encouraging businesses to give."

His intervention came at the NCVO annual conference in London where it was announced that Prince William is to receive an award for his voluntary work in Chile with Raleigh International, teaching in the Patagonian village of Tortel.

Mr Etherington said naming and shaming the meanest businesses should be a last resort. But the government's plea for a new chapter in business giving had not yet materialised.

He refused to name any of the uncharitable firms at this stage, but the NCVO published case studies of successful partnerships between voluntary organisations and firms including NatWest, Avon Cosmetics and Kind Direct, a distributor of goods donated by firms to charities.

The NCVO manifesto said the government should set a target for UK businesses to give 1% of their profits to charity, worth £1.25bn a year.

Business in the Community, a group of 700 socially responsible firms, said the NCVO figures underestimated firms' investment of time and money in community projects.

David Blunkett, education and employment secretary, announced further concessions for charities in addition to a promise on Tuesday to scrap a £10-£15 charge for security checks on volunteers.

webTitle: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Forbidden Planet | The Thin Red Line | Futbol Argentina
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Will Hodgkinson and Simon Burnton
fields.body:
Films

Forbidden Planet (Fred McLeod Wilcox, 1956) 5pm, TCM Sci-fi version of The Tempest, with Walter Pidgeon's Morbius the Prospero figure marooned in space with virginal daughter Anne Francis and Robby the Robot. Leslie Nielsen's rescue-mission crew is charmed by the Eden it finds, then terrorised by the Monster from the Id. Impressively made, though some of the acting lets it down.

Au Hasard, Balthazar (Robert Bresson, 1966) 6pm, FilmFour The story of a donkey, Balthazar by name, whose life's struggles are presented as an austere, enigmatic parable. The donkey - closely associated in Bresson's Catholic scheme of things with Christ - is a beast taking on ever-heavier burdens, moving from child's pet to circus performer to agricultural toiler, and finally being roped into a smuggling operation. Breaks your heart, without resorting to outright sentimentality.

The Thin Red Line (Terence Malick, 1998) 8pm, Sky Premier Malick returned from a 20-year self-imposed exile to make this, only his third feature, and most of Hollywood flocked to enlist in the project. His adaptation of James Jones's novel is set during the savage battle for Guadalcanal in the Pacific during the second world war. It's a semi-mystical meditation on men in battle that builds a collage of thoughts and feelings, amid scenes of terrifying brutality, committed on an island of stunning beauty. A strange and magnificent paradise lost.

Nosferatu The Vampyre (Werner Herzog, 1979) 12.25am, FilmFour Interesting to view this remake of FW Murnau's 1922 silent, creepy classic in the light of Shadow Of The Vampire, the new Malkovich/Dafoe movie about the making of the original Nosferatu. Produced, written and directed by Herzog, it suffers from an almost undead enervation, replicating Murnau's admittedly chilling images scene by scene. Fantastic cast, though - Bruno Gant and Isabelle Adjani as the vampire-cursed Harkers; Klaus Kinski a ghoulish abomination as Dracula.

Rumble Fish (Francis Ford Coppola, 1983) 1am, Carlton Cinema In the early 80s this was the coolest film of all - adolescent boys would speak in hushed tones about the iconic power of The Motorcycle Boy; cineastes would marvel at the bleak black and white photography, the only colour coming from Mickey Rourke's violent pet shop fish. Now it all looks rather pretentious - a dourly romantic view of troubled youth in which a gang-fighting Matt Dillon hero-worships elder brother Rourke. But Coppola presents being misunderstood in such a handsome light that it emerges as just another form of Hollywood vanity.
Paul Howlett & Will Hodgkinson

Sports

Futbol Argentina 9pm, Bravo Argentine football, hitherto shown only at a ridiculous hour on Channel 5, is about to join Bravo. Weekly highlight programmes start next week, but they've thoughtfully provided us with an introduction to the football of the land that gave us Diego Maradona, Claudio Caniggia and Hernan Crespo. Just don't mention the hand of God.
Simon Burnton

Weekly highlight programmes start next week, but they've thoughtfully provided us with an introduction to the football of the land that gave us Diego Maradona, Claudio Caniggia and Hernan Crespo. Just don't mention the hand of God. Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Poor little rich girls
fields.trailText: The Big Tease | The vice | Position Impossible: In Search Of The Kama Sutra
fields.body:
I have always been fascinated by Pamela. She is the Mitford sister nobody mentions. Her name has been blotted from the family bible. Her face airbrushed from the group photos. This is invariably the sign of a black sheep.

Turn Albert's face to the wall, mother

Never more mention his name

He brought disgrace on our family

And put us all to shame

Not, however, in Pamela's case. Pamela never did anything wrong. Pamela never did anything much. Her obituary writer - who showed signs of pumping away with his foot to keep afloat - said that she was well known in the poultry world; notably for introducing the Appenzeller Spitzhaube chicken to Britain, a bird which wears, like a cocktail hat, a rather charming arrangement of feathers on its head.

Chickens loom large in the Mitford story. Lord Redesdale set his face like stone against educating his daughters, having heard that hockey overdeveloped the calves, so Lady Redesdale kept chickens and, with the slender profits from the eggs, hired governesses. Also slender, you suspect.

Lady Redesdale said that whenever she saw a newspaper placard which began "Peer's daughter...", she knew it would be one of hers. She also knew it would not be Pam. In a flock of black sheep, Pam was the baa lamb. She was, of course, not even mentioned in The Big Tease (Omnibus, BBC2), a no-expense-incurred biography of Nancy Mitford, supporting the current run of Love In A Cold Climate. You could just smell the Chanel and the horses.

Nancy's surviving sisters, Diana, Lady Mosley and Deborah, Duchess of Devonshire, appeared as witnesses for - it is hard to be sure - either the defence or the prosecution.

Diana: "I think Nancy was the most disloyal person I've ever met in my life. Of course, that was what made her such fun."

Deborah: "She was a wicked tease - cruel sometimes. She said I never learned to read and had to point with one finger. Perfectly true. She used to say that my mental age was nine. Also perfectly true, but it didn't go down very well at the time." Unless, of course, she was nine at the time.

All the Mitford girls headed like heat-seeking missiles for high-flying men: Unity was besotted with Hitler; Diana married Oswald Mosley; Jessica ran away with a communist to fight in Spain; Deborah got her duke; and Nancy fell hopelessly in love with a Frenchman, who did not love her. "He was hugely oversexed and incredibly ugly - horrible spots, angry ones, terrible tiny little wisps of smoke coming out of them," erupted Lord Norwich, emitting wisps of smoke himself.

She moved to France to be near him and contracted cancer a month after reading of his engagement. It was Pamela who nursed her. "She was perfect by herself. The only thing that went wrong in Nancy's life was the men in it. They were hopeless," said Diana, and lowered her beautiful eyelids.

The success of a detective series depends on the power generated by the detective. You are rarely tempted to take up the job. Sherlock Holmes, inspecting the inside of his squalid hat, would deduce correctly that he was a stranger to dry cleaning, drank to forget and was programmed to self-destruct. Pat Chappel (Ken Stott) in The Vice (ITV) is scruffy, five o'clock shadowy, bulbous and in love with a prostitute. He will do nicely.

In the last of the current series Vickers (Tim Piggot-Smith at his most heh, heh, heh) was running orgies for businessmen, which seemed to involve waitresses nervously offering strawberries in their teeth. I would have thought Environmental Health could have closed this down without recourse to Vice, but Chappel arranged a far more dramatic denouement. My own view is that anyone who trusts an informer called Damon needs their bumps felt.

The unexpectedly gripping thing about Position Impossible: In Search Of The Kama Sutra (Channel 4) was why the man in the helpful illustrations wore a rather dashing red hat throughout his exertions. In the west, it is considered polite to remove your hat. Before it falls off. You could, if well disposed, put the whole thing down to enthusiasm, like the Duchess of Marlborough, who recorded that "His Grace returned from the wars this morning and pleasured me twice in his top boots." But surely not in his top hat?

webTitle: £10m plan for putting first industrial suburb back on the map

fields.headline: £10m plan for putting first industrial suburb back on the map
fields.trailText: Tough powers forcing landowners to hand over derelict buildings and sites for redevelopment are to be invoked by a government agency in an attempt to rescue the old manufacturing heart of Manchester and preserve England's first industrial suburb.
fields.body:
Tough powers forcing landowners to hand over derelict buildings and sites for redevelopment are to be invoked by a government agency in an attempt to rescue the old manufacturing heart of Manchester and preserve England's first industrial suburb.

With concern growing about the rapid decline of the Ancoats area, which contains seven grade II* listed buildings and a clutch of early 19th century cotton mills, the North West Development Agency has threatened around 100 owners with compulsory purchase orders. The exercise could cost it £10m.

In one of the largest exercises of its type in a British city, the agency said it had been forced to act to prevent a crucial 20 acres, barely half a mile from the centre of Manchester, "sinking into oblivion".

Fears are growing that some owners are holding on to key sites and buildings in the hope of making a quick killing as land appreciates in value on the back of nearby developments.

Manchester city centre, which housed only a few hundred people 10 years ago, now has a population approaching 10,000 with a few penthouses fetching £1m.

But so far the wealth has failed to trickle down to the Ancoats district, which has been earmarked for redevelopment by an urban village company, backed by the development agency and the city council.

It is labelled the world's first industrial suburb, and its oldest cotton mill dates back to 1798, while many of its successors pioneered mass production with steam-driven spinning techniques.

While a few buildings have been transformed into new workshops and cafes, the village company says scores of others can be converted into mixed use embracing flats and offices.

Only 400 people now live in the area, although planners hope it will eventually accommodate 3,000, with new schools and health centres.

But Lyn Fenton, the company's chief executive, said the company was determined to ensure that new housing went to people on lower incomes to create an inclusive community.

"We would be very disappointed if we ended up with only high-priced apartments, because higher earners are already catered for in the city."

While land in Manchester city centre is going for up to £7m an acre, prices - so far - are much more depressed in the Ancoats area. However, the development agency has set aside around £10m to buy land and properties.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attaachments please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Free thinking
Robert Muetzelfeldt's letter (Feedback, February 1) is a prime example of one of the classic misunderstandings about free software, yet it was written in the largest "open source" package in the world - the English language. English is an open standard, owned by no one; and anyone is free to modify it as they wish. Does this make it impossible to make a profit using English? Of course not. Ask Glyn Moody. Gideon Hallett
diogenes@freeuk.com

Doomed
Like Robert Muetzelfeldt, I also liked the sound of Glyn Moody's book, Rebel Code, but did not want to pay £9.99. I have discovered a subversive organisation called a "library" which enables me to read this, and millions of other books, for free. Surely the publishing industry is now doomed. A Royle
admin@ecsoftware.co.uk

Open season
David Harper (Feedback, February 2) is right to sing the praises of open standards such as the internet standards defined in requests for comment (RFCs). They are valuable because they are available to everyone and built on consensus and best practice. However it is not accurate to describe them as "open source". The Open Source movement (see www.opensource.org/osd.html) states that, among other things, software licensed as open source "must allow modifications and derived works, and must allow them to be distributed under the same terms as the license of the original software". In other words, you can take a copy of an open source program, understand, change and improve it, and re-release it (still as open source) to the general benefit of all.

Public standards are definitely not open source, since this rule does not apply. Individuals changing or "improving" standards leads to the sort of chaos we see in the browser world, where each different browser and version has its own annoying quirks and incompatabilities. This cynical attempt to "own" the browser market causes pain to us all. If this approach were applied to TCP/IP or SMTP (mail), then the internet would grind to a halt.
Nick Rozanski
nick@rozanski.com

Write on
I'd like to commend Glyn Moody for such an excellent article about free software and Linux (Online, January 25). As a Linux user and supporter I'm naturally happy to see a positive article on the subject, but I was particularly impressed by how well written the whole thing was, and how well you understood and explained the issues. Lars Jannsen
lars@ukmix.net

Time to split
In Andrew Ward's survey of how to deal with large files (Online, February 1) he could have mentioned a useful utility called FileSplit, which is freeware available at www.partridgesoft.com FileSplit is a utility to split large files into smaller files so that they can be easily copied to floppy disks or transferred via email.

Files can be split directly from Windows Explorer by right-clicking on any file and selecting Split File. I have used it to split all sorts of files without problems.
Mike Cox
oxfordtours@ntlworld.co

Handy iTool
I found Andrew Ward's article about free internet hard drive storage interesting and informative. However, he failed to mention the offering by Apple, iDisk, which is part of the iTools service. The service is available to all Mac users with OS 9. Once you have signed up for iTools you get 20 megabyte of free iDisk space. You can then make an alias of the iDisk on your desktop, which acts like any other hard disk. Double-click on the alias and your computer will automatically dial up your ISP and mount your iDisk space. You can then drag and drop files to and from your folder just like your local hard disk. Although Xdrive has a similar option, iDisk acts like any Mac hard disk and is fully integrated into the Mac OS. You do not have to use a browser and there is no additional software download and use.
Andy Kingsley
andykingsley@hotmail.com

Hack 'n' crack
Online refers to a DoS (Denial of Service) attack as a hack and L0pht as hackers. A DoS attack is actually a crack used on Usenet well before the hordes of marketdroids tried to claim the internet. L0pht are not hackers. They are white hat crackers dedicated to exposing security flaws. There is a fundamental difference between crackers and hackers. Hacker live to create while crackers enjoy breaking into systems. As a hacker in training, I find this annoying, especially as Glyn Moody wrote Rebel Code, a book about the greatest hackers known (ESR, RMS, Linus and Alan Cox). Please try to stop this worrying trend in the media to misuse terms and try to change their meaning. Jamie Dainton
mail@dainton.org.uk

Be cautious
Susan Koomen (Feedback, February 1) should beware of jumping too readily to the conclusion that brain tumours are connected to mobile phone usage. For example, the only people I know who have caught a cold this winter have been alcohol drinkers - does this mean that alcohol causes colds, or simply that I know a lot of alcohol drinkers?

With half the population owning mobile phones, one should expect mobile phone users to have as many illnesses as anyone else. A government panel of UK medical experts sat last year to search specifically for health problems from mobile phone usage. They found absolutely none, but sensibly advised users to be cautious about over-use. After all, no one thinks a torch is dangerous, but would you shine one into your ear for six hours a day?
Dave Neale
dave.neale@btinternet.com

webTitle: Hartlepool is now a marginal, fears Labour

fields.headline: Hartlepool is now a marginal, fears Labour
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Mandelson resigns

New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour leaders have added Hartlepool to a list of constituencies considered vulnerable to a Tory surge at the election amid fears that the controversy engulfing Peter Mandelson could undermine support for the party.
fields.body:
Labour leaders have added Hartlepool to a list of constituencies considered vulnerable to a Tory surge at the election amid fears that the controversy engulfing Peter Mandelson could undermine support for the party.

Officials in Labour's northern region have agreed to channel extra resources into Hartlepool, including activists from neighbouring constituencies, to bolster Mr Mandelson's position during the campaign.

The former cabinet minister had a 17,508 majority in 1997, which on paper would make it a safe seat, but the party's northern executive is worried there could be a backlash against him after his second spectacular resignation.

Hartlepool, Labour for more than quarter of a century, is one of four constituencies out of 28 held by the government in north-east England on an "at risk" list.

Embarrassingly for Mr Mandelson, the other three were all won from the Conservatives at the last election - Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, Stockton South, and Tynemouth.

"Hartlepool was recognised as a special case before the recent shenanigans," said a Blairite MP in the region. "Peter's always polarised people. Unfortunately more and more of them are going to the pole opposite his."

Labour lost control of the local council to the Liberal Democrats last year for the first time since the 1970s and the Tories have picked a popular businessman and boxing promoter, Gus Robinson, as their candidate. Miners' leader Arthur Scargill and a fuel protester have already announced they will stand in a contest likely to turn into a political circus as fringe candidates are attracted by the media spotlight.

A number of allies of Mr Mandelson, forced to quit the cabinet a second time last month over the Hinduja passport affair, believe he should quit Hartlepool and politics.

The former Ulster secretary, however, has declared his intention to use Sir Anthony Hammond's inquiry to counter allegations he lied over Srichand Hinduja's passport application and stand again in Hartlepool where senior figures in the constituency Labour party have continued to back him.

A local poll at the weekend found a majority of people in the seat thought he should step down.

Harry Blackwood, editor of the town's evening newspaper, the Hartlepool Mail, recently wrote that Mr Mandelson was viewed by locals as an "absent MP" who neglected the constituency.

"In a town where it was said that you could pin a Labour rosette on a monkey and people would vote for it, things have changed," said Mr Blackwood. "Hartlepool voters got rid of the Labour controlled council in last May's elections after 22 years in charge, and they could turn against Mandelson in the same way."

fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Solicitor Laura Christian, who declared she was standing as a Socialist Alliance candidate in the election against the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, at Hornsey and Wood Green, north London.

Ms Christian, who represented victims of the Paddington rail crash, said she was fighting "against the oppression of asylum seekers and the attacks on basic civil liberties, such as the right to jury trial".

Bad day

Beleaguered Europe minister Keith Vaz, victim of William Hague's euro attack on Tony Blair during PMQs: "Your European policy is like your minister for Europe - not trusted by anyone, giving no straight answers and half the cabinet wants to get rid of him. Everyone knows that your European policy is to keep the minister and dump the pound. Shouldn't your policy be to dump the minister and keep the pound?"

Today

Commons: Education and employment questions. Social security contributions (share options) bill, remaining stages. Children's commissioner for Wales bill, remaining stages.

Lords: International criminal court bill, committee.

fields.headline: Waiting and watching
fields.standfirst:
The Middle East holds its breath as it awaits the implications of Sharon's victory
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Middle East holds its breath as it awaits the implications of Sharon's victory.
fields.body:
As the invasion of Lebanon in 1982 dragged Israel deeper and deeper into a profitless war, one minister asked his fellow cabinet members, referring to Ariel Sharon, then minister of defence, "Why have we put an elephant in charge of all this?" The objections to Sharon have always been not only to his politics but to his unstable, overweening and impulsive character. The question might well be asked again today, not that much short of 20 years later, after Israelis have made him not just a minister, but prime minister, at such a critical time for their country.

It is a perplexing choice, since Sharon is capable of delivering neither peace nor security to his fellow citizens, and might make some volatile decision which would endanger what is left of both. But it is one which symbolises the fact that the whole of the Middle East is entering an era of perplexity. The mood in Middle Eastern capitals on "the day after", which is what the Israelis weeks ago christened the morrow of Sharon's unavoidable victory, is not angry, not warlike and not, or not yet, particularly apprehensive, but above all puzzled. Of course this perplexity is not absolutely new. It has been growing ever since the second Palestinian intifada began, after the failure of the Camp David talks last year.

But Sharon's actual arrival in power emphasises that political purpose has nowhere to go and policy no hook on which to hang. The scaffolding which for at least a decade has kept regional politics in balance, however imperfectly, is damaged and already partly collapsed. That applies above all to the Oslo process, which every government and significant movement in the Middle East used in diverse ways. Whether you supported Oslo, sought to modify it or opposed it, it provided a justification for power, a field of action for policy and, because it was ongoing, you could always appeal to the future when under attack by critics.

That, perhaps, is what Yasser Arafat meant when he said in London three years ago that the alternative to Oslo was "chaos" - not so much that without Oslo there would be immediate mayhem as that nobody would know what to do any longer. And it may well be one reason, apart from the desire to upstage Sharon by acting more apparently reasonably, that yesterday he was mysteriously ready to look forward to the continuation of the peace process.

But Oslo is not the only part of the framework of action in the region that has been weakened. The attempt to contain Iraq - half success, half failure - has been in trouble for some time. Whether it will be revived in a more than rhetorical way by the new American administration is unclear, still less whether the US will take serious covert action aimed at unseating Saddam. Again, this half success was, like Oslo, something on which governments could count, whatever they actually thought of the policy.

In Iran, what had appeared to some to be an unstoppable movement toward reform, a movement expected to ultimately lead to Iran's full rehabilitation and to better relations with western countries, has faltered. Recent verdicts in the Iranian courts have condemned Iranian intelligence agents for the murder of intellectuals but blocked further inquiry into who among the Iranian establishment inspired them to these crimes. In a process of judicial regression, these have been followed by more hostile verdicts against journalists and newspapers. As Geneive Abdo wrote, after having to leave Iran this week, the reform wing in Iran seems in retrospect to have provided cover for the right rather than to have truly opposed it.

In any case, Iran, in the light of these new, less hopeful developments, has become a more uncertain factor in the region than before. Although not at all of the same order, recent difficulties between Turkey, Europe, and the US add to the general uncertainty. Finally, there have been increases in oil prices and could be more to come and, to all this, the Bush administration brings its own quota of uncertainty. It has yet to reveal, or perhaps even to formulate, its key policies in the Middle East.

A year or so ago the Middle East had a number of "destinations", movement toward which was assumed as a matter of practical politics and diplomacy, even if there were many private doubts. These included an Israeli-Palestinian settlement; peace between Israel and Syria; an end to Saddam's time in Iraq without him being able to wholly break out of his isolation; the gradually achieved ascendancy of the reformers in Iran; and closer relations between Turkey and Europe, including rapprochement with Greece. All but the last are now in much doubt. These different movements would, optimists hoped, to some extent reinforce each other. If we are still going to these places it is far less easy to say how we are going to get there.

S haron certainly has no answers to the questions before Israel. In part, he represents that side of Israeli politics which is like a long wrestling contest, with the heavyweights of a certain generation returning again and again to the ring in pursuit of prizes. Sharon has now won the crown which has eluded Shimon Peres. But he has no plans. The time when he had plans was 20 years ago, when he had grandiose schemes to re-engineer the Middle East.

Jordan was to lose its royal family, become the Palestinian state and take in the Arabs of the West Bank and perhaps of Israel proper as well. Lebanon would be a Christian-dominated client state, purged of Palestinians; Iran and Turkey allies; Syria neutralised; Egypt neutered. It was a time of quite unrealistic Israeli imperial ambitions and Sharon was the most unrealistic of them all. The war he hustled to prosecute brought the opposite of what he had intended. He struck at what he called "the snake's head" of the PLO leadership, and did indeed get it out of Lebanon - but only to live to fight another day and return to Palestine after the first intifada had helped lead to Oslo.

Sharon is an old man with no solutions, not even the solution of war. He can make life more difficult for the Palestinians, but it is hard to see how very much more miserable that could be. He has learned enough in the years since Lebanon to know that a general conflict with the Arab states, which in any case they would be exceedingly reluctant to undertake, however provoked, would solve nothing. In any case, his election does not at all ease Israel's political paralysis and general elections may not be far away. They might bring Binyamin Netanyahu to power - but he too has no solutions. The problem with which the failure of Camp David brought Israel face to face is that nobody wants war but few are ready to pay the price for peace. Choosing has-beens as leaders, meanwhile, is not so much politics as a displacement activity.

Yasser Arafat is another old man who cannot square the circle. His sharp political instincts tell him how far he can run ahead of his people and he rarely exceeds that limit. His experience also tells him that waiting often pays off, events are unpredictable and opportunities do sometimes reoccur. He was wise enough to warn the Americans that the time was not ripe for a final settlement, that it would be impossible to reach and that the Palestinians would be blamed. He will wait on events, as will leaders throughout the Middle East. It is a sad condition for a region in which the desire for a normal, modern life is so apparent everywhere, if strangely mixed with attitudes that make such a life so difficult to achieve.

martin.woollacott@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Music production
fields.standfirst: Armed with his debut track Love on Radio, and a thick skin, Mike Anderiesz sets   out to become a pop star on   the internet. It's not that easy
fields.trailText: Armed with his debut track Love on Radio, and a thick skin, Mike Anderiesz sets out to become a pop star on the internet. It's not that easy
fields.body:
Whenever the likes of Napster are called upon to justify their particular brand of piracy, they always hint at MP3 empowering rather than preying on musicians. MP3, it is argued, gives unknown bands a chance to reach new audiences, to create, compress and publish studio quality music at the click of the mouse.

No more waiting around for some A&R man to discover you while hoards of talentless yobs with great haircuts prance around on TOTP. The theory goes that if you want to be heard you can be. So, equipped with my own three-minute dance sensation entitled Love on Radio, I set off to find fame and fortune.

The first shock was a major one. Heading off to www.acidplanet.com, I got my first glimpse of the competition, namely hundreds of wannabe stars who had used the same music-making package (the excellent Acid 2 Pro) to far greater effect.

Imaginatively arranged and perfectly mixed, most of them could be played down your local club with pride, whereas mine sounded like it had been knocked up in two hours on a PC (which it had). Not one to be discouraged, I posted my track anyway, returning a few days later to discover that only 12 people had bothered to download it. The most charitable response from one listener was: "Nice chorus, shame about the rapper."

While MP3 has democratised music, it has also transferred a truckload of new responsibilities to the artist. With the conventional music model, you could rely on a record company to pay for sound engineers, producers and marketers to make your track worthy of attention. Now it's all up to you, and if you don't start with professional songwriting tools (a decent sequencer, soundcard and plug-in digital effects are a must) and a modicum of production skill, no one is going to care how good the basic idea is.

A certain degree of support is offered by artists' collectives such as www.songwriter.com, but selling direct to the consumer is a lot harder than it sounds.

A trip to the newly relaunched www.MP3.com revealed further weaknesses in my strategy. Even if my track had been professional enough, all you achieve by simply posting music is to give some brain-dead Californian student a free fix of your work. The internet does not provide a showcase for artists looking to be snapped up by a record label; it is a true alternative to conventional music retailing, and thinking like a record company is essential to getting anywhere. For a start, you will need an album, or at least a collection of five to 10 tracks you can mail to your fans should you get any.

You will also need to decide how best to market your newfound talent. For example, though posting an MP3 file to your website is easy, no one but a small circle of friends will know it's there. This is one reason for the rise of true online publishers such as www.peoplesound.com, who provide you with a web page, a streaming audio demo of your track, and even make and sell your CDs in exchange for a 50% royalty. Naturally, you first have to prove yourself worthy (by registering and sending in some tracks) but even if you are chosen for the playlist, you run the risk of being lost among the hundreds of artists doing the same thing and you can count your time in the "charts" in days rather than weeks.

The internet is a far more "vertical" record shop than anything you find in the High Street. Users browse specifically for the type of music they like, and unless your style falls into the electro, techno, or trance category (and the harder the better) there is a good chance no one will ever hear it. One possible answer to this is the growing number of MP3 radio stations such as http://radio.mp3.com, which play continuous loops of tracks where a single click will take you to the download page.

The downside is that getting on the playlist is still time-consuming, and whereas a local radio station guarantees you several thousand listeners at a time, few MP3 stations are heard by more than a few hundred at once. The more you look at the online model for music distribution, the more sense the conventional one makes.

The final truth, however, is the most alarming. Heading to the infamous www.napster.com it does not take a genius to see that the average MP3 punter cares nothing for whether I am talented or not. Of the thousands of tracks freely available, 95% of the downloads are for established stars, with Westlife's What makes a Man still being pirated more than 1,500 times a day while my single track lies totally unnoticed.

Although Napster's new deal with the record labels will ensure that the lads make a few pennies somewhere down the line, it offers very little hope for anyone less famous. So, there you have it. Original MP3 music is alive, remarkably professional and available from dozens of websites. It remains, however, a promotional tool for artists with record company support, or those with a loyal fan base and a CD to flog. Perhaps when MP3 radio takes off, it will offer a genuine chance of breaking new talent. In the meantime, it merely encourages clever producers to plunder the web at will for good ideas to cunningly weave into their own tracks. Needless to say, I am not prepared to take such a risk with my precious material.

Oh, who am I kidding? I sucked and they knew it.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Steel workers back strikeSteelworkers have voted overwhelmingly to strike in protest at compulsory job losses, it was announced last night.
fields.body:
Steel workers back strike

Steelworkers have voted overwhelmingly to strike in protest at compulsory job losses, it was announced last night. Workers at the Scunthorpe plant in Lincolnshire voted by 60% in favour of strikes and 83% for industrial action short of a strike.

The ballot was called by the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation in protest at job losses announced at the factory last year by steel group Corus.

Since then the company has revealed plans to cut more than 6,000 jobs across the country, mainly in Wales and the north east of England.

City Slicker settles

Trinity Mirror has settled out of court with former City Slicker Anil Bhoyrul, sacked last year for his role in the Mirror newspaper's share tipping scandal. The company is understood to have agreed a payment of £16,000 but no legal costs. Mr Bhoyrul was due to present a case for unfair dismissal next week.

He and James Hipwell were fired for tipping firms whose shares they owned in their column.

Mr Hipwell, who works for public relations agency Max Clifford, is considering his legal position in the light of the settlement.

Doubt cast on Abbey name

Abbey National could prove to be a "brand too far" for Lloyds TSB if its £20bn bid is successful, according to market analysis by Datamonitor. It says Lloyds TSB would not be able to add Abbey to its name. Lloyds has insisted it will maintain the Abbey brand for two years.

Abbey's board yesterday rejected the Lloyds TSB bid, describing it as a "inadequate and subject to material uncertainities", including whether the goverment will block the bid on competition grounds.

Alli tunes in to digital radio

Lord Waheed Alli, the television tycoon behind the C4 series the Big Breakfast, has become chairman of the Digital Radio Group, a consortium including Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, GWR, SMG and Charles Dunstone's Carphone Warehouse.

The group is bidding for the final digital radio licence in London which will support eight stations. They will include a country music specialist Ritz 1035 and a station aimed at the gay community provided by Purple Radio.

Lord Alli said the two previous London digital licences had provided existing mainstream analogue stations with a digital platform but had not substantially increased choice.

Sema bid this week

US oilfield services and electronics company Schlumberger will probably launch its bid for troubled Anglo-French information technology services firm Sema ahead of the weekend, banking sources said yesterday.

They did not say if the bid was expected to be hostile or agreed by the Sema board, but said it planned to bid for Sema's entire share capital and that the offer was likely to be 70% cash with the remaining 30% in shares.

webTitle: Business: Floatation of Orange in jeopardy yesterday

fields.headline: Orange float price pared
fields.standfirst: Investors' wariness about wireless poses threat to BT's restructuring plans
fields.trailText: The success of France Télécom's flotation of its mobile phone subsidiary Orange hung in the balance last night as institutional investors deliberated whether yesterday's 18% price cut was sufficient to tempt them to buy shares.
fields.body:
The success of France Télécom's flotation of its mobile phone subsidiary Orange hung in the balance last night as institutional investors deliberated whether yesterday's 18% price cut was sufficient to tempt them to buy shares.

The market backlash against telecoms stocks also threatens to derail BT's corporate restructuring programme, built round flotation of its mobile phone business, BT Wireless.

It will give other float prospects - KPN Wireless and Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobil/One2One - cause for concern.

BT, which releases third-quarter results today, denied that instability in the Orange float would damage attempts to float its wireless division this year. "Our plans remain exactly as we said already," a spokesman said. "We intend to list up to 25% of BT Wireless. Those plans remain our plans."

France Télécom announced yesterday it was slashing the price range for Orange shares from the original €11.5/13.5 to €9.5/11. Based on the mid-price of the ranges, that would see around €1bn lopped from the proceeds. The company also extended the deadline for retail investors to buy shares by one day to Friday.

Late yesterday, an Orange spokesman said institutions were responding to the price cuts. "The equity offer is now well subscribed."

France Télécom had blamed "challenging market conditions" and reluctance of institutional investors for the cut.

Last night it was unclear how many investors would be swayed by the cut.

France Télécom insisted that the issue would go ahead next week and there would not be any further cut in the price.

"The market climate has worsened in the past few days and investors seemed to be more and more sensitive to the price," France Télécom's chief financial officer, Jean Louis Vinciguerra, told a conference call after the cut was announced.

Telecom stocks have been hard hit in recent months as the costs of acquiring third-generation mobile phone licences and rolling out new networks pushed up debt levels.

Underwriters of the Orange float, led by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein and Société Générale, found institutional investors unwilling to buy stock at the earlier price.

"It was a consensus view of the banks to suggest to France Télécom that it was the right thing to do," said Edward Cumming-Bruce of Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein.

Analysts say a drop in price so close to the float date signals that Orange is fighting for investors in a buyer's market.

Institutions complained that the original pricing structure put Orange at a premium to sector favourite Vodafone. "Ultimately the problem was they really couldn't justify the valuation," said Jeff Currington at Morley Fund Management.

It is still unclear whether the price cut, which reduces the market valuation of Orange from €55.2bn/64.8bn to €45.6bn/52.8bn, is sufficient.

Tim Rees at Clerical Medical said that even after the price cut "it is still not obvious that Orange is cheaper than Vodafone".

fields.headline: All change for gaming world
fields.standfirst: Get it all in proportion says Greg Howson
fields.trailText: Get it all in proportion says Greg Howson
fields.body:
Lara Croft may be the best-known woman in games, but if she were real it is likely her oversized chest would see her toppling over rather than raiding tombs. Could it be because she was designed by a man? If Junko Kawano had been involved, Lara may have been a well-rounded character rather than just top-heavy. Kawano is the producer of Konami's forthcoming PlayStation 2 game Shadows of Memories, and one of an increasing number of women involved in video game production.

Historically, few women have been involved in game development. Games were generally viewed as being made for men by men, with the representation of female characters - there to be rescued or ogled at - hardly enticing women to play.

However, with the multimillion-selling PlayStation helping to create an increasingly mainstream audience, more and more females not only play but produce.

Caroline Green, a graphic artist at British software house Kuju, has noticed the change. "The number of women in the industry has increased significantly," she says.

The reasons are varied. Ever-expanding graphical sophistication and processing power has led to more realistic-looking games, which in turn has enabled designers to produce titles that involve more than sports, driving and shooting. Shadows of Memories is a good example. It is Kawano's first game in charge and, although she emphasises the team effort, you sense this is her personal project.

The non-violent, time-travelling title is heavily influenced by Faust and is largely narrative driven - Kawano describes it as a digital novel. Despite this, she denies taking deliberate aim at the female market. "We didn't intentionally leave out violence to attract girls although it probably helps them enjoy the game," she insists.

But even a cursory glance reveals that the female characters play an integral part in proceedings. Kawano stresses she never intended the female characters to be stronger than normal but "as a woman I know what women are like". So, unlike the mini-skirted stereotypes usually associated with games, the women in Shadows of Memories are, well, normal.

For example, Miriam is middle-aged and fairly unsatisfied with her lot - not exactly typical game territory. Perhaps unexpectedly, Shadows' main character is male.

It is significant that Shadows is coming out on PlayStation 2, as more powerful hardware has helped increase the numbers of female development staff in other ways.

Catherine Skinner, of the game developers Supedo sees other changes as important. "The PC/console games industry is beginning to converge with many other industries - web, interactive TV and telecoms," she says. "Industries like TV and the web have high proportions of female production staff, and as these different production skill sets become integrated into the games industry, so will the men and women who work in them."

But will the increasing numbers of female developers eventually change the portrayal of women in video games? Robson thinks so. "On the whole we are no longer purely portrayed as sex objects," she says. "There are a lot of strong female characters in games that men like to look at, but women want to be like. The trend towards this type of character will grow as more women get into the industry."

But Skinner sounds a note of caution: "At a basic level, female production staff act as a reality check on blatantly offensive portrayals of women in games, but unfortunately power doesn't usually lie with the production staff.

"Until the industry and its investors feel a need to develop new genres and reach a broader market, there's still going to be pressure to cater primarily to the proven core of 15-30-year-old male gamers. "And that means a pressure to continue with existing genres and their stereotypes, along with sexist marketing campaigns."

Some in the industry are more cautious, however. Skinner says: "I don't think it's true that female production staff necessarily make more female-friendly games, or that men necessarily make less female-friendly games."

The Sims is a prime example of a title that has cross-gender appeal. The game, which lets you run (or ruin) peoples lives, has sold 280,000 copies in the UK. Al King, the marketing director of the publishers EAUK, feels this is down to its realistic environment: "It's about people in the real world and not guns or planes or monsters," he says.

As games become part of the mainstream, and appear across formats ranging from consoles to mobile phones, it's clear that the days of boys making toys for other boys are fading. Skinner argues that more imagination will be needed to capitalise on this market. "There will be more female gamers - and more male gamers, for that matter - when there are a greater range of game genres. "And that depends on having a wider range of people with different backgrounds and visions involved in production, be they female or male."

Lara Croft may be a game icon but, with the increasing numbers of female development staff, future heroines should at least be more realistically proportioned.

fields.headline: Byers clears Express deal
fields.trailText: The government yesterday gave its approval to the acquisition of Express Newspapers by Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell.
fields.body:
The government yesterday gave its approval to the acquisition of Express Newspapers by Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said he had decided against referring the £125m takeover to the competition commission. There was speculation that Mr Desmond might face further scrutiny on public interest grounds because of his adult entertainment interests, which range from sex websites to magazines such as Asian Babes.

Insiders noted that Mr Byers would have been keen to approve the deal before a general election is called. His decision came days after the office of fair trading submitted its report on the sale.

Mr Desmond said he had never doubted the government's approval. "While we appreciate that all due processes needed to be undertaken, we were always confident of a successful outcome. The decision by the secretary of state now allows us to get on with the job of rebuilding our great newspapers."

Mr Desmond's plans for the titles include widespread job losses among journalists at the Daily and Sunday Express in the next month in an effort to pare down costs.

The approval may also hasten the sale of Express Newspapers' 50% stake in the Docklands printing plant, West Ferry, which it shares with the Telegraph Group.

The Telegraph has served notice that it intends to exercise its right to buy the half share owned by the Express but there is conflict about price. The Telegraph says the stake is worth £20m, while Mr Desmond's advisers suggest a price of £80m. An arbitrator is likely to be appointed within the month.

Mr Desmond, who also owns more mainstream consumer magazines including OK! and Attitude, put his stable of top-shelf titles and websites up for sale last month.

fields.headline: Women                    on the gaming front
fields.standfirst: Women are playing computer games like never before. But female players are different to their male counterparts, finds Karlin Lillington.
fields.trailText: Women are playing computer games like never before. But female players are different to their male counterparts, finds Karlin Lillington.
fields.body:
More violent than a Quake gorefest, more scheming than Age of Empires: no topic inflames gamers more than the great gender battle. Gaming - online, on a PC or on a handheld - is still seen as a guy thing.

The few women characters tend to be S&M variations of Barbie - tough, pneumatic chicks with skin-tight, skimpy clothing (can Lara Croft really scale rocky ledges in those hotpants?).

Seemingly even rarer than women characters are women gamers. Gals who do venture into the gameplaying world usually have a story to tell about abusive or condescending behaviour from male players. When women form all-female "clans" to play as a team - a trend that took off with Quake - they are harangued by male players for excluding men. Popular women's gaming sites such as Womangamers.com and Gamegirlz.com are full of this debate.

Women complain that most games feature mindless storylines that portray them as sex objects or add-on fluff. And they hate the advertising and packaging. "If they could lose this fascination with huge breasts and hips," sighs Maura McHugh, a systems administrator and game player. No wonder women aren't really into gaming. Except they are. Women buy half of all software games and 48% of consoles, says the Interactive Digital Software Association, although some purchases are gifts. Men constitute 55% of gamers overall, according to a recent study by the Virginia-based analyst PC Data. For online gaming, women are now the majority, making up 50.4%.

"For a long time, publishers and manufacturers have overlooked women," says Sean Wargo, a senior analyst with PC Data. At 45% of the market, women constitute a huge and largely untapped audience. Untapped, because most are playing games for which they pay little or nothing - online games, pre-installed card and puzzle games on PCs, and free downloads.

Wargo says women are enthusiastic players of free games connected to advertisements, and are also fans of card, puzzle, trivia and gambling games online.

This is also why female gamers remain relatively invisible. "The hardcore game industry is most interested in the people who are paying," he says. "There's a perception that women don't know what they want and won't pay for games."

This may be the fault of games' developers and publishers. "It may be just that the way games are presented doesn't appeal to women," says Wargo. "You are talking about a pretty male-dominated industry."

That's why Phaedra Boinodiris and her sister Ismini set up the gaming portal Womengamers.com. "Most gaming magazines, game box covers, gaming banner ads, and gaming websites cater to the young male," she says. "Our aim is an environment where women gamers can be integrated with the rest of the community. It's time female preferences were taken into account."

Women gamers can feel isolated, she says. "We feel like pioneers in one of the last frontiers. Ismini and I have developed a clearer understanding of what we imagine our mother went through as one of the first women graduating in computer engineering back in the 60s."

"Very few developers and publishers try to capture the female audience," says Vangie Beal, the founder of the Canadian website Gamegirlz.com. "I often stumble across something and think 'only a guy could really appreciate this'. I attribute it to the limited number of women working in developer positions at those companies. There is little or no female perspective."

Most studies report a gender divide in the kinds of PC and console games played. Males tend to like action, while women are more into role-playing adventures. Men like strategy, driving things and shooting things. Women like good stories, character development and solving problems. "They read the backstory in the manuals and really get into the entire gaming experience," says Martin Feeney, a software programmer who hosts a games site at the Irish portal Online.ie.

But women don't necessarily dislike shoot'em-ups, as many women gamers and the proliferation of all-female Quake clans will testify. Many would just prefer a good story to go with the gore. Often, games that cross gender barriers, such as Ultima and EverQuest, have action and adventure elements. "In they end," says Beal, "they all just want a good game to play."

Many women gamers note that the gender issue is often overplayed. Games could be better, and hostilities can erupt between male and female players, but guys show plenty of interest in women's gaming sites and make up a large proportion of their audience. "A little less than a third of our site members are men and yes, they are typically extremely supportive," says Phaedra. "Once in a while we get the 'Shouldn't you be ironing your man's underwear' type of email, but thankfully not very often."

The violent, often sexist content of many games is cited as not only a turn-off to female players, but as a prime reason why girls don't bother with engineering and computing careers. A report last year by the Association of American University Women found that girls disliked most games and saw them as part of a computer culture that seemed unappealing as a work environment. A December report by a US children's advocacy group, Children Now, said that nearly half of popular computer games had negative images of females.

McHugh claims the games are getting better, with more women characters and complex stories. And there's good reason for them to improve, says Jason Armitage, a senior analyst in London with International Data Corporation. More than a quarter of western European homes will have 128-bit gaming consoles by 2004 - with the UK leading the market - and a battle will break out between the console-makers Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo.

Still, he doesn't expect any big shift in strategy right away. "Early adopters are a pivotal group and are heavily weighted towards males. The level of investment [to produce a software title] means they will target this top tier - the 14- to 35-year-old male."

What would make a game more attractive to women? "A game that's well-designed with a real story to it, a real plot, and good characters," says McHugh.

And what do men think women gamers want? "Good background story and interesting story development," Feeney says. "No pointless, difficult sections that interrupt the flow of the game. Strong roles for female characters without giving them obscene outfits or unrealistic proportions. "In fact," he says, "all the above sounds good to me, too."

webTitle: Business news site joins dot.com casualty list

fields.headline: Business news site joins dot.com casualty list
fields.trailText: News and business services website eCountries became the latest dot.com casualty last night, announcing it was unable to "obtain further funding" and that the company would be closed in the next few days.
fields.body:
News and business services website eCountries became the latest dot.com casualty last night, announcing it was unable to "obtain further funding" and that the company would be closed in the next few days.

"Our traffic and editorial reputation have been growing fast, but trading conditions for internet-based companies are extraordinarily challenging," said founders Donal Smith and Jonathan Schmidt, former FT executives who established the company in 1999.

Before the internet bubble burst, the website poached some big journalistic names including Michael Elliott, Newsweek's international editor, who became its editor in chief.

webTitle: Granada admits ad revenues are down

fields.headline: Granada admits ad revenues are down
fields.trailText: Leading ITV broadcaster Granada announced yesterday that its advertising revenues have fallen as the network has struggled to maintain audience share.
fields.body:
Leading ITV broadcaster Granada announced yesterday that its advertising revenues have fallen as the network has struggled to maintain audience share.

The media group said revenues in the first quarter had fallen by 5.1%. It said the figures had to be set against a strong performance during the previous year and predicted a turnaround in the final quarter.

Its chairman, Charles Allen, insisted that advertising revenues had been expected to fall. But he said the last year had been a period of "rapid change and strategic development for Granada".

Concerns about Granada's advertising revenues have hit its share price. When Granada was floated last July, the initial public offering was 515p. Shares have been rebased, and the equivalent price now is 280p.

Granada said the integration of United News & Media's television businesses, bought for £1.75bn, was progressing well. It intends to achieve cost savings of £30m in 2002.

The ITV network performed strongly in January. Figures released this week show audience share up 1.1 points on last year, breaking through the 39% barrier.

Granada's programmes got off to a strong start. Popstars, made by its LWT subsidiary, has become one of the most talked-about shows of the year and achieved a strong youth following. Recent episodes have achieved a 50% share.

webTitle: Business: Sega President donates millions to abandon Dreamcast

fields.headline: Sega receives £370m dream gift
fields.standfirst: Seag President donates millions to help company offset abandonign of Dreamcast console
fields.trailText: The president of games company Sega set an impressive example of managerial responsibility yesterday by donating his entire £370m stake to help the company offset the cost of abandoning the Dreamcast games console.
fields.body:
The president of games company Sega set an impressive example of managerial responsibility yesterday by donating his entire £370m stake to help the company offset the cost of abandoning the Dreamcast games console.

Isao Okawa - who was the second largest shareholder in the Japanese video games manufacturer before his act of generosity - returned 19.87m shares in Sega, as well as giving the company millions of yen in shareholdings in related sector companies.

The gift fulfilled part of a promise made by Mr Okawa last week to use ¥85bn from his personal wealth to reverse the fortunes of the ailing firm.

His pledge was made after Sega announced that it would take an ¥80bn hit this year to close its loss-making Dreamcast operations and concentrate on software creation.

Half of Mr Okawa's donation came in the form of a 12.53% stake in Sega, worth ¥32.7 bn. The remainder included a 4.8% stake in information ser vice company CSK, a 3% holding in computer software publisher Ascii and a 33.7% stake in NextCom, a network services firm.

Mr Okawa said he would also donate bonds and shares in unlisted companies.

A spokesman for Sega said the company had not decided how to use the gift but was in no rush to sell the stock.

"The shares we received are mostly those in our group firms which we hope to retain in the medium to longer term, assuming we win backing from creditor banks."

Mr Okawa's move is rare - although during recent years several Japanese executives have taken responsibility for business failures by committing suicide.

Investors have applauded the decision to abandon the 128-bit Dreamcast console as crucial for the profitability of a company that is facing a fourth successive year of losses. The move has caused Sega shares to rise by 7% so far this month - compared to a 3% fall in the benchmark Nikkei 225 average.
