fields.headline: Abortion pill under threat
fields.standfirst:
Religious right on the rise. As Christian blockbusters take on Hollywood, Congress prepares to limit right to choose

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Religious right on the rise. As Christian blockbusters take on Hollywood, Congress prepares to limit right to choose.
fields.body:
Republicans made their first attempt of the new presidency yesterday to pass a law restricting abortion rights in the US.

A bill introduced into both houses of Congress is intended to prevent some doctors prescribing the "abortion pill" mifepristone, otherwise known as RU-486, authorised for use in the last months of Bill Clinton's presidency.

The pill, available in 13 other countries, including Britain, induces abortion during the first seven weeks of pregnancy without recourse to surgery.

The licensing of the drug in the US in September 2000 by the food and drug administration has opened a new front in the long argument between supporters and opponents of birth control and abortion and has rapidly become the focus of the anti-abortion movement.

The bill, sponsored by Senator Tim Hutchinson of Arkansas and Representative David Vitter of Louisiana, requires any doctor prescribing the pill to be qualified to handle complications from incomplete abortions and licensed to perform abortions.

Its purpose is explicitly to restrict the prescription of RU-486, which is why the FDA rejected such conditions when the drug was approved last year.

Mr Hutchinson said the only purpose of his bill was "to ensure the health and safety of women who are prescribed RU-486", but Gloria Feldt of the Planned Parenthood Federation accused the bill's backers of "not liking science that contradicts their ideology".

The Hutchinson-Vitter bill will provide a crucial test of the willingness of the new Republican-controlled Congress to make abortion a central issue in the political situation created by the November 2000 election.

While most Republicans are opposed to abortion rights, leaders of the party on both sides of the row recognise that the issue could polarise the electorate, not yet reconciled to Mr Bush's disputed election, and damage the party in the 2002 midterm elections.

If the legislation is passed by Congress there is little doubt that Mr Bush will sign it.

"I think the FDA's decision to approve the abortion pill RU-486 is wrong," Mr Bush said last year.

"I fear that making this abortion pill widespread will make abortions more and more common, rather than more and more rare."

He has since said that he does not have the power to overturn the approval of RU-486 on prescription, but that he would like to investigate whether the approval was conducted appropriately.

The arrival of an avowedly "pro-life" president in the White House has re-energised anti-abortion conservatives.

Although Mr Bush mostly kept quiet about the issue during the campaign, he has already delighted conservatives by reimposing a Reagan-era ban on US international support to organisations offering abortion advice or operations.

At state level, the Republican party remains generally committed to tightening the law on abortion by any means possible. In Virginia this week, the legislature passed a law obliging doctors to offer detailed anti-abortion information, including pictures of foetuses, to women seeking terminations.

Although conservative Republicans want Mr Bush to take the lead in a new campaign against the right to choose, he appears to be adopting a step-by-step approach.

Last month, in a message to anti-abortion groups, he said: "We share a great goal, to work towards a day when every child is welcomed in life and protected in law.

"We know this will not come easily or all at once."

webTitle: Autonomy hammered after trader's note leaks

fields.headline: Autonomy hammered after trader's note leaks
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software company, yesterday said it had complained to regulators over a "trading idea" circulated by a broker at Merrill Lynch alleging that the company had lost key staff.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge-based software company, yesterday said it had complained to regulators over a "trading idea" circulated by a broker at Merrill Lynch alleging that the company had lost key staff.

Autonomy's share price fell more than 10% after the note and further rumours of a big sell-off by a partner that were labelled "completely untrue" by Mike Lynch, the company's chief executive.

Autonomy's share price started the day at £20.07, but quickly fell to £18 by midday. The shares closed at £18.37.

The note, headed "Trading ideas - Sell Autonomy", said that key staff who had worked on Autonomy's knowledge management software were now working on a rival product for Microsoft at its laboratory in Cambridge. "The point is the software is going to be very similar to Autonomys [sic] so Autonomy will not be able to charge hefty licensing fees," read the note, which was meant to be seen only by trading staff within Merrill Lynch but escaped via email to be circulated among fund managers yesterday morning.

Merrill Lynch last night said it had no comment to make on the note, but it is understood that the firm will make a formal retraction of it today.

Mr Lynch insisted the staff mentioned had not worked at Autonomy as it claimed, and said his company's legal department had consulted with regulators about the note and its effects. "People can draw their own conclusions about what's going on," he said.

An official research note sent to Merrill Lynch clients by the bank's analyst, Simon Andrews, reiterated some of the earlier "idea's" concerns about competition from Microsoft, but Mr Andrews said he main tained a neutral "hold" rating on Autonomy's shares.

Mr Lynch said Microsoft's new software was not a direct competitor in Autonomy's market in knowledge management software. "Their product is not similar to Autonomy's product," he said.

Autonomy yesterday announced the first shipments of its iVoice software, which enables voice recordings stored on computers to be searched for key words or phrases.

451.com, the subscriber-only information technology news website, confirmed yesterday that it was cutting 20% of its workforce, closing offices in Australia, Hong Kong and Germany. The 11 redundancies were reported to have been ordered by the website's backers, Durlacher investment bank, after concerns over losses.

The website was launched last year, and charges individuals £400 a year for access to the service.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText: Snappy
fields.body:
Snappy

Travel agent Lastminute.com has entered into a partnership with 12Snap , a company which develops systems for mobile commerce. The partnership is intended to allow Lastminute to market online products direct to customers over their mobile phones by sending text messages.

Sounds good

Speech and sound technology company NXT reported slightly reduced first-half losses yesterday and sounded an upbeat note on its prospects. Posting a pretax loss of £6.1m for the six months to December 31 versus a loss of £6.5m in the comparable period, NXT said sales had "progressed to plan", rising 40% to £2.6m.

Signal failure

After insisting last week it had no problems with its MSN Messenger service, Microsoft has admitted there had been disruption of the net-based system which was rectified by updating server software.

Upbeat

The collapse of technology stock prices represents "temporary growing pains" and the IT revolution will resume soon, according to Urban Backstrom , governor of Sweden's central bank. "The bursting of what some have called an IT bubble is not the end of the new information technology's era."

webTitle: Business: Murdoch close to £48bn DirecTV deal

fields.headline: Murdoch close to £48bn DirecTV deal
fields.standfirst: Rupert Murdoch's satellite operations to merge with American DirecTV
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch is close to a deal which would see the merger of his satellite television operations with the leading American player, DirecTV, to create a $70bn (£48bn) business.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch is close to a deal which would see the merger of his satellite television operations with the leading American player, DirecTV, to create a $70bn (£48bn) business.

Insiders said a deal between Mr Murdoch's News Corporation and General Motors, the US car maker which owns DirecTV, had been agreed in principle. An announcement is expected to be weeks away, and sources cautioned that the terms of the transaction had not yet been fully agreed.

Talks between the two sides are thought to involve GM spinning off Hughes Electronics Group, the subsidiary which houses DirecTV. News Corp would then fold Sky Global Networks, the holding company for its satellite TV interests, into Hughes.

A complex series of share swaps and sales would see Mr Murdoch's News Corp left as the biggest shareholder alongside other investors expected to include Microsoft and Liberty Media, the company con trolled by cable TV pioneer John Malone.

DirecTV has about 10m subscribers in the US and fills a gap in News Corp's empire - which has interests ranging from BSkyB in Britain to Star TV in Asia. Mr Murdoch declined to discuss the talks except to say that discussions are progressing.

News Corp, presenting its second quarter results, said X-Men, the mutant band of superheroes that made it to the big screen last year, had helped to offset a weakening advertising market.

Operating profit at the company's filmed entertainment division including TV production rose fourfold on the back of strong video sales of X-Men in the US.

The company warned that lower advertising revenues at its Fox Television network would leave full-year earnings at the lower end of expectations. Mr Murdoch was keen to play down the extent of the drop in advertising. "While the advertising market has softened it's not the disaster that's been reported," he said.

Advertising revenues from the company's British newspapers, including the Times and the Sun, rose 8% during the quarter.

BSkyB, which also reported half-year figures, said it had met its target of 5m subscribers by the end of last year, but at a price. Losses at the company in the first half grew from £61.5m to £112m.

The company had 5.25m subscribers as of February 6, and said it remained on track to reach 7m by 2003.

"I think we're going to ex ceed that target and profitability will come sooner," BSkyB chief executive Tony Ball said. "We'll have 7m subscribers in 2003, although at the rate we're running now it could be earlier than that."

Revenues during the first half increased by £236m to £1.09bn but costs were £214m higher, reflecting the increased investment in acquiring new customers.

Marketing expenditure increased by 18% to £212m, of which more than half was the cost of acquiring new customers. Separately, BSkyB's BiB joint venture spent £88m subsidising set-top boxes.

Programming costs were up 24% at £535m.

BSkyB is writing off £25m in losses related to its investments in the internet, an admission that some of the bets made in online companies during the boom were unlikely to pay off. Stakes were taken in a series of companies, including Streets Online, Gameplay and Toyzone.

Some 655,000 transactions were made through Open, BSkyB's interactive retailer, during the period.

fields.headline: Hospitals heist hint
fields.trailText: Given the punishment meted out to tech and telecom investors yesterday it was hardly surprising that some were in need of first aid.
fields.body:
Given the punishment meted out to tech and telecom investors yesterday it was hardly surprising that some were in need of first aid.

But the interest shown in Community Hospitals Group seemed to be more than just medicinal. CHG shares closed to 65p higher at 665p on talk that a 750p a share bid was on the way. According to one theory, Bupa had agreed to sell its 26.7% stake in CHG to the mystery predator.

A month ago CHG, Britain's fourth biggest hospital operator, received several takeover approaches after the government blocked a £230m (650p a share) offer from Bupa on competition grounds. Since then, CHG has posted solid interim figures, leaving it in a strong position to negotiate a higher take-out price.

However, sources close to the company attributed yesterday's rise to institutional buying which followed post-results presentations.

fields.headline: At this price?  Antisoma
fields.trailText: Few companies are more of an investment gamble than a pharmaceutical research business, so it is no surprise that Antisoma's share prices has bobbed up and down over the past couple of years.
fields.body:
Few companies are more of an investment gamble than a pharmaceutical research business, so it is no surprise that Antisoma's share prices has bobbed up and down over the past couple of years.

Antisoma buys the rights to newly discovered drugs, mainly from academic bodies, and then carries out the clinical trials on people.

Failing just one trial can destroy a drug's commercial potential; success can be a licence to print money.

Antisoma aims to license any successful product, leaving the marketing and production to one of its partners.

The company, which specialises in anti-cancer drugs, has been criticised as being a one product business - essentially Theragyn, an ovarian cancer treatment.

Theragyn is nearing the end of the final phase of clinical trials. If it passes it could be on the market by 2003, producing revenue that chief executive Glyn Edwards said would be more than the company could spend.

But the risk of failure is ever present, and Antisoma yesterday stressed that it had three different products in clinical trials, and four at the pre-clinical stage. If Theragyn falls at the last hurdle it could have another product on the market by 2004.

webTitle: Business: Shares in telecom market down

fields.headline: Technical hitches
fields.standfirst: Market forces:  Shares in telecom market down
fields.trailText: It was all rather predictable. With tech bellwether Cisco missing forecasts for the first time in more than six years and France Télécom cutting the price range for flotation of its mobile phone division, Orange, there was only one way the London market was headed yesterday - lower.
fields.body:
It was all rather predictable. With tech bellwether Cisco missing forecasts for the first time in more than six years and France Télécom cutting the price range for flotation of its mobile phone division, Orange, there was only one way the London market was headed yesterday - lower.

Things could have been worse. Down 96 points in midday trading, London's main index, the FTSE 100, fought back in the afternoon following a better than expected start to trading in New York.

Not that this was any consolation to investors holding telecoms and technology stocks, who watched the FTSE Techmark 100 fall 83.72 points, or 3%, to 2,635.38.

The final reading showed the FTSE 100 67.8 points adrift at 6,225.6 as market turnover hit 2bn following exceptionally heavy trading in London's biggest stock, Vodafone , off 5.75p to 222.75p.

Nearly a billion Vodafone shares changed hands as nervous investors baled out after the news from Orange and ominous noises from telecoms watchdog Oftel. In its first stage review of the mobile market, Oftel said operators were making more money than they should be in a competitive market.

Traders said they had not seen anything like the turnover in Vodafone since its acquisition last year of the German telecoms group, Mannesmann, after which many German investors sold unwanted Vodafone shares.

Whispers that the heavyweight investment bank, Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, had cut its Vodafone target price from 340p to 290p exerted further downward pressure on the stock.

Vodafone was not the only telecom stock suffering. BT, which unveils third quarter figures today, fell 42p to 680p as investors pondered the impact of the Orange news on its plans to float of its wireless operations - something it must do to reduce its debt.

Over in the tech sector things were little better. Traders singled out Dimension Data , down 20p to 475p, as the company most exposed to the grim figures from Cisco. Dimension is Cisco's largest resale partner outside the US.

Others affected were those in related industries. Bookham , which makes chips for telecoms networks, slipped 37p to 893p, while equipment firms Spirent and Marconi fell 35p to 490p and 22.5p to 634.5p respectively.

Amid the panic utility stocks prospered as investors looked for safe havens. Scottish & Southern Energy rose 12.5p to 610.5p while United Utilities put on 10p to 585p.

And lower down the market, a few stocks were making headway. Aircraft seat manufacturer Britax was proving popular among the market's shrewder players. More than 3m shares changed hands as the price moved on 7p to 141.5p, with the gossips talking about a 150p per share bid in the next few days.

At the end of January, Britax said that it had entered discussions with potential suitors.

Elsewhere, there were more unscrupulous rumours swirling around drug delivery specialist SkyePharma , off 1.5p to 90p.

This time it was not a bid from Irish group Elan that was making traders excited but the hopes of a deal with a blue chip pharmaceutical company.

Wallpapers and fabrics company Walker Greenbank , jumped 3p to 31.5p on speculation that takeover talks - first revealed back in October - were close to fruition.

Dealers are talking about a take-out price of 40p-50p. Word that analysts at CSFB's offices in New York are about to publish a "buy" note helped paper group Rexam gain 6.25p to 263.25p.

On Aim, punters were piling into Media Content , advisers to Manchester United , up 11.25p to 225p, on hopes that it would benefit financially from the football club's marketing deal with the New York Yankees. Media Content shares ended 0.75p better at 4.5p.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Material World | The Jewish Journey | Night Waves
fields.body:
The week before St Valentine's Day seems a good time to contemplate the essential nature of love, especially as viewed by those incurable romantics, the Italians. Or maybe not. Recent findings from the University of Pisa have cruelly demystified what is actually going on across those crowded rooms. Quentin Cooper reports in The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4) that Pisan researchers have categorised romantic palpitations as chemically akin to compulsive-obsessive disorder. Both spring from very low levels of the neurotransmitter serotonin.

The oldest surviving house in Britain dates from the 12th century. It belonged to Aaron of Lincoln and is still around because the owner had it built like a fortress - a prudent move for a wealthy member of the town's small Jewish community. His co-religionists, invited over by William the Conqueror, were soon being persecuted and taxed to the hilt, and were eventually expelled by Edward I. As Andrew Sachs discovers in the first episode of The Jewish Journey: 1,000 Years Of Jewish Life In Britain (8.0pm, Radio 4), it set a grim precedent.

In Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) Patrick Wright explores the remarkable manuscript collection in the John Rylands Library in Manchester. One of its greatest treasures has been dated at around AD150, a Greek papyrus bearing the earliest known fragment of the New Testament in any language.

webTitle: Leader: doors must not be shut on asylum seekers

fields.headline: Sliding doors
fields.standfirst:
They must not be shut on asylum seekers
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The run up to an election is the worst possible time for reforming asylum procedures. Conservative party officials have hailed the way immigration in earlier elections "played well" in the tabloids, and Labour leaks have shown Tony Blair worrying about the government looking soft. Even so, Jack Straw, who visits Stockholm today for talks with EU interior ministers, is right to be pushing two issues: speeding up the UK's current application process; and seeking a common European approach to asylum seekers.
fields.body:
The run up to an election is the worst possible time for reforming asylum procedures. Conservative party officials have hailed the way immigration in earlier elections "played well" in the tabloids, and Labour leaks have shown Tony Blair worrying about the government looking soft. Even so, Jack Straw, who visits Stockholm today for talks with EU interior ministers, is right to be pushing two issues: speeding up the UK's current application process; and seeking a common European approach to asylum seekers.

The need for a common European approach becomes ever more obvious as numbers grow. Equity demands that those arriving should be fairly distributed across the 15 member states. The UK is not taking a disproportionate share: although it accepts the second largest number, once that is related to population, Britain takes seventh place. The issue has been made more acute by a recent high court ruling barring asylum seekers being returned to France or Germany because of their stricter admission criteria. Both countries restrict admission to applicants facing persecution from governments, ignoring the threats which war lords or factions in civil wars can pose. This makes the UK more attractive to the organised gangs running illegal immigration rackets.

A draft EU directive for harmonising approaches is already out for consultation. It will need to ensure a common approach on three crucial fronts - criteria, procedures, and protection. If it does not, "asylum shopping" will continue. The draft already has greater safeguards than the home secretary has proposed, but it will need to incorporate both the 1951 Geneva Convention and the even greater protection extended to asylum seekers by Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights. What must not happen is a levelling down to the lowest common denominator.

Where Mr Straw is wrong is in seeking to rewrite the 1951 convention (with 137 signatories, that has little practical chance); in suggesting that countries from which refugees flee can be divided into three classes of risk: high, intermediate and safe (that is too crude); and in wishing to keep all refugees in camps close to the countries from which they come. All that needs further thought. But what matters most is that the meeting in Stockholm must not result in the withdrawal of the right to make an asylum claim in Europe.

webTitle: Leader: Supping with Sharon Rules for dealing with Israel's new leader

fields.headline: Supping with Sharon Rules for dealing with Israel's new leader
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: His was a bloody career. He is seen now as the arch-enemy of peace. He exhibited, particularly in Lebanon in 1982, an appalling disregard for human life and the human rights of his Arab foes. After the Sabra and Shatila camp massacres, Israel itself declared him unfit to be defence minister. Had the UN's proposed international court existed then, or had a special tribunal been created as in the Balkans, he might have faced war crimes charges. As Israel's new prime minister, he seems set on destroying the hard-won advances of the Oslo process. His election could be the prelude to a disastrous escalation of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Ariel Sharon's success poses myriad questions. It is also an issue for a government that took office promising an ethical foreign policy. How should Britain and the international community deal with this disreputable man?
fields.body:
His was a bloody career. He is seen now as the arch-enemy of peace. He exhibited, particularly in Lebanon in 1982, an appalling disregard for human life and the human rights of his Arab foes. After the Sabra and Shatila camp massacres, Israel itself declared him unfit to be defence minister. Had the UN's proposed international court existed then, or had a special tribunal been created as in the Balkans, he might have faced war crimes charges. As Israel's new prime minister, he seems set on destroying the hard-won advances of the Oslo process. His election could be the prelude to a disastrous escalation of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Ariel Sharon's success poses myriad questions. It is also an issue for a government that took office promising an ethical foreign policy. How should Britain and the international community deal with this disreputable man?

As usual, this dilemma is not clear-cut. For a start, Mr Sharon is no dictator, no midnight coup-leader. He is Israel's democratic choice. Is it open to outsiders to seek to invalidate the people's decision by, for example, imposing sanctions? George Bush, Vladimir Putin, and Jiang Zemin all attained equivalent positions by less convincingly legitimate means. All three have current responsibility for sustained, systematic human rights abuses, in Iraq, Chechnya and Tibet. Ethically speaking, should Britain thus cut ties with the US, Russia and China? If not, then why pursue Slobodan Milosevic and others over the Sabra-like atrocities at Omarska camp in Bosnia?

Mr Sharon says he is a changed man. Those who believe in redemption, moral and otherwise, must surely give him the chance to prove it. But then, consider the political realities. Of 4.5m eligible Israeli voters, only 1.6m backed Mr Sharon. Should all Israelis be condemned by the minority's foolishness? Perhaps it should be recognised instead that Israel is a deeply divided society that yearns for peace yet is unable, through short- sightedness and fear, to make the necessary sacrifices. Israel has not turned its back on peace. But it has clearly, for now at least, lost confidence in the prospect.

Those who would judge Mr Sharon must also judge themselves. The "stupid, lousy left", in Shimon Peres's angry words, bears much responsibility for this debacle by ducking the battle. The vacillating Palestinian leadership is also to blame. What has it to show now for over 300 intifada deaths and the destabilisation of Ehud Barak? At Taba, Yasser Arafat was closer to most of his goals than he is likely to be again, perhaps in his lifetime. All that is off the table now. Israel's Arab voters largely boycotted the poll. This was the icing on the Likud cake. As for the rejectionists of Damascus, Beirut and elsewhere, they publicly deplore Mr Sharon's arrival and privately celebrate it. He is not the only warmonger; and they have no moral superiority, no plan but pain. Like Mr Sharon, they prefer confrontation to compromise. It is easier, and it is usually somebody else's children who die.

The fundamental moral lesson of this sorry mess is surely that violence, from whatever quarter, just makes matters worse. The priority now is to stop the fighting and re-educate the old warhorse, if that is humanly possible, in the paths of peace. It is not enough for Robin Cook to pretend this is a normal transition. Britain must make clear its moral repugnance of much that Mr Sharon stands for and has done. Yet nor can it walk away, holding its nose. More than ever, the Middle East needs tough-minded, honest brokers capable of facing down this "Lion of God".

fields.headline: King and I
fields.standfirst: Natalie Cole has been a prostitutes' tout, a junkie and the winner of no fewer than eight Grammys. She tells  Dave Simpson about scandal, success and her beloved father Nat
fields.trailText: Natalie Cole has been a prostitutes' tout, a junkie and the winner of no fewer than eight Grammys. She tells Dave Simpson about scandal, success and her beloved father Nat.
fields.body:
At the age of 31, Natalie Cole was about to die. Smoke poured in beneath the door of her room on the 15th floor of the Las Vegas Hilton. Seated next to her on the sofa, her bodyguard chose the moment to proclaim his secret passion, declaring: "Natalie, we ought to make love here and now, because it's the last chance we're going to get." Natalie was unconcerned. She reached into her bag and started freebasing cocaine.

"Eight people died," she says now of the incident in 1981. She and Nate, her bodyguard, were rescued, but he never recovered from the effects of smoke inhalation. "That was a real scary situation, but I didn't even have the sense to be afraid. I was more concerned that if I was gonna die, I was gonna die loaded to the gills. Thank God I had sent my baby son home, because I probably wouldn't have had the sense to care for him."

That incident is just one of the startling revelations in Natalie Cole's autobiography, Angel on My Shoulder, which is generating tabloid headlines in America. Cole always seemed the girl who had everything. Daughter of Nat "King" Cole, she grew up in a family dubbed "the black Kennedys" to become one of the true divas of modern soul, the winner of eight Grammys. In the UK, she is best known for hits such as Miss You Like Crazy and Unforgettable, her 1991 album of her father's songs. But her book lifts the lid on a secret history of addiction and abuse.

Cole details overdoses in tenement blocks, near-fatal car crashes, arrests, collapses, several tragic deaths and her sexual abuse at the hands of an unnamed family member. Her candour is doubly unexpected because the Natalie who emerges is not always very nice.

"Everyone's been surprised [by the candour]. I'm not a big reader of autobiographies, so I assumed that's what you did." She laughs. "But at the same time, I can afford to be honest now and I hope it helps someone.

"I feel enough distance from the person I used to be. I'm not ashamed about my life any more because I've learnt from it." Cole's tale - delivered with disarming humour - is not just another drugs story, but one of the struggle for identity, of the consequences of grief and, most of all, of the pressures of following in the footsteps of one of the most famous black entertainers of the 20th century.

Born on February 6 1950, Natalie Cole had an idyllic, if isolated, early life. Her father was one of the first black entertainers to secure a huge white audience, and the Coles were the first non-white family to live in the exclusive Hancock Park district of Los Angeles. Every three weeks Natalie was escorted to the black community on the other side of town to get her hair done. For years that was her only real taste of black culture. She was well into her teens before she realised that her family wasn't like anybody else's. King Cole had four children, but doted on Natalie. The velvet-voiced singer was convinced his daughter had inherited the "gift", and he introduced her to the world onstage.

But everything changed with Nat's death from lung cancer in 1965. At 15, Natalie had to find a way to deal with a personal tragedy that was also a very public event. "My mother worked hard to create this controlled exterior, which she continues to this day," she says. "I don't think I ever really bawled or cried. That creates a pocket that you put all your stuff into, and it soon gets too heavy to carry." A week after the funeral, Natalie was in trouble for shoplifting. Her mother, appalled by the shame it brought on the family, sent her to a psychiatrist. The long, hard road had begun.

As a child, Natalie was prone to allergies and became accustomed to what she calls "a conga line of substances" - a pill here, a quick jab there. In college she graduated to heroin and LSD. There Cole discovered the blackness that she felt had been denied her, at one point working with the Black Panthers. Her major driving forces were confusion over her identity, and rebellion against her father's name. "I continually acted up to get attention," she says. "My father gave me that, and once he left I felt that I didn't have any.

"I also felt resentful about having to live up to certain standards because I am 'the daughter of . . .'. I was saying, 'I am not perfect. Now let me show you how not perfect I am.' "

For most of the early 1970s, heroin blighted Cole's career in struggling soul bands such as Black Magic. She was insecure - shouted requests for her father's music were not welcomed - and terribly addicted. In one of "many rock bottoms", she worked as a "prostitutes' lure", walking the streets of Harlem to grab the attention of potential clients.

Through "immense self-will" she kicked heroin in 1975 and a year later ended Aretha Franklin's nine-year run as the Grammys' best R&B female vocalist. Cole married Marvin Yancy, her songwriting partner and a Baptist preacher, and the couple had a son. Then, in her new role as queen of the disco era, she got hooked on cocaine.

"No one knew a lot about addiction in those days," she sighs. "People would say, sometimes very angrily, 'Why can't you just stop? Don't you know who you are?' But the problems were still there within me. So yeah, I went back into it about a year after the birth of my son."

Rather than help to cure her addiction, showbusiness nurtured it, but Cole does not want to pass the buck. "I was young, very successful, and very stupid and naive. That's a deadly combination, whether it leads to drugs or out-of-control sex. I was so busy getting high I didn't have time for sex."

Her health began to suffer, and one day her son rode his tricycle into a swimming pool while she was smoking crack. Then, in 1983, Cole successfully went through a rehab programme. The walls that had been built up through years of abuse gradually tumbled down, not least when one of her drug counsellors told her she was still grieving for her father. "I said, 'What? No way! I'm over that!' Which couldn't have been further from the truth."

Cole's complex relationship with her mother is equally important. Now 78, Maria Cole sued the four children in 1998 over the contents of their father's will. Despite Natalie's efforts, the pair don't speak and Maria reacted "negatively" when Natalie sent her a copy of her autobiography. Indeed, Cole's story has no Hollywood-style happy ending, and several issues remain unresolved.

Although she finally embraced her father's music with the worldwide hit Unforgettable, her career goes up and down. She bears a terrible guilt over her first husband Yancy's death in 1985, seven years after she introduced him to cocaine, not knowing he had a heart condition. "That will stay with me for ever," she says. "We were actually talking about getting back together. Then he died."

A second marriage, to record producer André Fischer - so she writes - exposed her to violence. Cole admits she was "dangerously naive and stupid", and that despite everything, she is still too trusting. So, for now at least, she is no longer dating.

However, it's too easy to view Natalie Cole as a victim. She has emerged from the car crash of her life with dignity and morals, and determined not to let her equally fatherless son, Robbie (now 23 and studying music), make the same mistakes she has. She is also campaigning for state counselling for children affected by bereavement or broken homes.

When the darkness returns, she finds it helps to laugh. "I can laugh at myself because I've had to. Everything would have been much worse if I'd been the singing son of Nat 'King' Cole."

 Natalie Cole's Love Songs album is out now on Warner Brothers. Angel On My Shoulder is published by Warner Books, price £18.99.
fields.bodyText: At the age of 31, Natalie Cole was about to die. Smoke poured in beneath the door of her room on the 15th floor of the Las Vegas Hilton. Seated next to her on the sofa, her bodyguard chose the moment to proclaim his secret passion, declaring: "Natalie, we ought to make love here and now, because it's the last chance we're going to get." Natalie was unconcerned. She reached into her bag and started freebasing cocaine. "Eight people died," she says now of the incident in 1981. webTitle: Arts feature: Sex and death in the theatre

fields.headline: To die, to sleep, perchance to dream . . .
fields.standfirst: Sex and death are drama's eternal themes - no wonder the bed is one of the theatre's most important props
fields.trailText: Sex and death are drama's eternal themes - no wonder the bed is one of the theatre's most important props.
fields.body:
We make love and, if we're lucky, die in bed. We sleep and dream there. Yet relatively few plays take place exclusively in bed. In the bad old days of censorship, it was largely a matter of decorum - to the Lord Chamberlain, bed implied hanky-panky. Now it is more a practical question: if drama is about taking characters on a journey, what can happen to them if they spend much of their time horizontal?

Dramatists, however, are an ingenious lot; in recent years several have given new meaning to the phrase "confined to bed" by turning a physical restriction into an opportunity. Jim Cartwright's play Bed showed seven old people lying side by side in a vast vertical bed and drifting through their dream-driven memories. At one point an elderly pair even descended through a hole in the bed, like Jack and Jill in reverse, to fetch a glass of water.

But other writers have shown that the bed can be used as a source of debate and dreams. In Brian Clark's Whose Life Is it Anyway? the hero, paralysed from the neck down, claimed the right to die by being taken off his life-support machine; the arguments were so interesting you forgot about the play's lack of physical dynamic. Pinter, in his Oliver Sacks-inspired A Kind of Alaska, shows his heroine awakening at the age of 45 after a 29-year "sleep", to be confronted by a changed world; but what one remembers, in performance, is Judi Dench's fierce sense of recollected gaiety as the resurrected Deborah.

If any dramatist can be guaranteed to turn an apparent limitation into a major asset, it is Alan Ayckbourn, and in Bedroom Farce he had the brilliant idea of putting three bedrooms and four couples on stage, with an itinerant pair of jokers, Trevor and Susannah, hawking their neuroses around like door-to-door salesmen. The title played on our traditional expectations of illicit sex. But Ayckbourn's breakthrough was to show that the bedroom is also a place of terrifying self-revelation.

Much the funniest scene took place in the bedroom of Trevor's parents, Ernest and Delia. They come back from an awful dinner at a swanky restaurant and sit up in bed eating pilchards on toast, while Ernest reads aloud from Tom Brown's Schooldays. The semi-detachment of the long-married was highlighted when a demented Susannah burst in. "Do you know what it's like to be ignored?" she passionately enquired. "Well yes, as a matter of fact I do," replied Joan Hickson, evoking a lifetime of emotional solitude. Few dramatists know more about what happens in bed - or doesn't - than Alan Ayckbourn.

If the bedroom has only recently become the exclusive setting for a play, beds have long featured in drama. Bed and Bard could be the subject of a thesis. Instantly one thinks of the closet scene in Hamlet, Iachimo stealing out of a trunk to peer at the sleeping Imogen in Cymbeline and the seeming-dead Henry IV unwarily leaving his crown on his pillow. Shakespeare could not show us explicit sexual love but it's amazing how much you can deduce from his plays about his characters' off-stage behaviour. I reckon the Macbeths, nocturnal wandering aside, would have been pretty good together in bed whereas Portia is likely to find Bassanio's eyes, after marriage, wandering towards the boys in Belmont.

But this is a key point about the bed in drama: even when it is not present, it looms large. No dramatist was more physically circumspect than Ibsen and yet his plays, to use a John Osborne simile, are as sexually obsessed as a medieval monastery. There's a great moment in A Doll's House, after Nora has danced her frantic party-piece tarantella, when Torvald can hardly wait to get her into bed; with typically mordant irony, Ibsen then has Dr Rank pay a late-night call to announce his impending death. And it's astonishing how riddled with sexual references Hedda Gabler is. We can easily imagine the horrors of Hedda's honeymoon with Tesman. And you don't need to be a Freudian to see the significance of Judge Brack's preference for taking "the back way".

Physical inhibitions, in short, have their own power - you don't always need to see a bed to imagine it. I can recall at least two productions of Congreve's The Way of the World, for instance, where a bed has been prominently and gratuitously deployed in case we missed the raunchiness under the raillery. Even Coward knew how to fill his plays with the heady aroma of sex without getting his characters into bed: the middle act of Private Lives, for instance, is an extended piece of love-play in which Elyot and Amanda romp fastidiously around a sofa.

Only in farce does the bed become indispensable . Even here the promise is greater than the reality, for the bed is more often a source of pain than of pleasure. Feydeau was the great master of the bed as potential minefield. In one of his plays a bed swings embarrassingly into view at the inadvertent press of a button, and in Le Dindon a deaf elderly couple remain oblivious to an alarm that rings like a tocsin under their mattress.

Sex and death: these are the eternal themes of drama and as long as they remain so the bed will be a necessary piece of theatrical equipment. But the bed also fulfils myriad other functions in drama. It can be a focus for trickery and deceit - think of Jonson's Volpone conning his eager supplicants in his Venetian king-size. It can also be a source of revelation. The pivotal scene in Pinter's Betrayal, also set in Venice, shows Robert coolly appraising Emma of his discovery of her affair.

Beds and drama go together like a horse and carriage. Even when convention kept beds unseen they still dominated the action. Now the bed has been put centre-stage. It can be used for disclosure and concealment, lies and truth, birth and death, moral enquiry and mundane bed-and-butter issues. The story of 20th-century drama is of an abandonment of the drawing-room to explore the rest of the house. As a result, the bed has become king. And, though it presents dramatists and designers with the task of how to give physical expression to a horizontal inclination, you can be sure of one thing: it's a challenge they won't take lying down.

fields.headline: Tap nerds
fields.trailText: Arthur Smith
fields.body:
It can't be long before the rustic theme park village introduces Ye Olde Video Shoppe, complete with a dodgy owner who looks as if he could introduce you to a cheap hitman. In the future, when every TV programme and film ever made will be available at all times, we will scarcely recall the days when you could rent a video from the greengrocer. There will be no more videos. No more Blockbuster, which, anyway, only has 8m copies of one blockbuster. Mr Video in Balham is still there but it exudes anticipated nostalgia. As did the film I rented there three weeks ago.

I think it was John Osborne who said, "I could not love someone who did not love This Is Spinal Tap." For men of a certain age, being a Tap nerd is a cherished memory. I still find myself sometimes in the corner at parties, exchanging furtive Tappisms with bearded men. So I was worried that it might only get a B-minus in the test of time. Some of the jokes may have been repeated too often, such as drowning in someone else's vomit, the volume control that goes up to 11, the big bit of ham and the small bit of bread.

Spinal Tap invented a genre of cod documentary that has been imitated so much that I wondered if the original could still be fresh. I feared that, with its recent re-release on video, the little coterie of Tappists might disband for ever. That when asked, "What is the funniest film you've ever seen?" I'd have to search for a new answer.

I pulled the cassette from its thin blue jacket and started not watching it. I still haven't and I'm not going to. Meanwhile I owe the man at Mr Video £31.50 and counting.

fields.headline: Smoking guns
fields.standfirst: Eighteen soldiers who tested positive for cannabis and cocaine this week are likely to be kicked out of the army.  Ken Lukowiak , who knows a thing or too about drugs and the forces, says let's cut them some slack
fields.trailText: Eighteen soldiers who tested positive for cannabis and cocaine this week are likely to be kicked out of the army.  Ken Lukowiak , who knows a thing or too about drugs and the forces, says let's cut them some slack.
fields.body:
In the spring of 1983, my battalion was posted to Belize in Central America. Before we departed we were warned on various occasions about the high-potency marijuana that Belize was apparently famous for. In case the importance of these warnings didn't quite sink in, the battalion's junior NCOs, of which I was now a newly promoted member, were given a lecture on drug abuse by a plain-clothed sergeant of the royal military police.

The lecture's level of information (such as marijuana is also commonly known on the mean civvie streets as "dope" or "weed", and is rolled into cigarettes that are called "reefers") only made us wonder just where the army thought we had all been the last 20 years or so. Obviously not on the council estates where most of us had been brought up. At one point the military policeman (MP) lit a nice sized piece of Moroccan hashish and passed it around the room. The logic behind this was that should we ever be walking past the bike shed in Belize and smell such an aroma wafting through the air, then we'd know what it was - and even more importantly what to do about it. In reality of course we had as much chance of smelling a piece of burning hashish in Belize, (which is quite different from the smell of burning grass) as we did of seeing an iceberg, and why the MP didn't just burn a piece of grass instead, I do not know. After all, it wasn't like he didn't have any. For identification purposes, he had a large glass-faced cabinet that contained a neatly labelled amount of most the world's types of dope.

Unfortunately for me, when we did finally arrived in Belize, I was one of the few to ignore the warnings. I not only smoked dope just about every day of our six-month tour, I also thought it would be an act of pure genius to smuggle a few pounds of it back home.

There wasn't a lot of drug abuse in my day. Of the 120-plus soldiers stationed at our company location in Belize I knew of only two others who smoked marijuana. At the time if the army did have a drug problem within it's ranks then if anything it was one of over indulgence in alcohol. In fact in the army military hospital in Woolwich a whole ward was dedicated to weaning soldiers off the legal liquid narcotic. As for other drugs, once, on a trip to Belize city, a friend and I purchased a gram of cocaine - which today I now know was the most expensive baking powder in Central America.

In the end I was caught, discharged from the army, and sentenced to 18 months in prison. At my trial no one from the regiment came to speak on my behalf and the fact that only the year before I had put my life on the line and even killed for "them" - whoever they may be - if anything, seemed to count against me. An example had to be made. And it was.

A couple of weeks into my sentence I was joined in HMP Winchester by three onetime members of 3 Para. They, like me, had fought in the Falklands and again, like me, had fallen foul of the law a year latter. Their crime was to gang-rape a girl in the block one night. And yet when they stood before a court they were allowed to wear their uniforms and medals and various members of their battalion appeared to speak on their behalf. And even back then there was this bit of me that couldn't help but feel that someone's got their priorities all wrong here.

Last year six members of 1 Para were found to have smoked marijuana after their company was randomly drug tested. When the news broke, the papers were filled with various quotes from the usual Ministry of Defence and army suspects who all toed the party line of zero tolerance and called for the instant dismissal of the soldiers concerned.

In the Sun one unnamed Parachute Regiment officer was quoted as saying: "They should be lined up against a wall and shot." Very little was made of the fact that the soldiers concerned had all just recently returned from operational duties in Sierra Leone and that maybe, just maybe, for once a little bit of slack could be given in their direction.

If space can be found in military hospitals for alcohol abuse, then why not for other types of drugs? To train people to kill and then to throw them out into civvie street with no therapy or counselling may just be a few thousand court cases for compensation just waiting to happen. Anybody know a good lawyer?

fields.headline: 'Fast Eddie' Parker
fields.standfirst: Professional pool player who was the inspiration for Paul Newman's role in The Hustler
fields.trailText: "Fast Eddie" Parker was the man who inspired the film The Hustler, but he always insisted that he was a "money player" rather than a hustler. "A hustler will let the other guy win, and then up the bet," he explained. "He's conning his opponent. A money player freezes up the money in advance and plays his best right from the start."
fields.body:
"Fast Eddie" Parker was the man who inspired the film The Hustler, but he always insisted that he was a "money player" rather than a hustler. "A hustler will let the other guy win, and then up the bet," he explained. "He's conning his opponent. A money player freezes up the money in advance and plays his best right from the start."

Parker, who has died of a heart attack aged 69 while making an appearance at the US Classic Billiards Eight-Ball Showdown near Brownsville, Texas, made his living playing his best.

Born in Springfield, Missouri, he began shooting pool in Kansas City aged nine, and by the time he was in high-school he had already earned the nickname "Fast Eddie".

He was taken under the wing of six-time world champion Benny Allen. "I never had any idea I was going to shoot for money until I started studying with Benny," he said. But his hustling edge was apparent early.

In 1950, Allen took Parker to a match between world champion Willie Mosconi and Irving "Deacon" Crane, to study Mosconi's form. Parker, already married to his wife Peggy, and needing money, noticed Mosconi left a cigarette burning before beginning each rack.

He bet a stranger $20 that Mosconi would run each rack before the cigarette burned out. Mosconi ran seven straight; Parker made $140 dollars. "I told Benny I hadn't seen a single stroke, I was too busy watching Mosconi's ashtray."

After serving in the navy, where he won the California championships, his only competitive titles, Parker began playing for money. He drifted to Louisville, Kentucky, where he befriended a young man working his way through college in the famed Bensingers Pool Hall.

Walter Tevis borrowed one of Parker's aliases to create Fast Eddie Felson, the hero of his novel The Hustler in 1959, which became Robert Rossen's hit movie in 1961. Paul Newman played Felson, Jackie Gleason played a character based on the legendary "New York Fats", Rudolph Wanderone. Tevis changed that to "Minnesota Fats", and Gleason's performance was so memorable that Wanderone began calling himself Minnesota Fats.

Although Wanderone cashed in on his notoriety, including a series of high-profile TV matches where he generally lost to Mosconi, Parker's identity remained a secret between himself and Tevis. Long after he went public as "Fast Eddie", Parker was forced to resort to passing a polygraph test to prove it.

"About 30% of the movie was real," he later said. He had never had both thumbs broken, only a single finger. But Eddie's beating of a rich Kentucky businessman at three-cushion billiards was real. "It was my biggest-ever jackpot, $30,000," Parker explained. "But I only got $12,000. I split 40/60 with my stakehorse, who'd put up the money I'd bet."

Before retiring in 1980, Parker set a world record by sinking 22 balls on a single shot. He began producing instructional books and videos, which Paul Newman used when he reprised the Fast Eddie role in Martin Scorsese's The Colour Of Money. As the real Minnesota Fats once said, "Gleason could play, Newman only made it look good."

Parker sold merchandise, did exhibitions and made personal appearances. In 1988 he finally went head-to-head with Mosconi; Mosconi winning at eight-ball, Parker at nine-ball. Although The Hustler portrayed the seamier side of the game, it made pool more glamorous and acceptable. At the US Classic, Parker told an interviewer that "pool has cleaned up its act. When I was a kid, you weren't supposed to go into a pool hall. Now it's a very reputable sport."

That evening he complained of not feeling well, sat down, and had a heart attack. He was airlifted to a hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Back at the tournament, cue balls Parker had signed earlier for a $10 fee were auctioned for $1,000, the money defraying his funeral expenses. Fast Eddie was a money player to the end.

He leaves a wife, son, and seven grandchildren.

fields.headline: The Four Margarets
fields.standfirst: A powerful quartet of women holds some of the top jobs in the Labour party - and they share the same name. They are feminising the political machine, says  Anne Perkins , so why don't their policies appeal to female voters?
fields.trailText: A powerful quartet of women holds some of the top jobs in the Labour party - and they share the same name. They are feminising the political machine, says  Anne Perkins , so why don't their policies appeal to female voters?
fields.body:
As comparisons go, it is a delicious one. Four close chums, all with a touch of the jolly hockey sticks about them, strong women each. And all with the same name. It is almost as if the Four Marys, a comic strip mainstay of the girls' magazine Bunty for the past 40 years, has become flesh.

Maggie Jones, Margaret Prosser, Margaret Wall and Margaret McDonagh are close friends. They go shopping together and spend weekends away as a foursome. Earlier this week, they met for dinner (at a suitably cool central London restaurant), something they do as often as they can spare the time. But it is unlikely they spent the evening discussing gymslips and gymkhanas as the Four Marys do. These women have captured the commanding heights of the most powerful machine in British politics - the Labour party. Four years after Blair's Babes were first feted (and later scorned) by the British press, the new Labour leadership say they are proving that it is possible to feminise even the most aggressively male of institutions.

Labour's national executive committee or NEC, the keeper of the party conscience, is now controlled by women. Jones, 45, public policy director of the public sector workers' union Unison, became chairwoman of the Labour party in October. Wall, who is in her 50s and national secretary of the MSF union, is her deputy. Prosser, 63, who made her name as women's officer in the hostile environment of the Transport and General Workers Union in the 80s, has been the party's treasurer for the past five years. And McDonagh, 39, is the most powerful of them all. She climbed through the ranks of London Labour party to become the national party's first woman general secretary in 1998.

But despite being the first party to have a meaningful female presence in its positions of influence, Labour has not succeeded in appealing to women voters. The influential Fawcett Society published a study earlier this week showing that women's disillusionment with Labour has risen sharply in the past year. Tony Blair's personal "satisfaction rating" among women fell from 50% in January 2000 to 38% in November, and women voters are markedly more unhappy with the government than their male counterparts. The Four Margarets, it seems, have a bit more work to do in the run up to the election.

Maggie Jones is adamant that the Labour party's modus operandi is changing. "It's warmer, it's more open and it's more consensual," she claims. Wall agrees: "Everyone, especially women, feels they can contribute. It is more inclusive."

If true, this is a sea change. To anyone with a memory longer than 1997, the idea of the NEC, the once semi-public arena for all Labour's internal conflict, as a warm and friendly body run by women is a revolutionary one. In the old days, participants in what was then the monthly meeting of the NEC would emerge spitting bloodied teeth live into the lunchtime television news to declare another victory (both sides always said they had won). It was a shell-pocked no-man's land, fought over inch by inch by the tribes that struggled for control of Labour. Usually it was left versus right, sometimes it was party versus government, but always it was conflict.

And now? It's hard to find anyone who doesn't think the NEC's bi-monthly meetings a kinder, gentler place. "It's definitely having an effect," says Helen Jackson, a tough and experienced MP, parliamentary aide to successive Northern Ireland ministers, and member of the NEC for two years.

For example, we've moved right away from silly votes. In the old days, people would put in a resolution, and there would be a vote, and they would lose. But the vote would be recorded, so they would feel they had done their bit on, say, raising the minimum wage to £5 an hour. But they hadn't changed anything."

The four Margarets' favourite word is "outcome". Look how little confrontation achieves, they say, and how much damage it can do. They insist that it is possible to make a difference without having a chest-thumping row first. Prosser is convinced that confrontation doesn't pay. "Look at human relations. You have to persuade people that they want to do what you want them to do."

"We got going in about 1995," says Maggie Jones who, with Wall, is largely responsible for the system of linking party, trade unions and leadership called Partnership in Power. "The whole ethos was about non-confrontational policy-making. It was revolutionary. We thought we would never get [the party] conference to accept it. But they did."

There are some unexpected converts to this supposedly feminised approach. For example, Dennis Skinner, the former miner and veteran of 30 years of uncompromising left-wing politics, is one. "In the past 18 months there has been a growing feeling, from unexpected areas, that it's OK to say your party piece [at the NEC]. And I am beginning to look at things in a different way. I'm not so sure now, looking back on the nights when we sent out for fish and chips to keep us going until midnight, that these were actually the highlight of my life."

But what have the four women changed? Critics charge - and even supporters fear - that Labour's powerful women, in their quest for new ways of doing things, risk being identified with all the most mistrusted aspects of new Labour. They are in danger, they say, of being portrayed as the puppets of a centralised, authoritarian administration, fig leaves for democracy.

And where once each meeting of the NEC was attended by a dozen television crews and closely monitored, not only by fans of the big fight but by everyone who cared where the Labour party or government was heading, it is now cursed with anonymity. The executive meets less often, its activities are largely governed by the agenda of the party's Millbank headquarters (none of the ordinary members on the NEC had even heard of the much-criticised new logo) and the way its members are elected is designed as far as possible to exclude the awkward squad. But the real test is approaching. Over the next few weeks, the election manifesto will be finalised. The four Margarets are at the heart of the debate. In the minefield of possibilities and promises, on the future of the railways, on crime and punishment and public investment and pensions, lies a fragmentary vision of the future. There will probably be fewer women MPs in the next parliament than in this one. Far from reaching critical mass in 1997, the local parties which select candidates have slipped back into the old ways of choosing the first man to hand. So can these women use their power to squeeze into Labour's top priorities a commitment to change the law so that it is once again possible to have all-women shortlists?

All four women are committed to them. Two - Wall and Jones - run the selection panel which over the next few weeks will slot candidates in to the seats where vacancies exist. But such a commitment would not be universally popular. Once more the unfair and unflattering eye of the tabloid press would linger over the women in the class of 97. It is the first big test of consensus, of whether it can bring results - or whether, in the end, politics always comes down to power and the determination to use it.

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.trailText:
"Katherine's like one of the boys. She's got a man's attitude to training - she gets in there, works very hard and gives as good as she gets."
Linford Christie on training Olympic bronze-medal winner Katharine Merry, Eve
fields.body:
"Katherine's like one of the boys. She's got a man's attitude to training - she gets in there, works very hard and gives as good as she gets."
Linford Christie on training Olympic bronze-medal winner Katharine Merry, Eve

"Personally, I don't find it frustrating that most people think models are stupid. If I weren't a model myself, I'd think the same way. It's fun to objectify beautiful women. I objectify beautiful women as much as anybody, and I am a beautiful woman."
Milla Jovovich, Nova

"Our research shows the Sassy as a new breed of woman in the UK. She knows what she wants. She is a high-flier who likes being around her friends, and she is looking for the right man who will fit in with her lifestyle. Single life in the city is once again a desirable state for these women."
Sue Wall, marketing manager for Baileys, sponsor of C4's Sex and the City

"The pressure on young girls reading this will be to think: I should be being sexy, I should be flirting with boys and I should be wearing make up. But by encouraging young girls to be sexual you don't only open them up to the possibility of older boys taking advantage of them, you open them to the possibility of paedophiles. They will say, 'She's 10, but she's asking for it'."
Dr Michele Elliott, director of the children's charity Kidscape, about pre-teen glossy Mad About Boys

"With our flexi-time and generous holiday entitlement, you'll fit your working life around your other commitments with ease. And don't worry if you don't have recent office experience, you probably demonstrate the skills we're looking for every day: Because being a parent or running a household equips you for the workplace far more than you may realise . . . Just think about it."
MI5 recruitment ad for admin assistants, She

"I went to watch footie and went to a pub to see a stripper. At first I was just disgusted by all the men drooling over this girl but then I realised she was the one who had all the power. And I thought, go girl! But the best thing about being a bloke is that you just don't care how you look any more. I put on a stone over the time I was Adam. Fiona would never have had chips with a meal but Adam did and he drank pints of lager when Fiona drank wine."
Fiona Waddington who spent three months as a 20-year-old man for a C4 documentary, The Sun

Amy Fleming

webTitle: Leader: A swell party But some swells had little to celebrate

fields.headline: A swell party But some swells had little to celebrate
fields.standfirst:
Prince William attends PCC bash, despite complaints about intrusive photographs last year
MediaGuardian.co.uk

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: William - the prince no longer to be known as HRH - who attended last night Press Complaints Commission anniversary bash is of course the same royal who complained as recently as last October about intrusive pictures. And, yes, the guests included the oft-complaining Blairs. And Camilla Parker-Bowles; and what the commission's press release breathlessly bundled together as soap stars and politicians. The PCC's principal clients were evidently determined not to miss out on the celebration. But what, exactly, did they think they were feting?
fields.body:
William - the prince no longer to be known as HRH - who attended last night Press Complaints Commission anniversary bash is of course the same royal who complained as recently as last October about intrusive pictures. And, yes, the guests included the oft-complaining Blairs. And Camilla Parker-Bowles; and what the commission's press release breathlessly bundled together as soap stars and politicians. The PCC's principal clients were evidently determined not to miss out on the celebration. But what, exactly, did they think they were feting?

Undoubtedly, the PCC is a better organisation than its predecessor, with an authority and reputation that has helped stave off the statutory regulation that looked perilously close 10 years ago. It is also free, allowing complainants a means of redress without the vast costs of going to court. Even the PCC's leading critics concede that it has a positive effect on press behaviour .

But it is far from perfect. Complaining successfully is difficult, and the general sense is that in its role as conciliator rather than judge, the PCC inevitably favours the newspapers over the public. "Punishment", when it takes the form of a small correction with nothing like the impact of the original story, can leave complainants deeply dissatisfied.

The PCC, too, was not set up to be proactive. As a result, it does not reach out to shape the culture within which editorial decisions are taken or the way people - soap stars, royals, politicians - are treated. For some of these categories there are no hard and fast rules: the PCC should be continuously checking the way journalists make their decisions about public interest and the boundaries of the private sphere.

The royals and the prime minister's family - among others - have certainly had things to complain about. A certain distance from a body which has not always come up with appropriate answers might have been more fitting yesterday.

fields.headline: Wired way to share memories
fields.standfirst:
The days of dusting off old picture albums from the attic to show your friends or relatives are over. Jack Schofield tells us why
More net news
fields.trailText: The days of dusting off old picture albums from the attic to show your friends or relatives are over. Jack Schofield tells us why
fields.body:
Putting pictures on the web is the quickest and easiest way to share them. You don't even need a computer to do it. And although you may never have thought about starting an online photo album, there is a very good chance you already have one.

The simplest and cheapest way to get your pictures online is to have it done as part of the D&P (developing and printing) process. Such services have become common in the US over the past couple of years, and Fotango, a start-up based in London, now offers one in Europe.

Post a 35mm or APS film to Fotango and it will put your pictures online free. You can also order a set of prints or a Photo CD when you send off the film: see www.fotango.com for prices. The service is also available via WH Smith, which means you can take your film into any branch for processing, and have the pictures put online for an extra 99p.

D&P services usually produce good results because they scan the original nega tives, not machine-made prints that may be of variable quality. And since manual scanning is hard work, they save a lot of effort.

Of course, it is not happy snappers who are driving the online album market. It is, rather, the growing number of people who are buying digital cameras, as the image quality goes up and prices come down.

Digital camera owners tend not to say: "I'll stick a print in the post". They probably don't have any prints. They can and do offer to send pictures by email, but this can create problems.

Image files can be large, and take time to upload and download. Recipients often do not like receiving large attachments by email, and may have problems decoding them. Worse, a handful of images can fill up a mailbox, which may mean more important mail is "bounced" (rejected).

The obvious solution is to put the pictures on a web page, so people can look at them when they like. And when the first free web space became available on GeoCities and similar "homesteading" sites, that is what many keen photographers did. However, this still required too much time and effort for people who just wanted to put a couple of snaps online - especially if they were just snaps of things they were auctioning on eBay.

About three years ago, PhotoPoint came up with the solution. PhotoPoint lets you put pictures on the web by emailing them to photos@photopoint.com. You then log on to the service using your email address, and search for other people's pictures by using their email addresses.

Also, once you have put a picture in a PhotoPoint album, it has a unique address. This means you can email a friend a link to a picture and they can go straight to it. For example, my photo of New York, a theme hotel in Las Vegas, is here.

What could be easier - if you just have just have to click on a web link? PhotoPoint now offers other ways to upload photos. You can upload up to 10 images at once, by browsing for each one on your hard drive and selecting it in a search box. It works exactly like adding an attachment to an email message in Hotmail or Yahoo. Almost every online album site has the same facility.

PhotoPoint has also introduced Image Express software for Microsoft Windows. Download this helper application and you can upload up to 100 pictures at a time. Finally, the site has a tie in with Kodak's PhotoNet Online service in the US, so users can have films processed and then transfer the image files to PhotoPoint.

If you only want to upload one or two dozen pictures, you should have no problems with a service that lets you upload six to 10 at a time. But if you want to upload a couple of hundred, or a couple of thousand, then make sure you choose a service with bulk upload software such as Image Express.

Another useful PhotoPoint feature, not found on all services, is the ability to rotate an image. This solves one common problem, which is accidentally uploading pictures as horizontals when they should be vertical. PhotoPoint also allows simple cropping, while other sites offer "image enhancement" software.

Dozens of rivals have entered the online album business over the past couple of years. It has attracted some big players including Kodak, Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Sony, as well as start-ups such as Ophoto, Shutterfly and - in the UK - PhotoBox.

Most are free, but derive some income from making prints. This includes printing images on mugs, plates, T-shirts, mousemats and other memorabilia. If you allow it, they are also happy to make prints for your friends, or even for people you don't know who just like the picture.

Many other web sites have also added photo album facilities, including the leading portals: Yahoo, AOL and the Microsoft network, MSN. If you already have a Yahoo or Hotmail address, then you already have an online photo album. Visto includes one too.

The idea of making prints raises one of the problems that is usually hidden by photo album services: image size. If you use a digital camera, selecting the best possible image quality will result in a multi-megabyte file. Even compressed JPEG (.jpg) images will often range from 200K to 900K. If you just want to share a snapshot, this is far too large: about 35-135K would download quicker. However, if an image is going to be used for printing, you want the best resolution you can get.

Typically online albums will let you upload any image you like, but will only display a reduced version. For example, my New York picture was uploaded as a 182K image with a resolution of 1280 by 960 pixels, and on Yahoo, that is what you get.

However, the one you can see on PhotoPoint has been reduced to a 43K JPEG with VGA resolution (640 by 480 pixels), while the one on Fotango has become ludicrously small.

Another problem I had with Fontango was that I could not see how to link to a whole album. This is easy with PhotoPoint, and Yahoo. For comparison purposes, all contain the same four photos.

Another point to consider is the total amount of space allowed. For example, my four Las Vegas photos already take up a megabyte, so Yahoo's generous 25 megabytes of free space may only hold 100 pictures.

Some sites allow an infinite amount of storage - dangerous, if there is no limit on uploading multimedia files and movies! - while others are more circumspect.

The obvious way around such limits is to open multiple accounts. You could give them different names (scholialasvegas, scholia friends, scholiapets etc) or simply numbers (scholia001, scholia002 and so on). There are already people with more than 200 Yahoo accounts.

All the online photo albums let you keep your pictures private. However, you can "publish" them to the global populace, if you like, and list them in Yahoo-style category guides. Many albums also have "guest books" where visitors can leave comments.

But if you really want to be the next Sam Haskins or Ansel Adams, do the job properly and design a website to suit your pictures.

Online albums are just a simple way to share snaps with friends.

fields.headline: I'm no arms dealer
fields.trailText: Your article (Former Thatcher adviser to chair Wafic Said company, February 7) repeats some well-worn inaccuracies about me which I would like to correct. Despite its endless repetition in the press I am not, and never have been, an "arms dealer".
fields.body:
Your article (Former Thatcher adviser to chair Wafic Said company, February 7) repeats some well-worn inaccuracies about me which I would like to correct. Despite its endless repetition in the press I am not, and never have been, an "arms dealer".

The truth is much less interesting. I am proud to have played a small part in helping Britain secure the government to government Al Yammamah contract with Saudi Arabia, thus protecting many thousands of British jobs. But I received no commissions whatsoever from this.

As to your claim that I have been involved in a string of "controversial Middle Eastern arms deals" - I have not, and whoever the fantasists are who peddle these fables, they have yet to name a single deal in which I am supposed to have played a part.

As for being in the Ritz hotel in September 1993 at the same time as Jonathan Aitken, I was indeed staying there that weekend but I was unaware of Mr Aitken's presence in the hotel and did not meet him. This was acknowledged by your former editor at the time this story was reported.
Wafic Rida Said
London

fields.headline: Alert for new threats
fields.trailText: Thank God, we are getting back to real politics (It's a friend's duty to speak up, February 7). Rear Admiral Eugene J Carroll's excellent summary of the national missile defence system (NMD) should put us all on red alert.
fields.body:
Thank God, we are getting back to real politics (It's a friend's duty to speak up, February 7). Rear Admiral Eugene J Carroll's excellent summary of the national missile defence system (NMD) should put us all on red alert.

It is a pretty watertight argument which even those who wore CND badges to win parliamen- tary nominations should heed.

The Rear Admiral has placed our two-fold responsibilities before us in the UK. Otherwise we will be pulled into the new arms race.
Illtyd Harrington
London

webTitle: Letters: Brown makes a meal of it

fields.headline: Brown makes a meal of it
fields.trailText: John Gray may well be correct (Comment, February 7) that the demise of Peter Mandelson heralds the emergence of Gordon Brown as the key player in the present government. He seems less on the mark, however, in his description of the ideological consequences of this "turning point in British politics".
fields.body:
John Gray may well be correct (Comment, February 7) that the demise of Peter Mandelson heralds the emergence of Gordon Brown as the key player in the present government. He seems less on the mark, however, in his description of the ideological consequences of this "turning point in British politics".

Far from marking the fusing of "equal opportunity" with the "most durable traditions [which?] of British social democracy", is there not growing evidence to suggest that what is emerging around Brown is a combination of economic prudence bordering on the punitive with a US-style moral authoritarianism?

Might we be witnessing a new post-Thatcher consensus that owes less to Clinton and the vacuities of the third way and more to Bush and the asperities of the religious right? In short, after Butskellism, not Blaijorism but Brushism.
Alan Hooper
a.hooper@herts.ac.uk St Albans, Herts

If anything shows a lack of moral sense (Brown holds court with the moralists, February 1), it's discussing "moral sense" over a working breakfast. These working breakfasts must go, Gordon. There's no point in arguing against a culture of long working hours if you yourself don't set an example by insisting: "At breakfast I'll just concentrate on eating my cereal, thanks very much."
Andrew Wilks
London

fields.headline: Cash on the tables
fields.trailText: You quote Andrew Clark, the partner in charge of anti-money laundering services at PricewaterhouseCoopers (Internet casinos a cover for crime, February 2), as saying that traditional casinos have long been recognised as vehicles for money launderers. "You can walk in with wads of cash and buy chips and not even do any gaming and then leave with a cheque." He clearly has not tried!
fields.body:
You quote Andrew Clark, the partner in charge of anti-money laundering services at PricewaterhouseCoopers (Internet casinos a cover for crime, February 2), as saying that traditional casinos have long been recognised as vehicles for money launderers. "You can walk in with wads of cash and buy chips and not even do any gaming and then leave with a cheque." He clearly has not tried!

His identity would be recorded on arrival; his cash transactions would usually be recorded on video and a suspicious transaction of this nature would certainly be reported to the National Criminal Intelligence Service.

If he purchased chips but did not play, he would normally have cash returned to him on leaving. Only if he won could he expect to be paid out by cheque, the details of which would be recorded for inspection by the Gaming Board.

These stringent safeguards have ensured that there has not been a single recorded case of money laundering in a casino in this country for many years.
David Beeton
Director general, British Gaming Association
