fields.headline: Spot the camel
fields.trailText: • Does anyone know what has become of the stuffed camel who, for many years, has kept watch over the M5 a few miles from the turn-off at junction 23 across the fields from Bridgwater in Somerset? Someone must know because he has been well cared for, with a new coat of paint and sometimes a jaunty hat or a tinsel scarf. The camel has brightened my journey east but last week it was missing.
fields.body:
 Does anyone know what has become of the stuffed camel who, for many years, has kept watch over the M5 a few miles from the turn-off at junction 23 across the fields from Bridgwater in Somerset? Someone must know because he has been well cared for, with a new coat of paint and sometimes a jaunty hat or a tinsel scarf. The camel has brightened my journey east but last week it was missing.

I hope there is nothing sinister afoot and that he will re-appear in a smart new outfit soon. Am I the only one that has enjoyed his presence over the years? Surely not.
Brian Kirby
Broadclyst, Exeter

 It appears your design gurus (Design of the times, G2, February 6) and your correspondents have misunderstood the new Labour symbol. Pioneered by the singer Prince, it is not a logo but a name: "The party formerly known as Labour."
Graeme Garden
Enstone, Oxon
graeme@dapplecot.demon. co.uk

The Musicians' Union (Playing with fire, G2, February 6), in common with every other union in this country, had its legs chopped from beneath it by the Thatcher government, thus precipitating the decline of the once proud music profession into what it has become today - the money-spinning pop music recording business.
Michael Fuller
Harpenden, Herts

Henry Phillips (Letters, February 7) is not the only one to have discerned the darker side of Sir Cliff. What of that 1965 hit In The Country, where the great Christian, after sympathising with the plight of his girlfriend (overwhelmed by the pressures of life in the city, hemmed in by the faceless, uncaring masses, who reaches out her hand for succour), then tells her that her hero is off in the country, romping with some other bird?
Martin Crookall
Reddish, Stockport
martin.crookall@manutd.com

Steve "Shagger" Norris is more liberal that I thought. I had not realised that he supported "legalising gay sex in public" (Simon Hoggart, February 7).
Toni Bolam
Penybont, Carmarthen
tonibolam@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Mr Straw's flawed idea
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee says that the "only solution" to the vast flow of asylum seekers and displaced persons is "solving problems at source" (Comment, February 7), but isn't the reality that the west's efforts to impose solutions has made the problem worse?
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee says that the "only solution" to the vast flow of asylum seekers and displaced persons is "solving problems at source" (Comment, February 7), but isn't the reality that the west's efforts to impose solutions has made the problem worse?

A significant proportion of asylum seekers in the EU come from, or via, the Balkans - where Nato forces are widely deployed and where every government is endorsed by the west and pursues economic policies devised by western institutions such as the IMF.

It is western military intervention plus western imposed impoverishment of the Balkans which has created the impetus for emigration, while fostering the corrupt regimes who mouth the slogans of the transition to the market but in practice facilitate the people-smuggling rackets. Sadly, Polly Toynbee is prescribing another dose of the disease of western intervention as the cure.
Mark Almond
MPAHel@aol.com
Oriel College, Oxford

The government's plan to toughen the rules for asylum seekers by restricting their claim to asylum to the first "safe country" they reach ('Asylum seekers to be 'sent back', February 6) may appear an easy way out but it is fraught with difficulties.

Just one example from our files illustrates this. It concerns a professor at Kabul university who sought refuge in the UK, having travelled via Pakistan after threats were made to his life in Afghanistan. He was only allowed into the UK after very intensive questioning at the point of entry - Heathrow.

Is it now being suggested that he should have remained in that region? The Guardian reported some months ago that academics and writers who had fled from the Taliban to Pakistan were now being attacked following pressure from the authorities in Afghanistan and those in Pakistan who support the Taliban's extreme religious beliefs. One had been shot and another forced to return, while countless others live in fear of their lives. How can "safety " be accurately assessed? What kind of society are we becoming?
John Akker
cara@academic-refugee.org
Council for Assisting Refugee Academics

Does anybody really imagine that the home secretary's new proposals on asylum are anything other than a further turn of the screw against refugees and immigration rights? Is he really going to disperse hundreds of Croydon-based immigration officials to such places as Kosovo, Afghanistan or Sri Lanka to process applications? Does he really believe that a persecuted Kurd would report to officials in Ankara or Baghdad with their papers ? Of course not. Refugees flee because of war, environmental disaster, persecution and poverty. No flick of Jack Straw's quill will deal with such problems. Straw's alternative is nothing less than the politics of barbarism.
Dr Martin Upchurch
Martin.Upchurch@uwe.ac.uk
University of the West of England, Bristol

The concept of a "safe country" for asylum seekers is one which the Home Office has persistently misinterpreted. They treat the idea as if it were an absolute, whereas according to the courts a safe country means one which is safe for that particular applicant. It means first that they must admit the individual to their asylum process rather than sending them back. Second, according to the court of appeal, it means readiness to recognise persecution by non-state agencies such as the FIS in Algeria. No refugee should be sent to a "safe country" until the courts are satisfied that that country is safe for that particular refugee.
Earl Russell
House of Lords

fields.headline: Israel has decided
fields.trailText: Your accurate judgment that the Israeli election result "marked an overwhelming rejection by the Israeli people of the eight-year-old Oslo peace process" is not at all the same as the headline under which it appears (Israel gives up on peace with Sharon victory, February 7).
fields.body:
Your accurate judgment that the Israeli election result "marked an overwhelming rejection by the Israeli people of the eight-year-old Oslo peace process" is not at all the same as the headline under which it appears (Israel gives up on peace with Sharon victory, February 7).

Most Israeli voters want a settlement along the lines envisaged in UN security council resolution 242: territorial compromise by Israel, contingent on an end to Arab hostilities. Yet they know that Ehud Barak made continual unilateral concessions to that end - offering withdrawal from 95% of the West Bank, the Golan Heights to Syria, and the creation of a Palestinian state - and failed to elicit any Arab response save demagoguery and violence. Israel has not given up on peace. She has judged, with reason, that a diplomatic model of "give-and-take" cannot take effect when one side only is giving and one taking.
Oliver Kamm
London

Your headline echoes the feelings of most of us, but it is premature. It was former terrorist Menachem Begin who shared the Nobel peace prize with Egypt's Anwar Sadat and one time hardliner F W De Klerk who did likewise with Nelson Mandela. Rightwing presidents Nixon and Reagan were the most successful in obtaining arms agreements with the former Soviet Union against expectations.

History is full of such ironies. In the world's most sensitive trouble spot perhaps even an implacable hardliner like Sharon, with a landslide victory behind him, will fare better in the quest for peace than his more liberal predecessor
Richard B I Fitzwilliams
London

I wonder whether the EU countries, including Britain, are going to adopt punitive measure against Israel following the election of Mr Sharon. After all, such measures were taken against Austria when Jörg Haider was elected, and like Mr Sharon he too was demo-cratically selected. In my opinion they deserve the same treatment, unless of course we adopt the usual double standards which have become the trademark of our foreign policy.
Dr Peter Kandela
Staines, Middlesex

Sharon received the votes of about 35% of the Israeli electorate. Is this really a "massive landslide"?
Martin Davidson
London

George Bush, Ariel Sharon. What next? William Hague?
Steve Shaw
Bude, Cornwall

webTitle: Business built on altruism feels Alder Hey effect

fields.headline: Business built on altruism feels Alder Hey effect
fields.standfirst: Darling of the animal rights lobby tripped up by human organs scandal
fields.trailText: Pharmagene's chief scientific officer, Robert Coleman, meticulously unlocks one of the huge refrigerators in the biotechnology company's laboratories in Royston, near Cambridge. "This one needs defreezing," he remarks, swinging open the door to reveal a mass of steamy stalactites. Each drawer in the broom-cupboard sized fridge is bulging with plastic sachets.
fields.body:
Pharmagene's chief scientific officer, Robert Coleman, meticulously unlocks one of the huge refrigerators in the biotechnology company's laboratories in Royston, near Cambridge. "This one needs defreezing," he remarks, swinging open the door to reveal a mass of steamy stalactites. Each drawer in the broom-cupboard sized fridge is bulging with plastic sachets.

Mr Coleman pulls one out and brushes off the ice. It contains a sliver of red material, a few centimetres long. The label reads "liver".

Pharmagene has more than 250,000 bits of human body in its compact laboratory, which would test the stomach of even the most devoted fan of horror films. The company provides a unique service - it tests drugs on human tissue, reducing the need to use animals.

"Our whole business relies on altruism," says chief executive Alistair Riddell. "The goodwill that makes people give blood, or donate their organs."

Pharmagene floated last July with a market value of £142m, raising nearly £40m on hopes that it could persuade drugs companies to use its tests on human body samples as a partial alternative to tests on animals by controversial firms such as Huntingdon Life Sciences. Pfizer, Glaxo SmithKline, Novartis and AstraZeneca are all clients, to a greater or lesser degree.

Over the past month, the firm has been thrust into the public gaze. It unwittingly found itself as a darling of animal rights supporters, as violent activists came close to shutting down Huntingdon. Then its supply of donated tissue was briefly halted last week as the nation wrung its hands about the Alder Hey scandal, in which surgeons removed organs during autopsies without permission.

Understandably, Pharmagene is at pains to point out that it accepts human tissue from patients only following stringent consent procedures. "From the start, this company has been absolutely meticulous about adhering to all sorts of procedures," says Mr Coleman. "We've turned away samples in the past when some level of consent has been lacking."

During the Alder Hey controversy, nurses at some of the 16 hospitals which provide tissue to Pharmagene were reluctant to approach to explain consent forms to patients, effectively cutting off the supply. The problem was short-lived, but it was worrying - Dr Riddell says that securing a plentiful supply of fresh body parts is the company's biggest challenge.

About 70% of Pharmagene's samples are removed from living patients, during routine operations. For example, surgeons remove a few centimetres of healthy colon at each end of any diseased section when operating on sufferers of bowel cancer. If the patient is agreeable, this may find its way to Pharmagene to help test how effectively new medicines are absorbed in the intestine.

The other 30% of tissue samples are removed after death, from patients who have pledged their bodies for scientific research. These samples are often more valuable, and need to be acted upon urgently. Pharmagene has a sophisticated network of links with medical centres, allowing it to receive donations within a few hours of a patient's death.

"We get a phone call and we immediately arrange a courier to go and collect the material," says Mr Coleman. "We have to be ready when the tissue is ready."

Peterborough Hospital keeps a national register of people who have pledged their bodies for research. Mr Coleman and Dr Riddell are on the list, as is much of Pharmagene's workforce.

So can Pharmagene's research replace the drugs tests on rats, mice and dogs which so many people find objectionable? Since the Thalidomide tragedy, government regulations require new medicines to be tested on animals, so at present Pharmagene's work is an additional, rather than alternative, stage. Mr Coleman says: "Despite the similarities we have with animals, there are a huge number of differences. That's the reason so many drugs fail in clinical trials."

He believes human tissue research should take place before animal testing, though the latter cannot be stopped completely: "There is a continuing need for some animal testing but the challenge is to limit it to the minimum necessary."

Perhaps Pharmagene's more immediately promising sideline is in testing where genes are expressed in the body, using the same tissue samples. The human genome project has thrown up thousands of different "target" genes, involved in disease mechanisms. Pharmagene can help drugs firms produce accurate drugs by pinpointing where these targets are active.

More than 3,700 people have donated tissue to Pharmagene since the company was founded five years ago. Can the firm rely on a steady supply if, as expected, its business expands? Dr Riddell says: "The only reason there could be a negative impact on us from Alder Hey is through guilt by association - because we are, in some sense, in the same sector."

He is hopeful that the scandal will not affect long-term donations for research: "I think not - there seems to be an undercurrent of enthusiasm for donating. But how do we really know what goes through the collective brain?"

Making the break

Pharmagene was founded in 1995 by Gordon Smith Baxter, a former SmithKline Beecham executive, and Robert Coleman, a pharmacologist from Glaxo Wellcome.

Frustrated at working in big organisations, they wanted to try their idea of "facilitating the experimental use of human tissue" in a start-up company.

Revenues have risen from £430,000 in 1997 to £1.26m last year, although the company warned at the end of last year that mergers such as that between Glaxo and SmithKline had caused some customers to defer payments.

Pharmagene lost £4.21m last year but, after raising £40m in a flotation, has plenty of cash to absorb its spending of £350,000 a month.

In addition to testing drugs for clients, the firm develops its own products.

fields.headline: Anne Burns
fields.standfirst: A test pilot and scientist, she worked on jets and in her spare time set records as a glider pilot
fields.trailText: Anne Burns, who has died aged 85, was a test pilot, research scientist and gliding champion. She worked at the Royal Aeronautical Establishment (RAE) from 1940 to 1976 and, as principal scientific officer, received the Queen's Com mendation for Services in the Air (in 1955 and 1963).
fields.body:
Anne Burns, who has died aged 85, was a test pilot, research scientist and gliding champion. She worked at the Royal Aeronautical Establishment (RAE) from 1940 to 1976 and, as principal scientific officer, received the Queen's Com mendation for Services in the Air (in 1955 and 1963).

Much of her work was on BOAC's Comet 1 in the mid-50s and on low- and high-level turbulence. She held eight world and 20 national women's gliding records, and was the first woman to be British glider champion (in 1966).

Born in Haworth, Yorkshire, into a family descended from Sir Edward Pellew - a naval hero in the Napoleonic War - she was a tomboy, who, curiously, witnessed a plane crash at the age of five. As a teenager at the Abbey School, Reading, she gave her class the slip during a trip to Woodley aerodrome and persuaded a pilot to take her up in a Gipsy Moth.

At St Hugh's College, Oxford, she was only the second woman to read engineering science. She gained a first, a blue for hockey, a half blue for squash and had her sports car impounded by the proctor. A special decree had to be passed in the college congregation for her to enter the men-only Edgell Shepee scholarship for engineering science, which she won.

On the outbreak of war she was sent to the RAE, where she learned to fly in a Tiger Moth and did flight testing for the air services, including the troop gliders used on D-Day and at Arnhem. After the war she began her work in civil aviation, specialising in crash investigation.

In 1947, she met Denis Owen Burns, another scientist at the RAE, who gave her out lbw at a cricket match, but married her to make up for it. They spent their holidays skiing and climbing before they took up gliding in 1954.

At this time, she became involved in the Comet investigation, after two had broken up at altitude in 1954. The flight testing involved a team flying an unpressurised Comet up to 40,000ft to see what broke first, knowing they did not have enough parachutes to go round.

Burns was the first woman on the team, a fact that received some media coverage, though she considered the risks part of her job, and that she was first and foremost a scientist.

She carried on this research investigating the links between metal fatigue and clear-air turbulence at high and low levels, which required many hours in a Canberra bomber under extreme conditions.

In her gliding career Burns set a national distance record on her first solo cross country flight. In 1957, she was the first woman glider pilot to cross the Channel. Four years later, during a week's stay in South Africa, she and Denis broke five world records and 12 national ones. On one flight, she was struck by lightning and knocked out at the controls, but recovered to take advantage of the conditions to set an altitude-gain record despite a hole in her wing.

More cups and records followed, but she ended her career in August 1977, when a birdstrike forced her into a nose dive. The cockpit canopy was jammed, causing a difficult exit at 2,000ft, and, as a result, her foot was caught in her parachute shrouds. She righted herself only to land in a fruit tree, much to the annoyance of a local farmer.

She retired from the RAE in 1976 and, with Denis, took up fly fishing and snooker with the same single-mindedness as she had displayed in all other aspects of her life. When he died in 1990, she turned to gardening and bowls.

There were no children.

fields.trailText: Venture capital firms took a big hit in 2000 thanks to the dot.com collapse and valuation slump. This year, they are determined to learn from their mistakes, reports Christopher Price
fields.body:
Who would be a venture capitalist (VC) in 2001? Having got it so wrong in 2000, when the funding frenzy in the dot.com market even saw a portal launched for sheep farmers, early-stage investors must now try and regain some credibility and get their investments back on track.

But where, exactly, will their cash go in 2001? It is an eight billion-dollar question - the amount earmarked for VC investment in the technology market this year.

Siren voices are only too willing to offer advice. Wap? A mere stepping stone to third generation (3G) mobile services. And 3G? An expensive experiment that will cost operators, and investors, dear. Business-to-business (B2B) internet services? Well, look what happened to business-to-consumer (B2C). And so on.

One thing is certain: early-stage investors appear determined not to repeat the mistakes of the previous 12 months.

"People had too narrow a focus on one segment of the market," says Nick Wood, a director with New York-based technology fund, MetVP. "It's important that investors have a variety of technology investments. Not to do so invites unnecessary dangers."

Dan Conaghan, a director with NewMedia Spark (NMS), a UK-based VC group, agrees: "We will not be making any B2C investments this year. We need to rebalance our portfolio."

NMS has 55 investments and a £100m fund. It expects to make 15 new investments in 2001, 10 less than last year. However, the funding strategies the group and the industry adopt this year, says Conaghan, will mark a return to more conservative values.

"In 1999 and early 2000, there was a belief among start-ups and investors that the time from the start to a public flotation was a year to 18 months. Now it has gone back to four to seven years. It's very healthy for everybody - entrepreneurs stay to build the business and investors are long-term supporters."

The driving force behind VC investments this year will be those ventures employing core technologies. Having flirted disastrously last year on the peripheries of technology with B2C service businesses, the key words dominating VC vocabulary now are "proprietary", "defensible" and "patentable".

In other words, those start-ups that have built a business around a technology that will give them a head start over the opposition will be well placed for funding.

However, identifying the technologies that will be core to the future of a particular industry or service is the challenge, and it is here that the winners and losers will be decided.

For John Taysom, founder and co-chief executive of Reuters Greenhouse Fund (RGF), one of the largest UK corporate technology investment funds, the answer is to fathom the problem and then to find the venture that is addressing it. It is, he says, a uniquely European attitude.

"Silicon Valley is a trout waiting for the food to swim by; in Europe, you have to be a pike and go out and look for what you want. Here, genius flunks geography."

This view, that the region's future technology jewels are disparate and need seeking out, is one supported among Europe's burgeoning VC industry. It makes the task of identification all the harder, and points to an acceleration in regional partnerships, alliances and acquisitions.

"Europe-wide know-how is a must," says NMS's Conaghan, whose group has offices in four European cities.

However, NMS is taking its geographical reach and digging deeper into the region's technology psyche. "After the events of last year, we decided to take a step back and look at a five-year view of the technology space. We've been to universities across Europe talking to research departments. We're not expecting to see the next core technology, but we're gaining an insight into where research is taking us."

Mobile internet, broadband telecommunications and networking applications are the three areas on most VCs' agendas. To this, NMS would add data services, fibre optic technologies and applications for smart and SIM cards.

RGF prefers to invest in ventures that have a resonance with its parent company. Thus it usually considers start-ups that operate in the financial data, information retrieval and database services markets.

Areas it is currently studying for investment include patents and their potential for usage in a mergers and acquisition (M&A) market increas ingly driven by the capture of ideas. "We see great value in a database of patents and how that might be used in valuing M&A," says Taysom.

Other pertinent subjects include digital watermarking, "things networks do badly", connectivity between the virtual and physical worlds and a variety of XML (Extensible Markup Language) and other developments relating to the corporate arena.

MetVP, which has a $10m fund aimed at Europe, is targeting the environmental science, enterprise software and nanotechnology markets this year.

The absence of anything to do with the consumer market is marked. However, within these target markets, all three VC firms underline the importance of core competencies, strong management, identifiable applications and long-term sustainability.

Wise words, easily spoken after the puncturing of the dot.com bubble in 2000. It remains to be seen if the dose of reality will sustain such conviction as the technology market recovers.

webTitle: Indonesia may force Wahid out in weeks

fields.headline: Indonesia may force Wahid out in weeks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia
fields.trailText: President Abdurrahman Wahid's tenuous grip on power in Indonesia weakened further yesterday when opposition MPs warned that the could reduce the process of impeaching him from months to a few weeks.
fields.body:
President Abdurrahman Wahid's tenuous grip on power in Indonesia weakened further yesterday when opposition MPs warned that the could reduce the process of impeaching him from months to a few weeks.

Fissures in the cabinet also widened with the departure of the justice minister, Yusril Ihza Mahendra.

Mr Mahendra said he had been sacked for suggesting that the president should step aside while he is investigated for alleged corruption. Mr Wahid said he left voluntarily after being told his colleagues wanted him to go.

He is the second minister to leave the government in the past six weeks because of differences over Mr Wahid's often erratic style of government.

Meanwhile tens of thousands of Mr Wahid's fanatical followers rampaged through east and central Java, the centre of his support, burning the offices of the main opposition parties in protest at the attempts to impeach their hero.

Thousands opposed to Mr Wahid took to the city streets throughout the country, including the capital Jakarta, where 3,000 students marched peacefully to the presidential palace.

Alvin Lie, an opposition MP who played a key role in the investigation which led to parliament beginning the impeachment procedure last Thursday by censuring the president, said he and his colleagues were "very disappointed" by Mr Wahid's "very negative" response.

The constitution gives Mr Wahid three months to respond to the censure before parliament can issue a second and final warning.

But Mr Lie said: "The three months is just a grace period, a probation period. If at any time the president shows a negative response or makes mistakes, we can issue the second warning immediately.

"It looks like we are going to do that next week, unless the president radically changes his attitude."

Ade Komaruddin, an MP for Golkar, the former government party, said MPs were still debating their next move. "The majority of legislators want him to do the decent thing and resign immediately," he said.

It is a sign of his increasing desperation that Mr Wahid tried to impose martial law last week, but his cabinet and generals refused to back him.

"It's clear that he's losing control," the political analyst Andi Mallarangeng said.

Mr Mahendra's departure came as little surprise after his statement that he could not stay silent about the scandals. "I am the justice minister and these were questions of law," he said.

Mr Wahid was censured for his alleged involvement in two multimillion-pound financial scandals.

It is not suggested that he benefited personally, but the suggestion that he used the money for political purposes has helped the opposition to attack him for his ineffective and controversial style of governing.

Mr Mallarangeng said other ministers, particularly from Golkar, might resign soon.

The vice-president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, still backs Mr Wahid, but it is unclear how solid her party's support is.

Security forces in Surabaya, the country's second city and capital of East Java, fired teargas and warning shots but were unable to hold back 30,000 demonstrators determined to destroy the Golkar provincial office yesterday.

Many of the rioters were members of the paramilitary wing of Nahdlatul Ulama, the 30m-strong Islamic movement which Mr Wahid chaired before becoming president in October 1999.

fields.headline: Globalisation: friend and foe
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: In the rich countries today pet-owners spend £11.3bn a year on pet food while one in seven of the world's population goes to bed hungry.
fields.body:
In the rich countries today pet-owners spend £11.3bn a year on pet food while one in seven of the world's population goes to bed hungry.

The growing abyss between rich and poor has become almost unimaginable: the world's three richest men have combined assets equal to the output of the world's 48 poorest countries and their 600m people.

Yet as we look back on the past 50 years we can see that globalisation has also brought many benefits.

Per capita food production and consumption have increased by 20%, and malnutrition rates are down by almost a third since War on Want was founded in 1951.

Since the 1960s the number of babies dying before their first birthday has halved, and people in developing countries now live on average until they are 64 rather than 46 years old. But the benefits of globalisation are not distributed equally, either within or between countries.

As Nelson Mandela said at the last Labour party conference: "The danger is that globalisation can come to mean only the free flow of goods and finance, the open access to markets, the breaking down of barriers to trade and commerce. The concern for the common good, which characterised ... international solidarity ... is in danger of being lost in the current understanding of a global world."

Many of us are angry about the inequities and suffering that threaten to tarnish the new millennium but, paradoxically, globalisation has also given us the tools to do something about it.

At War on Want, our computers send daily emails full of details of strikes, protests and campaigns from Brazil to Bangkok.

Email also helps us to coordinate our responses with like-minded organisations.

The short-term successor to Jubilee 2000, Drop the Debt, is now housed in War on Want's building and is trying to win a new deal on third world debt by the G8 summit in Genoa in July.

While governments in Africa still spend nearly three times more money servicing their debt than they do on health services, this struggle has to go on.

"Turning swords into ploughshares" is as crucial today as it was when War on Want was founded 50 years ago, especially as the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, announced last week that Britain will continue to export arms to the Moroccan army to maintain its illegal occupation of the Western Sahara.

While the Department for International Development was funding, with War on Want, the building of food warehouses for 150,000 malnourished Sahrawi refugees in neighbouring Algeria, the Foreign Office gave the go-ahead for Royal Ordnance to supply new parts for 105mm guns to Morocco.

War on Want is now seeking legal advice about requesting a judicial review of the Foreign Office decision, which we believe contravened the EU code of conduct on arms exports.

Our organisation was founded to combat this type of destructive violence and to wage the real war, the war against global poverty.

As a tiny charity based in London, it sometimes seems that War on Want's work can only ever be a drop in the ocean. But globalisation has made international solidarity more powerful than ever.

Our supporters in the UK's trade unions and the labour movement know that there is even greater need for people to work more closely with one another to confront the inequities of globalisation, and they keep alive in action our tradition of solidarity.

Catherine Matheson is the executive director of War on Want Fenner Brockway House

37-39 Greater Guildford St

London

SE1 OES

Telephone 020 7620 1111

www.waronwant.org

fields.headline: The bitter taste of oranges
fields.standfirst:
Haiti campaign Help for union wins rises for Cointreau and Grand Marnier fruit-pickers
http://www.guardian.co.uk/globalisation/
fields.trailText: When you next pour a digestif of Cointreau, savour the taste of bitter oranges. The fruit is hand-picked by Haitian labourers involved in a protracted industrial dispute linking poorly paid workers in the developing world directly to consumers in Europe.
fields.body:
When you next pour a digestif of Cointreau, savour the taste of bitter oranges. The fruit is hand-picked by Haitian labourers involved in a protracted industrial dispute linking poorly paid workers in the developing world directly to consumers in Europe.

For decades citrus groves near Cap-Haitien, in the north of the Caribbean country, have provided orange peel for the Cointreau distillery in Angers, France, and for another French liqueur manufacturer, Grand Marnier. The trade is a reminder that, until the only successful slave revolt in history swept Napoleon's troops off the malaria-infested island of Hispaniola, Haiti was a French colony.

Fruit pickers, descended from slaves imported to cut sugar cane, have always received low wages. For the past two years, however, War on Want has been running an international campaign to raise pay in thispoorest country in the Americas.

"At the Cointreau plant in the north of Haiti, men and women labour all day to make the minimum wage of 36 gourdes - a little over £1," War on Want maintains.

"The factory is in a squalid condition - toilets and showers are disgusting. Working without gloves or protective clothing, the workers are soaked in the orange spray and inhale the citric acid vapour - fingernails are corroded away, and lung complications are common."

War on Want is backing the Cointreau workers, who have formed a union. Like many overseas aid charities, it operates through a local partner. Last year War on Want spent £15,000 supporting Batay Ouvriye, a trade union organisation founded in 1994, whose Creole title means "Worker's Battle".

The charity has also coordinated a letter-writing campaign, supported by the London-based Haiti Support Group, aimed at the French headquarters of Cointreau, though the action stops short of calling for a boycott.

The unions and War on Want have already won a significant victory: in July, after a lengthy campaign, Grand Marnier agreed to raise the wages of 300 plantation workers by more than half. Day labourers now receive 95 gourdes (£2.70) a day.

Yannick Etienne, a director of Batay Ouvriye, welcomed the deal. "These people had been working for many years with very poor salaries. They had no protective equipment and had to buy their own knives."

The chief executive of Grand Marnier, Claude de Jouvencel, confirmed that pay had been raised and separate showers and toilets installed for men and women."We will review the salaries in June again this year," he said. "When you have people comparing wages here in France with what is paid there, you have to put it in the context of the labour environment of the country."

Cointreau's elaborate label - "Speciality of France since 1849" - does not mention the source of its ingredients. But the company, which claims that plantation workers on piece rates already earn more than £4 for an eight-hour day, has failed to reach a settlement with its workers.

"Cointreau does not own land [or] production facilities in Haiti," a company statement said. "Both are managed by Guacimal, in which Cointreau has a minority, although significant, shareholding."

An improved offer - "far above the minimum legal wage" - would raise piece rates so that workers earn £6 a day, Cointreau claims.

"Showers and sanitary installations, cleaned regularly and in good condition, are at employees' disposal.

"Guacimal provides additional protection, such as meshed reinforced gloves, boots and waders to its employees. The employees work in an open air building which is very well ventilated."

The consequences of fair trade campaigns are difficult to forecast in a world of highly mobile capital. Foreign investors can be scared off by bad publicity, close down a local operation and throw employees out of work.

"There is the danger that a company will leave but that is happening less and less," says Steve Tibbett, a campaigner with War on Want.

"Companies are finding they have nowhere to hide. Campaigns reach further and further afield; wherever firms set up, trade unions follow. International firms simply have to pay decent wages."

Later this year the charity is sending out two officials from the GMB union to provide more advice and expertise.

Despite the UN mission withdrawing from Haiti after the disputed parliamentary elections last year, War on Want insists it is committed to the country, though it does not keep staff there permanently.

Batay Ouvriye fears that trade unions will increasingly be picked on by supporters of the ruling party, Fanmi Lavalas.

Last June a Haitian trade union organiser was shot dead; Batay Ouvriye blamed Lavalas members once linked to the Tontons Macoutes militias run by the former Duvalier dictatorship.

"It is a very bad situation," Mr Etienne says. "Some companies have withdrawn because of the political instability. A lot of the people are leaving the country by boat. People are pretty desperate."

Haiti facts

 Population 8.1m

 Life expectancy 53 years

 Illiteracy 56%

 Infant mortality 68 per 1,000 births

 GDP per capita £273

Despite the UN mission withdrawing from Haiti after the disputed parliamentary elections last year, War on Want insists it is committed to the country, though it does not keep staff there permanently. Batay Ouvriye fears that trade unions will increasingly be picked on by supporters of the ruling party, Fanmi Lavalas. Last June a Haitian trade union organiser was shot dead; Batay Ouvriye blamed Lavalas members once linked to the Tontons Macoutes militias run by the former Duvalier dictatorship. "It is a very bad situation," Mr Etienne says. "Some companies have withdrawn because of the political instability. A lot of the people are leaving the country by boat. People are pretty desperate." fields.headline: Sir Humphrey gets wired
fields.standfirst:
Britain's new e-envoy is keen to prove the government is moving online, reports Neil McIntosh
More net news
fields.trailText: Britain's new e-envoy is keen to prove the government is moving online, reports Neil McIntosh
fields.body:
Britain's new e-envoy is brushing aside scathing criticism of the government's e-commerce plans and promises Whitehall is on track to meet its 2005 target.

In an exclusive interview with Guardian Online this week, Andrew Pinder insisted all government services would be online within the next four years, meeting a deadline set by the prime minister, Tony Blair, last year.

His assurances come despite a report from internet analyst Forrester Research, published on Friday, which cast doubt on Whitehall's ability to deliver the ambitious promises of e-government.

Pinder has been working in a caretaker role for the past three months, after the resignation of the first e-envoy, Alex Allan.

He says permanent appointment to the role will allow him to focus on longer-term planning.

"Some of the time I've been very conscious that someone else could be coming in to take over," he said. "I've not been wanting to steal the limelight or take decisions which they should be taking."

There had been suggestions that Pinder was reluctant to take on the role permanently; his name had not cropped up on many observers' shortlists because of his insistence that he would only take the job for the interim period.

Now he is finally able to look more than a few months ahead there are plenty of hard decisions which need to be taken, according to Forrester Research.

In its paper, eGovernment fails the grade, it states bluntly that "the UK government's aggressive e-commerce plans won't come to fruition." It says only the intervention of the private sector will allow the government to reach its goal of 100% electronic delivery of government services to businesses and consumers.

Worse, it grades the efforts of a sample of departments from A to E, awarding an average of D. Departments hit with an E grade include the Department of Social Security, Office of National Statistics and Customs and Excise.

Even the online efforts of the Office of the E-envoy got a lowly D rating, beaten by the the likes of the Inland Revenue (IR) and Department for Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS), which both scored the top mark awarded - a C.

"Plans for delivering services are wrong-headed," writes Forrester analyst Caroline Sceats.

"Only the IR and DCMS show any understanding of the pressures the government will face as a portal in the competitive internet environment. The result: opportunities for building on strengths go to waste."

The Forrester report's comments have been dismissed in some quarters as being under-researched, naive and focused on the comments of a handful of IT suppliers who would stand to benefit most from the failure of the e-government initiative and subsequent out-sourcing of work.

Pinder, although clearly unhappy about Forrester's conclusions, prefers to be more diplomatic. He points to what he claims is the progress the drive is having, and the results already achieved.

He is quick to reject the suggestion that the "Sir Humphreys" of Whitehall are intent on stalling the e-government initiative.

"I think that is rubbish," he says. "The civil service is not resistant to change. There are issues with the civil service, as with any large organisation.

"One is that this is a large supertanker which takes a long time to turn, and it takes a while for people to take on board this new method of communicating. This is just as hard for people here as it is for those in the private sector.

"Take banks, for example; I don't think banks are doing any better in e-commerce than the UK public sector.

"The second issue is that the public sector is enormously diverse, with lots of sections, and trying to get people to be creative about what they do online is a big challenge - probably a bigger challenge than anyone in the private sector is having to face."

Despite these problems, and the criticism, Pinder is confident that government will meet its 2005 deadline.

"We've had the first round of e-strategies, published on departments' websites," he says. "Those strategies show that most departments are well on track to hitting the 2005 target. If people took the trouble to read that they would see it.

"The big issue for me is that we don't just want them to hit the 2005 target; we want them to do it in some style. We want them to deliver these services, not just by putting these things online, but we want them to really target these services and be much more creative, using this new medium in a different sort of way."

And, despite Forrester's misgivings, that kind of talk appears to be what industry wants to hear. There, reaction to Pinder's appointment has been positive.

Jim Norton, head of e-business at the Institute of Directors, says he is "delighted" by Pinder's appointment. "I wanted someone who had both public and private sector experience and Andrew's got both of those.

"To my mind he has acquitted himself well in a difficult time - it's not an easy period when you're acting as interim. I wish him good luck in what is a very challenging job."

Meanwhile, Tim Conway, director of industry affairs at the Computing Services and Software Association, was also happy with Pinder's appointment.

"We particularly welcome the fact that he's been in the job three months now," Conway says. "He understands what the job is about and can get on with the very important tasks which his job entails.

"His profile - having worked in the civil service and some large organisations outside the civil service - means he is well suited to taking on the change management role."

webTitle: Deal on dome sale goes to the wire

fields.headline: Deal on dome sale goes to the wire
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Legacy, the controversial consortium hoping to buy the Millennium Dome, is locked in discussions with a series of major property developers less than a week before it is due to complete the £125m deal.
fields.body:
Legacy, the controversial consortium hoping to buy the Millennium Dome, is locked in discussions with a series of major property developers less than a week before it is due to complete the £125m deal.

Robert Bourne and his Irish backers are seeking one or more new partners to bolster their bid ahead of next Wednesday's deadline.

Labour donor Mr Bourne and executives of Dublin-based Treasury Holdings have held discussions with Grosvenor Estates, owned by the Duke of Westminster, Stanhope Properties, and Quintain, a firm that already owns land on the Greenwich peninsula.

The talks follow government pressure on Legacy to widen its share base to improve its prospects and undermine criticism that the dome could be sold to a consortium owned 80% by an Irish company and 15% by Mr Bourne, who during recent years donated £100,000 to Labour. Bank of Scotland owns the other 5%.

The influence of Treasury Holdings within Legacy will inevitably be reduced if another organisation takes a stake. Construction giant Sir Robert McAlpine has also signalled it is now prepared to take a 5% stake.

Next week is make-or-break time for the deal after deputy prime minister John Prescott and dome minister Lord Falconer made clear they would pull the plug on negotiations if these were not close to completion.

The new consortium could include land adjacent to the dome, currently owned by Quintain. Legacy's plan is to create a hi-tech park inside the dome but while it insists it has pledges of support from major companies to rent space, most have been slow to admit their backing publicly.

Another potential bidder emerged yesterday, if the Legacy deal collapses, with Galliard Homes announcing it had formed a consortium to build high-rise flats on the site.

fields.headline: Sarah suspect abused by crowd
fields.standfirst: Two arrested in angry mob scenes outside court as man accused of murdering eight-year-old is remanded in custody
fields.trailText: Two arrested in angry mob scenes outside court as man accused of murdering eight-year-old is remanded in custody.
fields.body:
A crowd screamed abuse as the man accused of the kidnap and murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne was driven away from court after appearing before magistrates yesterday.

Roy Whiting, 42, of Littlehampton, West Sussex, confirmed his name and age before Chichester magistrates, and was remanded in custody.

The magistrates refused an application for bail and said that Whiting would appear for a preliminary hearing at Lewes crown court on February 19.

As Whiting was driven from the rear of the court building, a crowd of more than 200 people hurled abuse. Men and women, some with pushchairs, as well as children of school age shouted "scum" and "die" while others threw eggs at the car taking Whiting back to jail.

The car, followed by two police vehicles, stopped 100 yards away at a level crossing and the crowd gave chase, but it sped away before they could reach it. Police blocked the road with a van to stop motorists chasing, while up to 50 officers on foot spread out to block the crowd.

One man was arrested on suspicion of causing criminal damage after he allegedly threw a drinks carton at the vehicle carrying Whiting.

Another member of the public was arrested for a suspected public order offence. Both were released on bail pending further inquiries.

None of the crowd had been allowed into court as the 20 seats reserved for press and public were filled by reporters. Sarah, from Hersham, Surrey, disappeared from a lane near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, near Littlehampton, on July 1 last year.

Her body was found 16 days later in a shallow grave just off the A29 near Pulborough, about 12 miles from where she was last seen. The scene became a shrine as more than 5,000 people laid flowers and gifts along the roadside.

The latest evidence emerged last month when Sussex police released a photograph of a clown-patterned curtain, which prompted more than 300 members of the public to respond with information.

On July 23, the News of the World launched its campaign "For Sarah", in which it named convicted sex offenders.

The paper claimed its decision to name and shame paedophiles reflected public outrage over the murder. However, it relented after two weeks in the wake of condemnation from the police, the probation service and the Home Office.

The u-turn followed a number of vigilante attacks on alleged offenders and on innocent men mistakenly identified as paedophiles.

Sarah's parents were not in court yesterday.

fields.headline: Megrahi lodges Lockerbie appeal
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The Libyan intelligence officer who was jailed for life for the Lockerbie bombing yesterday lodged an appeal against the conviction.
fields.body:
The Libyan intelligence officer who was jailed for life for the Lockerbie bombing yesterday lodged an appeal against the conviction.

Lawyers for Abdel Baset al-Megrahi, 49, filed the appeal at the high court in Edinburgh. If leave to appeal is granted, five judges will decide within six months whether Megrahi's conviction should stand.

Robert Black QC, the Edinburgh law professor who was the architect of the trial, said it was unlikely that Megrahi would be denied the right to an appeal.

Last week Megrahi was sentenced to life, with a recommendation that he serve a minimum of 20 years, for the murder of the 270 who died in the Lockerbie bombing. In their ruling the judges said there was proof beyond reasonable doubt that Megrahi had planted the bomb in a suitcase on a plane leaving Luqa airport in Malta. The suitcase was loaded on to Pan Am flight 103 in London.

But the judges conceded the evidence before the court was open to interpretation.

Grounds for the appeal will not be made public until the full hearing, which will be held in Camp Zeist in the Netherlands in May at the earliest.

But it is unlikely that there will be any fresh evidence and Prof Black said the appeal would likely be made on any of three legal grounds.

Ground A would be that certain findings, including the acceptance that Megrahi bought the clothes which surrounded the bomb, were not justified by the evidence. Ground B would be that the evidence does not justify the findings in fact that there was a piece of baggage which was sent unaccompanied from Malta to Heathrow. The third ground would be that the evidence as a whole does not justify proof beyond reasonable doubt of guilt.'

Since the return to Libya of Megrahi's co-accused, Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, who was acquitted, there have been protests against Megrahi's conviction.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Air crash deaths charges
fields.body:
Air crash deaths charges

An engineer has been charged with manslaughter in connection with the deaths of a pilot and two passengers in a helicopter crash near Twyford, Berkshire, in March last year. Paul Kenward, 46, of Biggin Hill, Kent, has also been charged with breaching navigation orders. He will appear before Slough magistrates on Monday.

Sex offender absconds

Police are searching for sex offender William Anthony Knowles, 39, also known as Patrick Duran, who has ab sconded from a prison pre-release hostel in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, and is described as potentially dangerous to children.

Toy salesmen trigger alert

A commuter sparked a security alert yesterday after reporting to police what he believed to be two men wielding guns on a train. Armed officers intercepted the train near Hoylake, Merseyside, but found the "gunmen" were toy salesmen with children's plastic guns.

Jerry Hall gems theft denied

An antiques dealer denied stealing jewellery and a computer from the home of actress and model Jerry Hall when he appeared in court yesterday. David Bryce, 32, of Wandsworth, south London, was remanded in custody until March 1 by Richmond magistrates.

Briton dies in cliff fall

A British holidaymaker died after falling from a cliff in the Canary Islands, it was confirmed yesterday. Tony Butland, 27, from near Leeds, West Yorkshire, was walking along the clifftops near Tenerife at the weekend when he is believed to have slipped. Spanish police are investigating.

More women in work

More women are working in the UK than ever before, according to figures released by the office for national statistics today. A record 12.5m women have jobs, 843,000 more than a decade ago. But fewer than half of lone mothers have a job.

Crimestoppers for children

Scotland Yard yesterday said it was considering launching a Crimestoppers helpline for children to help cut juvenile crime. Children could claim up to £500 for information leading to a conviction.

Stags locked in battle

A passerby dialled 999 after spotting two stags whose antlers had become locked together during a fight at Covehithe, Suffolk. Firefighters from Southwold found the two deer had become tangled up with string and cut them free.

One winner of £4m jackpot

One ticket holder won the £4m jackpot in last night's national lottery draw with numbers 2, 5, 33, 37, 40, and 45. The bonus number was 22. Lottery extra numbers were 1, 3, 35, 38, 41 and 45.

webTitle: Troops not told of shells' toxic risk

fields.headline: Troops not told of shells' toxic risk
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: The government last night admitted that thousands of British troops serving in Kosovo were placed at risk from the deadly effects of depleted uranium, the substance linked to Gulf war syndrome, after a health warning failed to reach soldiers during the 1999 Nato conflict.
fields.body:
The government last night admitted that thousands of British troops serving in Kosovo were placed at risk from the deadly effects of depleted uranium, the substance linked to Gulf war syndrome, after a health warning failed to reach soldiers during the 1999 Nato conflict.

The Ministry of Defence admitted that it failed to brief troops on the special health notice which warned that depleted uranium (DU) created a "heavy toxic powder".

John Spellar, the armed forces minister, said a lengthy "mounting order" was sent to troops serving with Nato in Kosovo in 1999 which gave detailed instructions on how to avoid contact with the substance, which can lead to cancer. But he admitted the message did not reach all troops.

In a written parliamentary reply, he said: "My department is now aware that not all [troops] have actually been briefed."

Mr Spellar told MPs in a parliamentary answer last November that troops did receive health advice. In his reply last night he admitted he had created a misleading impression.

Mr Spellar admitted the MoD withdrew a pre-deployment course last summer which was set up to brief troops on the danger of DU. The course was reinstated last month, days after Mr Spellar performed a u-turn and agreed to offer medical screening for troops who served in the Balkans.

The breakdown in commu nication will embarrass ministers who were forced to admit last year that health notices about DU failed to reach troops serving in Saudi Arabia during the 1991 Gulf war. A message, advising soldiers how to avoid breathing in DU dust, never reached its destination.

Mr Spellar said the medical screening programme was designed to provide reassurance because the government did not accept any link between DU ammunition and illnesses suffered by troops.

fields.headline: Digital radios 'priced too high'
fields.trailText: The government yesterday warned that hi-fi manufacturers must make digital radio sets cheaper if they want listeners to upgrade from traditional analogue equipment.
fields.body:
The government yesterday warned that hi-fi manufacturers must make digital radio sets cheaper if they want listeners to upgrade from traditional analogue equipment.

Janet Anderson, broadcasting minister, said that prices must fall. "Thirty-five million people in the UK can reach it, but few can yet afford it," she said of the digital radio technology.

Speaking at the Commercial Radio Companies Association, Ms Anderson added: "I want to reiterate this government's support for the ground-breaking work of the digital radio broadcasting industry in the UK.

"But we also want to ensure that more people can enjoy its great quality and growing diversity."

The cost of digital hi-fi radios ranges from £500 to £2,300, while in-car radios cost from £250 to £6,500, the minister said.

webTitle: Disputed Bacon art works go on display

fields.headline: Disputed Bacon art works go on display
fields.standfirst: Huge exhibition of previously unknown paintings and photographs opens but doubt surrounds their authenticity
fields.trailText: A huge exhibition of works attributed to the late Francis Bacon opens today at the Barbican Gallery in London despite fears of a last minute injunction from the artist's estate.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A huge exhibition of works attributed to the late Francis Bacon opens today at the Barbican Gallery in London despite fears of a last minute injunction from the artist's estate.

Before yesterday's preview, representatives of the estate, which jealously defends the copyright and reputation of the artist, visited the exhibition of works whose ownership and authenticity have been bitterly contested .

The estate's lawyers, Payne Hicks Beach, said last night they had no comment to make.

The archive has been the subject of a simmering row since Mr Bacon, regarded as one of the major painters of the 20th century, died in 1992.

Both the Institute of Contemporary Arts and the then Tate Gallery considered exhibiting the archive, but backed off in the face of the unresolved dispute.

Although the Barbican exhibition is peppered with the word "attributed", Tate Modern has given it some credibility by lending Bacon sketches, dating from the 1950s and 1960s, which it bought two years ago.

A spokeswoman for Tate Modern said: "We have lent six works on paper, totally authentic and not in any way disputed, which allow an interesting comparison to be made. Beyond that we cannot comment on the exhibition."

John Hoole, director of the Barbican Gallery, said he has "no doubt that the vast major ity of the works must be by Bacon".

When Mr Bacon died of a heart attack, aged 82, the sole heir of his estimated £11m estate was John Edwards, an East End barman who was his companion for many years. The inheritance included the contents of his chaotic studio, which has now been reconstructed in a gallery in Dublin, the artist's birthplace.

But boxes of papers were allegedly given, just four days before his death, to Barry Joule, a Canadian who was his neighbour in London and later a friend. Mr Joule said yesterday that when Mr Bacon gave him the papers, he said: "You know what to do with it", and that this was familiar code for a gift.

Part of the Bacon mythology is that his genius poured straight on to the canvas, without any preparatory work.

The hundreds of sheets of paper in the archive include hoarded photographs, clippings, pages torn from magazines and books, the medical text book illustrations which fascinated him and scribbled sketches.

The photographs include images which recur in his finished work, including the screaming nurse from the Eisenstein film Battleship Potemkin.

Album X is an old photograph album given him by his nanny, from which the photos were torn and replaced with heavily worked collages and overdrawn photographs.

The authenticity of the archive has been questioned by David Sylvester, a leading expert on Bacon. He concedes that the sheets of paper must have come from Bacon's studio, but doubts that the overpainting and sketches are in the artist's hand.

Mr Joule has been accused by other sources of betraying his friend's intentions. It has been suggested both that he tampered with the papers and that if he was indeed given them by Bacon, the intention was that they should be destroyed.

Mr Joule said that he has frequently felt crushed by the bitterness of the row.

"I think that there's an element of jealousy. I'm not an artist or a scholar - I'm a carpenter, so why the hell should I have this stuff?" he said.

"Then there's the gay thing. They claim him as their own and I happen to be a straight man.

"But there's no doubt in my mind, he gave them to me to keep, and I kept them. If he'd come back and asked for them back, I'd have given them back. But he didn't come back. He died and I had to decide what to do with them."

He added: "I have highs and lows. Exhibitions are a high, so this is a good day."

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: Winning ways of Gordon the plunderer

fields.headline: Winning ways of Gordon the plunderer
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown arrived on the front bench in the Commons, laughing and joking with Tony Blair. Laughing and joking? With Tony Blair? Things must be desperate. The prime minister was about to shaft him.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown arrived on the front bench in the Commons, laughing and joking with Tony Blair. Laughing and joking? With Tony Blair? Things must be desperate. The prime minister was about to shaft him.

And so he did. Shortly after that he told us to expect a referendum on membership of the euro within - he implied - two years of the election. The chancellor himself would prefer it some time after a giant meteor has wiped out all life on earth. At least that way he'd know the result in advance.

Step back with me two hours in time, to 1pm yesterday. I was at the Channel 4 Political Awards, to be shown at 8pm on Saturday. It'll be a funny show, so catch it if you can, though it goes out at the same time as Casualty. You might find it hard to tell the difference. ("This man's career is hanging by a thread! We need oxygen, a blood transfusion, and a heart transplant!" "But doctor, look, the Mandelson case file says 'do not resuscitate!'")

At my table was Lembit Opik, the LibDem MP who has spent the last few years telling us that the meteor could strike at any time. I asked if we wouldn't have a few weeks' warning, to send up a nuclear device up to smash the rock before it hits us. He said we might get two minutes. What a cheery companion he proved to be.

Jon Snow, the presenter, made a joke about Michael Meacher "only stopping by to pick up the rent". That got a big laugh.

Lembit Opik appeared on camera talking about Gordon Prentice, a keen opponent of fox-hunting. He, Lembit, had suggested to him that it should remain legal, but there should be a regulatory agency called "Off-fox". Mr Prentice had replied "using the same words, but in the reverse order".

There were some queeny "whoo, whoos" from the assembled pols and hacks, but Gordon Brown looked much amused.

Stephen Pound, the Labour MP for Ealing, was briefly fooled on air by a phone call from Tony Blair - actually a member of Radio 4's Dead Ringers team. The prime minister would like to visit his constituency. "I can promise you no tomatoes," said Mr Pound, "but a few kiwi fruits and aubergines, perhaps..."

The next winner was the Observer's Andrew Rawnsley, for his book about New Labour and their general contempt for the voters. It is said that Gordon Brown was a source for this work, but now regrets telling the author whatever it was he said.

As the oeuvre was being praised, the chancellor looked thunderous. Margaret Beckett, two seats away, smiled a tight little smile.

Mr Rawnsley praised his wife for all her help. "She is my rock, my comfort and my joy," he said. The chancellor's jaw literally hung open. He hugged himself, like someone signalling the maitre d' to bring a strait jacket.

Then Mr Brown himself won the top award of all, for "the MP who has been the most outstanding figure in the House". They showed short clips of people praising him. He looked delighted. Who wouldn't be? Labour MP Bob Marshall-Andrews declared on the monitors: "He is an absolutely typical Lowland Scot. He believes in the virtues of toil, and plunder."

Back in the Commons, Mr Blair was replying to William Hague. Did an early referendum on the euro mean within two years of the next parliament? (The Tory leader seems to have given up any hope of winning.)

"Early in the next parliament would, of course, be within two years," Mr Blair replied. Mr Brown scowled.

Win some, lose some. But he seems to win nearly all the time, so I don't suppose he'll mind too much.

fields.headline: After 27 years, Downing is freed
fields.standfirst: Judge expects to quash Stephen Downing's conviction in the Bakewell murder trial
fields.trailText: Judge expects to quash Stephen Downing's conviction in the Bakewell murder trial
fields.body:
Stephen Downing, who supporters claim is the victim of Britain's longest-running miscarriage of justice, was freed on bail yesterday with the expectation that his conviction for murder will be quashed.

But he returned home after 27 years behind bars with a stain on his reputation after a lawyer for the prosecution claimed no one else was responsible for the crime.

This was contested by his supporters - and police said no decision had been taken on whether to re-open the murder inquiry.

Yesterday Mr Downing walked from Littlehey prison in Cambridgeshire, where he had been spent the last four years, to enjoy a brief moment of triumph.

Grinning broadly, he said: "I would like to thank all the public and the media for their support and help.

"I am elated and I now hope to spend some valuable time with my family."

He shook hands with a prison officer and then left in the company of two reporters from a Sunday newspaper.

Mr Downing, 44, was jailed for life in 1974 for the killing of typist Wendy Sewell, after he found her badly battered but still alive in the cemetery where he worked in Bakewell, Derbyshire.

He was then 17 but had the reading age of an 11-year-old. He was convicted mainly on the basis of a confession obtained after he had been interrogated by Derbyshire police for more than seven hours, during which time he had to be shaken awake and officers took bets on whether he would confess.

He was never informed by police that he was under arrest or in custody and was not told of his right to consult a solicitor.

His counsel, Edward Fitz-gerald QC, told the court of appeal in London yesterday that there was strong reason to believe that he did ask for a lawyer but his request was denied.

"There is a most powerful case for saying that this conviction is unsafe," said Mr Fitzgerald.

"For this man, who has served 27 years, to serve a day longer would not be just."

Julian Bevan QC, for the prosecution, said the crown accepted that the confession could have been ruled inadmissible at his trial.

A full appeal hearing will not take place for at least three months but Mr Justice Pitchford, the judge who granted bail, said he agreed that Mr Downing's conviction would probably be quashed on appeal.

However, his character will bear the stain of the comment by Mr Bevan, who said: "Such investigations as have taken place into this by the criminal cases review commission do not support the assertion that another person was responsible."

Wendy Sewell's husband David, who still lives in the house which he shared with her, was at the appeal court yesterday and seized on the comment made by Mr Bevan.

Asked if he still thought Mr Downing was guilty, he replied: "They did in there, didn't they? He's been convicted and served his time."

The criminal cases review commission referred his case to the court of appeal in November after years of campaigning by his family and a series of investigative articles by Don Hale, the editor of the local newspaper, the Matlock Mercury.

Mr Hale said outside court: "It's been a long, hard campaign. This is good news for everybody. It shows that justice does prevail."

He questioned Mr Bevan's assertion that no-one else could be found responsible. "Perhaps they haven't seen all the evidence."

A statement issued on behalf of Mr Downing's parents, taxi driver Ray, 66, and Juanita, 67, said: "The Downings are absolutely over the moon and delighted with the news. It has not sunk in yet and they are both rather emotional."

They left home for a reunion with their son yesterday holding a congratulations card.

Mr Downing has consistently denied murder and so has been ineligible for parole, which could have given him freedom 10 years ago.

He has maintained a spotless disciplinary record in prison but now faces the difficult task of adjusting to freedom. He has never had a bank account, never driven a car, and never had a girlfriend.

Pamela Birds, an old friend of the Downing family, said: "Stephen should have been home years ago."

webTitle: Saudis track down drink den owner

fields.headline: Saudis track down drink den owner
fields.trailText: A business associate of the Briton facing execution in Saudi Arabia for a car bomb killing was yesterday moved from his prison cell in Dubai for extradition back to the Saudi capital, Riyadh.
fields.body:
A business associate of the Briton facing execution in Saudi Arabia for a car bomb killing was yesterday moved from his prison cell in Dubai for extradition back to the Saudi capital, Riyadh.

Gary Dixon, 55, was involved in running illicit drinking dens with Alexander Mitchell, who at the weekend confessed on Saudi television to causing the explosion which killed another Briton. Mr Mitchell could be beheaded in public if convicted.

Mr Dixon, also known as Gary O'Nions and Gary Lyons, established the first commercial-scale drinking den in Riyadh. He fled to Dubai after being arrested in Saudi Arabia last April on suspicion of illegal manufacturing and distribution of alcohol. The Saudis obtained an extradition order after he was held in Dubai.

The promised British consular access to Mr Mitchell had not been delivered by early yesterday evening. And in a statement issued through her solicitor yesterday, his sister, Margaret Dunn, 41, said: "We were shocked at his physical appearance in the televised performance that was supposed to be his confession. He looked drugged or something and nothing like the brother we know and love."

Yesterday, Mr Dixon phoned a friend from his cell in the Dubai CID jail, saying he was about to be moved to Interpol's regional office in Abu Dhabi - from where he would be extradited to Saudi Arabia.

Mr Dixon was in jail at the time of the two car bombings last November but yesterday expressed fears that trumped-up charges could be brought against him on his return to Saudi Arabia.

Like Mr Mitchell, Mr Dixon was originally employed at the security forces hospital in Riyadh, where he installed the hospital's computer system.

Although small-scale illicit drinking has existed among expatriates in Saudi Arabia for years, Mr Dixon was the first to turn it into an industry. His Empire Club was equipped with a gymnasium, restaurant, disco and in-house brewery. It had several hundred members paying subscriptions of 60 riyals (about £10) a month.

"About six years ago there was a major bust," a friend of Mr Dixon and Mr Mitchell recalls. "The club closed for a reasonable time but Gary's sponsor - a high Saudi official - kept him in the kingdom."

It re-opened, only to be raided again about three years ago. Again, the club re-opened.

Former members believe the club was able to keep re-opening because Mr Dixon paid a share of the profits to his Saudi sponsor and to a senior police officer in the Sulaymaniyya district of Riyadh.

The occasional raids were instigated by the mutawwa (religious police). Despite tough anti-drink laws, the ordinary police were relatively tolerant.

A third raid on the Empire Club came just over a year ago. Mr Dixon was out of the country attending a birthday party and his wife, Mary, was arrested.

Mr Mitchell stepped in to help. He used his influence with the chief of police and secured her release - though it took about four months.

This time the Empire Club stayed closed.

Following his arrest last April on alcohol-related charges, Mr Dixon was released on bail. He says he decided to sneak through the desert across the border into the United Arab Emirates, from where he believed the British embassy would help him to return to Britain.

Mr Dixon claims that Mr Mitchell, using his knowledge as an ex-soldier, gave him training in desert survival to prepare for the journey.

Arriving in the Emirate of Dubai, Mr Dixon says British officials were unwilling to help him. He has spent seven months in jail.
