Former members believe the club was able to keep re-opening because Mr Dixon paid a share of the profits to his Saudi sponsor and to a senior police officer in the Sulaymaniyya district of Riyadh. The occasional raids were instigated by the mutawwa (religious police). Despite tough anti-drink laws, the ordinary police were relatively tolerant. A third raid on the Empire Club came just over a year ago. Mr Dixon was out of the country attending a birthday party and his wife, Mary, was arrested. Mr Mitchell stepped in to help. He used his influence with the chief of police and secured her release - though it took about four months. This time the Empire Club stayed closed. Following his arrest last April on alcohol-related charges, Mr Dixon was released on bail. He says he decided to sneak through the desert across the border into the United Arab Emirates, from where he believed the British embassy would help him to return to Britain. Mr Dixon claims that Mr Mitchell, using his knowledge as an ex-soldier, gave him training in desert survival to prepare for the journey. Arriving in the Emirate of Dubai, Mr Dixon says British officials were unwilling to help him. He has spent seven months in jail.

webTitle: Bleak new world, as seen by the MoD

fields.headline: Bleak new world, as seen by the MoD
fields.standfirst:
Drought, disease and social unrest - the face of future conflict
Change and catastrophe
fields.trailText: Global warming, scarcity of fresh water and other vital resources, the spread of Aids, demographic shifts and, not least, the lack of a "fighting ethos" in the armed forces, could dramatically change the face of future conflicts, the Ministry of Defence warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Global warming, scarcity of fresh water and other vital resources, the spread of Aids, demographic shifts and, not least, the lack of a "fighting ethos" in the armed forces, could dramatically change the face of future conflicts, the Ministry of Defence warned yesterday.

They are among a huge range of issues highlighted in an unprecedented exercise designed to promote a debate on Britain's defence and security policy over the next 30 years.

The MoD raises the prospect of genetic warfare or "biogenetic terrorism" targeting food sources, and micro, unmanned, airborne vehicles (UAVs) developed through nanotechnology. Meanwhile, military action by states will be subjected to ever-increasing scrutiny from the courts - including the proposed international criminal court - the public and pressure groups.

"The ability of the media to affect the public and political agenda on a national and global scale is likely to increase and may have a major impact on where, how and when the UK and others react to natural disasters, humanitarian crises and conflicts," says the report.

Change and catastrophe

 In Britain, the number of people aged 40 or below will fall by 2.7m by the year 2030. Ethnic minorities will rise to 10%, from 6% now

 By the middle of the century two-thirds of the population of the EU will be over 65, "not economically active"

 Global warming could cause serious problems for key British defence facilities

 By 2025, two-thirds of the world's population could be living in "water-stressed" conditions

 By 2020 Britain could be importing 90% of its gas. "Main sources of supply will include Russia, Iran and Algeria"

 By 2010 Aids will be a more serious problem in Asia than in Africa

 Economic migrants "may introduce domestic conflicts into recipient states or provoke new conflicts"

 The ageing of populations in western countries is likely to make them more dependent on migration to maintain their workforces at the required level

 Military operations will be subjected to ever-increasing judicial and public scrutiny, particularly in areas such as the rights of civilians in conflict, the use of child soldiers, defence exports and the proliferation of small arms

 Crime, terrorism and political extremism may increasingly require "a military element to the government response"

 Technological advances could include "biogenetic terrorism" (targeting food sources), micro unmanned airborne vehicles and quantum cryptography, providing secure communication

 There will be no circumstance requiring a British contribution on a signficantly larger scale than the 1991 Gulf war By 2025, it adds, there will be more than 2bn graduates in the world. "The idea of a transnational educated elite who identify more with their peers in other countries than with their compatriots may become more of a reality. Better educated (and more affluent) people will be more likely to question all aspects of government policy, including the role of the armed forces."

The ministry's document, The Future Strategic Context for Defence, is based on "internal thinking". It covers the environment, economics, law, morality and politics in search for what one senior MoD official called "joined up solutions". He added: "There is no such thing as a military solution".

In an intriguing passage, the MoD says Britain will probably become a net importer of gas over the next decade and by 2020 could be importing as much as 90% of its needs. It adds without comment: "The main sources of supply will include Russia, Iran and Algeria".

It says global warming will lead to extensive flooding of coastal areas that could cause "serious practical and safety issues for some key UK defence facilities [a reference to dockyards and airfields] and lead to increasing requests for military assistance at home".

Fresh water, meanwhile, will become increasingly scarce. "If present consumption patterns continue, by 2025 two-thirds of the world's population will be living in 'water-stressed' conditions". Flooding, combined with the shortage of fresh water, is likely to inflame "existing ethnic, cultural or religious tensions".

Despite technological advances and the use of unmanned weapons systems deemed "too risky for humans", there will still be a need for people prepared to face up to extreme danger and severe physical and mental demands.

"The requirement to engender and foster fighting spirit is enduring," the MoD warns. "Maintaining fighting ethos may be difficult in the light of social and legal changes and the possibility of increasing attention to, and criticism of, defence activity".

Peacekeeping operations will be affected by the spread of Aids, with the number of cases in Asia overtaking those in Africa by the year 2010, the MoD says.

The report adopts a more sanguine approach to the threat from the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction than a recent analysis by the Pentagon, its American counterpart. It also stresses the importance of close military ties to Britain's European allies. However, on two conclusions it agrees with the Washington study. The technology and capability gap between Europe and the US is likely to widen. That mismatch, it warns, has implications for Nato's ability to conduct effective multinational operations in the future. Secondly, it states: "In the period to 2030, the US is almost certain to remain the world's only military and economic superpower".

Russia, meanwhile, poses no conventional military threat, says the MoD, which goes out of the way to recognise Moscow's concerns, in particular the spread of Islamic fundamentalism and instability at Russia's borders.

The comment reflects the lukewarm, though unstated, attitude among senior British officials - in contrast to their counterparts in Washington - to the fur ther enlargement of Nato to include the Baltic countries, Romania and Bulgaria. The MoD also plays down the threat from so-called "rogue states" - the original reason given in Washington for the need for a US national missile defensive shield. The report says: "Many analysts believe that 'countries of concern' will gradually, though belatedly, adapt to the post-cold war security environment and become less of an overt menace".

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, said yesterday that the MoD had never before set out its "forward thinking" in such a way.

The ministry also published a second document, Defence Policy 2001, setting out immediate priorities, including support for the EU's common foreign and security policy.

fields.headline: Sharon's return evokes bitter memories
fields.standfirst:
Shatila view Fear of new onslaught vies with urge for bloody victory
Election reults
fields.trailText: There is no real difference between so-called Israeli moderates and extremists, Labour and Likud, Ehud Barak and Ariel Sharon. That is a standard, bedrock Palestinian view.
fields.byline: David Hirst in Shatila refugee camp, Beirut
fields.body:
There is no real difference between so-called Israeli moderates and extremists, Labour and Likud, Ehud Barak and Ariel Sharon. That is a standard, bedrock Palestinian view.

It is as firmly held in Beirut's Sabra and Shatila refugee camps as anywhere else, even though the massacre that took place there 19 years ago - gen erally regarded as the most damaging such episode in Israel's history - is indelibly associated with Sharon, the defence minister during the Israeli invasion of Lebanon.

Abu Mujahid, who runs a youth centre in Shatila, was there. On the night of September 16 1982 he could not get home past the Israel army that had laid siege to the camps.

"It was like daylight at night," he said of the flares it continuously threw up. For the next 48 hours, aided by the siege and the flares, rightwing Phalangist militiamen, Israel's Lebanese allies, went through the camps, slaughtering up to 2,000 men, women and children left defenceless by the enforced departure, a few days before, of Yasser Arafat and his guerrillas.

When Abu Mujahid finally made it he saw "corpses so bloated and blackened in the sun that fathers couldn't recognise their own sons, bodies torn apart and strewn about, along with dead animals, like garbage".

"Sharon may have ordered this," he said, "but, for me, they are still basically the same. The only difference is that when Labour kills, it pretends to regret it, while Likud does it with a smile."

But for Suheil Natur, a researcher, Mr Sharon will, in fact, be much worse than Mr Barak, less because he is who he is than because of the conditions in which he has come to power.

"Of course," he said, "the very name Sharon carries a message: 'prepare yourselves for war'."

But there have been extremist prime ministers before. "Older camp residents recall the shock they felt when Menachem Begin, leader of the pre-independence Irgun terrorist underground, came to power in 1977; to be followed later by the more extreme Yitzhak Shamir, leader of the Stern gang.

"The difference this time," he said, "is the whole climate of extremism in Israel, the fact that the peace process is virtually dead, and the logic of violence has taken over.

"After Oslo we had thought that co-existence would be come possible, that the Israel peace camp would push for a reasonable Palestinian state. But, instead, it accepted all these interim arrangements that tore the heart out of one in advance.

"Now, with the intifada, it hardly raised a squeak of protest at the brutalities of the army; and then it swallowed the line that Arafat only repaid generosity with violence.'

"Yes," said a teacher with the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), who is forbidden to express political opinions publicly. "Israelis are democratic, unlike us; but by voting for Sharon they show that they, not just he, don't want peace.

"Frankly, I prefer Sharon anyway. At least with him things will be clear. And we are not afraid."

Some believe that, under Mr Sharon, Lebanon's Palestinian refugee camps will become a target again. Some don't. But all identify with their compatriots in the occupied territories, who are seen to have shouldered the struggle for which they formerly paid such a high price.

"The intifada has given us new hope," said Nihad Hamad, a social worker. "At least there is now talk of the right of return.

"With Sharon there may be war. But with war there is hope of victory - and, anyway, anything is better than rotting here for another 19 years."

They say it is not they, but Mr Arafat and his Palestine Authority, who are in a panic at the coming of Mr Sharon. In the run-up to the elections, the Palestinian Authority had urged Israel-Arabs to rally behind Mr Barak.

"Just what business is it of Arafat's trying to market Barak, the bad, for Sharon, the even worse - and with the blood of our latest martyrs?" asked Abu Mujahid.

Mr Arafat is seen to have invested his all in a fraudulent peace process, which is now on the point of blowing up in his face.

Arab governments are seen to be scared too. "Of course," said Suheil Natur, "they are again singing the old song: that we must give any new man his chance, whoever he is. After all, they say, didn't Begin, the first of the Likudniks, become the first to make peace? But peace with Egypt was the easiest; Israel had to yield none of its historic claims; Egypt got all her territory back."

Jordan is perhaps the most fundamentally exposed. "Remember," he said, "the Sabra and Shatila massacre was all about driving us out of Lebanon, dumping us in Jordan, and turning the Hashemite kingdom into the Palestine state. It didn't work last time, but already he's talking about trying something like it again."

For those with only the squalor, confinement and indolent futility of camp life to lose there seems to be a sort of grim exhilaration in the feeling that a long struggle may now be moving towards a climax, costly though it will be.

"There will be no peace between us until we knock the superiority complex out of the Israelis," said the UNRWA teacher.

"Sharon personifies that complex. But under Sharon they are going to feel real pain, pain like they have given us for 50 years; because the intifada will expand - and I think Hizbullah will get into the act too."

The kind of peace that most of them speak about remains what it always was, a "return" not to an Arafat state but to what is now Israel.

webTitle: Defiant militias vow to escalate uprising

fields.headline: Defiant militias vow to escalate uprising
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian reaction Try to crush us and Israel will forfeit all security, say West Bank leaders
Election results
fields.trailText: The field commanders of the Palestinian uprising yesterday issued a defiant challenge to the new hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, warning they will make life unbearable for Israelis if he tries to crush their uprising.
fields.body:
The field commanders of the Palestinian uprising yesterday issued a defiant challenge to the new hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, warning they will make life unbearable for Israelis if he tries to crush their uprising.

"If the Israelis think that Sharon will make security for them, we say loudly that Israel will never have security at all," said a statement from the Fatah leadership yesterday. "We call for stepping up the intifada and resistance in the face of the butcher Sharon."

In the Palestinian-controlled cantons of the West Bank, from Nablus in the north to Bethlehem in the south, Fatah militia leaders said the staggering election victory for Mr Sharon meant that Israel had lurched so far to the right as to make genuine negotiations impossible in the near-future.

During the campaign, Mr Sharon vowed that his government would never negotiate with the Palestinians while under fire, and that he would never give up parts of Jerusalem or the West Bank's Jordan Valley - areas Mr Barak was willing to trade for peace.

The Palestinians argue that that leaves them with just one choice: an escalation of the four-month uprising to wear down Israelis until Mr Sharon is ready to talk peace on more generous terms. The militias of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement announced their escalation on Monday, coinciding with new warnings from the militant Islamic Jihad organisation of attacks inside Israel's borders.

Although some 320 Palestinians have been killed in the last four months, the uprising is no longer being fought by a mass movement but instead by militias carrying out planned attacks on Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers. That has tipped the balance in the Palestinians' favour, and in recent weeks Israelis have been killed on an almost daily basis.

Occupation

"Sharon has chosen war against the Palestinians, and it is easier for the Palestinian people to make war against Sharon than against Ehud Barak," said Hussein Sheikh, who commands the Fatah militia in the West Bank city of Ramallah. "The policies of Sharon show that the peace process is gone with the wind. We think he wants the occupation to go on forever, but under another name."

In Bethlehem and Ramallah, there was a growing sense that confrontation was inevitable. Tanzim leaders were hunkered down in emergency meetings, awaiting the first move from Mr Sharon and sketching doomsday scenarios involving the founding of new Jewish settlements, or re-occupation of territory - a path es poused by the general's far-right allies.

Hussam Khader, who leads the largest Fatah militia in the Nablus area, said he expected Mr Sharon to continue enclosure of land and, if the conflict continued, to "attack or punish" the headquarters of the Palestinian security forces.

He added: "What I would advise Mr Sharon to do now is to behave as a prime minister, and not as a general in Beirut. If he behaves with an army mentality, he will lead the area to an expanded war."

In his victory speech yesterday, Mr Sharon called on the Palestinians to renounce violence, and stop the drive-by shootings and bombings which have killed more than 50 Israelis. Senior Likud leaders followed up on Mr Sharon's appeal by advising the Palestinians to "lower their expectations".

But the new reality of the Middle East created by Mr Sharon's victory makes a scaling back by the tanzim militias unlikely. Among the Palestinians, as among the Israelis on election day, the hardliners appear to be gaining the upper hand.

Israel's embrace of the greatest villain in the Arab world an equally strong reaction from the Palestinian administration, from members of Yasser Arafat's security apparatus to his negotiating team.

Jibril al-Rajoub, the West Bank security chief, told Israel radio yesterday, that Mr Sharon was deluded if he thought he could dictate to the Palestinians.

"I think it's the Israeli people who need to worry. If there is any mistake or craziness in your government, you will be the first victims," he said, speaking in the Hebrew he learnt during his years in Israeli jails. "The prime minister and his policies and the statements he has made that he wants to dictate peace and dictate terms on the Palestinian people and the Arab world is craziness that will drag us into bloodshed."

The senior Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erakat, said that Mr Sharon was "dreaming" if he thought he could reach a deal with the Palestinians while refusing to give any ground on parts of Jerusalem occupied after the 1967 war. Unless Mr Sharon is willing to rapidly rewrite his position, "what is there to talk about," Mr Erakat asked.

In the streets of Ramallah, ordinary Palestinians affected indifference to Mr Sharon's victory. The stock response was that if Mr Barak, the peacemaker, had unleashed helicopter gunships and tanks to crush the Palestinians, when what could there possibly be left to fear from an old war horse like Mr Sharon?

Others struggled to find a glimmer of hope. "We think it is easier to deal with Mr Sharon because it is so very clear what kind of man he is. He said right away what he wanted to do," said Hassan Yousuf, the leader of the Islamist Hamas movement in the West Bank.

fields.bodyText: The field commanders of the Palestinian uprising yesterday issued a defiant challenge to the new hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, warning they will make life unbearable for Israelis if he tries to crush their uprising. "If the Israelis think that Sharon will make security for them, we say loudly that Israel will never have security at all," said a statement from the Fatah leadership yesterday. "We call for stepping up the intifada and resistance in the face of the butcher Sharon." In the Palestinian-controlled cantons of the West Bank, from Nablus in the north to Bethlehem in the south, Fatah militia leaders said the staggering election victory for Mr Sharon meant that Israel had lurched so far to the right as to make genuine negotiations impossible in the near-future. During the campaign, Mr Sharon vowed that his government would never negotiate with the Palestinians while under fire, and that he would never give up parts of Jerusalem or the West Bank's Jordan Valley - areas Mr Barak was willing to trade for peace. The Palestinians argue that that leaves them with just one choice: an escalation of the four-month uprising to wear down Israelis until Mr Sharon is ready to talk peace on more generous terms. The militias of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement announced their escalation on Monday, coinciding with new warnings from the militant Islamic Jihad organisation of attacks inside Israel's borders. Although some 320 Palestinians have been killed in the last four months, the uprising is no longer being fought by a mass movement but instead by militias carrying out planned attacks on Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers. That has tipped the balance in the Palestinians' favour, and in recent weeks Israelis have been killed on an almost daily basis. Occupation "Sharon has chosen war against the Palestinians, and it is easier for the Palestinian people to make war against Sharon than against Ehud Barak," said Hussein Sheikh, who commands the Fatah militia in the West Bank city of Ramallah. "The policies of Sharon show that the peace process is gone with the wind. We think he wants the occupation to go on forever, but under another name." In Bethlehem and Ramallah, there was a growing sense that confrontation was inevitable. Tanzim leaders were hunkered down in emergency meetings, awaiting the first move from Mr Sharon and sketching doomsday scenarios involving the founding of new Jewish settlements, or re-occupation of territory - a path es poused by the general's far-right allies. Hussam Khader, who leads the largest Fatah militia in the Nablus area, said he expected Mr Sharon to continue enclosure of land and, if the conflict continued, to "attack or punish" the headquarters of the Palestinian security forces. He added: "What I would advise Mr Sharon to do now is to behave as a prime minister, and not as a general in Beirut. If he behaves with an army mentality, he will lead the area to an expanded war." In his victory speech yesterday, Mr Sharon called on the Palestinians to renounce violence, and stop the drive-by shootings and bombings which have killed more than 50 Israelis. Senior Likud leaders followed up on Mr Sharon's appeal by advising the Palestinians to "lower their expectations". But the new reality of the Middle East created by Mr Sharon's victory makes a scaling back by the tanzim militias unlikely. Among the Palestinians, as among the Israelis on election day, the hardliners appear to be gaining the upper hand. Israel's embrace of the greatest villain in the Arab world an equally strong reaction from the Palestinian administration, from members of Yasser Arafat's security apparatus to his negotiating team. Jibril al-Rajoub, the West Bank security chief, told Israel radio yesterday, that Mr Sharon was deluded if he thought he could dictate to the Palestinians. "I think it's the Israeli people who need to worry. If there is any mistake or craziness in your government, you will be the first victims," he said, speaking in the Hebrew he learnt during his years in Israeli jails. "The prime minister and his policies and the statements he has made that he wants to dictate peace and dictate terms on the Palestinian people and the Arab world is craziness that will drag us into bloodshed." The senior Palestinian negotiator, Saeb Erakat, said that Mr Sharon was "dreaming" if he thought he could reach a deal with the Palestinians while refusing to give any ground on parts of Jerusalem occupied after the 1967 war. Unless Mr Sharon is willing to rapidly rewrite his position, "what is there to talk about," Mr Erakat asked. In the streets of Ramallah, ordinary Palestinians affected indifference to Mr Sharon's victory. The stock response was that if Mr Barak, the peacemaker, had unleashed helicopter gunships and tanks to crush the Palestinians, when what could there possibly be left to fear from an old war horse like Mr Sharon? Others struggled to find a glimmer of hope. "We think it is easier to deal with Mr Sharon because it is so very clear what kind of man he is. fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: Election results
fields.trailText: Editorial, Al-Ahali Egyptian opposition weekly
fields.body:
Editorial, Al-Ahali Egyptian opposition weekly

There was no chance to make a preference between two similar war criminals who competed for the premiership post in Israel on Tuesday. There was no chance to make a preference between Barak, who is very bad, and Sharon who is much worse. Right now, it is clear that the division in Israel is between extremists and more extreme groups who might differ on the means, but agree on the same goal: total control of the Arab world.

Rami G Khouri in the Lebanese Daily Star

Sharon's election will neither achieve peace with justice, not perpetually delay it. My own guess is that Sharon's victory will have the same historical impact that we witnessed when other rightwing Likud leaders assumed the political leadership of Israel in recent decades _ In each case, their tough-guy, all-this-land-belongs-to-me-because-God-gave-it-to-Abraham- Isaac-and-Jacob approach proved politically unrealistic and untenable.

Al-Baath, official paper of the Baath party

The victory of the bloody terrorist and war criminal Sharon as head of the Israeli government is a clear message by the Zionist entity to Arabs amounting to an official declaration of war. By choosing Sharon the Israelis chose escalation, terrorism and aggression _Israel has put the fate of peace in the whole world, not only in the Middle East, under the mercy of a general who is obsessed with wars and the myth of Israel's Biblical lands extending from the river Nile to the Euphrates.

Editorial, Jordan Times

Although Sharon is a new prime minister, he is not new as an extremist politician and a bloody army officer who is responsible for shedding lots of innocent [Arab] blood and souls.

What concerns us here in Jordan is that Sharon built up his reputation as the man who came up with the theory that "Jordan is Palestine" and that it should be alternative nation for Palestinians. Although he declared recently that he gave up this theory and that he respected the peace agreement signed between Jordan and Israel (1994), we need to hear that from him again after taking over the premiership post. He must announce that "Jordan is Jordan".

Amos Oz in Yediot Ahronoth

Ariel Sharon is Arafat's gift to the Israeli and Palestinian peoples. Ehud Barak was defeated in the winter of 2001 for exactly the same reason Yitzhak Rabin was murdered in the autumn of 1995, and Shimon Peres was defeated in the spring of 1996: All three were ahead of their time.

Like many leaders in Israeli history, these three had _ what Arafat lacks: the courage to compromise and make peace even as many of their countrymen called them traitors.

Hemi Shalev in Ma'ariv

Sharon's campaign was clever enough to obscure his problematic past and quiet any public fears about his election. His moves in the coming days will reveal whether the voters were like Little Red Riding Hood led astray by a wolf dressed like an amiable grandmother _

Barak wasted the national goodwill granted him in the last elections like a gambler with no God and no tomorrow. Arrogantly _ Barak led the left from the greatness of victory to the anguish of defeat. By linking his own fate to that of the policy he helmed, Barak turned out to be a millstone that now threatens to sink the peace process entirely."

Yoel Marcus on Ariel Sharon in the Ha'aretz

The time for tractor rides with your grandchildren is over. You can take off the makeup and get rid of the plastic smile. You won't have 100 days of grace, not even 100 hours. Hopefully, while you were keeping your mouth shut and the voters were asleep, you thought and planned what kind of prime minister you wanted to be. One thing you can do for certain - frame a portrait of yourself for the next one in line.

webTitle: Game, set and DNA match against Becker

fields.headline: Game, set and DNA match against Becker
fields.trailText: It had all the ingredients of a particularly bad sex comedy.
fields.body:
It had all the ingredients of a particularly bad sex comedy.

Among the more surreal tales surrounding the paternity suit launched against Boris Becker by the London-based model Angela Ermakova were stories of stolen sperm, artificial insemination and Russian mafiosi hatching sinister blackmail plots.

But yesterday the 33-year-old retired tennis star accepted the rather more mundane truth, conceding that he was the father of a 10-month-old girl who Miss Ermakova claims was conceived in a broom cupboard at the upmarket Japanese restaurant Nobu in central London.

"I do accept the fatherhood. I take responsibility, and I will take care of little Anna," Becker said in a statement issued by his spokesman in Munich after a preliminary hearing at the high court in London.

"I hope that this statement will end all the speculation of past weeks. Children are the most important people in our world. Whatever I can contribute, I will do for Anna's future as a happy girl."

Miss Ermakova, 33, says she first encountered Becker in the Met Bar at the Metropolitan Hotel in Park Lane in 1999, in the weeks after his farewell Wimbledon tournament, in which he lost a quarter-final match against Pat Rafter in straight sets.

Later that evening, Miss Ermakova claims, she and Becker had sex in a broom cupboard at the hotel's fashionable Japanese restaurant.

But despite the baby's resemblance to Becker, the three-times Wimbledon champion denied he was the father. His lawyers suggested that Miss Ermakova had inseminated herself with his sperm after oral sex - a deception the German newspaper Bild Zeitung claimed was part of a blackmail plot devised by the Russian mafia.

But last month Becker agreed to DNA tests to ascertain if he was the father, and yesterday accepted that the results corroborated Miss Ermakova's claim.

The legal battle, which began on Monday, came to a swift end yesterday after lawyers for the two sides met at the high court. Becker was not in attendance.

"I am very relieved Boris Becker has now accepted the situation," Miss Ermakova said in a statement issued through her solicitors. "I hope to be able to resolve financial matters with Boris Becker in the near future."

Becker and his wife Barbara separated two weeks before their seventh wedding an niversary in December last year, immediately before the tennis player was publicly linked with German rapper Sabrine Setlur, 26. Last month, they were granted a divorce.

Barbara Becker, a 34-year-old former actress and singer, is reported to have won a £15m settlement, along with custody of the couple's children, Noah, six, and Elias, one.

Staff at Nobu last night refused to comment on the liaison between Becker and Miss Ermakova - or on the practicability of using its broom cupboards for anything other than storing brooms. "It's not really something that we would know about," a spokeswoman said.

webTitle: Straw tries to soften rejection of drug report

fields.headline: Straw tries to soften rejection of drug report
fields.standfirst:
Users given cautions need not tell employers

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The government yesterday tried to take the sting out of its rejection of a report urging reform of drugs laws by announcing that the 50,000 offenders cautioned each year for cannabis possession will not be given criminal records in the future.
fields.body:
The government yesterday tried to take the sting out of its rejection of a report urging reform of drugs laws by announcing that the 50,000 offenders cautioned each year for cannabis possession will not be given criminal records in the future.

Ministers announced that they intend to change the legislation on the rehabilitation of offenders to ensure that the cautions 266,000 people receive each year for all offences, including drugs, will not have to be declared to employers or when travelling abroad.

They also agreed they would review sentencing to ensure that those who are caught selling drugs to a few friends are not treated as harshly as professional dealers.

Home Office ministers have been criticised for their rejection of the 24 main recommendations of the report of the Police Foundation inquiry into the state of Britain's drugs laws.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, finally announced his "considered response" to the landmark report of the inquiry, chaired by Dame Ruth Runciman and which included two serving chief constables.

Mr Straw confirmed yesterday that he had rejected its key recommendations to end the imprisonment of those convicted of cannabis possession and for a less serious classification of drugs such as ecstasy and LSD, which are bracketed with heroin and cocaine. The inquiry argued that the criminal penalties for cannabis possession often did more harm than the drug itself.

The Home Office response yesterday said it was necessary to keep a prison sentence on the statute book for simple possession of cannabis as "an important backstop to ensure that defendants appear in court" and "as an incentive to treatment".

Ministers agreed with the Police Foundation that ecstasy was less toxic than heroin or cocaine but said that when, three years ago, the advisory council on the misuse of drugs discussed its status it concluded that it posed "very real risks of fits, seizures, mental disturbances and death".

It also identified possible longer-term risks to mental health.

Similarly, on LSD the Home Office agreed it was less dangerous than heroin or cocaine but said it should remain a class A drug because "a bad trip is impossible to predict and can be terrifying".

The official Home Office response adds: "Users may be prone to accidents while they are hallucinating and they experience flash backs, often some considerable time after the event."

It also warned that LSD can complicate mental problems such as depression, anxiety and schizophrenia.

One result of the report, however, is that an anti-drug driving publicity campaign - similar to the familiar drink- drive advertisements - is to be launched by the transport authorities.

But the rejection of the landmark report dismayed drugs law reform campaigners.

The head of the inquiry, Lady Runciman, said: "It is disappointing that a real opportunity for constructive dialogue and incremental change has been missed. All our most far-reaching recommendations have been rejected. At no point has the rationale underlying the proposals been addressed. It leaves us with a law that is out of touch with reality. I believe this is good report. Its time will come."

David Winnick, a Labour backbench member of the Commons home affairs committee, agreed with Lady Runciman, adding that he hoped a more sensible debate on drugs would emerge after the pressures of the forthcoming general election campaign had passed.

webTitle: Fast response promised on medicinal cannabis

fields.headline: Fast response promised on medicinal cannabis
fields.trailText: The government will move quickly to legalise cannabis for medical uses such as relieving post-operative pain endured by multiple sclerosis sufferers if it passes current clinical trials, the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, promised yesterday.
fields.body:
The government will move quickly to legalise cannabis for medical uses such as relieving post-operative pain endured by multiple sclerosis sufferers if it passes current clinical trials, the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, promised yesterday.

He renewed the promise when he appeared to give a progress report on the trials to the House of Lords science and technology committee, which has already urged the government to license the manufacture of cannabis products for medical purposes.

Mr Clarke said: "If the clinical trials into cannabis are successful, the government is clear that we are willing to amend the misuse of drugs act to allow prescribing.

The Home Office and the Department of Health were very clear that "once the outcome of the trials is clear, we will act expeditiously to ensure that any approved treatment can be brought into circulation".

Brian Davis, of the medicines control agency, told peers he could not say whether the new cannabis products would be available within the next two years.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 10 Iranian Jews lose appeal bid
fields.body:
10 Iranian Jews lose appeal bid

Iran's supreme court denied an appeal yesterday from 10 Iranian Jews convicted of spying for Israel.

Three supreme court judges ruled that the appeal "contained repetitious material". Reuters, Tehran

Okinawa wants top marine out

A city assembly on Okinawa unanimously called yesterday for the dismissal of the US Marine commander there for allegedly calling government officials on the island "a bunch of wimps" in an email. AP, Tokyo

Elephants Thai the knot

Possibly the world's biggest wedding will take place in Thailand this Valentine's Day when elephants Phlai Bua Ban (Mister Blossoming Lotus) and Pang Oi Jai (Miss Sweetheart) wed north of Bangkok.

The honeymoon is big, too: Ms Sweetheart has to share the groom with 19 females. Reuters, Bangkok

Aristide sworn in to lead Haiti

Haitians celebrated the return to power of Jean-Bertrand Aristide yesterday, dancing in the capital, Port-au-Prince, before the presidential inauguration.

But few diplomats, let alone world leaders, attended the ceremony. The opposition boycotted November's presidential election because of alleged irregularities in last May's parliamentary vote. AP, Port-au-Prince

Croats order generals' arrest

A Croatian court ordered the arrest of General Mirko Norac and his deputy Milan Canic yesterday, the first time Zagreb has pursued its military leadership for alleged crimes in its 1991 war of independence. AP, Zagreb

Blind cod wins pool in Norway

A blind cod caught for the 40th time by a Norwegian fisherman has been sent to an aquarium so that he can retire in peace.

Harald Hauso, 69, threw back the cod each time he caught it in Hardanger fjord, because it was too thin to eat. But the old cod returned again and again. Mr Hauso might visit the fish and its new pal, a short-sighted halibut. Reuters, Oslo

fields.headline: Sharon twists knife in Muslim wounds
fields.standfirst:
New Isreali PM proclaims that the holy city will belong to the Jewish state forever
Election results
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon yesterday returned to the starting point of the Palestinian uprising that catapulted the hardliner to Israel's prime ministership and proclaimed the holy city belonged to the Jewish state forever.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon yesterday returned to the starting point of the Palestinian uprising that catapulted the hardliner to Israel's prime ministership and proclaimed the holy city belonged to the Jewish state forever.

Amid the blare of a ram's horn, Mr Sharon climbed up to the great stone face of the Wailing Wall, the last relic of the biblical temple of the Jews.

He rubbed his hand along the ancient stones and told reporters: "I am visiting Jerusalem, the capital of the Jewish people for the past 3,000 years and the united and indivisible capital of Israel - with the Temple Mount at its centre - for all eternity."

In the crowd, a man shouted: "Death to Arabs." The symbolism could not have been sharper.

On September 28, Mr Sharon ignited the uprising that has killed nearly 400 people by visiting an adjacent disputed holy site, revered by Muslims as the Haram al-Sharif and Jews as the Temple Mount.

Coming full circle yesterday, fresh after his astonishing capture of 62.5% of the vote against 37.4% for the defeated prime minister, Ehud Barak, Mr Sharon was as opposed as ever to compromise with the Palestinians.

But he said he was now on a mission to heal. "I will bring unity and I'll bring peace to the citizens of Israel and stability to the Middle East." As evidence, his aides produced a letter yesterday from the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, congratulating him on his landslide victory.

"Our hands will continue to make peace because both sides expect it," Eyal Arad, Mr Sharon's security adviser quoted the letter as saying. "I hope this year will be the year of building with peace, the peace of the brave, in the best interests of the peoples and the states of the region."

However, the conciliatory tone sat uneasily with the angry rhetoric from the commanders of Mr Arafat's militias yesterday, who were adamant Mr Sharon's election will lead to an escalation of the uprising.

In attempts to erase a 50-year history of dealing ruthlessly with Israel's enemies, Mr Shar-on's aides yesterday claimed the right has a better chance of making peace. They said Mr Sharon remained commited to a peace agreement with the Palestinians, but not when Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers are under fire.

Mr Sharon faces an equally urgent task of building a government from the fragmented parliament he inherits from Mr Barak. He has called for a national unity government, and negotiators from the Labour and Likud parties are to open talks today.

However, with Labour in a shambles after Mr Barak's resignation following his election rout, Mr Sharon may be forced into a narrow, rightwing, and unstable government.

Within the Likud, many senior figures will be wary of a unity government, particularly those loyal to the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, who are not overly eager for Mr Sharon to entrench his position.

Inside the Labour party, the state is set for a bruising succession battle with the Nobel peace laureate, Shimon Peres, fending off challenges from a younger generation in the former Knesset speaker, Avraham Burg, cabinet minister Haim Ramon, and the outgoing foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami.

Despite his elder statesman image, Mr Peres' candidacy is compromised by accusations that he helped catapult Mr Sharon to victory by under mining Mr Barak's campaign. "I am not sure it would be right for him to lead the party now as it would create a great deal of controversy," said Colette Avital, a Barak loyalist.

Mr Sharon is to send an envoy to Amman for talks with Jordanian officials in his first contacts with the Arab world since being elected, a source close to Mr Sharon said.

The source added that Mr Sharon's adviser on the Arab world, Majali Wahabi, would head to the Jordanian capital today to meet officials for discussions about "the diplomatic situation".

Israel Radio reported that Mr Wahabi, a Druze Arab, was expected to visit Egypt and Gulf countries in the next few days.

fields.headline: No 1815
fields.standfirst: Arnold Schwarzenegger
fields.trailText: Arnold Schwarzenegger
fields.body:
Also known as: Arnie, Big Arn, Arnholdt, Ah-nuld, The Terminator, Governor Schwarzenegger.

I'm sorry. We are talking about Arnold Schwarzenegger, aren't we? The very same. Teutonic star of umpteen high-octane action flicks, former Mr Universe and potential Republican governor of California.

A-ha! So that's what you're on about. After years of hovering delicately around the subject, the 53-year-old he-man has finally come out and publicly admitted that he could, possibly, at some point, vaguely think about the general idea of just maybe running for office in his adoptedhome state. "I've thought about it many times," he recently remarked, "because I love politics."

Right. So, what's brought this on then? Well, apparently it's all to do with the electricity crisis in California, where dwindling power supplies have caused headaches across the state. And Schwarzenegger, who blames California's Democratic governor Gray Davis, has a plan.

What? He's going to start running on an enormous treadmill with a generator strapped to his back? Not quite. He's declared that, should the crisis go on much longer, he will have no option but to take over the reins himself.

Still, at least this way he won't be running for president. Don't bet against it. Recently asked whether he could even campaign for the White House as a naturalised US citizen, he blithely replied: "Well, you'd have to redo the constitution. But they've had so many amendments that it's not really a problem."

Oh dear. And do we actually know any of his policies? Not keen on single parents. Big on exercise.

OK. So, next stop the governor's mansion. Could be.

Most likely to say: "I'll be back - in 2004!"

Also quite likely to say: "Hasta la vista, Mr Davis."

webTitle: Naked women go ape at monkey study

fields.headline: Naked women go ape at monkey study
fields.trailText: Twelve biologists counting monkeys in rural Kenya were put to flight this week by an a angry horde of more than 300 naked women.
fields.body:
Twelve biologists counting monkeys in rural Kenya were put to flight this week by an a angry horde of more than 300 naked women.

The 12 were conducting a census of the endangered Tana River Colobus monkey - a project funded by the World Bank - when the women stripped and charged at them.

It is thought they were protesting against a plan to turn the area into a nature reserve for the primates, which are unique to the area.

The scientists abandoned their equipment and fled.

The incident, in the Tana river district of south-east Kenya 40 miles from the Indian Ocean, is the latest in a series of clashes between villagers and the Kenya wildlife service, which is seeking to resettle them outside the proposed reserve.

The women were from the village of Baomo, which the service is planning to clear. About 2,000 families are affected by the resettlement plan.

The local police chief said the women were forced to retreat when police officers arrived and fired shots over their heads.

No arrests were made but security was tightened.

fields.headline: Ukrainian president fights for survival
fields.standfirst: Allies desert embattled Kuchma as prosecutor links leader with secret tapes at heart of journalist murder case
fields.trailText: President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine was fighting for his political life yesterday after the general prosecutor's office ended months of stonewalling to confirm that audio tapes indicating presidential complicity in the murder of an opposition journalist were genuine.
fields.body:
President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine was fighting for his political life yesterday after the general prosecutor's office ended months of stonewalling to confirm that audio tapes indicating presidential complicity in the murder of an opposition journalist were genuine.

The announcement came a day after thousands of anti-Kuchma demonstrators marched in Kiev, denouncing the sump of corruption that is the presidential court, only to be met by masked thugs breaking up the "tent city" established by protesters on the capital's main shopping street.

The threats to Mr Kuchma's political survival grew as leading opposition figures in Ukraine's notoriously fractious political scene announced they were uniting on an anti-Kuchma platform.

But the biggest threat to his hold on power came with the confirmation by the general prosecutor's office that Mr Kuchma's voice was on the tapes at the heart of the so-called Gongadze scandal.

Georgy Gongadze, the editor of a Ukrainian internet newspaper which focused on corruption, disappeared in September and a beheaded corpse, believed to be his, was found in a forest outside Kiev in November.

After denying that the corpse was Gongadze's, then spinning out the investigation to play for time, the authorities now say it is more than 99% certain that the missing journalist was murdered and that the beheaded body was, in fact, his.

A presidential bodyguard covertly recorded conversations in the presidential office, purporting to show Mr Kuchma, the interior minister and senior security officials using profane language while discussing a kidnapping operation to get rid of the "nuisance" journalist.

Mr Kuchma has persistently denied the allegations, but international pressure on him is increasing and a protest movement dubbed "Ukraine Without Kuchma" is gaining ground. Meanwhile, former political allies are jumping ship, joining the opposition pushing for his impeachment.

After weeks of contradictory statements from the general prosecutor's office, widely seen as an attempted cover-up, the deputy general prosecutor, Alexei Bahanets, said yesterday that Mr Kuchma, the interior minister, the secret service chief, and the president's chief of staff had all been questioned about the tapes and had confirmed that their voices could indeed be heard on them.

He also said that while the voices were genuine, the tapes had been doctored, and the president still denied that the incriminating evidence on the Gongadze case was authentic.

On Monday an MP, Serhy Holovaty, said Mr Kuchma had told him the tapes were genuine.

"I admit that Melnychenko's recordings are true. It is true that I have been recorded. I admit it," Mr Holovaty quoted Mr Kuchma as saying.

The recordings were made by the former presidential bodyguard Mykhailo Melnychenko, who placed a digital recorder under a sofa in the president's office.

He fled the country with his family after the general prosecutor's office issued an arrest warrant.

Mr Melnychenko is believed to be in Prague and the Council of Europe has issued a statement demanding that none of its members extradite him to Ukraine.

The general prosecutor, Mykhailo Potebenko, said at first that the tapes were a fabrication. Then he announced that even if they were real, they were illegally obtained and could not therefore be produced in court. Then he ordered Mr Melnychenko's arrest. Last Friday Mr Pote benko was put on six weeks' compulsory leave, finally admitting before he left that the tapes could be real.

The Council of Europe, the European Union, and the US ambassador in Kiev have all voiced their concern about the case, accusing the authorities of dragging their feet in investigating the allegations and condemning the pressure put on the media by the Kiev regime.

But the western pressure is yet to have much effect. Mr Kuchma is preparing to welcome President Vladimir Putin of Russia in Kiev next week and yesterday a state-controlled printer's refused to print the daily edition of the newspaper Kommersant-Ukraina, because it carried a picture on the front page of Tuesday's anti-Kuchma protesters mocking an effigy of the president.

Dutch and Austrian experts have examined the Melnychenko tapes and found them to be genuine.

Ukrainian MPs familiar with the tapes say they comprise 300 hours of recordings, and that the explosive passages on the Gongadze case are made up of 11 "episodes", the recorded excerpts having been spliced on to one tape "without editing or falsification".

webTitle: Falun Gong farce plays the streets

fields.headline: Falun Gong farce plays the streets
fields.standfirst: Beijing turns to parody in its war on the sect
fields.trailText: The plump boy in a purple jumper is pretending he believes in Falun Gong, the banned sect which the Chinese government has made desperate efforts to stamp out.
fields.body:
The plump boy in a purple jumper is pretending he believes in Falun Gong, the banned sect which the Chinese government has made desperate efforts to stamp out.

"Mummy tells me I'll go to heaven. There'll be lots of nice things to eat there and I won't have to do any work," he tells a sceptical friend.

Those in the small crowd on Tianshan Road in Shanghai laugh at his efforts to mimic the distinctive hand exercises Falun Gong members use in meditation.

It is one of very few laughs in the amateur street theatre show Pro-Science and Anti-Heresy, staged on the steps of the Tianshan Cinema in a dampening drizzle.

Some smaller children chant a little ditty, punctuated by wooden clappers, to the effect that the Falun Gong is an evil "cult" and its master, Li Hongzhi, is a wicked man. The children, members of the junior youth league, salute at the end of their number.

A group of young women sing of "the benefits of science". They wear coloured blouses and scarves, like the operatic heroines of the famed Cultural Revolution.

Later they change into yellow sweatshirts and trousers to round off the show with a sedate fan dance, heralding China's "advance into a new age".

The Tianshan Road show is part of a national campaign to mobilise public opinion against the Falun Gong, 18 months after it was banned.

Details of last month's group suicide attempt in Tiananmen Square, and evidence that the four women and one man who set themselves alight were supporters of the sect, feature prominently in the campaign.

Falun Gong spokesmen abroad insist that the movement had nothing to do with the protest, in which one person died.

The performance is reminiscent of the stylised amateur dramatics which accompanied the political campaigns of the Mao Zedong era. The difference is that in China today the masses choose whether they want to to watch.

Most passersby stop for a moment and then move on to do their shopping, buy a lottery ticket or go into the fast-food outlet next door. Some push their way through the performers into the cinema, which is showing Chicken Run.

"We don't believe in Falun Gong," several bystanders say, but they refuse to elaborate on their feelings about the anti-cult campaign.

Other Shanghainese say they are appalled by the suicide attempt but are also alienated by the government's heavy-handed propaganda.

A local official admits that there is a "small number" of Falun Gong adherents in the area.

The plump boy's sketch ends when his sceptical friend persuades him that he is being "cheated" by the Falun Gong and should study some science instead.

But what should they do about Mummy's evil friends?

"I know," the plump boy cries, "let's go and tell a [government] cadre about them!"

When the show is over, the spectators are invited to sign an anti-cult petition. Few of them bother.

webTitle: Prized purchase 'Missing' Poussin bought for Louvre

fields.headline: Prized purchase 'Missing' Poussin bought for Louvre
fields.trailText: One of the great masterpieces of French painting, believed for two centuries to have been lost, has been bought for the Louvre in Paris for about £4.4m.
fields.body:
One of the great masterpieces of French painting, believed for two centuries to have been lost, has been bought for the Louvre in Paris for about £4.4m.

Sainte Françoise of Rome Announcing the End of the Plague, by Poussin, went on display at the museum yesterday. It had been in private hands for more than a century, and handed down from generation to generation before being sold to a junk shop.

"It seems essential to conserve this canvas for our national heritage, especially as so many works by Poussin have recently left France," Jean-Pierre Cuzin, head of the Louvre's department of paintings, said.

"It is an exceptional painting because of the unusual way in which it treats its subject, because of its nearly perfect state and, above all, because of its shining beauty," he said.

This typically sumptuous work by the French painter who spent most of his working life in Rome was painted in 1657 for Cardinal Rospigliosi, who became Pope Clement IX in 1667. It was last heard of in an inventory of paintings belonging to the cardinal's nephew in 1713.

The painting probably stayed in Italy until the mid 19th century when Alexis Le Go, the secretary of the French Academy in Rome, bought it and took it home to France.

webTitle: Speculation tax clears practical but fails the political test

fields.headline: Speculation tax clears practical but fails the political test
fields.standfirst:
Plan could earn poor countries $250bn a year

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: As John Major found to his cost in September 1992, global financial speculation is an almost irresistible force. Governments can find their economic strategies in tatters when the markets lose confidence and rush for the exit.
fields.body:
As John Major found to his cost in September 1992, global financial speculation is an almost irresistible force. Governments can find their economic strategies in tatters when the markets lose confidence and rush for the exit.

For Britain, the exit from the exchange rate mechanism was beneficial, but for less developed countries the aftermath of defeat at the hands of the speculators has been more people in poverty, cancelled surgical operations and a rise in the number of children not in school.

As the 1990s wore on, the number of countries affected by financial crises grew. Mexico in early 1995, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and South Korea in 1997, Russia in 1998, Brazil in 1999 were the main focus of the speculative attacks, but other countries - the Czech Republic and South Africa, for example - found their currencies under fire.

One consequence of the increase in both the number and the severity of the financial crises has been renewed interest in the work of an American economics professor, James Tobin, on a tax on speculation. War on Want has become one of the main proponents of the so-called Tobin tax.

Professor Tobin floated the idea in a series of lectures at Princeton in 1972. This was when the post-war system of fixed exchange rates backed by controls on the free movement of money was collapsing and the search was on for a new framework of international economic management.

As Prof Tobin has freely admitted, the idea did not find much support in the 1970s, when the vogue was for deregulation and fewer restrictions on markets. "It did not make much of a ripple. In fact, one might say it sank like a rock."

In most central banks and finance ministries, extreme scepticism about the Tobin tax persists to this day. Prof Tobin quotes Otmar Issing, then chief economist at the German Bundesbank and now a member of the board of the European central bank, as saying of the plan for a tax on speculation: "Oh, that again. It's the Loch Ness Monster, popping up once more."

But to Prof Tobin and his supporters the tax has two big plus points. They believe that if short-term flows of capital were taxed at the rate of about 0.25% per transaction it would not only "throw sand in the wheels" of international speculation but also provide $250bn or so a year that could be redistributed from western financial institutions to the developing world.

Steve Tibbett, a senior campaigner for War on Want, said: "The overriding reason we have campaigned so hard on the Tobin tax to be introduced as part of a raft of measures to help stabilise the world economy is because of the devastating effect of the last major financial crisis on our partners.

"We felt strongly that the Tobin tax was one of the few proposals around that had widespread political support combined with a wide appeal. As a campaigning tool it has the advantage of being a relatively neat, simple and direct way of tempering what is probably one of the least regulated global markets.

"The revenue-raising aspect also helps."

War on Want can claim support for its campaign in various trade unions, a host of voluntary agencies and more than 100 MPs.

Even so, the chances of the international community levying the tax any time soon are remote.

Why should that be? The first objection - that a Tobin tax is technically impossible in a hi-tech world of instant money flows - is probably the weakest. Studies have shown that it would be perfectly possible to keep tabs on foreign exchange deals.

The second argument, that it would make capital markets less efficient, is also pretty spurious. A Tobin tax would not prevent long-term direct investment, but it would penalise "hot money" speculation, which makes up the bulk of the $1.5 trillion a day trade on the foreign exchanges.

But the capital markets could still function perfectly well: a transactions tax of 0.25% would not deter speculators convinced that a currency was ripe for devaluation.

It is politics that is the killer. Despite its merits, including the fact that it could increase aid flows sevenfold, the political will for a Tobin tax is absent in the places that matter: Washington, London, Tokyo, Frankfurt.

Unless and until that changes, the Tobin tax will remain on the drawing board.

fields.headline: Titanic relaunch
fields.trailText: Norwegian shipping magnate Fred Olsen yesterday bought a slice of Belfast city centre from Harland & Wolff and plans to turn it into a £400m residential and commercial development named Titanic Quarter.
fields.body:
Norwegian shipping magnate Fred Olsen yesterday bought a slice of Belfast city centre from Harland & Wolff and plans to turn it into a £400m residential and commercial development named Titanic Quarter.

The £46m deal, for100 acres of land, halves the debts at the struggling Northern Ireland shipyard where Mr Olsen is a majority shareholder.

Mr Olsen will apply this summer for planning permission to build Titanic Quarter, named after the ill-fated liner which was built at the yard.

Harland needs a promised contract from the Ministry of Defence to remain viable.

webTitle: Charity drive Rescuing Daewoo becomes a patriotic duty

fields.headline: Charity drive Rescuing Daewoo becomes a patriotic duty
fields.trailText: In a reversal of the concept of corporate charity, the South Korean public is being asked for donations to prevent bankrupt Daewoo Motor falling into foreign ownership.
fields.body:
In a reversal of the concept of corporate charity, the South Korean public is being asked for donations to prevent bankrupt Daewoo Motor falling into foreign ownership.

The patriotic rescue attempt comes as Daewoo - which has already swallowed billions of pounds of taxpayers' money - is shaken by new strikes and allegations of executive corruption.

Daewoo workers yesterday staged a rally (above) to demand the arrest of Kim Woo-chong, the founder of the group.

The Daewoo fighting fund is being set up by 380 business, political and religious leaders who are opposed to government attempts to sell the carmaker to General Motors and Fiat.

Through a public appeal, the group aims to raise one trillion won (£500m) to buy a stake in Daewoo, which was a leading light in the South Korean economy until the collapse of its parent group two years ago.

The group plans to sell millions of charity "shares", worth £4 each, as a step towards persuading the government to bail out the firm and save the jobs of its 13,000 workers.

"All of us are responsible for Daewoo Motor's problems, rather than it being attributable to only the government, management or militant workers," said one of the group's most prominent members, former deputy prime minister Choi Gak-kyu. "Efforts to solve the problems should start with our sacrifice. Workers should also join in."

This week prosecutors began a hunt for Mr Kim, who is reportedly in hiding in Europe, over allegations that he set up a £1bn slush fund at the company's London-based operation, British Finance Centre.

webTitle: The long fight to improve workers' lives

fields.headline: The long fight to improve workers' lives
fields.standfirst:
Labour rights Charity helps fledgling union gain strength
http://www.guardian.co.uk/globalisation/
fields.trailText: When Indra and Han Aditiana were fired from their jobs at a garment factory in November, 2,000 of their colleagues refused to work until they were reinstated and conditions at the plant improved.
fields.body:
When Indra and Han Aditiana were fired from their jobs at a garment factory in November, 2,000 of their colleagues refused to work until they were reinstated and conditions at the plant improved.

After talks the management of PT Pacific Rimasri Garment, on the outskirts of Jakarta, backed down.

The management of the factory, which produces clothes for foreign companies, including Marks & Spencer, gave the two employees their jobs back, recognised the factory branch of the Textile and Garment Workers' Association (ABGT), and promised to end the intimidation of female staff and address a list of other complaints.

The workers' side was led by Yanti Mala, the chairwoman and only full-time employee of ABGT. "It was a small victory but the struggle there is not over," she said.

"When the union asked for an end to compulsory overtime, use of child labourers and introduction of maternity leave, the company said things would improve in January 2001. But the conditions are still the same so we are planning more action."

Belligerence of this kind is a new departure in Indonesian labour relations. The former dictator Suharto allowed only one workers' organisation, the toothless All-Indonesia Workers' Union, as a sop to international criticism of his repressive policies.

When he fell from power in May 1998 the picture began to change, but only very slowly and not always for the better, according to Ms Mala.

"We were in crisis then, so the government said workers had to be patient and not make demands, for the sake of national recovery," she said. "Almost three years later they still side with the companies in most disputes and use the same arguments against us."

The extent of the continued oppression is shown by the fact that ABGT has only grown from 500 members at its foundation in 1997, when it was illegal, to 4,000 now.

"Bosses threaten workers with dismissal if they join a union," Ms Mala said. "And there's a lot of sexual intimidation as well. We're really fighting an uphill battle."

The struggle has become slightly easier in the past year, thanks to assistance from War On Want, which has agreed to contribute 80m rupiah (£5,800) a year for two years and to help with training leaders and union members.

ABGT learned about the British charity through the Social Information and Legal Guidance Foundation (Sisbikum), which made the initial proposal and is still controlling the money flow, as Ms Mala and her colleagues admit they are not adequately trained to handle such sums.

"By next year we should no longer be necessary," Sisbikum's executive director, Arist Merdeka Sirait, said. "ABGT should have developed so that it can run its own affairs, which is exactly what we want."

Ms Mala said this year's aim was not to attract thousands more members but to improve the awareness of the current membership. "We've decided to make this a year of consolidation", she said.

The garment industry is by no means the only one in which workers are struggling to organise themselves or improve their conditions.

Nationally, less than 20% of Indonesian workers are union members and almost all of them are facing the same uphill battle.

War On Want is also helping the Bakti Pertiwi Foundation (YBP), a small labour rights education and mobilisation organisation based in the Jakarta suburb of Bekasi, home to numerous factories.

"Most labourers have a limited education and the concept of workers' rights is very foreign," said Abdurrahman, YBP's director.

"During the crisis more than 500,000 people were laid off from factories in Greater Jakarta and none of them got a fair deal. We are trying to make sure that people know their rights so that sort of thing doesn't happen again."

Mr Abdurrahman is doing that with half a dozen staff working in a small unpretentious house, but is happy with the set-up.

"We don't want lots of publicity or a big office," he said. "We just want to concentrate on training labourers to learn about their rights and help union leaders with capacity building."

One of their main campaigns is to get the minimum wage raised. A recent social survey reckoned that people in Jakarta need to earn at least 600,000 rupiah a month to be able to live according to the government's minimum standards, and the current minimum wage is only 427,000 rupiah.

This forces employees to work overtime, Mr Abdurrahman claims. "It's a vicious circle; they need more money so they are willing to work longer which means they don't worry about their conditions so much. Then the companies can squeeze their employees even more and so they will want more money."

It remains to be seen whether workers ' conditions improve significantly in the near future. No sustainable economic recovery is materialising and so the government is showing no sign of turning its attention to labour issues.

In the meantime activists such as Ms Mala and Mr Abdurrahman, with help from War On Want, promise no let-up in their efforts to help their fellow workers.

Facts on Indonesia

 Population 209m

 Life expectancy 65 years

 Illiteracy rate 16%

 Infant mortality 48 per 1,000 births

 GDP per capita £720

webTitle: Railtrack official's dual role raises safety concern

fields.headline: Railtrack official's dual role raises safety concern
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was last night accused of compromising safety by appointing its company secretary, Simon Osborne, to the same role at Rail Safety, a subsidary set up after the Paddington train crash.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night accused of compromising safety by appointing its company secretary, Simon Osborne, to the same role at Rail Safety, a subsidary set up after the Paddington train crash.

The accusation was made by Aslef, the train drivers' union, after Rail Safety confirmed that Mr Osborne was doing both jobs and said that it was a "legitimate" appointment.

The concern expressed by Aslef and several train operating companies is that Mr Osborne's position as secretary to both companies could be compromised.

Rail Safety was established by Railtrack to distance itself from direct involvement in safety issues pending the outcome of Lord Cullen's inquiry into the Paddington crash.

Railtrack faced considerable criticism from the government that it should not be responsible for investigating safety issues involving the company.

Mr Osborne's new position came under further examination yesterday after it was disclosed that he signed a memorandum from Railtrack attacking the government's plan for legislation to name individual directors in corporate manslaughter charges.

Mick Rix, general secretary of Aslef, said: "Sharing a secretary with Railtrack must inevitably compromise Rail Safety's independence.

"It is a particularly inappropriate that a senior rail safety official should be representing a company against the government's corporate manslaughter proposals."

Mr Rix said: "This reinforces our view that railway safety supervision should be separated from Railtrack completely."

Rail Safety said that, as Railtrack's company secretary, it was legitimate for Mr Osborne to carry out both jobs. His function was to ensure that the subsidiary met its legal obligations and he would not be responsible for policy.

A Railtrack spokeswoman said that of the 11-strong board - which had to be approved by the rail regulator - eight were independent and non-executives.

They include Sir Frank Davis, formerly chairman of the health and safety commission, and Richard Proffit, of the civil aviation authority.

Several train companies hinted last night that they would protest over the appointment. They had nothing against Mr Osborne but said that the new company had to be "squeaky clean".

Rail Safety is likely to have a temporary existence. Its future is largely in the hands of Lord Cullen, whose report into the Paddington crash and safety throughout the industry, will be published during the summer.

It has been widely predicted that Lord Cullen will propose a powerful independent safety authority for the industry into which the rail inspectorate would be incorporated.

fields.headline: SRA halts franchise bidding
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The strategic rail authority yesterday halted the bidding process for a rail franchise covering the Midlands, Wales and East Anglia because it would not bring sufficient passenger benefits.
fields.body:
The strategic rail authority yesterday halted the bidding process for a rail franchise covering the Midlands, Wales and East Anglia because it would not bring sufficient passenger benefits.

It said it was not satisfied with the value of proposals from the incumbent, National Express, which is one of Britain's biggest train operators.

Mike Grant, the SRA's chief executive, said he had told National Express and its partner, Group 4 Falck Global Solutions, last year that any detailed proposals would have to be competitive.

"We took the view that neither party's proposals would have delivered the benefits passengers were looking for.

"We have always said that we would not agree longer franchises unless we were satisfied that they offered sufficient benefits to passengers and taxpayers."

National Express, which holds several other franchises, runs a mix of urban and rural lines. The Central Trains franchise ends in 2004, and National Express has been looking for a 20-year extension.

Mr Grant is not satisfied with the value of the proposals contained within the joint bid.

He said that the council-run passenger transport executives thoughout the franchise area felt the bids failed to resolve several areas of concern.

Richard Brown, NE's commercial director, said he was "surprised and disappointed" by the announcement. NE felt that in the longer term, halting the process was not in the interests of Central Train passengers.

He said the company would meet the SRA and hoped to reach an agreement.

webTitle: Notebook: Oftel's less than successful act

fields.headline: Telephones policy is mobile and fickle
fields.standfirst: Oftel's less than successful act
fields.trailText: This is not a fun time to be a UK mobile phone operator. Having last year had every possible penny wrung out of you by the government during the bidding for a third generation mobile operators licence - and having shares marked down by teenage scribblers as a result - another branch of the government, Oftel, now tells you that your profits are too large.
fields.body:
This is not a fun time to be a UK mobile phone operator. Having last year had every possible penny wrung out of you by the government during the bidding for a third generation mobile operators licence - and having shares marked down by teenage scribblers as a result - another branch of the government, Oftel, now tells you that your profits are too large.

Perhaps they are too large, but if they had not been so large then the Treasury would not be £22bn better off from flogging licences. And of course to pay for the licences, the phone companies are going to need to rake it in for a while yet.

The mobile operators might not be the most popular companies with the public, but this really is cheeky: the government taking - in the form of one of the most fiendish auction processes devised to maximise its income - with one hand, and threatening to take away with the other (in the form of regulations from Oftel - witness yesterday's comment that there was no case for price controls "at the moment").

One wonders if there is some legal action being pondered in the boardrooms of the four winning bidders if any price regulation by Oftel comes to pass.

Some of what Oftel has to say is very sensible - the need for greater transparency in prices, notably.

But Oftel's less than successful performance in dealing with BT on the ground is hardly an encouraging thought about its likely dealings with mobile operators in the air.

Capital crime

GE Capital is still trying to spoil the £1bn deal Halifax agreed at the weekend with the Equitable Life insurance company. The financial services arm of General Electric is known for throwing its weight around. This time, though, it looks as if it has left it too late to break up the party.

Halifax's recovery team is already behind the desks in Equitable's head office in Aylesbury, and the fund managers at the bank's insurance arm, Clerical Medical, are preparing to invest the £30bn of assets held on behalf of Equitable's policyholders.

But then if any group is going to succeed in wrecking a deal that every other potential bidder baulked at, it is GE Capital. It is the champion of clever of wheezes and can be expected to dissect the fine print in the lengthy documents on which Halifax insists the ink has dried.

GE Capital's late intervention in this battle might end up having the effect of further destablising the 1m Equitable policyholders who have had very little to cheer about in recent months. Unless the Americans really can find a way to produce many more millions for policyholders it should admit that the game is up, and quickly. These policyholders deserve a bit of certainty.

French window

France Télécom has just found out what dangerous, violent places financial markets can be. Going about its innocent business, selling a slice of Orange in order to finance expansion plans at the mobile group, the poor French company has been mugged. Its minders on a trip to the London and Paris stock markets - 17 supposedly hard nut investment banks - proved no match for a loutish gang of institutional investors who, at a stroke, have relieved France Télécom of something close to £1bn.

It is a buyer's market in telecoms paper just now. With several further big mobile-related share issues in the pipeline, the pension and insurance funds have decided that Orange presented an irresistible opportunity to set a useful price benchmark - on their own terms.

To the extent that the institutions have allowed themselves to be stuffed with so much overpriced telecoms paper over the past three years, Orange can be seen as redressing the balance to some extent. But the big investors should also remember that France Télécom had little choice but to bring Orange to the market and with little margin to try to tough it out. Others may be less desperate to be similarly gouged, and that could hit investment in new networks, slowing down revenue development and profits growth.

That aside, investors big and small should remind themselves of the pure quality of the Orange brand. In a business sector which is not noted for serial underachievement, this company has flourished, and there is every reason to believe it will continue to do so.

The view here two days ago was that Orange would be priced to sell and that the shares are an immediate "buy."

We stick with that view and would simply note that, thanks to institutional muscle and their ruthless application of the laws of demand and supply, shares in Orange are now a 17% better buy than they were at the beginning of the week. The offer closes at 4pm on Friday.
