webTitle: Co-op to shake up financial services

fields.headline: Co-op to shake up financial services
fields.trailText: The Co-op is to bolster its banking and insurance operations as a result of recommendations by the commission reviewing the movement's future.
fields.body:
The Co-op is to bolster its banking and insurance operations as a result of recommendations by the commission reviewing the movement's future.

The report, which will be published this morning with the support of the government, is understood to fall short of calling for a full merger of the Co-operative Bank and CIS, the insurance arm.

The two operations - among the most profitable in the movement - are to work more closely together to find ways of selling more products to their customers. Currently the CIS's 3m customers and the Co-op's 2m have little overlap.

The financial services businesses will operate from Co-op's 1,100 stores which can already take deposits from customers. They are also expected to look for more ways to develop travel policies and funeral care cover, embracing all parts of the sprawling empire which includes retailing, farming and funeral homes.

The bank and insurance operations will attempt to capitalise upon their existing ethical investment stance.

By working more closely together the two businesses are expected to save costs but avoid large-scale job cuts.

The Co-op refused to comment.

fields.headline: 1,500 Cammell jobs go 'in days'
fields.trailText: Cammell Laird threatened to cut up to 1,500 jobs when it gave warning yesterday of shipyard closures unless the government comes up with financial support within days.
fields.body:
Cammell Laird threatened to cut up to 1,500 jobs when it gave warning yesterday of shipyard closures unless the government comes up with financial support within days.

Juan Kelly, the chairman of Cammell, wrote to the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, demanding an "urgent and positive conclusion" to requests for aid for a cruise ship contract.

Pressure on both company and the government has risen because European funding is being phased out.

Les Royle - head of Luxus, a start-up company, which might place the vital order - has started discussions with foreign yards.

The Cammell board is planning to discuss which yards in north-west and north-east England could be shut if there is no decision or the government refuses help.

"We have no choice but to take action," Mr Kelly told the industry secretary in his letter.

The Birkenhead base - at which the Luxus vessels would be constructed - is unlikely to close immediately but smaller yards on Merseyside, Tyneside and Teeside will probably go.

Luxus has signed a letter of intent for the £350m vessels but will proceed with a firm contract only if the government delivers certain guarantees.

Proposals made so far by the DTI have failed to break the logjamand Mr Royle is unwilling to wait much longer for a new DTI offer.

"We are talking to French and other foreign yards and we will place the order wherever the best offer is made for Luxus," he said.

Cammell has been in trouble since since a £50m deal to lengthen a cruise ship for the Italian cruise ship company, Costa Crociere, was cancelled at the last minute.

By the time the deal was suspended, Cammell had already spent £34m building a mid-ship section that was rejected for allegedly shoddy workmanship. The charge is rejected by Cammell amid threats of legal action.

John Stafford, the chief executive who was architect of a renaissance at Cammell, resigned last week after the company announced first-half losses of £3.5m compared to £7.7m profits for the same period last year.

Cammell has been a market favourite but its stock has fallen from a year's high of 147p to 10p in recent months after the City took fright at a foreign investment strategy followed by the Italian debacle. Last night the shares ended down 0.25p at £14.25.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: GM - now weed all about it | A handle on the ancestors
fields.body:
GM - now weed all about it
Five scientists at Silwood Park, the Natural Environment Research Council's centre for population biology, have been monitoring conventional and genetically modified oilseed rape, potato, maize and sugar beet for 10 years, in 12 different places. They were looking to see whether the GM crops turned into superweeds and invaded the countryside, or distributed their alien genes into other wild plants. They discovered what every gardener knows: without human help, weeds win, crops perish. "In no case were genetically modified plants found to be more invasive or more persistent than their conventional counterparts," they report in Nature today. But there is a caveat: future GM traits such as drought tolerance might help a crop on the way to superweed-status.

A handle on the ancestors
Stone axes from Tanzania more than 1.5 million years old show signs of having been used to work acacia wood, according to Manuel Dominguez-Rodrigo, of the Universidad Complutense, Madrid. Until now, the oldest bits of woodwork were some 400,000-year-old spruce spears from Hanover in Germany.

But Homo erectus may have branched into carpentry much earlier. "That our forebears had the ability to fashion wood into utensils a million years earlier than previously thought," says Dominguez-Rodrigo, "will cause us to reassess our understanding of their ability to hunt and gather."

Seek the plaice in the sun
The giant sunfish Mola mola starts off as a 2mm larva and grows to about 14ft long. It blobs about the tropic ocean, grazing on jellyfish. In adulthood, its weight is nearly two tons, but numbers are declining. A team backed by National Geographic, Monterey Bay Aquarium and the Taiwanese Fisheries Research Institute are learning how to track the big blob by satellite. Five have been tagged so far: transponders will deliver location, ocean temperature and depth of water by satellite every two minutes.

fields.headline: Keeping it in the family
fields.standfirst: Ferocious predators, lost continents, cabbages - the evolution of the ostrich has it all, writes  Henry Gee
fields.trailText: Ferocious predators, lost continents, cabbages - the evolution of the ostrich has it all, writes Henry Gee
fields.body:
If evolution teaches us anything, it is that there is nothing new under the sun. Being lazy, she repeatedly re-uses stereotypical shapes when confronted with similar circumstances. For example, the position of a bipedal runner with silly expression has been filled by a variety of creatures almost as soon as backboned animals crawled out of the ooze. The dinosaurs filled this niche prolifically, with lightly built, tiny headed creatures with names such as Ornithomimus ("bird-mimic") and, prophetically, Struthiomimus ("ostrich-mimic").

When the dinosaurs snuffed it, their place was taken briefly by a brigade of beefy flightless birds - distantly related to modern cranes and rails - each with a head the size of a shire horse, but with a beak (and presumably the attitude) to match. The crown then passed to the ratites, a distinctive group of birds still alive, but with many picturesque, extinct relatives. Thoroughly modern ratites include the ostrich of Africa (and, once upon a time, Europe and Asia), the rhea of South America, the emu and cassowary of Australasia and the kiwi of New Zealand.

Among recently extinct relatives (pushed over the brink, one suspects, by human agency) were 11 species of moa, also from New Zealand, and the elephant birds of Madagascar. Ratites range in size from the fluffy and petite kiwi to the elephant birds, 10 feet tall and likely claimants of the Edwina Currie prize, awarded to the producer of the largest eggs - some a metre in circumference.

Readers of H. G. Wells' classic tale Aepyornis Island will be glad that the elephant bird is extinct. In the novel, a man is cast away with one of these giant eggs, which hatches into a huge, intelligent and vicious adversary.

Moas and elephant birds are brought to life in a report in today's Nature. Alan Cooper of Oxford University and colleagues have examined the family history of the ratites by comparing their DNA sequences. They brought in DNA extracted from two species of moa and an elephant bird. The results will contribute to an ongoing debate about continental drift.

But hold it there - what have ostriches got to do with continental drift? The answer lies in geography. Ratites share a southern heritage, being distinctive members of the fauna of the ancient southern supercontinent of Gondwanaland. The origin and evolution of the ratites parallels the 90- million-year break-up of Gondwanaland into modern South America, Africa, India, Madagascar, Antarctica, Australia and New Zealand.

The latest evidence presented by Cooper and colleagues suggests that the lineage leading to the South-American rhea was the first to diverge from the ratite stock. This ties in with the first cracks in Gondwanaland that separated South America from Africa around 90 million years ago. This implies that the ratites are an extremely ancient group, having become a distinct lineage back in the cretaceous period, around the time that Ornithomimus and Struthiomimus were strutting their stuff, and long before the carthorse-sized carnivorous cranes appeared.

Of course, ratites back then might have looked quite different from the way they do now - they may even have had the power of flight - and each kind might have adopted the niche of bipedal runner with silly expression quite independently, on each continent.

The next branch in the ratite family tree is that of the moas- gleaned from the DNA of ancient moa bones - coinciding with the separation of New Zealand from the eastern edge of Gondwanaland 82-85 million years ago.

After that, the story becomes confused, as the lineages leading to ostriches, elephant birds, kiwis, cassowaries and emus diverged fairly rapidly. The closest cousins in this rumble of ratites are cassowaries and emus: fossil evidence suggests that these birds have been distinct for around 35 million years, so all the other lineages must have become distinct between around 82 and 35 million years ago.

Cooper and colleagues think that Australia and Antarctica, the centre of the ancient supercontinent, were the birthplace of these ratites. Emus and cassowaries evolved where they stood, and kiwis puddle-jumped to New Zealand (already inhabited by moas) by way of New Caledonia and the now-sunken Lord Howe Ridge.

The Cinderella of Gondwanaland was a spit of land wedged between Australia, Antarctica, Madagascar and India. This wedge allowed the ancestors of elephant birds to reach Madagascar, and ancestral ostriches to reach India. As Gondwanaland split, Australia migrated eastwards, Antarctica veered southwards and India moved northwards. When India collided with Asia (an impact, still ongoing, that formed the Himalayas) the ostriches disembarked. The earliest known fossils of ostriches come from Mongolia, India and Europe, suggesting they made landfall in Asia, before heading to Africa.

What happened to this crucial, lost piece of the Gondwanaland jigsaw? It is still there, if you know where to look. In the Southern Ocean, just about equidistant from modern Australia, Antarctica and Africa, is the remote and soggy Kerguelen archipelago. It was once a favourite haunt of whalers and known for its seals, penguins, French oceanographers and "Kerguelen cabbage" - a rich source of vitamin C for mariners.

Kerguelen is all that remains of a piece of Gondwanaland that Cooper and colleagues suggest might be crucial to the story of the ratites. So, if asked about the connection between ostriches and cabbages, you know the answer. The mantle of bipedal runner with silly expression has moved on, of course. You know where.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. His book Deep Time comes out in paperback soon, from Fourth Estate.

fields.headline: Is there anybody out there?
fields.standfirst: Astronomers think the answer may be blowing in the wind, writes  Jonathan Tennyson
fields.trailText: Astronomers think the answer may be blowing in the wind, writes Jonathan Tennyson
fields.body:
Seen any UFOs recently? No? Well I haven't, but then I am a scientist - a breed notoriously impervious to this brand of visitation from "little green men" or perhaps I should say "LGM", as they are known in academic circles, maybe to hide the implicit sexism.

But in academe, things are stirring on the LGM front. While reported visitations are still received with scepticism bordering on hostility, the feeling that we are not alone in the universe is widely accepted. More intriguing is that the possibility of spying on LGM in their own homes is becoming a real possibility.

Before anyone rushes off to their travel agents to book a trip to a truly unspoilt holiday destination, I should stress that it is voyeurism, not visits, that I am talking about. Up until fairly recently it was a matter of fierce debate among astronomers as to how many billions of other stars we could see that also had planets orbiting them. Or indeed whether any of them did.

Then a few years ago people started observing such planets mainly by the slight wobble they caused to the motion of their own sun as they orbited it.

At first, such sightings were surrounded by controversy. Some of the original claims had to be withdrawn because of difficulties in interpreting the observation. But now there is an increasing body of confirmed sightings, even round stars which seemed highly unlikely candidates to support planetary systems. Planets seem to be ubiquitous.

But how does that help with finding LGM? The late astronomer Carl Sagan was a great man, not only because of his ability to communicate the excitement of science to many, but also because of his occasionally off-beat scientific ideas. It was Carl Sagan who persuaded Nasa to do a truly stupid scientific experiment: could they detect signs of life on Earth?

As the Galileo space probe was on its protracted voyage to Jupiter, Sagan got Nasa to turn its telescopes towards our planet and tell us what they saw. Among all the clutter of "civilised" 20th century life: radio and TV signals and so forth, Galileo detected one feature loud and clear. This feature was methane, sometimes known as marsh gas.

Why is a signal of methane so important? In an atmosphere full of oxygen, like the one on earth, methane should rapidly be destroyed to form carbon dioxide and water. It is present in our atmosphere in significant quantities because it is constantly being produced not only by decaying vegetation but also by "flatulent rumenoids", as the journal Nature so tactfully described it.

Of course, there is no great technology in cows farting. Perhaps even more importantly a brontosaurus could undoubtedly let rip to good effect. Life on Earth has been visible in this fashion for many millions of years.

This distinction in timescales is important and one which makes the search for extra-terrestrial intelligence (Seti) so difficult. Earth has been emitting radio signals for less than a century, not even a blip in the lifetime of the universe. Against 10 billion years, a hundred million years or so of methane is still short but not impossibly short. One in a 100 are long odds, but not impossibly long, particularly if there are lots of planets to look at.

Does this help us find LGMs? Well not immediately as, at the moment, the newly discovered planets cannot be seen against the bright, bright stars they orbit. But telescope technology is evolving fast: already astronomers are laying plans for detecting these tiny specks of planetary light by cancelling out the huge flaming background.

Once this can be done, in maybe a decade or two, it will only be a short step to look for the tell-tale signs of oxygen and methane. We may then not actually be able to see inside the LGM's house, but should know whether he or she had beans for dinner!

Well I haven't, but then I am a scientist - a breed notoriously impervious to this brand of visitation from "little green men" or perhaps I should say "LGM", as they are known in academic circles, maybe to hide the implicit sexism. But in academe, things are stirring on the LGM front. webTitle: Is your website still up and running?

fields.headline: Is your website still up and running?
fields.standfirst:
Domain name providers have been going bust. Sophie Tweedle warns there could be more
More net news
fields.trailText: Domain name providers have been going bust. Sophie Tweedle warns there could be more
fields.body:
The seductiveness of owning your own domain name is not hard to grasp; millions of us now sport an online identity.

For some it is just the chance to link up with relatives and friends all over the world. For others - who have snapped up 10, 20 or even 50 domains - it is a vital means to build, maintain and protect a business.

But whichever category you fall into, one fact remains the same: many of Britain's small e-businesses are becoming ex-businesses and it is the customers who are paying the price - quite literally.

In the past two months around 10 domain name providers have gone bust. But as more frustrated and bewildered customers raise their voices the eventual number is expected to be far greater.

Among the list of burnouts are Lollinames.co.uk, Justnames.co.uk, Dotltd.com, Webnetics.co.uk, Bestprice names.co.uk, Easyzone.co.uk, and Redhotant.co.uk.

When a company goes bust, its servers are switched off, and as far as the internet is concerned, your domain name no longer exists. If the website cannot be reached the emails do not work any more either. For an internet business this could be catastrophic. And, even for owners of only one domain, months of time, energy and money spent creating the site have been wasted.

If the company is not operating anymore then neither will its administration desk. But some customers have discovered to their horror that their domain name provider did not pay its bills and never even registered the domain in the first place.

They have found themselves tangled up in a protracted battle with the company's liquidators and the registry to prove they ever had the name in the first place. The longer it goes on, the more chance there is of someone else buying your domain.

An important port of call is Nominet - the registry for all .uk names. If you are one of the lucky ones and your domain was registered properly, then it should be recorded here and nobody else can register it again. However, they charge a hefty £80 to re-register, so finding another ISP to do it for you is the cheapest course of action.

So how can you protect your online alter egos? The wisest move is to make sure you get the right ISP to begin with.

A spokeswoman from Nominet said: "When a company goes bust they do not exactly pick up the phone and call to let us know. The first we know of any difficulties is when a customer contacts us, desperate because their domain has gone down and they can't get any answers.

"People lead busy lives and may not realise for weeks that their site is down, which can have serious implications for their business."

When the virtual gold rush began 18 months ago, thousands of companies jumped on the get-rich-quick bandwagon, but now the money is running out.

And with two small ISPs going bust each week, the chances of floating are remote: internet investors are now very choosy.

The moral? Do your homework before signing on the dotted line and request official confirmation of your registration. It is a small price to pay for not being left high and dry.

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Big seller | Carry PSone
fields.body:
Big seller

Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? has become the first British game to sell a million copies in the UK, according to ChartTrack, which monitors retail sales.

The game, developed by Hothouse Creations and published by Eidos Interactive, has achieved sales worth almost £30 million in only 121 days. WWTBAM? has benefited from being available on several platforms, with a Game Boy version still to come.

So far, 624,000 copies have been sold for the Sony PlayStation, 347,000 for PCs and about 39,000 for the Sega Dreamcast.

Carry PSone
Wild Things has announced a flat-screen monitor with built-in stereo speakers for the Sony PSone console, making it a portable games machine that can also play audio CDs. It runs from a car's cigarette lighter, but a battery pack will be available. The monitor is expected to cost about £100 and should be reaching the shops now.

PS2 sales
Sony Europe says it sold 812,000 PlayStation 2 consoles last year, starting on November 24. The UK led the way with 172,000 units ahead of France (153,000), Germany (124,000) and Italy (65,000). Sales were "in line with deliveries" - limited by Sony's inability to meet demand. Sony has also taken over Red Zone Interactive, a developer of sports simulations such as NFL GameDay, NHL FaceOff and NBA ShootOut.

On the way
Codemasters is developing a football quiz for Wap phones. It will be called LMA Football Quiz, after the company's football management game. The next PlayStation version of that, LMA Manager 2001, is due on March 9.

Electronic Arts is working on two online versions of The Sims, its best-selling people simulation, according to Newsweek magazine. Sims Online wil enable players to compete against one another as Sims, and send each other email and instant messages.

fields.headline: New chip on the block
fields.trailText: This is the inside of a new breed of chip from IBM, as seen by an electron microscope at 15,000 times magnification.
fields.body:
This is the inside of a new breed of chip from IBM, as seen by an electron microscope at 15,000 times magnification.

You can clearly see six levels of inticriate circuits and a tungsten interconnect, part of new technology from IBM called CMOS 9S, which uses copper to link the innards of chips together. This allows high-speed transistors - the on/off switches which act as a computer's brains - to be linked using microscopic copper wiring only 0.13 microns wide - that's around 800 times thinner than a human hair.

Because copper is a better electrical conductor than the aluminium used in other chips, microprocessors made from it can run 25 to 30 times faster than others. But while the chips purr along in the multi-megahertz range, they will still use less power than today's versions: a big advantage as demand for sophisticated battery-powered mobile devices soars with the arrival of 3G mobile networks and palmtop computers.

Now almost every other major manufacturer of microprocessors - including Motorola and Intel - is pumping resources into research of copper circuits, in an attempt to make up on IBM's reputed three-year lead in the technology.

Computers sporting copper chips are already shipping: Apple has used IBM's technology in its PowerPC range since 1998 and IBM will put the new CMOS 9S chips in its new high-end e-server machines.

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Fuji brings out new FinePix | Record break into Europe
fields.body:
Fuji brings out new FinePix
Fuji has unveiled the successor to the FinePix 4700Zoom - one of last year's hottest digital cameras. Due in April, the FinePix 6800 Zoom offers a slightly different take on its predecessor's upright James Bond gadget-influenced styling, as well as delivering improved image resolution (3.3 megapixels as opposed to 2.47) and, at 160 seconds, twice the amount of video footage. The camera also features an updated version of Fuji's controversial Super CCD, which uses interpolation technology to allegedly increase image resolution, in this instance up to 6.0 megapixels. The model also features a 3x optical zoom and stores images on its accompanying 16MB SmartMedia card. Its price is likely to be around £700.

A cosmetically-similar, though lower specified version, the FinePix 4800 Zoom, which has a megapixel count of 2.4 and can store up to 80 seconds of video, goes on sale in June for around £500.

Also due in the summer is the FinePix 2300, a budget model with a resolution of 2.1 megapixels that stores images on embedded flash memory.

Olympus zoom in for nice pair
Olympus has kicked off 2001 with a pair of top-end digital cameras aimed at the serious amateur photographer.

In the stores now are the £800 Camedia C-3040 Zoom and the £500 Camedia C-2040 Zoom. The C-3040 is the successor to last year's C-3030 model - one of the first cameras to offer 3.4 megapixel resolution images.

The 2001 version keeps both the traditional styling of its predecessor and its 1/1.8inch 3.4 megapixel CCD (image sensor). However Olympus has added an enhanced 2.5x digital zoom (in addition to the 3x optical zoom) and has updated the camera's JPEG movie shooting/editing facilities by offering the option of disabling sound while shooting video. The camera also sports manual facilities, including white balance and exposure and comes with a 16MB SmartMedia card.

Also new from Olympus is the £500 Camedia C-2040 Zoom, a mid-market camera that has a resolution of 2.11 megapixels, a 3x optical and 2.5x digital zoom and an 8MB SmartMedia card.

Sharp's slim screens scoop
Sharp has announced three additions to its range of ultra-slim LCD TVs. Due on sale in the summer are the 13inch LC-13C2, 15inch LC-15C2 and 20 inch LC-20C2. These join Sharp's existing trio of models which are starting to arrive in the stores in limited quantities.

All three new models sport conventional 4x3 shaped screens (widescreen versions are expected in 2002), boast a 160 degree viewing angle and feature integrated speakers, sockets and an analogue TV tuner. Picture resolution from the black TFT LCD panel screens is rated at 921,600 pixels. The models are finished in silver and are accompanied by a small floor stand, although they can also be hung on a wall. Prices are expected to be around £1,500 for the 13inch model, £2,000 for the 15inch and £4,000 for the 20inch.

Record break into Europe
RecordTV, the controversial internet based-VCR system, may soon be coming to Europe. The company has confirmed that it is has been in talks with German media giant Bertelsmann with a view to offering programmes available via the web. Users simply state what they want to record and then watch the programmes online at their own convenience. The move is indicative of Bertelsmann's recent approaches to web companies. Several months ago it also sealed an alliance with on-line music swapping service Napster. Earlier this year, RecordTV suspended its US-based virtual VCR service after members of the Motion Picture Association of America filed a lawsuit against the company. The lawsuit has a trial date of July 2001.

fields.headline: Sound plans
fields.standfirst: Andy Parfitt is the Controller of BBC Radio 1
fields.trailText: Andy Parfitt is the Controller of BBC Radio 1
fields.body:
How is Radio 1 embracing net culture? We've had a Radio 1 station site since 1995-96. I see the net as a natural extension of our brand and we can engage with our audience online in new ways. We've set out to have the best understanding of our target 15-24 audience bar none - getting it right means knowing all about their favourite sites and incorporating the Radio 1 site seamlessly into on-air features.

Is the net changing the way people approach radio? Certain characteristics are universally appealing about radio, such as its intimate, one-to-one relationship. However, the net is enhancing that relationship. There's far more choice. I regularly listen to a range of US stations from the Philadelphia public service channel WHLM to KROC in LA. There's also a new depth of relationship you can build with listeners who are viewing the site.

Has technology such as MP3 damaged or liberated the music industry? That depends on who you listen to! Most people understand that, in the longer term, MP3 and Napster-style file sharing systems challenge the current distribution and revenue models. That doesn't mean the end for the industry. Given a new model, such as subscription, the core skills that the industry brings - A&R, production and marketing - remain and the new technology is liberating. Some senior people in the industry see themselves in the business of identifying talent and helping that talent make and market the best music. Not shifting plastic discs about the planet!

What was your first introduction to computers? I was a sound engineer in the 1980s and a lot of the kit had computer interfaces. Some were crude but others, such as SSL computer mix-down, were pretty sophisticated. I didn't sit in front of a PC until I got a "proper" day job, struggling to teach myself WordPerfect on an ancient one!

Any favourite websites? I like the Kawasaki California Triples site... don't ask! I like design that simplifies complex sites and the guide to 10 Downing Street has a floor plan as a navigation aid. The BBC's online news site is a giant.

Any favourite gadgets? There's a site called Sonicbox which is a portal for internet and other radio stations. You can also get an actual Sonicbox and access hundreds of radio channels. It will soon be wireless around the home too. I can flick between Radio 1, KROC L.A. and Morning Edition America on the NPR network in the shower.

Anything you particularly like or dislike about technology? I loathe the fact that I live in a city with an advanced mobile telephone network, and on my way home there's a huge reception hole! However, I love the fact that people seem to be asking questions of technology and the technologists say "ah that's a few years away". In other words, I think our expectations and imaginations are working as fast, if not faster, than the inventors.

Visit: www.bbc.co.uk/radio1

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Knowing the ropes
fields.trailText: St Kilda
fields.body:
St Kilda

There are a number of mysteries surrounding these islands. There's no saint called Kilda and no island called Kilda. And where did the Soay sheep come from? The sheep are on the island of Soay (Norse for sheep), but did the Vikings put them there so they could call in for fresh meat on their way down the west coast, or were they already there?

A more recent mystery lies in the famous long ropes the St Kildans used to harvest seabirds and their eggs on the steep cliffs, which are very much a feature of the islands; the most impressive is below Conachair, falling vertically 400m into the sea. Hemp and horsehair ropes were used, and possibly ropes of sheepskin surrounded by plaited cowhide. One danger was the rope fraying over a ledge, so cowhide was used on the edge while fulmar oil kept it supple.

The strength of the ropes was regularly tested by three men pulling on either end. But in The Wild Goats of Great Britain and Ireland by G K Whitehead, there's a mention of ropes made of goat hair being used on St Kilda. I've spoken to the author, who thinks the source of information was a letter which can't be found.

Further research has yielded nothing, and it's difficult to imagine that the length of hair on goats made rope-making feasible. The St Kildans did keep goats, mainly for milk, but only for short periods, as the goats fell off the steep cliffs into the sea or disturbed the sea birds. Sheep could be deterred from going onto the ledges by straw ropes stuck with feathers, but the goats simply ate them. So were the goat hair ropes a case of mistaken identity, confusion with horsehair? A mystery indeed. Any information would be gratefully received.

I've spoken to the author, who thinks the source of information was a letter which can't be found. Further research has yielded nothing, and it's difficult to imagine that the length of hair on goats made rope-making feasible. The St Kildans did keep goats, mainly for milk, but only for short periods, as the goats fell off the steep cliffs into the sea or disturbed the sea birds. Sheep could be deterred from going onto the ledges by straw ropes stuck with feathers, but the goats simply ate them. So were the goat hair ropes a case of mistaken identity, confusion with horsehair? A mystery indeed. Any information would be gratefully received.

 In a masterstroke worthy of their form during Frank Dobson's smooth mayoral campaign, Millbank makes a belated discovery over the enchanting new New Labour logo that will appear on latte mugs and other major symbols of the fight for social justice. What worries Millbank (needlessly, no doubt) is that news may leak that in the wrong hands the design could be twisted into something horrid. In the grand tradition of playing Beatles records backwards to unearth Satanic messages, the letters E, V, I and L are decipherable. Gosh. My colleague Marina Hyde rings Ann Widdecombe's office, asking assistant Nicole Hughes "if we might have one of those ghastly knee-jerk responses which attempt humour but always fall embarrassingly flat?" "Alrighty, I'll see what I can do," breezes Nicole. "I'll have a chat and see if she is in a humorous mood." No word yet, but early days.

 Meanwhile, news of Ann comes from Politico's bookshop, which has enlarged its product range. You can now buy a pair of knickers with "I love Ann Widdecombe" written over a key area. Despite the design fault that ruins any semblance of authenticity (they come without a padlock), these are the top sellers. Others include Alistair Darling knickers. These are white with a black trim, and saucily subtitled "A Hand Up Not A Handout".

 Information arrives of Hinduja whitewash man Skippy Hammond who we gather is a twitcher - one of those obsessive bird watchers who hires planes and drops everything to lay eyes on a rare bird. Meanwhile we are negotiating with Rolf Harris's people to use his fabled "Rolfaroo" drawing on next week's Skippy Special.

Yesterday we selflessly offered to act as guinea pigs should prolific email sender Peter Tatchell decide to trim back his contact list as part of any economy drive. The results were swift. "My apologies if you already received this email," reads the 4.02pm missive, before repeating some twaddle about Eminem and the Ministry of Sound, "many of the originals never arrived, so I am resending them all to be sure. Cheers! Peter."

 An American network is developing a "Texas Version" of castaway gameshow Survivor. In this version, contestants must drive from Amarillo through Fort Worth, Dallas, Houston and San Antonio, and then drive back through various other redneck strongholds, in a Volvo with a bumper sticker reading: "I Voted for Gore, I'm Gay, and I'm here to Take Your Guns." The first to complete the trip alive will be the winner.

webTitle: Hi-tech aid to take the sweat out of sex

fields.headline: Hi-tech aid to take the sweat out of sex
fields.trailText: After giving the world television to replace going out and the internet to replace shopping, technology may be about to take the sweat out of one of the last remaining urges to exercise: sex.
fields.body:
After giving the world television to replace going out and the internet to replace shopping, technology may be about to take the sweat out of one of the last remaining urges to exercise: sex.

In the ultimate boon to couch potatoes, a surgeon at a US clinic has patented an electronic implant which he claims will give women an orgasm at the touch of a button.

Today's edition of New Scientist reports that the surgeon, Stuart Meloy, of Piedmont Anesthesia and Pain Consultants in North Carolina, developed the idea out of a routine pain relief procedure.

As part of that procedure, he was placing electrodes in the spine of a woman patient to relieve her pain, adjusting the position of the electrodes according to her instructions.

"I was placing the electrodes and suddenly the woman started exclaiming emphatically," he said. "I asked her what was up and she said, 'You're going to have to teach my husband to do that'."

Dr Meloy stresses that his device would be used only in extreme cases where women could not achieve sexual satisfaction.

The stimulating wires would connect to a signal generator almost as big as a packet of cigarettes implanted under the skin of a buttock.

"Then you'd have a hand-held remote control to trigger it. But it's as invasive as a pacemaker, so this is only for extreme cases," he said.

Dr Meloy ruled out unlimited orgasms. The device would be programmed to limit use.

webTitle: Kidman in talks for London stage

fields.headline: Kidman in talks for London stage
fields.trailText: Nicole Kidman could return to the British stage, two  years after the role which made her the hottest ticket  in town.
fields.body:
Nicole Kidman could return to the British stage, two years after the role which made her the hottest ticket in town.

The actor, who has just parted from her husband Tom Cruise, has been asked to star at the Royal National Theatre in Ibsen's The Lady from the Sea.

Ms Kidman caused a storm when she stripped naked in The Blue Room at the Donmar Warehouse in 1999, with tickets changing hands for hundreds of pounds. Her performance was described by one critic as "theatrical Viagra".

She has been in talks with the director of the National, Sir Trevor Nunn, who is keen to bring her to the Ibsen play.

A spokeswoman for the theatre said: "Trevor has been talking to her for a long time. She has been very keen to do it." But she added that the deal was by no means done as talks took place before the couple's separation was announced.

Even so, she said, it was "looking very promising".

Kidman is one of a number of stars names being lured to the National, which last year had to cancel a number of performances due to scheduling problems. Glenn Close, who starred in the films 102 Dalmatians and Dangerous Liaisons, is being tipped to appear in a production of Tennessee Williams' A Streetcar Named Desire.

"Talks are well advanced, but as with Nicole Kidman, we do not have a date at this stage," said the spokeswoman.

Martine McCutcheon will star as Eliza Doolittle in a production of My Fair Lady, while Men Behaving Badly star Martin Clunes will appear in Molière's Tartuffe.

webTitle: Leeds fans jailed over shop attack

fields.headline: Leeds fans jailed over shop attack
fields.trailText: Two businessmen were jailed yesterday for smashing up an Asian-owned corner shop during last year's tense Uefa Cup clash between Leeds United and the Turkish champions Galatasaray.
fields.body:
Two businessmen were jailed yesterday for smashing up an Asian-owned corner shop during last year's tense Uefa Cup clash between Leeds United and the Turkish champions Galatasaray.

Patrick McVeigh, who was advertising sales director at the Yorkshire Post at the time, and his brother Terence, who worked for a mobile phone company in Leeds, were given nine month terms for the "mindless" attack.

Leeds crown court heard that the two men went berserk in Holbeck Wines off-licence on April 20 last year, hours before the second leg of the European fixture at United's nearby Elland Road stadium. Tension was high in the city after the deaths of two Leeds fans two weeks earlier in Istanbul, during violence before the first round.

Ian Skelt, for the prosecution, said that the McVeighs were part of a gang who invaded the shop in front of the terrified Patel family who ran it, and tore it apart. Patrick, 30, and Terence, 35, initially started grabbing beer bottles from a fridge while others created a diversion, he said.

When the Patels protested, Terence McVeigh reached up to remove a closed circuit TV security camera. Mr Skelt said: "At about that point one of the group threw a bottle, narrowly missing Mrs Patel's head _ Mr Patel sustained a cut lip."

Patrick McVeigh then overturned the shop till and swept goods off the shelves.

The men were later identified from video footage taken outside Elland Road, where other Leeds fans attacked police and journalists.

Both brothers pleaded guilty to causing affray and were also ordered to pay £300 each in compensation.

Anthony Kelbrick, defending Patrick McVeigh, said that an "exemplary life with numerous achievements" had been marred by a moment of drunken madness. He had also been depressed at the time over the death of an uncle whom he had treated like afather. He has been sacked by the Yorkshire Post.

Bryan Cox, for Terence McVeigh, said that alcohol and emotion about the fatal stabbings in Istanbul had influenced his client's behaviour.

Passing sentence, Judge Stephen Gillick told the brothers: "This was not high-spirited drunkenness. It was violent and terrifying conduct."

He added: "The only way courts can protect premises such as this from mindless hooligans _ is to make it clear to you and others that, drunk or not, depressed or not, good character or not, well paid or not, if they are brought to justice inevitably a sentence of imprisonment will be imposed."

fields.headline: Viagra rationing 'a risk to health'
fields.standfirst: Doctors say impotence masks serious problems and treatment should be freely available
fields.trailText: NHS rationing of Viagra and other drug treatments for impotence is endangering men's health since the condition is often an early sign of dangerous illness, a coalition of doctors and patients said yesterday.
fields.body:
NHS rationing of Viagra and other drug treatments for impotence is endangering men's health since the condition is often an early sign of dangerous illness, a coalition of doctors and patients said yesterday.

The "unfair and irrational" restrictions put on Viagra's use nearly two years ago meant that only about a fifth of those who would benefit were getting free treatment.

Government fears that wider NHS prescription would help to send its drug bill soaring were ill-founded, said the campaigners, responding to a government review of its rules.

Confusion about such drugs' availability was instead helping to deter men - always reluctant visitors at GPs' surgeries - even to report health problems to doctors.

John Chisholm, chairman of the British Medical Association's GP committee, said: "Erectile dysfunction is a highly distressing condition that has very considerable effects not just on men's lives, but on their relationships, their partners and families.

"It not only causes problems in sexual performance but leads to anxiety, depression, even on occasions suicide. We should not lightly dismiss the significance of the condition by regarding it as trivial, or a bit of a joke."

GPs are allowed to prescribe impotence drugs for a dozen conditions, including diabetes, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, polio and prostate cancer, and to refer patients with all conditions to specialist consultants where they are suffering "severe distress". But campaigners said this was adding to outpatient waiting lists.

The government's recommended treatment for Viagra is one tablet a week, and most GPs start patients on a pack of four 25mg tablets, costing £16.59. Up to 10% of men may suffer impotence problems at some stage in their lives, said campaigners.

There was no evidence that overwhelming demand would "bankrupt" the NHS, and more treatments would save money on treating social consequences of impotence, including alcohol abuse and absenteeism.

Ian Banks, chairman of the Men's Health Forum, said that at present men on average saw GPs only half as often as women. "Men will be even less likely to attend in these conditions. Erectile dysfunction is often one of the first signs of a more serious underlying condition, and I don't think it is up to the government to decide the impact on the man or his partner."

Campaigners also warned that men desperate for treatment might get supplies privately or through the internet.

webTitle: Sugar weeps as lawyer opens libel claim

fields.headline: Sugar weeps as lawyer opens libel claim
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur chairman Sir Alan Sugar yesterday left the high court in London in tears moments after his lawyer opened a libel case against a newspaper which alleged that he was a miser who refused to spend money on new players to bring long awaited success to the north London club.
fields.body:
Tottenham Hotspur chairman Sir Alan Sugar yesterday left the high court in London in tears moments after his lawyer opened a libel case against a newspaper which alleged that he was a miser who refused to spend money on new players to bring long awaited success to the north London club.

Sir Alan left the court sobbing just as Richard Rampton QC opened the case against the Daily Mail, which alleged in an article in December 1999 that he had refused to give any money to team manager George Graham for players.

Mr Rampton told the jury that Sir Alan was never involved in the buying and selling of players and that he would explain to the court in his evidence today that he knows little about football.

He said the article was not just sensational but nasty, and was a direct attack on Sir Alan's reputation.

The article, written by Daily Mail journalist Jeff Powell, was headlined "Why miserly Sugar must come out of his counting house and give George the money". The paper denies libel, claiming it was fair comment.

Mr Rampton told the court: "We suggest its meaning is as clear as daylight, that Alan Sugar is a miser whose unwillingness to release cash to George Graham when he needs it is behind Tottenham Hotspur's present lack of success."

He said Sir Alan, 53, was referred to as the miser of N17, (the north London postal district where Tottenham's White Hart Lane ground is located). It also claimed he had failed to secure success at Tottenham and that Mr Graham incorrectly thought large amounts of money would be available for new players when he took over as manager in 1988.

The court heard that Tottenham had a proud tradition, but in recent years had won few honours. Their last league title was in 1961, the year in which they also won the FA Cup, becoming the first English team to win the double.

Sir Alan is due to step down as chairman this month following criticism from fans.

Mr Rampton said closer examination of the amounts spent at Tottenham during Sir Alan's chairmanship would reveal no evidence to suggest he was mean and refused to finance the purchase of new players.

In fact, many new players had been bought and millions spent during Sir Alan's chairmanship.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Call for more hi-tech speed cameras

fields.headline: Call for more hi-tech speed cameras
fields.trailText: Bright yellow hi-tech speed cameras should become a common feature on Britain's roads to help cut motoring deaths, a senior police officer said yesterday.
fields.body:
Bright yellow hi-tech speed cameras should become a common feature on Britain's roads to help cut motoring deaths, a senior police officer said yesterday.

Speed cameras have been effective on road safety but speeding needs to be made as socially unacceptable as drink-driving, said Richard Brunstrom, the North Wales chief constable.

He is coordinating a two-year Association of Chief Police Officers' scheme, launched last April in eight police forces, in which speeding fines are recycled to buy more cameras.

Approximately 3,500 people are killed on Britain's roads each year in accidents largely caused by speeding.

"We need many more cameras and for them to be more visible," he told the all-party parliamentary group for road safety at the House of Commons.

"They ought to be bright yellow with locations published in the newspapers so that people know where they are and why they are there ... They need to know the consequences, which include losing your licence."

The pilot scheme in Northamptonshire, which tries to educate drivers about the dangers of speeding in addition to enforcing fines and introducing better road signs and layouts approaching accident black spots, has led to a drop in road deaths. Last year 55 people were killed on Northamptonshire's roads, down from 76 in 1999.

Pilot projects are at present being run in Essex, Northampton, Thames Valley, Nottingham, South Wales, Cleveland, Lincolnshire and Strathclyde.

It is hoped the scheme can be extended across most of England and Wales if the vehicles (crime) bill becomes law in April.

Vince Yearley, of the Institute of Advanced Motorists, said the cameras should be "brightly coloured with flashing signs underneath saying what the road speed is at that point ... This would avoid the danger of motorists feeling they have been entrapped".

But Trevor Magner, of the British Motorcyclists Federation, said poor driving standards were a greater problem in road safety. "What we need are more traffic officers who tell people what they are doing wrong."

webTitle: Charities say business giving too little

fields.headline: Charities say business giving too little
fields.trailText: Charity leaders called yesterday for the naming and shaming of prominent businesses that give little or nothing to support voluntary organisations working to benefit their local communities.
fields.body:
Charity leaders called yesterday for the naming and shaming of prominent businesses that give little or nothing to support voluntary organisations working to benefit their local communities.

The National Council for Voluntary Organisations produced a manifesto calling on the next government to publish an official league table showing the proportion of profits donated to charity.

It said the business sector provided only 5% of the voluntary sector's donated income. Charities received £315m a year from businesses, but 97% of this came from just 400 companies.

The remaining 3.7m businesses in the UK gave a grand total of £10m - averaging less than £3 a year each.

fields.headline: A bleeding nuisance
fields.standfirst: Does PMT really make some women suicidal as a survey claims, asks  Laura Barton
fields.trailText: Does PMT really make some women suicidal as a survey claims, asks Laura Barton.
fields.body:
Not long ago, I was sitting opposite a colleague who hadn't been working in the office for long. One afternoon, he offered to do a tea-run. Having asked everyone else what they would like, he leant across and said, ever-so-sweetly: "I'm sorry, I've forgotten your name." Everyone laughed, and so did I. In fact, I grinned so hard I thought my face would fall off. It was the only thing I could do to stop myself crying. Shortly after this minor incident, I packed up and went home.

Now I am a mild-mannered, well-balanced sort of a girl. I hold open doors, I suffer fools gladly. I am not in the habit ofsobbing when offered a beverage. But this particular day I was, as they say, "on the rag".

Premenstrual tension has a lot to answer for. We get weary, moody, hungry, spotty and irrational: why can't the whole world just shut up and let us eat our king-sized Mars bars in peace? It is estimated that up to 40% of women suffer from PMT so severely that they have to consult a doctor. Two to 4% have to take up to two days off work because they feel so dreadful.

Research published this week suggests that the problem for some women may be even more serious than has previously acknowledged. A study by the Women's Nutritional Advisory Service found that eight out of 10 women feel violent and aggressive as much as two weeks before a period, and 92% experience feelings of depression. More than half have even contemplated suicide.

Premenstrual tension (or "premenstrual syndrome" - the terms, say experts, are interchangeable) has long been the butt of jokes made by male colleagues and partners, but for many women it is far from a laughing matter. Melanie is one of those who suffer quite badly: "I get really painful periods - bad cramping, vomiting, clotting. For three or four days each month I feel really grotty physically which makes me feel really tired, snappy and irritable. I can get introverted and subdued, and often don't want to spend time with other people. I may also get a bit forgetful, feel rather distracted or 'out of it', and am definitely more impatient. Sometimes I get very upset for no real reason and will start to cry at the drop of a hat."

Oh yes, those mood swings. Once I slapped a boyfriend across the chest merely for singing too loudly in a Jacuzzi. And once I became so insatiably hungry that I wolfed almost an entire loaf of soda bread. I have even wept over the future of the Gold Blend couple.

Stephanie says her period makes her feel "absolutely, utterly dreadful". "Not only do I experience excruciating pain, but I get angry . One day my son had lined his collection of toy cars all around the room, and diagonally across it, too. My husband came downstairs and trod on one. He was so annoyed that he threw the car out of the window. I was furious so I threw my husband's radio alarm out of the bedroom window.

"I throw a lot of things. Enamel plates are hugely satisfactory, they make a fantastic sound."

Stephanie's sister-in-law, Jenny, also finds herself flinging crockery and eating compulsively. She will have two McDonald's breakfasts in the morning, and then stop off for fish and chips when out getting the office lunches. Her doctor once told her that if she hadn't been on hormone treatment she would have been in a psychiatric hospital.

The good news is that hormone and some herbal treatments do seem to be effective in limiting the worst symptoms of PMT. But we still don't really know why some women suffer more than others. Its cause is certainly hormonal, and may have a substantial link to nutritional deficiencies; the WNAS suggests avoiding wheat and caffeine, and eating corn, rice and oat-based foods instead. Now for the bad news. Gorging on sugary foods is not a good idea, as it prompts energy rushes and mood swings. You know it's a really, really bad day when you are not even allowed that mansion-sized box of Dairy Milk.

fields.headline: Eurozone snub to Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Britain was at loggerheads with Brussels last night over plans to establish a working group that excludes the UK.
fields.body:
Britain was at loggerheads with Brussels last night over plans to establish a working group that excludes the UK.

The European commission has suggested the 12 members of the eurozone should set up a working group to prepare its agendas separately from those of meetings of all 15 members.

In a paper to be presented to EU finance ministers on Monday, the commission also called for more regular meetings between eurozone finance ministers and the European Central Bank.

Pedro Solbes, the EU commissioner in charge of economic affairs, said it was logical that non-members of the eurozone should be excluded from the new working group. "For me it's probably reasonable to have this level of meeting in the same constitution as the eurogroup," he said.

Britain fought in 1997 to prevent the eurogroup gaining too much power, and won an assurance that its meetings would be prepared by representatives of all 15 states.

A Treasury spokesman said it had no difficulty with the eurogroup improving its informal organisation and the way its communicates with the ECB.

Analysts say that, indirectly, a more unified eurogroup could benefit Britain if it helped to stabilise the euro-pound exchange rate and improve the currency zone's response to financial and economic crises.

The Treasury said Britain was opposed to a new framework which bypassed the agenda-setting economic and financial committee, the key policymaking body which comprises representatives from all 15 member states, as well as ECB and commission officials.

A Brussels-based British official said: "There is no basis to establish that kind of group unless it includes representatives of all member states and there is no way that can happen without unanimous agreement."

webTitle: Analysis: The European Commission's decision to pick a fight with the Irish republic

fields.headline: Fiscal fights
fields.standfirst:
The European Commission's decision to pick a fight with the Irish republic, one of the eurozone's most successful economies, may backfire

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The European Commission's decision to pick a fight with the Irish republic, one of the eurozone's most successful economies, may backfire.
fields.body:
Somebody had to be first but few would have expected the Republic of Ireland - the European Union's star economic performer - to suffer the embarrassment of a dressing down from Brussels over the way it runs its shop.

One of the smallest economies in the eurozone, the Irish Republic has done well from membership of the EU and support for Europe has traditionally been much stronger than in its neighbour to the north and across the Irish Sea. So, with the weight of the EU's economic establishment about to come down on it, you might expect the Irish to be contrite. Far from it. Rather than bowing to pressure to change course, Dublin is defiant. And not without justification.

The republic's sin is to have cut taxes and increased public spending in its 2001 budget, at a time when the European commission and just about every other international organisation, including the International Monetary Fund and the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, is recommending a more restrictive fiscal stance to slow economic growth and damp down inflationary pressure.

Ireland's inflation rate was the highest in the eurozone last year, averaging 5.6%, and, having surrendered control of interest rates to the European Central Bank, it has no other weapon in its armoury to control booming economic growth, currently running at an annual rate of 12%. The chart shows the course of Irish inflation in recent years.

For its part, the Irish republic says tightening fiscal policy would have no impact on inflation because it is driven by external factors, such as the price of oil and the value of the euro, over which the government has no control. The best estimate available is that the I£1.2bn package of tax cuts will add about 0.31 percentage points to inflation after three years, a tiny amount compared to the damage inflicted by last year's surge in the oil price and have no impact whatsoever on EU-wide inflation.

Moreover, the package of tax cuts and spending increases announced in a budget at the end of last year is designed to tackle bottlenecks in the labour market and infrastructure. It includes incentives for participation in the workforce, particularly for married women. Tighter fiscal policy might, therefore, inhibit rather than enhance Irish ability to grow in the future without hitting capacity constraints.

The text books do not back the Irish case but some economists say orthodox models do not necessarily apply in its case. Although it has made great strides in the past decade, Ireland is still best viewed as a developing economy, which has yet to catch up with its richer neighbours. As such, it can afford higher rates of growth and inflation for several years before its competitive advantage in world markets is eroded.

Kitty Ussher, chief economist at Britain in Europe, the pro-Emu lobby group, says that 6% inflation in a very open economy that has been historically very poor is not a cause for concern. "We had 11% in 1990. Given the strength of the Irish boom, it's remarkable that Irish inflation hasn't been higher."

Irish arguments are not expected to cut much ice with EU finance ministers, who next Monday will be invited to endorse a recommendation from the commission that the republic be publicly reprimanded for fiscal policy "inconsistent with the 2000 broad economic policy guidelines". These require EU member states to steer roughly the same course.

EU ministers have the power to impose financial sanctions only if a member country is running an excessive budget deficit - Ireland's is in surplus. But a public ticking off may serve a wider purpose.

Ever since its launch, the euro has suffered from a perception that economic policymaking is fragmented. Although the currency is now recovering, its rise on the foreign exchanges owes more to gloom about the American economy and the dollar than enthusiasm for the fundamentals of the eurozone economy which, though good, could be better.

To cement its gains, the EU may need to press ahead with structural reform and make a better fist of communicating with the outside world. Instead of being seen to be at odds with each other and the ECB, finance ministers should present a united front to win the confidence of investors.

EU finance ministers appear to have accepted this criticism and are said to be working on a blueprint to improve economic coordination. This will be presented at March's Stockholm summit by Mario Draghi, the Italian treasury chief who chairs the agenda-setting economic and financial committee, which brings together top officials from all EU finance ministries and central banks, as well as the ECB and commission economists.

One of Mr Draghi's recommendations is expected to include bolstering peer review of member states' fiscal policies to overcome the impression in the outside world that individual countries have too much latitude.

While cracking the fiscal whip at the Irish republic may convey a favourable impression in global financial markets, it could backfire internally. The danger is that the commission has chosen to pick a fight with the wrong country. To the outside, the Irish may look an open and shut case of economic mismanagement but predictions of its demise have been made so often in the past decade that they have begun to ring hollow. A painful bust may lie ahead but it is more likely to come from implosion of business confidence in the US, with which the Irish economy has close links, rather than a surge of inflation.

Ireland is one of the few EU member states to be planning to hold a referendum to ratify the Nice treaty. Given the benefits of membership of the eurozone so far, the Irish people were expected to offer an enthusiastic endorsement. But if they feel they are being bullied and misunderstood they may turn hostile. And that could spell trouble for the currency the commission is trying to protect.

Mark Atkinson is the Guardian's economics correspondent

fields.headline: Blair shrugs off euro furore
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister is pushing social justice and enterprise to the top of his agenda, reports political correspondent Nicholas Watt
The speech in full
fields.trailText: The prime minister is pushing social justice and enterprise to the top of his agenda, reports political correspondent Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today laughed off the media frenzy over his announcement that a decision on a referendum on the euro could be held within two years of the next election.

As ministers settled around the cabinet table for their weekly meeting, the prime minister joked about the morning papers, saying that he only wished he could secure the same coverage for his more earnest pronouncements.

Downing Street has attempted over the past 48 hours to dismiss the significance of Mr Blair's announcement that he would assess whether Britain was ready to join the euro within two years of a Labour election victory. "This was a statement of the blindingly obvious," one source said.

There is no doubt, however, that Mr Blair's remarks about the euro in the Commons yesterday were an important clarification of the government's position on the euro which - ministers hope - will pave the way for Labour to enter the general election campaign with a clearer position on the issue.

By indicating exactly when Gordon Brown will assess his cherished economic tests, Downing Street hopes to clear the decks for Labour to concentrate on education, crime and health during the campaign.

The Tories made clear this morning that they are determined to unsettle Mr Blair's plans by exploiting voters' fears over the euro.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, said on the Today programme that voters, who are overwhelmingly opposed to the euro, would be increasingly attracted by the Tory policy to rule out British membership for the lifetime of the next parliament.

"They have absolute certainty that if they elect a Conservative government, the Conservative government will keep the pound," Mr Portillo said.

Tories are saying privately that they are delighted by the furore over the euro which has ensured that the prime minister's lunchtime speech on education has received less attention than Downing Street had hoped.

In the speech, delivered at a new secondary school built with private money in the Labour marginal seat of Enfield Southgate, the prime minister made clear that he is in full election mode.

He made a series of major announcements on education, pledging to double the number of specialist schools in the next five years to 1,500. The schools will also cover three new areas - science, engineering and enterprise.

The prime minister also set out his philosophy for what he hopes will be the first second term in Labour's history.

"It is time for a second phase of New Labour, defined less by reference to the old Labour party than by an agenda for the country, radically but firmly in the centre ground," he said.

Downing Street said that Mr Blair believes his success in running the economy in its first term means that today's Labour party no longer has to prove it has moved on from the days of Callaghan and Wilson.

This will allow the government to stake out territories which were once seen as mutually exclusive - achieving social justice while promoting an enterprise economy.

If the prime minister can ram home his attractive message between now and polling day, he should be on course for an historic victory. But the excitement over the euro shows that the Tories will do their best to knock him off course.

webTitle: UK support for single currency at new low

fields.headline: UK support for single currency at new low
fields.standfirst:
Poll reveals continued suspicion toward EU
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Britain has come out bottom in five of seven key categories of support for the European Union, with backing for the single currency down to a record low.
fields.body:
Britain has come out bottom in five of seven key categories of support for the European Union, with backing for the single currency down to a record low.

It also has the highest number of don't knows in any of the 15 member states.

New figures released today show a country still more sceptical than any other about the value of membership, the European Commission, support for the euro - just 21% - and a common foreign policy.

The latest Eurobarometer poll also shows that Britain has the lowest levels of support, 31%, for enlargement, a potential problem for a government which has set itself up as an "unashamed champion" of membership for 12 aspiring candidates from eastern and central Europe.

Britain also comes out second lowest in the two remaining categories, scoring 30%, slightly more than Sweden, on the benefits of EU membership and with 51%, just ahead of Finland, in support of a common defence policy.

Intriguingly, however, backing for European defence has increased by 2% since last year's row over the creation of an EU rapid reaction force (RRF), which the Tories have repeatedly warned could un dermine Nato. Unusually for a sensitive European issue, the government adopted a robust tone in rebuffing opposition claims on the RRF, suggesting that such an approach could pay dividends elsewhere.

Today's findings, a foretaste of a more detailed set to be published in April, continue a now familiar pattern, and one that is depressing for europhiles. But the uniquely high incidence of don't knows appears to suggest that there is much to play for in the European debate in Britain in advance of a spring general election and a likely decision on a referendum on euro membership within two years of the next parliament.

British don't knows are up to 35% and never lower than 16%. The average number of don't know replies in Britain to each question was 26%, compared to an EU average of 16% and 7% in Denmark.

Neil Kinnock, the British vice-president of the European commission, said yesterday: "Vast numbers of people feel they don't have enough information about the EU and want to know more.

"That is a sad commentary after 26 years of membership. The debate is wide open and so is the public mind. The more people know, the less they fear."

The previous full Eurobarometer poll, last spring, found that Britons' level of self-perceived knowledge about the EU was the lowest of any member state. It found 40% saying they "know practically nothing" about the EU. Only 2% claimed to "know a lot" about the EU.

The number of Europeans believing their country has benefited from EU membership is stable at 47%. Thirty-two per cent believe their country has not benefited from EU membership, while 21% are don't knows.

Overall support for the euro fell slightly by 3% to an average of 55%. Britain's 21% was down one point against the previous poll.

There was a significant drop in support for the euro in Sweden, down 12% to 26%, probably the effect of last September's no result in the referendum in Denmark.

Support for the euro in Ireland, where there has been sharp criticism from Brussels and the European Central Bank about the dangers to euroland of an overheating economy, rose by 6% to 69%.

Analysts expect a crucial year for the euro, as the EU economies strengthen and preparations continue for the introduction of euro notes and coins next January.

webTitle: Blair shows his hand on the euro

fields.headline: Blair shows his hand on the euro
fields.standfirst:
Special report: economic and monetary union
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair dramatically clarified his plans to take Britain into the single currency yesterday when he promised that a re-elected Labour government would decide within two years whether to hold a referendum.
fields.body:
Tony Blair dramatically clarified his plans to take Britain into the single currency yesterday when he promised that a re-elected Labour government would decide within two years whether to hold a referendum.

He promised the Treasury's assessment of the five economic tests for entry would be held within two years but vowed he would not bounce the British electorate by making the assessment within months of the election.

It is the first time Mr Blair has defined the government's previously vague timescale to make the assessment "early" in the next parliament.

He made the commitment in answer to a question from William Hague during prime minister's questions in the Commons.

Mr Blair told a startled Mr Hague: "Early in the next parliament means exactly what it says. Early in the next parliament would, of course, be within two years."

If the prime minister had said the economic assessment might be held later than two years after the election, it would have opened the serious possibility of Britain not entering the euro within the next parliament.

On the assumption that the Treasury concluded the British economy had met the five tests - especially that the British and European economies had converged - a Labour government would still have to hold a referendum, prepare notes and coins as well as negotiate with the EU on the entry rate for sterling against the euro.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press spokesman, said the referendum could be held within two years, but did not commit the government to this timetable.

Mr Blair's remarks reflect a new confidence about the euro within government after its rise on the markets. Pro-euro cabinet ministers, including Stephen Byers and Robin Cook, have also noted the clear statements from car chiefs that they will disinvest unless there is a real prospect of sterling joining the euro. They were eager not to allow any backsliding from the policy after the resignation of the pro-European Peter Mandelson.

Mr Hague later claimed that Mr Blair had "just blown his policy on the single currency out of the water" and "given the pound two years to live". He added: "There can be no doubt that the fate of the pound will be a huge issue at the election."

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy led pro-Europeans in welcoming the move, but claimed it was too late. Even a pro-euro cabinet decision in 2002 would leave little time to complete the nuts-and-bolts moves to join the euro before the 2005-6 election, some experts warned.

Eurosceptic claims that Mr Blair had effectively slapped down his chancellor, Gordon Brown, were dismissed by both Downing Street and the Treasury.

Mr Blair will today put the creation of a meritocratic Britain at the top of Labour's priorities - and identify university elitism as a crucial barrier to be demolished.

Following Mr Brown's attack last year on Oxbridge elitism, ministers have negotiated a package with 27 universities which currently recruit less than 80% of their students from state schools.

All 27 will be monitored for year-on-year improvement as targeted schools also get extra help to raise their pupils' expectations, part of a drastic makeover for the comprehensive system to extol choice and diversity over regimentation.

With Labour headquarters at Millbank gearing up for the expected May 3 election, the prime minister will use a speech at a north London school today to make a determined effort to persuade voters that, if re-elected, Labour will use its growing self-confidence and national affluence to be more radical than it has been since 1997.

The cabinet remains committed to reform of the public services as the centrepiece of its campaign. To ram home his message Mr Blair will today promise to match his ambitious plans for transport and the NHS with sweeping 10-year plans to revitalise both education and the criminal justice system.

The education plan will be unveiled next week, the crime plan later in the month as part of a flurry of announcements which precede Mr Brown's cautiously generous budget, probably on March 6 or 13.

Today the prime minister will argue that better public service - above all, education - provides the best means to break down the barriers to what he will call "a true meritocracy where people can rise according to their own ability".

Mr Blair will argue that Labour's task is to open up opportunity to all - not least by removing barriers of poverty, poor education, adult illiteracy and failing public services.

webTitle: Fan guilty of death threats to Billie

fields.headline: Fan guilty of death threats to Billie
fields.trailText: A disturbed fan who subjected Billie Piper to a campaign of "calculated viciousness" was yesterday convicted of making five threats to kill the 18-year-old pop singer and four threats against her parents.
fields.body:
A disturbed fan who subjected Billie Piper to a campaign of "calculated viciousness" was yesterday convicted of making five threats to kill the 18-year-old pop singer and four threats against her parents.

In an unusual move the jury at Blackfriars crown court requested that Juliet Peters, 32 who lives alone and has not worked for 10 years, should receive "help". In a note to Judge Brian Pryor QC they said: "We would like to make the recommendation for Miss Peters to receive help from a psychiatrist or counsellor."

Peters, who told the court that she sleeps during the day and is awake at night, was described by a psychologist of having below average intelligence, but she did not suffer from a mental disorder.

Remanding Peters in custody until March 2 for psychiatric reports, Judge Pryor said: "I have been pondering about this myself. Miss Peters to say the least is highly unusual. It rings accord with me, what the jury has written."

Peters, of Canning Town, east London, made a string of threatening phone calls to Ms Piper after she attended a performance of Channel 5's Pepsi Chart Show hosted by Ms Piper. She said that the singer had given her a "sly dirty look". Her response was to make 13 telephone calls last August to the star's record company in which she threatened to dismember and burn the pop star, decapitate her parents and shoot her on stage. She also abused Ms Piper's then boyfriend Richard Neville, a singer with the band 5ive.

In one of the calls Peters said: "Billie Piper's head needs cutting off, she needs decapitating and killing. She needs her body set on fire, and her body burnt to cinders ... so we don't have to suffer her anymore." Another call said: "Billie Piper is a bloody pig and I am going to kill her parents. I see them out shopping all the time. They're going to get their heads cut off soon. The silly cow is a silly bitch, she is going to be dead."

In another Peters said: "Next time she appears on stage she is going to be shot dead." In another she said: "She needs cutting into little pieces and petrol poured over her and just burned. I'll get a gun and shoot her parent's head off ... one bullet to the head should do it."

Ms Piper told the jury: "They [the calls] were just horrific. I could not understand why anyone would want to say these things. I had done nothing personally. It just seemed very bizarre and made me cry."

Peters was arrested after police traced the calls to her home. Under her bed they found two draft letters similar to an abusive one sent to the singer and hanging on her bedroom wall was a 5ive calendar opened at Richard Neville's picture. Detective Constable Victoria Merron said afterwards that the singer's mother was "delighted" with the verdicts. "It is particularly unpleasant to be a victim of these calls whether you are a celebrity in the public eye or not."
